fields.headline: Turkey, Swedes and tripe
fields.standfirst:
Draw sees Italy become group winners and first into the quarter-finals
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: At the precise moment the world, his dog and all the dog's friends were rightly feting the championship for the quality of its football and gorgeous entertainment value, a hound of game was served up.
fields.body:
It had to happen. At the precise moment the world, his dog and all the dog's friends were rightly feting the championship for the quality of its football and gorgeous entertainment value, a hound of game was served up.

Uneasy with the knowledge that defeat would mean elimination, neither Sweden nor Turkey could summon up the courage to chase victory. It was Euro 2000's first goalless draw and - by some distance - its poorest contest.

But this result at least leaves Group B enticingly open for while Italy have now definitely reached the quarter-finals, and as winners, who will join them remains uncertain until Monday night. For the sake of our sanity, we must hope it is Belgium.

Never let it be said that Turkey's Mustafa Denizli is a man blessed with courage only when it suits him, only when his opponent has faltered and finds himself, fleetingly, at a disadvantage.

Of all the coaches searching for points and salvation in the Low Countries, Denizli was the first to be condemned as a failure by his country's press, Sunday's opening-game defeat by Italy in Arnhem prompting calls for his head on a platter.

Yet Denizli would appear to be relishing the contest. Last night as the strains of the anthems drifted away, he turned smartly on a Cuban heel to face his detractors in the main stand; unbowed and unmoved, Denizli smiled broadly.

The point of no return is swiftly reached in tournaments and here, unashamedly clutching at straws, were two teams who had reluctantly redefined the their ambition after first-hurdle stumbles.

While it is safe to assume that neither seriously believed their stay would be extended to the final early next month, both had realistic expectations of emerging from the opening phase with honour rather than embarrassment.

Curiously, Denizli chose to relegate to the substitute's bench his accomplished play-maker, Sergen Yalcin. Still, the absence of the temperamental midfielder at least provided room for the inclusion of Muzzy Izzet of Leicester City and once of London's east end. There have been more tenuous sporting links - but not many.

Izzet was a peripheral figure as a game of surprisingly decent temperament flowed nicely between the two penalty areas.

Turkey's more pronounced urgency - perhaps reflecting their desperation for redemption in the eyes of their passionate followers - carried them forward more often but the transformation of effort into something tangible was proving their greatest problem.

Strangely, the better of the chances, and there were not many, fell to Swedish feet for while Turkey love to attack they have never really taken to defending, regarding back-pedalling as a betrayal of a rich tradition.

Sweden would have led as early as the third minute but for the athleticism of the Turkish goalkeeper Rustu Recber, who did well to raise himself off the ground to touch aside Kennet Andersson's swirling drive from some distance.

Celtic's Henrik Larsson was quiet on his first senior start since sustaining a horrific leg fracture back in October. But, at least he was back; he will be thankful for small mercies.

Larsson always seemed the most likely candidate to end what was a growing tedium for while only within touching distance of match fitness he retains the grace, balance and timing of a footballer of impeccable pedigree.

As games wear on, Turkey tend to be enveloped by both fatigue and lethargy; they have acquired the particularly nasty habit of pulling up exhausted long, long before the finishing line draws into focus.

As the skies darkened a painfully dull, at times rather bitter, war of attrition unfolded. The stakes were high and even those players who had initially hinted at flair and enterprise began to cut corners, presumably in the belief that it was better to be anonymous than make the crucial mistake.

With Turkey impotent when in possession and Sweden unable to summon up the courage to grab a wretched game by the scruff of a neck which cried out to be rung, the evening crawled along without harmony, without style.

fields.headline: The dynasty
fields.standfirst: From rag trade to riches
fields.trailText: C&A opened its doors to British shoppers for the first time in 1922. That original store, on Bird Street in central London, became a byword for fashionable, good value clothes and it was quickly followed by other outlets in Liverpool, Birmingham and Sheffield.
fields.body:
C&A opened its doors to British shoppers for the first time in 1922. That original store, on Bird Street in central London, became a byword for fashionable, good value clothes and it was quickly followed by other outlets in Liverpool, Birmingham and Sheffield.

By the turn of the millennium C&A had expanded across the UK and into Ireland and was operating more than 100 stores.

Controlling it all along has been a reclusive Dutch dynasty. C&A is named after the two founding brothers, Clemens and August, who opened their first shop in the Netherlands in 1861 and the business gradually fanned out across Europe.

Members of the Brenninkmeijer family have clung to their privacy and kept their heads low. "Openness is a sign of weakness," one elder was once overheard to say.

Selling ready-to-wear clothing has, with the exception of the UK, been highly profitable and the family's personal fortune is estimated to exceed £5bn.

The Brenninkmeijers like to keep it in the family, however, and there are said to be at least 200 of them working for C&A across the world.

In 1997 a non-family member was brought onto the C&A board in the UK for the first time and family members sit on the board in every country where C&A operates.

They rarely give interviews, they do not publish their financial results and they do not flaunt their wealth. They often send their children to school under assumed names and senior employees are asked to sign an oath of secrecy when they join the firm.

"There's not very much information about them and that's the problem," said Gerda Ackaert, a journalist at the Belgian daily De Tijd, yesterday.

With headquarters in Brussels, the core family members actually run the company from a secluded compound in the Netherlands.

The family comes from a strong Catholic background and is keen to be seen to be doing the right thing by its staff and customers. In normal circumstances it tries to take a "cradle to grave" approach to employment.

Anxious to dispel the idea that the business is riddled with nepotism, the family has let it be known that young Brenninkmeijers are only given jobs if they survive a drubbing at the company's annual meeting.

They go out of their way to reject suppliers offering products made using child labour and say that any of their partners exploiting their staff or the environment will have their contracts terminated immediately.

Asked yesterday what the family was really like, C&A's managing director Neil McCausland said: "There seems to be a lot of myth to their so-called obsession with secrecy. They're actually very nice people."

fields.headline: Odds fellow
fields.standfirst: Dutch backers thirsting for some Orange aid
fields.trailText: Those of us who have backed Holland to win the championships were feeling pretty queasy after the co-hosts' unimpressive opening game against the Czech Republic last weekend. Frank Rijkaard's men will encounter weaker opposition when they play Denmark in Rotterdam this evening.
fields.body:
Those of us who have backed Holland to win the championships were feeling pretty queasy after the co-hosts' unimpressive opening game against the Czech Republic last weekend. Frank Rijkaard's men will encounter weaker opposition when they play Denmark in Rotterdam this evening.

Hopefully, like England against Scotland four years ago, they will belatedly hit their stride and win well at 4-7 with the Tote. Denmark are 7-1 with Surrey, who are offering 3-1 about a draw.

France , down to 9-4 to lift the trophy with Ladbrokes, out-classed the Danes in their opening match but the world champions face a much tougher examination against the Czech Republic in Bruges this afternoon.

The French defence looked vulnerable early on against Denmark and if the Czechs can lift themselves after losing against Holland they could force a draw at 5-2 with Sunderlands. But given the attacking options at their disposal, a French win is marginally preferred at 5-6 with Chandler. A Czech victory is a top priced 100-30 with Stan James.

Betting on Group D is very close. The French are a best priced even money with Ladbrokes to win it, with Holland 10-11. Punters who believe the three points Holland gained in the Czech game will prove crucial can back the Dutch to finish on top at 5-4 with Heathorns. The Czech Republic are 16-1 with Stan James.

 Sporting have a speciality bet on England v Germany entitled Jerry Springer. It awards one point for every time a German player heads the ball with a 25 point bonus for a headed goal. The quote is 55-60 and, in the likely absence of Oliver Bierhoff, a sell is the preferred option.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 shorts
fields.trailText: • Portugal's Luis Figo, the scourge of England in their opening group game , is to leave Barcelona and join the Serie A champions Lazio, according to his agent.
fields.body:
 Portugal's Luis Figo, the scourge of England in their opening group game , is to leave Barcelona and join the Serie A champions Lazio, according to his agent.

The midfielder, who has a buy-out clause set at £35m in his contract at the Nou Camp, has been in talks with the Italian champions. "Things are very advanced with Lazio," confirmed his agent Jose Viega.

Meanwhile the Romania coach Emerich Ienei has outlined his strategy to nullify the threat posed by the Portuguese playmaker in tomorrow's group match. "There is only one way to deal with him," he said. "Someone has to follow him and attack him when he has the ball."

 The Belgian police have set up a two-man team dealing exclusively with ticket fraud on the internet.

The pair track contacts made via email. "They are finding out who is selling tickets, where they are going and what nationality is buying," said the police spokeswoman Els Cleemput.

Between 450 and 500 tickets have already been seized, with one German found with 107 tickets in his car.

 Olympique Marseille have confirmed their interest in signing the Sweden striker Kennet Andersson.

The 32-year-old, currently with Bologna, has experience of the French league after spells at Lille and Caen. "He's experienced and excellent at laying the ball off," said a spokesman for the French club, who are also attempting to lure Milan's Bruno N'Gotty to the Stade Vélodrome.

 Yugoslavia are to make radical changes to their starting line-up for Sunday's game against Norway.

Bordeaux's Nisa Saveljic will replace the suspended Sinisa Mihajlovic, and Savo Milosevic, who scored twice in the 3-3 draw with Slovenia, will partner Predrag Mijatovic in attack as Darko Kovacevic has a knee injury.

Zeljko Cicovic is preferred in goal to Ivica Kralj, but the midfielder Vladimir Jugovic is doubtful with a calf injury.

webTitle: Rivals squeeze Somerfield out of net shopping

fields.headline: Rivals squeeze Somerfield out of net shopping
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Troubled supermarket operator Somerfield yesterday confirmed it would halt its internet shopping division, 24-7, which has fallen victim to tough online competition from Tesco and Iceland.
fields.body:
Troubled supermarket operator Somerfield yesterday confirmed it would halt its internet shopping division, 24-7, which has fallen victim to tough online competition from Tesco and Iceland.

Somerfield said customers would no longer be able to order groceries by telephone, fax, email or interactive television. However, home delivery would continue for shoppers at Somerfield and Kwik Save stores.

Analysts said the move would damage Somerfield's future sales growth. Mike Godliman of retail analyst Verdict Research predicted 5% of supermarket food sales- £4.96bn - would be done online by 2005. "That's a big chunk of the market to ignore."

Sainsbury recently announced it would invest more in developing internet shopping and Asda is concentrating on improving its market share in this area.

Somerfield's 24-7 is understood to have been accumulating losses since it began operating last September and last month estimated annual turnover at £4m.

Somerfield did not deny speculation that two of its three 24-7 fulfilment centres received as few as 15 orders a week.

The division employs 226 people but Somerfield said it hoped to redeploy some of them. The unit was established under former chief executive David Simons, who was recently replaced by executive chairman John von Spreckelsen, who said yesterday: "The decision will clearly come as a disappointment to the staff of 24-7.

"We may well have a fresh look at the role of e-commerce food retailing within Somerfield in the future. But the hard fact is that 24-7 has not been growing and represents a significant distraction to management at a time when its focus has to be on the core Somerfield and Kwik Save business."

Somerfield is expected to report full year results on July 5. Analysts still expect the company's profitability to be suffering from its poor investment in Kwik Save. Some have speculated that the group will be split up or sold within the next year and underlined this by pointing to weakness in the company's brand names.

fields.headline: Germans spurn Freeserve
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: T-Online, the German internet unit of Deutsche Telekom, has doused rumours that it will bid for Freeserve by revealing that it may enter the British market by a joint venture with telecommunications group One2One.
fields.body:
T-Online, the German internet unit of Deutsche Telekom, has doused rumours that it will bid for Freeserve by revealing that it may enter the British market by a joint venture with telecommunications group One2One.

Wolfgang Keuntje, T-Online's chief executive, said the company was in talks with the British mobile operator - owned by Deutsche Telekom - aimed at launching internet services in Britain as it considered the benefits of buying an existing business.

"We could surely work together with One2One. We are talking with One2One about whether we can offer an internet access service but there is no timeframe," Keuntje said.

He added that talks with One2One would not prevent T-Online from making an acquisition or entering a different partnership.

However the market marked down the Leeds-based ISP. Shares in Freeserve dropped 6% to 442p, while electrical retailer Dixons, which owns 80% of Freeserve, fell 26p to 283.

A spokesman for One2One, Britain's fourth largest mobile telecommunications group, refused to confirm that it was talking to T-Online about offering an internet service, saying only that "it was not unusual for both parties to talk to each other about various projects".

A deal between One2One and T-Online would be similar to one in Austria where T-Online linked with Deutsche Telekom's mobile phone subsidiary max.mobil to offer an internet service.

Analysts said it would be difficult to build an internet service provider from scratch in the competitive UK market. "The question is whether you want to pay billions or several hundred millions for an acquisition or whether it is cheaper to set up a business from ground zero," Mr Keuntje said.

Freeserve has about 1.9m users, compared with T-Online's 5m making it Europe's biggest internet service provider.

Dixons put Freeserve on the auction block earlier this year and many experts say a sale could be announced on June 27 when Freeserve discloses its results.

T-Online has been the front-runner to buy Freeserve as the German group's strategy is to build a leading pan-European franchise in the rapidly consolidating internet market. It has targeted Britain, Italy and Spain as its main markets into which it wants to expand.

Mr Keuntje said he could not put an acquisition value on Freeserve. "I don't know how much Freeserve would cost," he said. "We have not studied the company in detail."

Albert Richards, analyst at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, said: "I think T-Online would be very interested in ac quiring the whole of Freeserve. But I don't think they want Freeserve at this price and I would be absolutely amazed if they bought it at levels like 600p. They would be better off investing [in One2One]."

A potential bid by T-Online for Freeserve is also being hobbled by the forthcoming share offer of its parent.

A bid for Freeserve would require Deutsche Telekom to amend its offer prospectus.

It has been speculated that Dixons would like 600p a share for Freeserve but this would value it near £6bn and significantly above that of its competitors such as Lycos and Yahoo! when measured on a per user basis.

fields.headline: Pregnant pause
fields.standfirst: Claire says she was fired because she was pregnant but her employers maintain it was her wayward behaviour with a bacon roll, an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: Claire says she was fired because she was pregnant but her employers maintain it was her wayward behaviour with a bacon roll, an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.body:
Claire and her baby Jenny put hope in my heart when I spot them sitting neatly in the corner of the tribunal waiting room. For one thing Claire does not have that exploded look that many new mothers have - as if the borders between their clothes, the bed sheets and the baby's clothes have been eradicated by the high wind of maternity blowing through their lives and dazing their expressions.

No, Claire is trim in a pink suit. She is even wearing nail varnish. And Jenny is a baby like a cherry - firm and clean and pink of cheek.

Well, it's important they look convincing because we are facing a stark conflict of evidence. Claire is saying she was sacked simply because she was pregnant. Her employer is saying she assaulted a colleague with a bacon roll. Talking to Claire, as she and Jenny look at me with their identical untroubled blue eyes, I am beginning to feel quite hopeful.

Claire's employers have pulled the very cheap stunt of being represented by counsel who appears herself to be ten or twelve months gone, probably with quads. The tribunal chair is falling over himself to accommodate her: "Now you will tell us, Miss Balloon, any time you think you might need a break?" I am thinking this may be quite often since it looks to me like Miss Balloon's bladder has about enough lebensraum to accommodate a communion wafer.

The sad truth is that these cheap stunts are generally highly effective: Miss B (tones of womanly sympathy): "I suppose at eight weeks, you weren't feeling that well?" Claire: "Umm, no, I felt a bit sick..." Miss B: "You got a bit upset with Mrs P about her scented candle, didn't you?" Claire: "Well, a little. But I'm sure she knew the smell was getting to me and she kept lighting it..." Miss B: "If you thought that, I guess you thought she was being pretty insensitive? I mean it must have made you feel awful and then she kept doing it and it was probably making you feel really sick..." I see the memory of old rage kindling in Claire's eyes. She is nodding as if entranced by Miss Balloon, hypnotised by her fug of hormones and soothing voice.

No, Claire is trim in a pink suit. She is even wearing nail varnish. And Jenny is a baby like a cherry - firm and clean and pink of cheek. Well, it's important they look convincing because we are facing a stark conflict of evidence. Claire is saying she was sacked simply because she was pregnant. Her employer is saying she assaulted a colleague with a bacon roll. Talking to Claire, as she and Jenny look at me with their identical untroubled blue eyes, I am beginning to feel quite hopeful. webTitle: Muted retail sales growth eases rates pressure

fields.headline: Muted retail sales growth eases rates pressure
fields.trailText: Sluggish retail sales figures yesterday reinforced expectations that the economy is cooling and interest rates may have peaked at 6%.
fields.body:
Sluggish retail sales figures yesterday reinforced expectations that the economy is cooling and interest rates may have peaked at 6%.

The office for national statistics said retail sales grew by 0.4% in May, half the rate expected in financial markets. Economists had expected a sharp rebound following a weather-induced fall in sales last April.

John Shepperd, economist at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, said: "We're in deflation territory here so from the perspective of the monetary policy committee it couldn't be better: a slowing trend of final demand and strong competitive pressure on prices keeping inflation low."

The picture of slowing economic growth was strengthened by the quarterly retail sales data, which give a better idea of the underlying trend than volatile monthly figures.

The ONS said retail sales grew by 0.2% in the latest three months compared with the previous three, the slowest increase since December 1998.

News of the modest growth in sales volumes came a day af ter evidence of a sharp slowdown in average earnings, which are closely monitored by the central bank for signs of inflationary pressure.

The increase in average earnings dropped from 5.7% to 5.1% in the three months to April compared to a year ago, their biggest fall since March 1993.

But Michael Saunders of Schroder Salomon Smith Barney Citibank warned against assuming that the next move in interest rates would be down.

He pointed out that total consumer spending was rising faster than retail sales, that industrial production was sharply up in April and unemployment was continuing to fall. "We doubt that GDP growth will slow sustainably to trend without higher base rates."

fields.headline: Anglian Water may go mutual
fields.trailText: Anglian Water is considering following the path set by Kelda, owner of Yorkshire Water, in handing back the assets of its core water business to its 5.8m British customers, senior executives indicated yesterday.
fields.body:
Anglian Water is considering following the path set by Kelda, owner of Yorkshire Water, in handing back the assets of its core water business to its 5.8m British customers, senior executives indicated yesterday.

Tony Eckford, managing director of the group's international division said the mutual society proposed by Kelda, known as a registered community asset mutual (RCAM) was one of a series of options being examined by Anglian.

Anglian, along with Pennon, owners of South-West Water, has been cited by analysts as a likely contender to adopt the RCAM model in order to boost its shares - and concentrate
on overseas acquisitions and managing water businesses at home and abroad.

Hit by strict price and environment controls, the water sector as a whole has lost 40% of its value in the past year. But Anglian's shares have risen by around £1 on expectations that it would "mutualise" its core business.

Mr Eckford acknowledged that the mutual mode raised a number of problems, including whether it struck the right balance between shareholders and customers and had the right incentives to promote efficiency.

But the main Anglian board which has been meeting in the Czech capital for the past three days, concedes that the British regulatory and political environment is inimical to max imising earnings in water. "We are doing a significant amount of work on this - I would be amazed if we didn't. It's not something we started yesterday." Mr Eckford said.

Announcing an expansion of Anglian's interests in central Europe, he said any solution would be complex. "We've got to re-engineer the whole structure of the company to do this and think through the consequences."

The group, which saw pre-tax profits grow marginally last year but enjoyed a surge in its international business, supplies water to 1.2m people in the Czech Republic.

Prague is to be the hub of its expansion into Poland, Germany, Slovakia and Bulgaria and Anglian is certain to bid - against French opposition from Vivendi and Lyonnaise des Eaux - for the right to privatise the bulk of the business managing water supplies for the Czech capital and its 1.2m population.

The group, which has also set its sights on South Asia and Latin America, already owns majority stakes in two Czech water companies and this week reached a deal to acquire the bulk of the equity in another.

webTitle: Tune up, turn on, bliss out

fields.headline: Tune up, turn on, bliss out
fields.standfirst:
Santana
Wembley Arena
***
fields.trailText:
Santana
Wembley Arena
***
fields.body:
On my way into the booming cavern of Wembley Arena, I bumped into a critic from another paper. I could tell from his glassy-eyed stare and lurching gait that he was upset. "It's fucking terrible!" he fumed. "The entire population of Essex is in there, listening to this stadium crap." He staggered off towards the bar, in search of some of Wembley's famous no-alcohol lager.

It wasn't quite as bad as that, even if the floor of the arena was crammed with fat, balding blokes from Romford clutching armfuls of pints, obviously hell-bent on enjoying a well earned night off from Euro 2000. Not so Carlos Santana, who at 52 seems no less skinny and wiry than he has ever been, even if the former electric-Afro hairdo has now disappeared under a back-to-front pork-pie hat. Surfing joyously on the vast success of his Supernatural album, Santana fronts his sprawling band of percussionists, vocalists, horn and keyboard players with an air of beatific self-satisfaction. He bends over his guitar strings to blow air-kisses to the audience, and makes buddha-like devotional gestures. "Peace! Love! Harmony!" he told us, in conclusion. "One love! A love supreme!"

And the music? At their best, the Santana band can cause mayhem with those steaming Latin grooves, with drummer Rodney Holmes leading the massed percussion onslaught, but it was significant that they did this most convincingly on the old warhorses, Black Magic Woman and Oye Como Va. You can see why the new, Grammy-scooping material works across such a broad canvas - it's like a compilation of current pop trends, hinting at hip-hop, plundering the Latin wave. It's like Herb Alpert's Tijuana Brass, digitally upgraded.

At least there was one moment of relative spontaneity, when Rob Thomas of Matchbox 20 arrived to sing Smooth, which he co-wrote. Thomas's twitchy, self-conscious performance was in stark contrast to the well-oiled Santana machine raging around him. These days, he is so blissed out he has managed to eradicate human error entirely.

fields.headline: An obscure message
fields.standfirst:
Adès Premiere
Aldeburgh festival/Radio 3
***
fields.trailText:
Adès Premiere
Aldeburgh festival/Radio 3
***
fields.body:
First performed by the New York Philharmonic last November and introduced to this country at Snape Maltings by the London Philharmonic under the composer, Thomas Adès's America (A Prophecy) is subtitled "message for the millennium". But just what that message contains is a bit obscure. On the one hand this setting of Mayan prophecies and Spanish texts (for soprano and orchestra with optional chorus) is a chilling reminder of the civilisations that were wiped out so that the brave new world of America could be founded. The soloist sings of the invaders who will come from the east, destroy their cities, and who will "burn all the land/burn all the sky". On the other hand, in the numbed and threatening lament of the second part, it seems to suggest that the nation that supplanted those endemic peoples is now intent on destroying its own world.

Yet Adès's music doesn't really offer a clinching judgment on either. There are, characteristically, some arresting sonorities - textures cleaved between high treble and lowest bass, luminous chords that materialise out of nowhere, madly tangled passages for the full orchestra threaded through with bold brass lines - but also material that seems strangely neutral, as if leaving the text to fend for itself. Obsessive Janacek-like work in the opening pages, as the scene is set for the soloist's first entry, is suddenly blown away by an eruption of diatonic brass (representing Christian triumphalism), which has the dislocating effect of one of Charles Ives's collages; while in the second part, the soprano's bleak message is haloed in shifting, wispy tendrils of melody.

The vocal writing itself (authoritatively delivered here by Janice Watson) moves in smooth, regular lines, aimed, presumably, at ensuring that the words come across. But they don't, and that failure to articulate the text fully, to give it a pertinent dramatic context, is the disappointment with America. The question of what all this invention is for never receives a convincing answer.

fields.headline: Jupiter staff offered £500m incentive
fields.trailText: Commerzbank is prepared to set aside up to 25% of the shares in its British fund management arm Jupiter for profit-linked staff stock options which could be worth about £500m.
fields.body:
Commerzbank is prepared to set aside up to 25% of the shares in its British fund management arm Jupiter for profit-linked staff stock options which could be worth about £500m.

The German bank will leave it up to Jupiter's management to decide who will qualify for the scheme.

"It is up to them to define the numbers and the means," said Commerzbank's head of asset management, Friedrich Schmitz.

More than 100 staff at Jupiter received big windfalls this month when Commerzbank paid £505m for the 25% of the bank that it did not already own; some executives received additional payments under a profits-related bonus scheme.

However the Commerzbank, which is facing a claim of unfair dismissal from Jupiter's founder and former chief executive John Duffield, is clearly keen to hang on to staff. It is already in talks about the new incentive scheme which could involve between 20% and 25% of the shares.

Mr Duffield, who received about £175m when Commerzbank bought the outstanding shares, is reported to be claiming £15m for wrongful dismissal and loss of bonus. Mr Schmitz shrugged off concerns that Mr Duffield might set up a new fund management group and seek to recruit from the Jupiter team.

"We have put in place an incentive programme and we have done all the necessary things to protect the business and motivate the people. I am very optimistic."

Mr Schmitz is keen to stress that Jupiter management will retain considerable autonomy following Commerzbank's acquisition of the remaining stake. "Jupiter will continue to work in a very independent environment. We want to protect the very special entrepreneurial spirit of the company."

It would be left to the regional managements to run the individual businesses with a small team in Frankfurt coordinating distribution and sales.

Commerzbank is continuing to look for a significant acquisition in the US. It has a business in San Francisco which has about $12bn under management.

fields.headline: Fiennes shines
fields.standfirst:
Coriolanus
Gainsborough Studios
London
****
fields.trailText:
Coriolanus
 Gainsborough Studios
London
****
fields.body:
Ralph Fiennes has already given us a volatile Richard II; he now offers, in Jonathan Kent's Almeida Theatre production, an even finer Coriolanus. And he reminds us of the curious similarities between the two men: both are brooding solitaries who think they are potential gods, prove fallibly mortal and ultimately die ignobly.

The key to Fiennes's performance lies in the delusion that soldierly valour transcends social obligation. In the heat of battle, he lingers lovingly on the phrase, "O' me alone, make you a sword of me". And at the last, when taunted by Aufidius, he harks back to his military exploits crying, "Alone I did it". This Coriolanus is a lonely dragon whose only real relationship is with his martial mother and who, outside the adrenaline-buzz of battle, has but a partial existence.

Fiennes is especially good at conveying ironic contempt for the people, mocking the accents of citizens and tribunes and exhibiting a flinty hauteur. It is a performance that neither begs nor solicits our sympathy: what it does is exhibit the psychological flaws of an arrested boy who craves maternal approval and who cries to Volumnia "chide me not" in sulky adolescent tones. It confirms Fiennes's status as one of our premier classical actors.

He also, unlike some of his colleagues, has mastered the tricky acoustic of the space: the only flaw in Kent's production is that some of the lines are rendered inaudible through shouting. Otherwise, it is excitingly staged with Paul Brown's set dominated by a rusty iron wall that descends with a thunderous clang and with the citizens established as a semi-permanent presence seated at an upstage table as if in permanent conclave.

There are some strong surrounding performances. Barbara Jefford is an outstanding Volumnia who turns her final plea to Coriolanus into an incrementally forceful argument that ends in physical attack. Linus Roache's Aufidius subtly hints at a homo-erotic fixation with the hero and seems most dangerous in his stillness. And Oliver Ford Davies's Menenius is not just a patrician apologist but a man whose thoughts are dominated by a fleshly delight in food and drink. But the excitement lies in seeing a well laid-out production of a great political play with an unequivocal star performance.

In rep until August 5. Box office: 020-7359 4404.

fields.headline: Germany head home for inspiration
fields.standfirst: Team-mates attack Matthäus as Ribbeck's woes increase, reports  Richard Williams
fields.trailText: Team-mates attack Matthäus as Ribbeck's woes increase, reports Richard Williams.
fields.body:
Yesterday the Germans became the first team to go home from Euro 2000. Not, Kevin Keegan will be sorry to hear, because they have opted out of the tournament, in which England are their next opponents, but in order to present themselves at an open training session at Breinig, a village in the Ardennes, just over the border from their training centre in Holland.

The idea was to allow the German people - and specifically several thousand people from the area around Breinig, at whose amateur club Egidius Braun, the current president of the Deutscher Fussball-Bund, cut his administrative teeth - to come and admire and applaud their representatives. In fact the session turned out to be a timely public relations exercise, since the simultaneous appearance on the same pitch of all 22 members of the Germany squad provided prima facie proof that they are not actually at one another's throats, at least in the physical sense.

In other terms it may be a different matter. Germany, three times European champions, began this tournament by scraping a highly unsatisfactory 1-1 draw with Romania. A firestorm of criticism descended on the camp, and the familiar figure of Lothar Matthäus was at its centre. Winning his 148th cap, the 39-year-old libero had given a poor performance and was substituted after an hour, clearly exhausted. "Lothar, get lost!" screamed the front page of a Cologne tabloid. Paul Breitner, the Marxist who played full-back in the 1972 team, used his newspaper to campaign for an immediate switch to a 4-4-2 formation, minus Matthäus.

But not all the criticism came from outside. Some of the players were every bit as ready to voice their disquiet. Jens Nowotny, the centre-back, demanded more responsibility, meaning that he felt he could do his job better if Matthäus were not around. Oliver Bierhoff, the captain and centre-forward, and scorer of the golden goal which won the 1996 tournament, complained - as usual - that he wasn't being served with enough crosses. Oliver Kahn, the goalkeeper, suggested that it might be a good idea to have a team meeting at which all viewpoints could be heard.

Matthäus made a spirited response. "If somebody can't tell me to my face what he has against me, then I feel sorry for him," he said. "If no individual has the nerve, then five can come together. But there aren't that many who can put up their hand if they are asked whether they played well. I won't allow myself to be made the scapegoat."

Yesterday morning Erich Ribbeck, the Germany coach, defended himself at a lengthy press conference. The day after his 63rd birthday, he began with a strikingly open admission of the poor quality of the team's performance, and of the urgent need to do something about it before Saturday's Group A meeting with England in Charleroi.

"We have one point while England have none," he declared, "and we are aware that a draw might be enough. But the important thing is for us to show on Saturday where we really stand. It will be a game presenting the greatest challenge to everybody, and I will do my best to field a formation of players who I believe have the greatest readiness and willingness to give their all. After lunch today we will present the players with a brief video analysis of the Romania game, highlighting the defects in our performance, most of all the loss of possession, the unforced errors, the balls passed straight to the opponents' feet. Second, we will point out where and when players were seen to be unfit. We definitely need players who are willing to run and fight for as long as possible, be it 90 or 95 minutes."

Did this mean that some of the players are not able to satisfy that basic requirement? "Maybe I ought to rephrase that. But certainly against England we'll need different qualities from those we might need against other opponents. England will be tough to beat because for them it's their last chance. So we also need players who can hold their own from a physical point of view, in stature as well as stamina."

Had he talked things over with Matthäus? "Yes. I'm confident that Matthäus is able to improve. He is in a league of his own, which puts him under special pressure, but it's totally unfair to blame our failure to win on him alone. I will certainly try to help him steer a course in which he continues to be important to the team. At this stage I can't say whether it's going to be successful, but I hope and pray it will be. webTitle: Totti takes the baton as Azzurri seek harmony

fields.headline: Totti takes the baton as Azzurri seek harmony
fields.standfirst: Vivek Chaudhary  sees a new Italian maestro come of age
fields.trailText: Vivek Chaudhary sees a new Italian maestro come of age.
fields.body:
It is unusual to see an Italian side with no forceful personality on the pitch. Gone are the days of Franco Baresi, Giuseppe Giannini and Roberto Baggio.

Instead there are lots of little stars twinkling in deep blue shirts but nobody shining brightly enough to catch the eye. The coach Dino Zoff said as much prior to the match.

When asked who was his team's playmaker dictating tactics and rhythm, he replied: "It is a shared responsibility. Every player knows he has a responsibility and it is important that they all play their part without looking to one individual."

In Francesco Totti there is perhaps a brighter star in the making. He may have proved himself at club level but the time has clearly come for the Italian orchestra to return to its tradition of being conducted by a maestro.

Last night the Roma striker went some way towards claiming the baton. There is no doubting his ability but the problem facing Zoff is just where to play Totti.

For his club he plays behind the front two. Last night he partnered Filippo Inzaghi, but the Roman was clearly at his best when he dropped deep. Pulling the strings obviously comes naturally to him and he combines power with a delicate touch and frightening vision.

Totti's goal said everything about him: an intelligent run into the box, a surge past his marker, and a deft header.

With Inzaghi, however, there are clearly communication problems and at times the two appeared to be on totally different wavelengths.

It was when he went to the middle of the park that he was at his most effective but Zoff could be seen gesturing to indicate that he wanted Totti to lead the line.

At least the Italians have someone who has the potential to become a pivotal force, something the Belgians were clearly lacking last night. But they have found new fire in their bellies. It may not look pretty but it is effective. This time last year they had lost to Luxembourg and the nation feared that they would merely be playing second fiddle to their more illustrious co-hosts.

Zoff's creation, though, is evolving with or without a recognised playmaker. Italy played at times last night like a team who knew where they were going; confident in the belief that the final destination was not far away.

Fortunately there are also suitors to Totti's potential elevation as chief organiser and Alessandro del Piero's arrival early in the second half, for Totti incidentally, merely added to the Italians' dominance.

The Roman against the man from Juventus. It should prove to be an interesting encounter.

The beauty of watching two teams such as Italy and Belgium is that with no recognised playmaker there is always an element of surprise.

Holland were only impres sive when Edgar Davids was on song, whereas you always knew Rui Costa was going to do something special on Monday night. Romania appear ordinary without Hagi.

Here were 11 Italians all sharing the responsibility that their manager had talked about earlier. Zoff's strategy is clearly working, and for Italian fans the glory days appear that little bit closer just when everybody has been ready to write the Azzurri off.

With qualification for the quarter-finals almost guaranteed, Zoff greeted his players with handshakes and warm embraces. They had all played their parts and carried out the duties he asked of them. Watch out, the Italians are getting organised.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 diary
fields.trailText: France change bases, the Dutch peak too early and Danish misery continues.
fields.body:
 France have switched their training base from Wavre to Knokke-Heist, near Ostend, a brave move considering the current dispute between the manager and the media. With the Gallic flair for setting up road blocks, it would have come as no surprise if their entry to the Belgian town had been blocked by journalists' cars. Roger Lemerre, France's coach, has not spoken to the press since they boycotted his meeting on Saturday. This followed the refusal of Didier Deschamps to appear at a conference - one of 15 players who have given the press the silent treatment. The farce looks set to run and run.

 The Dutch have peaked too early. Not in a playing sense, judging by their unconvincing win over the Czech Republic, but in their publicity stunts. Top this. A waste-disposal company, eager to advertise its services, has coloured a football pitch orange and put 22 cows in it with numbers stuck to their sides. The bizarre attraction caused a 12km tailback on the motorway between Amsterdam and Utrecht as motorists slowed to get a better look and it will remain in place until Holland are knocked out. The theme has been taken up by a farmer in the southern town of Clinge, who has dressed his sheep in orange wizard hats.

 The misery continues for Danish fans. Wishing to drown their sorrows after being taken to the cleaners by France, many found the currency they had been given back home was out of date and they were refused service in shops and restaurants in Bruges. "It is a scandal that Danish banks sat on bundles of notes that had been out-dated for two or three years," said a Danish chief superintendent, Kurt Hansen.

 Inspired by Cronjegate, the conspiracy theorists are having a field day. Perceived injustices against Romania and the Czech Republic have led to increased Euroscepticism in the east. Mircea Sandu, president of the Romanian Football Federation, claimed his country were the victims of a plot by western Europe to protect their own interests after his side's 1-1 draw with Germany, and the Czech goalkeeper Pavel Srnicek, who was beaten by a hotly disputed penalty against Holland, said: "They still think we're Russians or something. If they don't want to play fair, why don't they set up a different tournament for us?"

 If Andy Cole thought his impact on the tournament would consist solely of appearing as a cardboard cut-out in advertisements for Nike, a sports shop in Maastricht is suggesting a different approach. Its lifesize cut-outs have been dressed in their national kits. Edgar Davids proudly sports Dutch orange, Luis Figo looks pretty in Portuguese ruby, and a glum-looking Cole (or Colé) is wearing the red of Spain.

 If success is all in the preparation, Denmark's ambition does not stretch far. They have no plans to watch a recording of the game between their remaining opponents, in which Holland beat the Czech Republic. "We haven't seen the game but we heard the Dutch had real problems in the second half," said the forward Ebbe Sand.

 So pleased was the coach Vujadin Boskov at Yugo-slavia's comeback from three goals down to draw with Slovenia on Tuesday that he embraced his opposite number Srecko Katanec with three kisses. Diplomatic this was not, as it is a Serbian greeting. In case Boskov has forgotten, Slovenia became independent of Yugoslavia nine years ago.

 Belgium's striker Emile Mpenza has revealed that he was inspired to his match-winning exploits in the hosts' opening match by Miss Belgium, Joke van de Velde. Mpenza said he drew his energy for the game against Sweden from a call to a very "special friend". Belgians will hope Van de Velde remains close at hand.

webTitle: Matteo opts for a Scottish future

fields.headline: Matteo opts for a Scottish future
fields.trailText: Any hopes that Dominic Matteo might one day be the answer to England's left-sided problems were dispelled yesterday after the Liverpool defender made himself available for Scotland.
fields.body:
Any hopes that Dominic Matteo might one day be the answer to England's left-sided problems were dispelled yesterday after the Liverpool defender made himself available for Scotland.

Matteo, who has caps for England at youth, Under-21 and B level without ever playing a competitive match, was born in Dumfries and is set to play a part in Scotland's World Cup qualifying campaign.

"I am absolutely delighted that we can name Dominic in our squad for the opening World Cup qualifier against Latvia," said the Scotland manager Craig Brown.

"This is a major coup and a great boost for us. He has been desperate to play for some time but we wanted to ensure there were no questions about his eligibility."

The former Scotland captain Gary McAllister, who recently joined Matteo at Anfield, helped persuade the 26-year-old to play for the country of his birth. "He's a young player at one of the best clubs in the country," he said. "I will be more than pleased if he goes on to have a long international career."

Steve Stone is the latest player to become unsettled at Aston Villa. The 28-year-old winger, who was omitted from the side that lost to Chelsea in the FA Cup final, is being courted by Everton, who would have to pay £3m to meet Villa's asking price.

Everton's manager Walter Smith is also hoping to tie up a deal to bring Newcastle's former Italian Under-21 international Alessandro Pistone to Goodison Park. The left-back, who has suffered from injury and inconsistency since moving to Tyneside from Internazionale for £4.5m in 1997, would also cost about £3m and his arrival in the north-west would probably signal the end of Michael Ball's once promising career on Merseyside.

Another Italian defender, the Rangers captain Lorenzo Amoruso, is thinking over a move to Sunderland after a fee was agreed by the two clubs. "I left it with Lorenzo," said the Rangers chairman David Murray. "If the player is happy to go there, then fine."

The least popular managerial job in English football, at debt-ridden Sheffield Wednesday, may finally be filled early next week, although the Yorkshire club are still unable to name the man stepping into the breach.

Having been turned down by Joe Kinnear, Preston's David Moyes and Peter Taylor, the Wednesday board may now install the club's current caretaker manager Peter Shreeves on a permanent basis. The former Arsenal manager Bruce Rioch is also in the frame but is concerned about the prospect of Wednesday imposing a £4,000-a-week ceiling on players' wages which would restrict his movements in the transfer market.

The Arsenal striker Nwan-kwo Kanu has come under fire from the Nigeria Football Association chairman Dominic Oneya for "parading around the country promoting his heart foundation programme" rather than joining the squad for the World Cup match against Sierra Leone. "This is not how to be patriotic," said Oneya.

The French international Christian Karembeu will complete his £2.25m move from Real Madrid to Middlesbrough after Euro 2000.

The former Wolves striker John Richards has quit as the club's managing director.

The provisional liquidators at Airdrie have released 27 players, leaving the Scottish Second Division club with a playing staff of three a mere six weeks before the start of the season.

fields.headline: Turkey 0 - 0 Sweden
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Sweden: Hedman, Bjorklund, Lucic, Sundgren, Mild, Ljungberg, Alexandersson, Mellberg, Mjallby, K. Andersson, Larsson. Subs: Kihlstedt, Asper, Nilsson, Gustafsson, Petterson, Svensson, D. Andersson, A. Andersson, Osmanovski, Allback.

Turkey: Rustu Recber, Ogun Temizkanoglu, Fatih Akyel, Alpay Ozalan, Arif Erdem, Okan Buruk, Hakan Sukur, Suat Kaya, Muzzy Izzet, Hakan Unsal, Umit Davala. Subs: Omer Catkic, Fevzi Tuncay, Tayfur Havutcu, Tugay Kerimoglu, Sergen Yalcin, Tayfun Korkut, Osman Ozkoylu, Ergun Penbe, Oktay Derelioglu, Abdullah Ercan, Ayhan Akman.

Referee: D Jol (Holland)

1 The game kicks-off with both teams needing a victory to keep their hopes of progession to the quarter-finals alive.
2 Sweden win a free-kick 25 yards out; K Andersson takes after a short lay-off and beats the wall to force a flying save at the near post by Turkey 'keeper Rustu.
3 The resulting corner comes to nothing.
5 Booking Suat for Turkey after a foul 30 yards out. K Andersson again takes the free-kick, from a more central position, but skies it.
7 Sweden enjoying the best of the early possession before Arif breaks down the left. His fine right-foot cross from deep is put wide of the right-hand upright.
9 Turkey get their act together and switch to the right but Sweden muster well.
10 Soon-to-be-Turkish Izzet fails to get on the end of a deep cross when Hedman comes out early to claim.
12 From 40 yards out, Izzet lobs the ball to Arif just outside the area and he gets sin a creditable shot with the ball coming in over his head.
14 No real rhythm to the game yet. Both teams appear reluctant to commit too much given the importance of this match.
17 Sukur breaks down the left for Turkey but he is unable to find anyone with his cross.
18 K Andersson limps off after twisting his right ankle - a real blow for Sweden if he does not come back on.
20 Sweden try to put together a sweeping move out of defence and it takes them well into the Turkey half before the ball out-runs the recovered K Andersson.
21 Turkey spray the ball out wide to Arif deep on the left, but his poor control leads to a throw for Sweden.
22 Sukur breaks down the right, but his cross is too long and goes beyond Izzet just outside the six-yard box.
24 Sweden's first chance for a while when Larsson gets into a deep position on the right; his cross is good but, after some dainty head-tennis by the Turkey defence, thay manage to clear.
27 Sweden back in the game with a bang when Larsson's effort tests 'keeper Rustu.
28 Ljungberg exchanges passes with K Andersson before being legally bundled off the ball just inside the area.
29 Larsson picks up possession to the left of the Turkey area, cuts inside, back-heels for K Andersson to get around the back and shoot. Rustu blocks with his foot at the near post.
32 Ljungberg is unlucky not to find Larsson to his left when he shimmies into the Turkey area square-on to goal.
33 Sweden throw-in deep in the Turkey half, comes to nothing.
35 Larsson's fitness has been in doubt he is extended spell of injury, but he is moving about the field with ease at the moment.
37 Sukur wins a corner after a battle with Mellberg deep on the left. Comes to nothing.
40 Izzet goes down injured after tackling from behind after the ball had been released, as if he realised he was in line for a booking as he went in.
42 Ljungberg gets away from Suat just inside the area and the Turkish player looks to have pulled at the Swede as Rustu comes out to gather. Ljungberg certainly thought so and has a go at the ref.
44 Okan breaks well down the right for Turkey; he crosses into the penalty area but Sukur hesitates on his run and fails to connect.
45 Two extra minutes to play in one of the least tantalising matches of the tournament so far. Umit goes down injured, having turned his ankle on what looks to be a slippery pitch. webTitle: The best phone call scene: Stir of Echoes

fields.headline: The best phone call scene: Stir of Echoes
fields.trailText: Lisa (Ileana Douglas) is studiously avoiding answering her phone when her sister Maggie (Kathryn Erbe) calls. As Maggie begins to leave a message, her young son Jake (Zachary David Cope) wanders into the kitchen.
fields.body:
Lisa (Ileana Douglas) is studiously avoiding answering her phone when her sister Maggie (Kathryn Erbe) calls. As Maggie begins to leave a message, her young son Jake (Zachary David Cope) wanders into the kitchen.

"Lisa, it's me. Call me when you wake up. Look, is there any way you could possibly babysit for us on Friday night?"

Jake sits down at the kitchen table, eating a bowl of cereal. He starts talking to an unseen guest.

"I did, I told him_ What's your name?_ OK."

"I'd ask Grandma," Maggie goes on, oblivious to her son, "but then I've got to hear about it for a month. I've called everyone who could possibly do it, and no one's free."

Jake speaks without looking up from his cereal.

"Call Vanessa."

"Huh?"

"I said call Vanessa, and ask her about Debbie."

Maggie returns to the phone to wrap up her call.

"Anyway, call me back. Bye!"

She turns to Jake. He is sitting alone.

"Debbie? That's the girl who babysits for them?"

"Yep."

"Great idea. Great idea. How'd you know about Debbie?"

"Samantha told me."

He points to a figure that only he can see: Maggie, however, has already turned away and picked up the phone again.

"Hey, Vanessa - are you guys going out Friday night?"

See also: After Hours, Scream, The Last Seduction, Girl 6

Don't see also: Straight Talk

Pointless trivia: Stir Of Echoes director David Koepp has now co-written the screenplay to Sam Raimi's forthcoming Spider-Man.

webTitle: England the moths to West Indies flame

fields.headline: England the moths to West Indies flame
fields.trailText: West Indies aren't supposed to be much good away from home any more. After all, they have lost their last ten overseas Tests - three in Pakistan, five in South Africa, and two in New Zealand. But England isn't such unfamiliar territory: even though this is a youngish side, more than half of them have played county cricket here.
fields.body:
West Indies aren't supposed to be much good away from home any more. After all, they have lost their last ten overseas Tests - three in Pakistan, five in South Africa, and two in New Zealand. But England isn't such unfamiliar territory: even though this is a youngish side, more than half of them have played county cricket here.

And it showed. From the first over Ambrose and Walsh settled into the perfect line, one shade outside off stump and two shades short of a length. These two - and later their eager pupils Rose and the nippy King - backed their ability to put the ball in the right place, and came out on top because England's batsmen were drawn out like moths to a small, round, red flame.

Time after time the ball thumped into the same square foot of the pitch, and six of the first eight England wickets fell to nicks to the keeper or the slips, off similar not-quite-pitched-up balls. And, as a succession of batsmen trudged back to the pavilion, there was time to wonder why Michael Vaughan, the one obvious find of last winter's tour, was driving through the Midlands instead of through the covers.

But it's not all bad news for England. The pitch, while hardly a terror track, is offering a little too much lateral movement and, occasionally, variable bounce. That bounce will get worse as the match wears on, and West Indies will be batting last (unless Lara does something spectacular). The late flurry from Caddick and Gough gave England a more respectable total. That pair began well enough with the ball, although their aim was less pinpoint than that of Curtly'n'Courtney - probably the result of having to cope with a right- and left-hand combination from the start. England need to bowl a little fuller and straighter tomorrow - and then we could have quite a match on our hands.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: British troops leave Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: British troops left Sierra Leone today as deputy prime minister John Prescott insisted that Britain was not abandoning its former colony but moving into a new phase to help stabilise the country.
fields.body:
British troops left Sierra Leone today as deputy prime minister John Prescott insisted that Britain was not abandoning its former colony but moving into a new phase to help stabilise the country.

Britain is withdrawing most of its troops after a brief foray a month ago that strengthened government and UN troops in the face of a rebel offensive. About 200 soldiers will stay on for limited security duties and to train government troops.

Both Britain and President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah expressed confidence that the UN mission in Sierra Leone (Unamsil), humiliated by hostage seizures in May, was now able to keep the rebels at bay. But recent clashes between government forces and rebels northeast of the capital Freetown have shown that detained rebel leader Foday Sankoh's Revolutionary United Front rebels are still active.

Mr Prescott, on a visit to Freetown, played down the significance of Britain's withdrawal. "We are not leaving," he said after meeting the last contingent of marines on their way to HMS Ocean. "We are now moving into the second phase which is to help restore and rebuild and protect democracy in Sierra Leone and to help strengthen the [Sierra Leone] army itself."

Mr Prescott held 30 minutes of talks with Mr Kabbah, to whom he delivered a letter of support from prime minister Tony Blair. "I have been saying cheerio to our commanders who are now leaving on time with a job well done," he said.

Mr Kabbah expressed confidence that the UN was now up to the job, despite the seizure of hundreds of its peacekeepers in early May in a dispute over disarmament under a July 1999 peace deal and a rebel advance that sowed panic in Freetown. "I think they are over those stages," he said. "My understanding is that they have a robust mandate. They have a mandate to defend the people of this country and its institutions."

British task force commander Brigadier David Richards agreed. "I would concede that when we arrived here [the UN and the government forces] seemed on the verge of collapse but today they have been transformed. I am confident that what we have achieved here is to serve as a catalyst to enable the government and the UN to have another go, this time understanding what is involved."

Amnesty International warned that, although Freetown was now relatively stable, reports of human rights abuses - including arbitrary killings, rape and sexual abuse - were still flooding in from elsewhere in Sierra Leone. Mark Lattimer, an Amnesty official, called on the British government to pursue a long-term strategy to protect human rights in the country.

He said: "There is little doubt that Britain's support for the UN peacekeeping mission has saved countless lives. Without long-term protection, the fear is that there will be a catastrophic return to atrocious abuse of civilians by rebel forces." Unamsil's mandate should be altered to allow it to protect civilians' human rights at all times, not just when they are under imminent threat of violence, he said. Meanwhile, the UK should ensure that its weapons and training went only to pro-government forces with a clean human rights record and should link its package of support to stringent safeguards preventing government use of child soldiers.

An RUF spokeswoman calling herself Colonel Chakra delivered a threat to the residents of the capital, saying: "We will soon invade Freetown." Memories of the deliberate mutilation of civilians by rebels and of a rebel assault on the city last year which killed at least 5,000 people are still fresh. Colonel Abu Sesay, a former army officer, said: "We should not take what Colonel Chakra has said lightly."

webTitle: Gore must be bold on death penalty

fields.headline: Gore must be bold on death penalty
fields.standfirst: Americans are beginning to have second thoughts about the death penalty,  writes former Guardian US correspondent Mark Tran
fields.trailText: The issue of capital punishment can win or lose an American presidential election campaign, writes former Guardian correspondent in the US Mark Tran.
fields.body:
It would take a great deal of courage for any presidential candidate to come out against the death penalty, as most Americans favour capital punishment. In a recent Gallup poll, two-thirds backed capital punishment in murder cases, while a Newsweek poll showed 73% favouring the death sentence.

So it was interesting to see vice-president Al Gore flag his concerns in a meeting with a group of editors from the New York Times, although he was careful to restate his support for the death penalty in principle. Mr Gore made his comments just after the publication of a major study on capital punishment in the US, which said that more than two-thirds of convictions were so flawed they were overturned on appeal. The Columbia University report described America's capital punishment system as fraught with errors.

"If there is a study that shows a large number of mistakes, that has to make you uncomfortable," the vice-president said. "I have assumed up until very recently that the mistakes were rare and unusual."

Mr Gore has to be cautious in order not to expose himself politically to his Republican rival, George W Bush, who holds a 20-point lead over the vice-president on law and order issues. Other politicians, however, have been bolder. The state legislature of New Hampshire has voted to abolish the death penalty and the governor of Illinois has declared a moratorium on executions. Even governor George W Bush, who is proud of the record 131 executions he has ordered in Texas, just granted his first 30-day reprieve in a death penalty case.

The death penalty continues to receive a high level of support but there are signs of a shift in attitude. Although two-thirds of Americans backed capital punishment in murder cases in the Gallup poll, it was the lowest level of support in that survey in almost two decades. In the Newsweek poll, a high proportion - 38% - thought it should only be applied to those convicted of the most brutal murders or mass murders.

The US public is already having second thoughts about the nation's lax gun laws and favours measures to make it harder for people to buy guns, following a spate of shootings, notably the incident at Columbine school, near Denver, last year. Perhaps Americans are also beginning to wonder about their country's propensity for executions. They would certainly have second thoughts about executions if they could visit a death chamber.

I saw one at the Angola prison in Louisiana. What was most striking was the extreme care and effort which went into making the execution as "humane" as possible. Nobody actually gives the lethal injection, it's done through the flick of a switch, by somebody in a separate chamber, as if to insulate that person from what is about to take place. But paradoxically, the attempt to cleanse the whole experience only makes it more barbaric. I asked my guide, a prison official, whether he had ever witnessed an execution. To my surprise he replied: "No, and I hope I never will."

Executions contaminate those who have anything to do with them, including the body politic. Without diminishing the hideousness of some of the crimes committed, it must be said - as the Columbia University study showed - that the process is inherently flawed. It is all too easy to end up in the electric chair or to get a lethal injection if you are poor and black and cannot afford a decent legal defence.

Mr Gore has taken the first tentative steps in the debate on the death penalty. If he really wants to demonstrate some political courage, he should go further and say he favours a moratorium on executions. But it will be difficult. It was, after all, George W Bush's father who wrecked Michael Dukakis's presidential campaign with the notorious Willie Horton ad, showing how a convict committed rape while on parole in the state of Massachusetts; Mr Dukakis's home stage.
