fields.headline: Not so Merrie England
fields.standfirst: Poverty and its related problems are rife in areas facilely considered as rural idylls, says Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Poverty and its related problems are rife in areas facilely considered as rural idylls, says Derek Brown
fields.body:
The charms of the English countryside mask a host of social ills, highlighted by the Countryside Agency in its latest report.

Three million rural dwellers live below the official poverty line of half the average national income. In Cornwall, thought by many to be the most idyllic of English counties, average wages are less than three-quarters of the national norm.

Ewen Cameron, Agency chairman and West Country landowner, had some hard home truths for a London conference on social exclusion in the countryside.

"Some people in rural areas face disadvantage as acute as those in urban areas: low income, lack of a secure home, difficulties reaching health care and services, social isolation, and powerlessness. The difference is they are often hidden; obscured in the wider community alongside people in very different circumstances."

Cameron's comments go to the heart of a rapidly growing social gap, as serious as the so-called north-south divide or the national gap between rich and poor.

That is, the gulf of incomes and opportunities between the rural affluent and the rural deprived. The polarisation is accelerating as wealthy people move to parts of the countryside where farm incomes are falling, and unemployment remains stubbornly high.

In the Cotswolds, the quintessence of the rural idyll and the full- or part-time home of many rich newcomers, 27% of households have annual incomes of less than £7000.

In a Wiltshire village surveyed by the Countryside Agency, a third of households had incomes below £6000, while another third had more than £40,000.

The rural divide, however, goes deeper than crude incomes. As more and more urban dwellers head for the delights of country life, house prices are rising relentlessly - especially in the counties within striking distance of London.

Earlier this year, the agency estimated that up to 10,000 new affordable homes were needed each year to meet the needs of the rural population. But in the seven years to 1997, a total of just 18,000 were built.

As many as one in six of young adults born in rural communities are leaving for the cities because they can no longer afford to live in the country. And those who stay face a grim task finding work.

Unemployment figures for rural areas are often grotesquely distorted: by the influx of retired newcomers, the inclusion of country-dwellers who commute to work in towns, and by the relatively large proportion of part-time and seasonal jobs.

Income levels are more transparent. Average weekly wages in Cornwall, for example, are £297, in Northumberland £315, and in the Isle of Wight £323. That compares with a national average of £405.

More telling than any number of raw statistics, however, are the comments from case studies featured in the agency's latest report. One farming couple in the Peak District, somehow living on a quarter of the national minimum wage, comment: "When we got this farm it was a dream come true. But it's a nightmare now."

A farm worker who has been without work for nine years tells how "the bottom dropped out of our world". And an 18-year-old Cornish youth, both jobless and homeless, poignantly records: "Live was great until I hit 12."

fields.headline: Premier League TV rights
fields.standfirst: The BBC has lost the right to show English Premiership football highlights. What does the new deal mean for football clubs, TV companies and supporters?
fields.trailText: The BBC has lost the right to show English Premiership football highlights. We explain what  the new deal means for football clubs, TV companies and supporters
fields.body:
What football will we be able to watch on TV?
Next season's Premier League TV coverage will continue as before, with BBC1 showing the Match of the Day highlights package on Saturday night while BSkyB cover matches live.

For 2001/2 it will be all change, with a new deal lasting three years. ITV will broadcast a highlights package, fronted by former Beeb favourite Des Lynam, on Saturdays and Sundays. Live match coverage is split between BSkyB, which will show 66 matches a season, and cable company NTL, which will offer 40 pay-per-view live matches (choosing them after BSkyB has picked its 66 matches). Premier League clubs will also be able to show their own matches on their own TV channels, such as Manchester United's MUTV, and on their websites after midnight on Monday.

Other live football is subject to different arrangements. Coverage of European club competitions will continue to be split between ITV, OnDigital and BSkyB. With no new deals to cover football in the bag, the BBC will be even more determined to win rights to England international matches and the FA Cup. Don't hold your breath, but they could yet snatch the right to cover the Worthington Cup.

How will the deal benefit football?
In short, it means massive amounts of money for the Premier League. The current £670.5m deal provides every Premier League club with at least £10m each season. The new £1.1bn deal gives every club around £25m. This will enable clubs to attract top talent, while the expanded TV coverage will probably continue to contribute towards football's growing popularity, as it has done over the last decade.

What are the drawbacks?
The money is an obvious boon for the top clubs, but there are three main concerns:

1. Falling attendances Live TV coverage occasionally causes a particular game to have a lower attendance than it otherwise would. But the idea that wall-to-wall TV coverage causes a drop in attendance was disproved during the 1990s, when televised games proliferated while at the same time crowd numbers steadily increased.

2. An unsustainable boom Most of the TV cash is likely to go towards meeting the cost of increasingly large wage bills for star players. The capacity of English clubs to pay the best wages in the world will tempt an increasing number of big-name foreign players to the Premier League. Wage bills could spiral out of control. Clubs' complete dependency on an ever-growing pot of TV money could also be unhealthy. In its most recent six-monthly financial results, Manchester United's money from ticket sales was down, while merchandising rose 15% per cent and TV revenue increased by 73%.

3. A widening gap between rich and poor The riches handed to the Premier League drastically increase the disparity between the 20 Premiership clubs and the 72 other professional clubs in the first, second and third divisions. It is a classic example of a free market in action.

Some argue that the TV wealth does trickle down from the Premier League to the lower leagues. But many believe that the widening chasm between the top 20 and the rest will not be beneficial for football as a whole. The growth of this gap (in media coverage, profits, wages and skills) in the 1990s is demonstrated by the tendency of those clubs promoted to the Premier League to get relegated at the end of their first season. Only the richest of the clubs promoted in the last decade, such as Newcastle and Sunderland (with one remarkably well-managed exception; Leicester City), have survived in the top flight. The Premier League could become a de facto closed shop. A widening skills gap might even encourage it to cut ties with the other leagues.

Spiralling wage bills are likely to bankrupt many lower league clubs. A few will become "feeder" organisations for Premier League clubs, agreeing to hand over all the best young players they develop in return for financial support. The number, character and diversity of England and Wales's 72 professional clubs is likely to be irrevocably diminished.

Is it good for the TV companies?
Premier League TV rights are widely credited with saving BSkyB in 1992, which attracted a huge number of new users to its subscription satellite channel service after buying exclusive rights to show live football. BSkyB views the retention of those rights as central to its future success. Both BSkyB and NTL will want to recoup their colossal investment and consumers will face a big hike in subscription rates and pay-per-view prices.

Winning the right to replace Match of the Day with its own highlights package is a major coup for ITV. But BBC director general Greg Dyke today said that the ITV bid made "no economic sense" and predicted that it may relinquish its rights in the future because they come at too high a price. While it will be able to charge premium rates for advertising slots around its coverage, it lacks the revenue potential of subscription channels or pay-per-view.

And the consumer?
The armchair supporter will delight in round-the-clock Premier League coverage, but will have to pay more for it. The supporter of a Premier League club will enjoy watching big foreign stars, although clubs are unlikely to use their TV cash to reduce ticket prices. And spectators in the lower leagues may endure hard times - or even witness their club's extinction.

webTitle: June 15: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: June 15: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: • Sylvester Stallone and Burt Reynolds are to team up for a new action-packed racing car drama. Filming on Champs is scheduled to start next month with Renny (Die Hard 2) Harlin in the director's chair. Stallone is to play a veteran driver, and Reynolds a wheelchair-bound former top driver. Edward Norton is tipped for the role of the young buck coming up on the circuit.
fields.body:
 Sylvester Stallone and Burt Reynolds are to team up for a new action-packed racing car drama. Filming on Champs is scheduled to start next month with Renny (Die Hard 2) Harlin in the director's chair. Stallone is to play a veteran driver, and Reynolds a wheelchair-bound former top driver. Edward Norton is tipped for the role of the young buck coming up on the circuit.

 That 90s phenomenon, the 'new man', is to set to receive the full movie treatment from Universal. Natural Man will tell the story of a successful high-flyer who decides he wants to stay at home and look after the kids. According to writer Gigi Levangie, who was responsible for last year's cloying Stepmom, the film will pose the question "what makes a man a man?" Apparently Michael Keaton, Adam Sandler and David Schwimmer are all front-runners to play the lead role.

 Shanghai Noon co-star Owen Wilson is set to take the lead in a new comedy, Stealing Stanford, about a hapless bore who turns to a life of crime to pay for his neice's first term at a costly Californian university. The script has been written by Martin Hynes, best known for his role as George Lucas in the cult short George Lucas in Love. Kids in the Hall director Bruce McCulloch is in talks to direct.

 Following our earlier report, negotiations have broken down between 20th Century Fox and Jim Carrey over the low-budget thriller Phone Booth. The project, expected to start shooting this summer, has, however, gained the attention of another Hollywood bigwig, Will Smith.

 Two more members of Grammy award-winning boy band The Backstreet Boys have ventured into film. Brian Littrell will co-produce and co-star (with his fiancee Leighanne Wallace and bandmate AJ) in Olive Juice. Fellow band member Howie D, who starred in Parenthood in 1989, has recently signed to play a young Jewish man in the new feature Bloom.

webTitle: Top movies accused of triggering copycat crimes

fields.headline: Top movies accused of triggering copycat crimes
fields.trailText: Gladiator and the Jerry Bruckheimer car-thief thriller Gone in 60 Seconds are under suspicion of triggering copycat crimes on both sides of the Atlantic
fields.body:
The Roman epic Gladiator and the Jerry Bruckheimer car-thief thriller Gone in 60 Seconds (pictured) are under suspicion of triggering copycat crimes on both sides of the Atlantic.

Local residents in Wales are holding Gladiator responsible for an incident in which a schoolboy was stabbed with a home-made spear. Dale Robinson, 12, is currently in a critical condition after being stabbed in the head by a classmate. The classmate is thought to have been imitating the gladiatorial antics that play a large role in Ridley Scott's hit movie.

Meanwhile, in the Vancouver suburb of Burnaby, car crime leapt by 50% on the weekend of Gone in 60 Seconds' release. The film stars Nic Cage and Angelina Jolie as ace criminals charged with stealing (or 'boosting') 50 vehicles in three days, and has been accused of romanticising car crime, with its glamorous stars and dance soundtrack.

Burnaby suffers an average of 20 car thefts a weekend. In the weekend of the movie's release, that figure jumped to 31. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police believe the events are linked. "It does raise an eyebrow," said Constable Phil Reid. "It would be silly for us not to think that [the film] is a factor."

 Gone in 60 Seconds is released in the UK on 4 August

webTitle: Mel Gibson's latest hero: a rapist who hunted Indians for fun

fields.headline: Mel Gibson's latest hero: a rapist who hunted Indians for fun
fields.trailText: The true-life pioneer behind the new Mel Gibson action film has been revealed to be not so much the stuff of legend as of law courts
fields.body:
The true-life pioneer behind the new Mel Gibson action film has been revealed to be not so much the stuff of legend as of law courts. The summer action flick The Patriot takes its inspiration from the exploits of a certain Francis Marion, who took on the full might of the British army during the American War of Independence. But when he wasn't forging the land of the free, it seems that Marion was slaughtering Indians for fun and regularly raping his female slaves. Unsurprisingly, The Patriot script elected to gloss over this aspect of its protagonist's life.

Speaking to the Daily Express, historian Christopher Hibbert claims that Marion, also known as 'the Swamp Fox', was "very active in the persecution of the Cherokee Indians and not at all the sort of chap who should be celebrated as a hero. The truth is that people like Marion committed atrocities as bad, if not worse, than those perpetrated by the British."

In The Patriot (which stars Mel Gibson in the lead role), the Swamp Fox is renamed Benjamin Martin. An anonymous source from Sony Pictures admits that the film was originally conceived as a factual biography, until the makers got wind of Marion's true history: "They couldn't go ahead once historians had given them chapter and verse on the Swamp Fox, so they had to change his name."

This controversy is not the first to dog the film. Two months ago it was threatened by the US censors with a prohibitive certificate for a scene which featured two children slaughtering a British soldier.

The Patriot is not the first film to airbrush the biography of its true-life subject. Heinrich Harrer, the Zen-like seeker played by Brad Pitt in Seven Years in Tibet, for instance, was subsequently revealed to have been a Nazi. Most notorious of all, perhaps, was Burt Lancaster's soulful portrayal of the incarcerated bird-lover Robert Stroud in Birdman of Alcatraz. The film's release provoked mass demands for Stroud to be given his freedom, but the movie neglecting to mention that Stroud had fatally stabbed a man in the prison canteen, and juggled a love of ornithology with a deep fascination with child pornography.

fields.headline: Cook's odd African adventure
fields.standfirst: As Britain's soldiers pull out from Sierra Leone, foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall argues that their brief, if successful, mission may not ultimately make much difference to the African state
fields.trailText: As Britain's soldiers pull out from Sierra Leone, foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall argues that their brief, if successful, mission may not ultimately make much difference to the African state
fields.body:
It was an odd sort of intervention from the very start, welcomed by the government and people of the war-ravaged west African state of Sierra Leone, but criticised in Britain from the political right and left as a politically-inspired military adventure and as a revival of the colonial past.

While the United Nations, whose peacekeeping force was in danger of being driven into the sea by rebels of the Revolutionary United Front (RUF), thanked Britain for coming to the rescue, in London the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, was accused of acting recklessly.

One month ago, when the decision to send in over 1,000 British paratroopers, marines, special forces, and a flotilla of warships was taken, many in parliament warned of the danger of "mission creep". Now the complaint, as the last British combat troops leave today, is one of "mission interruptus".

The British commander in Sierra Leone, Brigadier David Richards, issued assurances that the ability of the Sierra Leone government of President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah and the UN to resist and ultimately defeat the RUF has been "transformed". But many analysts are warning that the country's problems are far from over - and that the British departure is premature, and could provoke a new escalation in the nine-year-old civil war.

Although Britain will maintain about 270 military trainers and advisers in the country for the foreseeable future, doubts about the country's stability centre on a number of factors.

One is the quality and organisation of the UN force, whose numbers have now been increased to nearly 12,000 men. Disputes have become apparent between the UN's Indian force commander and the large Nigerian contingent, with some Nigerian troops refusing to obey orders. Meanwhile, large groups of UN soldiers remain cut off up-country and there are fears that there could soon be a repeat of last month's hostage-taking by the RUF.

Although the RUF leader, Foday Sankoh, has been captured, the rebels remain very active. Attacks were reported north-east of Freetown earlier this week and thousands more refugees have joined those already displaced by the fighting. The RUF also continues to hold large chunks of territory, including the key diamond-producing areas, from which British troops made no attempt to dislodge them.

Mr Cook has spread a bit of a smokescreen over Britain's withdrawal, launching an initiative to ban the trade in illicit Sierra Leone diamonds and persuading the EU to block aid to neighbouring Liberia, which Britain accuses of aiding and abetting the RUF. But these demarches, while worthy, are unlikely to affect the situation on the ground in the near future.

The uncertain loyalties of various, well-armed militias to President Kabbah's government, the absence of any progress in resuscitating the discredited Lome peace process, and the problem of drugged or drunk child soldiers (recently photographed sporting British-supplied rifles) all add to the unpredictability of the situation as the last British marines head for home.

Right now, the British intervention in Sierra Leone can be judged to have been a success, in terms of its strictly limited objectives of evacuating foreign nationals, supplying some stability and supporting the UN. But in the longer term, and especially if things go badly wrong again, it may come to be seen as a mere, brief interlude in the steady descent of Sierra Leone into bloody chaos and anarchy.

fields.headline: Fiore fires Italians forward
fields.standfirst: Euro notes - Stefano Fiore Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Italy's finishing may still be awry at times but they still found the touch to frustrate Belgium in the King Baudouin stadium here last night. A first-half header from Francesco Totti and a firm shot from Stefano Fiore after the interval, combined with astute goalkeeping from Francesco Toldo, left the Italians strongly placed to win Group B and stay in the Belgian capital for the quarter-finals.
fields.body:
Italy's finishing may still be awry at times but they still found the touch to frustrate Belgium in the King Baudouin stadium here last night. A first-half header from Francesco Totti and a firm shot from Stefano Fiore after the interval, combined with astute goalkeeping from Francesco Toldo, left the Italians strongly placed to win Group B and stay in the Belgian capital for the quarter-finals.

Having won their opening games, neither Belgium nor Italy needed to risk defeat so a mutually wary approach would have been understandable. From the Belgians, nevertheless, a certain amount of panache was expected. They had, after all, kicked off the tournament with a rush.

Italy's start had been a little more circumspect. Though the co-hosts' win over Sweden had been solid and self-assured the Italians had performed fitfully against Turkey, missing chances and needing a debatable penalty to win the game.

So much for assumptions. The game soon wrote a script of its own. For a start Dino Zoff changed the shape of his Italy team, using Mark Iuliano, who had replaced the injured Gianluca Pessotto against the Turks, in a back four rather than three. Then Italy, far from attempting to pace themselves, flung themselves at the Belgian defence and were ahead by the sixth minute.

A volley over the top by Antonio Conte, for whom Gianluca Zambrotta's centre had arrived at an awkward angle, announced Italian intentions in the second minute. In the fourth a mistake by Gert Verheyen left Paolo Maldini with a chance in the six-yard area which he mishit to Filippo Inzaghi, whose shot was saved by Filip de Wilde.

Belgian hearts were still missing beats when Italy went in front. It was the simplest of goals, a free-kick from Demetrio Albertini on the right and a straightforward header from Totti, who had squeezed between the centre-backs.

No team wants to go a goal behind so early, yet Italy's aggression suited Belgium, who were quick to respond in like manner. Bart Goor met a square pass from Marc Wilmots with a soundly struck 20-yard shot which cannoned off the left-hand angle of post and bar. Then Wilmots set up Emile Mpenza for a shot on the turn which drew a sharp save from Toldo.

If the slow-turning Belgian defence looked a mite too open at times, it did nothing to spoil the entertainment. Italy's movements were more controlled, their passing more measured, their runs finding subtler angles. And their crosses posed the greater problems.

In attack Belgium were exploiting the achilles tendon problem which had made Maldini a doubtful starter. Whenever the alert Mpenza turned Italy's captain on the right their defence looked vulnerable.

By half-time, however, Italy had created sufficient clear chances to have taken a stronger grip on the game. Inzaghi was proving their most profligate striker, such as the moment after 40 minutes when a backheel by Zambrotta followed by Albertini's cross found him moving unmarked towards the near post. Again the volley was on but this time Inzaghi barely made contact.

Italy might have rued that miss four minutes later. A sharp turn by Mpenza in the area enabled him to lay the ball back to Wilmots, whose shot was less well aimed than it was beautifully struck, merely testing Toldo's diaphragm.

Certainly Toldo was slightly the busier of the two goalkeepers. He began the second half by turning aside a snap-shot from Lorenzo Staelens after Goor's free-kick had been half-cleared. A little later the persevering Wilmots headed just wide of the far post.

Now there was a better shape and more even tempo about Belgium's movements. At the back, however, they still made the occasional unforced error and were fortunate more than once. Fortunately for the Italians Fabio Cannavaro's reflexes were in good order when Goor broke through into the goalmouth, thwarting him with a swift interception.

Belgium's defenders are always going to find one-twos around the 18-yard line difficult to handle and, when Fiore moved on to a return ball from Inzaghi, they left a gap through which Fiore drove an emphatic shot past De Wilde.

It was a slight injustice considering that they had achieved little more than a header and a shot on target, and scored with both.

fields.headline: No 7 Stefano Fiore
fields.trailText: What about that goal against Belgium! Sensational wasn't it? But why I haven't heard of this lad before? Because a year ago the Calabrian-born Fiore was only a peripheral player at Parma.
fields.body:
What about that goal against Belgium! Sensational wasn't it? But why I haven't heard of this lad before? Because a year ago the Calabrian-born Fiore was only a peripheral player at Parma.

Really? So what happened? After years on the fringes of the Gialloblu (he joined the club back in 1994, and spent time at Padova and Verona before returning to Parma), the 25 year-old joined modest Udinese last summer.

And completely turned things round, I wager! Well sort of. Last season Fiore flowered into one of the best players in Serie A, and helped Udinese to a very respectable eighth place (although the year before they did qualify for the Uefa Cup).

So how long was it before Dino Zoff came knocking on his door? It was only in February this year that Fiore was called-up to the Italian squad (for a friendly against Sweden). He then made his debut a month later during the Azzuri's 2-0 mauling at the hands of Spain.

Hardly the most auspicious of starts Granted, but then Fiore shone in the 2-0 victory over Portugal in April, providing a steady stream of astute passes from midfield which ripped open the Portuguese defence. Since then he's been a regular.

So what's Zoff assessment of him? "Fiore has been playing well both as a pure midfielder and just behind the strikers and he has matured," is the view of the Italian manager.

Hardly a ringing endorsement is it? Well it is the famously gruff Zoff we're talking about.

I have seen Fiore pop up on the left and in the middle. What's his best position? Fiore plays in central-midfield for Udinese - but because he's a strong runner and got quick feet, he's equally at home in the hole behind the front two and on the left.

After all that press criticism of the Italian team, he must have enjoyed that goal last night. Not really. Unlike most of his team mates, Fiore seems refreshingly modest. "We were not upset by the critics and we are not exalted by the praise now," was his assessment. "We must continue to feel humble."

I've noticed that our playmaker is a real looker. How long do you give it before the tabloids dub him Stefano Phwoar-rie? About three days, probably

Not to be confused with: Dr Stefano Fiore, Department of Anesthesiology and Perioperative Medicine, Harvard. Billy Fury, singer with the Furies. Dino Baggio. Anyone in the Italian squad with long hair (which is all of them).

fields.headline: When Kim met Kim
fields.standfirst: Korea: special report
fields.trailText: A conversation between the two leaders which was staged for the the cameras before yesterday's summit
fields.body:
A conversation between the two leaders which was staged for the the cameras before yesterday's summit

Kim Jong-il (KJI): Did you sleep well last night?

Kim Dae-jung (KDJ): I slept well. I even had naengmyon [cold noodles] at Okryugwan restaurant.

KJI: I hope you weren't rushed at lunch. You won't be able to fully appreciate the taste of naegnmyon if you hurry.

KDJ: I thank you for your warm welcome. I am sure the people in the South were surprised to see you come to greet me at the airport.

KJI: Some Europeans have wondered why I am so reclusive. I am not such a great figure worthy to be called a recluse. The fact is I have made many secret trips to countries like China and Indonesia. How is it that people say I made a rare appearance to welcome you? I have been here and there without people knowing. Is the food to your liking?

KDJ: The food is delicious.

webTitle: When Player Trueman took on Gentleman Dexter

fields.headline: When Player Trueman took on Gentleman Dexter
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Could you solve a pub debate? When was the last Gentlemen versus Players match, and who were the captains? asks Keith Roberts
fields.body:
Could you solve a pub debate? When was the last Gentlemen versus Players match, and who were the captains? asks Keith Roberts

The distinction between professionals (the Players) and amateurs (the Gentlemen) in English cricket was abolished in 1962, so that was the last year this famous fixture was played. The captains were suitably typical of the flinty paid professional and the supposedly devil-may-care unpaid true-Blue amateur - Fred Trueman (Yorkshire) of the Players and Ted Dexter (Cambridge University and Sussex) of the Gents. The game, played at Lord's in July 1962, was drawn. The Rev. David Sheppard and Roger Prideaux both scored Gentlemanly centuries, and Trevor Bailey later took six wickets for them. Sheppard's hundred won him a place on that winter's tour of Australia, 12 years after his previous trip there.

Did Garry Sobers score a century on his Test debut? asks Glen Wheattem

No, he very much did not. Sobers didn't score a Test century until his 17th appearance, against Pakistan at Kingston in 1957-58. He did make up for it by taking his score to 365 not out, which remained a Test record for 36 years. Sobers had made his debut in the final Test against England in 1953-54, when he was only 17. He won selection for that game as a slow left-arm bowler (and batted at No.9): his first Test wicket was that of Trevor Bailey, who later wrote a biography of him. Sobers went on to play four Tests against Australia in 1954-55, four in New Zealand in 1955-56, all five in England in 1957, and the first two against Pakistan in 1957-58 without reaching three figures. Before that 1957-58 series he had made only three half-centuries, but he took a great liking to the Pakistan attack: innings of 52, 52 and 80 were followed by the 365*, then two more hundreds - 125 and 109* - at Georgetown.

He never looked back as a batsman: three more hundreds in his next three Tests, and 26 in all in 93 matches, finishing with 8032 runs at the tremendous average of 57.78. He was a fine bowler too - he ended up with 235 wickets, mainly taken in his seam-and-swing mode - and a fabulous fielder (109 catches). All in all Garfield St Aubrun Sobers, who was knighted by the Queen in 1975, shortly after his retirement, was probably the greatest allrounder cricket has ever seen.

One FH Farrands played for MCC in the late 19th century, and then became an umpire. There may be a family connection, so can you tell me any more about him? asks Steve Farrands

Frank Henry Farrands was born in Sutton-in-Ashfield in Nottinghamshire on March 28, 1835, and died there on Sept 22, 1916. He was a right-hand batsman and a fastish roundarm bowler at a time before full overarm bowling was the norm. He was on the MCC groundstaff for many years, starting in 1868 or possibly before, and also played two matches for Notts. He later became an umpire, and stood in seven Test matches between 1884 and 1888. One of the record-books notes that his surname is given as "Farrand" on his death certificate.

Is there a layman's guide to the Duckworth-Lewis system? I would like to be able to programme my hand-held computer to do the calculations (OK, so I'm an anorak) says Graham Porter

The Duckworth-Lewis method of deciding targets in rain-affected one-day games is not easy to understand, so I wish you luck with your programming! Basically the system works out what resources are left to the batting side - if you have all ten wickets standing, that's 100% of your wicket resources, and if you have used up 20 of your 50 overs when it rains, that's 60% of your overs left. You put the two together, find out the overall resources available and compare that with the other team's total. You can find a fuller explanation of the system, written by Messrs (or Professors) Duckworth and Lewis themselves, on CricInfo at http://www-uk.cricket.org/link_to_database/ABOUT_CRICKET/RAIN_RULES/DUCKWORT H _LEWIS_1999.html

Who was named as the Cornhill Insurance England Player of the Year in April? asks Linda Rose

It was Somerset's Andrew Caddick, who received a cheque for £11,000 and a glass trophy. The award covered last summer in England and the winter tour. Caddick returned to the England side against New Zealand last summer and took 20 wickets in the four Tests, then added 16 more in South Africa. Cornhill's sponsorship of Tests in England will end this summer, after 23 years and 131 matches.

Are internationals played in South Africa or Australia between May and September? asks Waqar Ali

Not until this year! That time is winter in both countries, so not much cricket is played. But there will be a short series of one-day internationals in Australia in August, the first ever to be played indoors. The matches, all against South Africa, are scheduled for Aug 16, 18 and 20 at the new Colonial Stadium in Melbourne's Docklands. It's a big new stadium with a retractable roof, which will be kept shut for the cricket. If anyone manages to hit the roof with a shot it will be called "dead ball".

Who was the last England batsman to score a Test double-century? asks Alison Bilton

The last one (to date) was Nasser Hussain's 207 at Edgbaston in 1997. He and Graham Thorpe (138) put on 288 for the fourth wicket, and cemented England's position after Australia had been shot out on the first day for 118. England won that match by nine wickets - but Australia came back to take the series 3-2.

My father and I have been arguing about the England v Rest of the World series in 1970, which was arranged after the South African tour was cancelled. Were full England caps awarded? And are these matches treated as Tests in the record books? asks MB Ryder-Whish

The five matches in that series were promoted and played as proper Tests at the time, but it was later decided to remove them from the record-books. The records stayed in "Wisden Cricketers' Almanack" until 1979, but were then quietly dropped. It was rough luck for Alan Jones of Glamorgan, whose only England appearances came in that series. fields.bodyText: Could you solve a pub debate? When was the last Gentlemen versus Players match, and who were the captains? asks Keith Roberts The distinction between professionals (the Players) and amateurs (the Gentlemen) in English cricket was abolished in 1962, so that was the last year this famous fixture was played. The captains were suitably typical of the flinty paid professional and the supposedly devil-may-care unpaid true-Blue amateur - Fred Trueman (Yorkshire) of the Players and Ted Dexter (Cambridge University and Sussex) of the Gents. The game, played at Lord's in July 1962, was drawn. The Rev. David Sheppard and Roger Prideaux both scored Gentlemanly centuries, and Trevor Bailey later took six wickets for them. Sheppard's hundred won him a place on that winter's tour of Australia, 12 years after his previous trip there. Did Garry Sobers score a century on his Test debut? asks Glen Wheattem No, he very much did not. Sobers didn't score a Test century until his 17th appearance, against Pakistan at Kingston in 1957-58. He did make up for it by taking his score to 365 not out, which remained a Test record for 36 years. Sobers had made his debut in the final Test against England in 1953-54, when he was only 17. He won selection for that game as a slow left-arm bowler (and batted at No.9): his first Test wicket was that of Trevor Bailey, who later wrote a biography of him. Sobers went on to play four Tests against Australia in 1954-55, four in New Zealand in 1955-56, all five in England in 1957, and the first two against Pakistan in 1957-58 without reaching three figures. Before that 1957-58 series he had made only three half-centuries, but he took a great liking to the Pakistan attack: innings of 52, 52 and 80 were followed by the 365*, then two more hundreds - 125 and 109* - at Georgetown. He never looked back as a batsman: three more hundreds in his next three Tests, and 26 in all in 93 matches, finishing with 8032 runs at the tremendous average of 57.78. He was a fine bowler too - he ended up with 235 wickets, mainly taken in his seam-and-swing mode - and a fabulous fielder (109 catches). All in all Garfield St Aubrun Sobers, who was knighted by the Queen in 1975, shortly after his retirement, was probably the greatest allrounder cricket has ever seen. One FH Farrands played for MCC in the late 19th century, and then became an umpire. There may be a family connection, so can you tell me any more about him? asks Steve Farrands Frank Henry Farrands was born in Sutton-in-Ashfield in Nottinghamshire on March 28, 1835, and died there on Sept 22, 1916. He was a right-hand batsman and a fastish roundarm bowler at a time before full overarm bowling was the norm. He was on the MCC groundstaff for many years, starting in 1868 or possibly before, and also played two matches for Notts. He later became an umpire, and stood in seven Test matches between 1884 and 1888. One of the record-books notes that his surname is given as "Farrand" on his death certificate. Is there a layman's guide to the Duckworth-Lewis system? I would like to be able to programme my hand-held computer to do the calculations (OK, so I'm an anorak) says Graham Porter The Duckworth-Lewis method of deciding targets in rain-affected one-day games is not easy to understand, so I wish you luck with your programming! webTitle: Blair's lack of spin won't wash

fields.headline: Blair's lack of spin won't wash
fields.standfirst: The Labour leader made his political fortunes through spin doctors so, Madeleine Bunting asks, will he really give them up now?
fields.trailText: The Labour leader made his political fortunes through spin doctors so, Madeleine Bunting asks, will he really give them up now?
fields.body:
The Labour government appears to have finally got the message. Voters are deeply suspicious of spinning. They don't like being told what to think. So last week at the Women's Institute meeting, Tony Blair promised a shift. "I think we in government - and that means me - have to trust people more. We don't need to fight over every headline."

Yesterday we heard that Mr Blair has pulled Alaistair Campbell, his belligerent press spokesman of six years, off lobby-briefing duties for a backroom election strategy planning role. Two senior civil servants will take over the role of briefing, signalling a straighter, 'less spun' approach.

But it will take more than a few well-intentioned words and a shift of responsibilities to root out a practice which has been central to the political culture of Mr Blair's Labour party. The man who first emerged into the national limelight as a potential party leader did so on the back of a well-spun soundbite - 'tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime'. Leopards don't change their spots that easily or quickly.

Crucial to Blair's brand of big tent politics has always been the importance of getting carefully crafted messages across to bring all the different audiences (Labour heartlands and Middle England) under the canvas. That required assiduously working with the media - media which were very hostile to Labour throughout the eighties and much of the nineties. Spinning was the inevitable result, and it won't end here.

Because for all Mr Blair's earnest wish to 'trust' more (that remark is a staggering confession) he simply doesn't have that ease of rapport with his electorate by which he knows he and his supporters speak the same language. He still repeatedly talks about the need for the government to communicate better - to get the message across - and he seems frustrated that the electorate still don't understand what the government has achieved. All that points to much more spin in the run-up to the next election, although it may become more subtle in deference to the focus groups, and Mr Campbell's fondness for expletives will be pushed into the background.

webTitle: Angry BBC priced out of market

fields.headline: Angry BBC priced out of market
fields.standfirst:
Huge bids win top football coverage for Sky and ITV as 36 years of Match of the Day ends
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC's reputation last night suffered another devastating blow when it lost the rights to screen Premiership football highlights to ITV in a multi-million pound auction.
fields.body:
The BBC's reputation last night suffered another devastating blow when it lost the rights to screen Premiership football highlights to ITV in a multi-million pound auction.

The loss means that Match of the Day, a Saturday night fixture for 36 years, will disappear from TV screens.

The result was deeply humiliating for the BBC director general, Greg Dyke, who had promised to restore the corporation's fortunes when he took over this year - and highlighted sport as a key area for improvement.

The BBC reacted angrily to the decision and accused Premier League officials of being driven by money rather than football.

"We're always uncomfortable with the auction process," a spokesman said. "It didn't give the BBC any credit for helping to build the audience for the Premier League since its inception. It seems only money talks these days."

But the culture secretary, Chris Smith, welcomed the deal, saying it would maintain access to football for a mass audience via terrestrial television.

"Coverage of football has increased dramatically over the last 10 years, and the competition over rights has produced a very lucrative deal for the Premier League clubs," he said in a statement.

ITV compounded the corporation's woes by announcing that Des Lynam, who moved to the network from the BBC last year, would present its show. ITV bid £183m for a three-year package beginning in August 2001, against the corporation's total of £123m.

Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB retained the main Premier League rights, which will allow it to show 66 live games a year for a total of £1.11bn in an auction decided with sealed bids yesterday afternoon.

A second package of 40 games, which will be shown on a pay-per-view basis, was won by Britain's biggest cable company, NTL, for £328m, bringing the windfall for the league clubs to £1.64bn over three years.

Barry Davies, the veteran football commentator, was one of many lamenting the end of what has become a Saturday night institution."It's a surprise. This is very difficult; it's the end of an era. Match of the Day has been my life but Motty (John Motson) is going to be totally gutted by this."

The BBC has successively lost the rights to screen Formula One motor racing, England's home international rugby games, Test cricket and the FA Cup final.

Last month, while ITV screened the FA Cup final and Channel 4 showed the first Test, BBC1 cancelled Grandstand because it had no live sport - and screened the musical My Fair Lady instead.

ITV outbid the BBC by £20m a year for the Premier League package, which gives it two weekly highlights shows, the main Saturday night slot plus a second on Sundays and some week nights. David Liddiment, ITV's director of programmes, described it as "a huge coup".

Under the existing deal, the BBC pays less than £20m a year and the corporation more than doubled its offer to £41m in the hope of hanging on to one of its few remaining sporting jewels. The ITV offer works out as £61m a year.

Mr Dyke attempted a brave face and said the offer was the highest the BBC could afford. "We are still very hopeful that the FA Cup, Worthington Cup and England internationals will return to the BBC and that Match of the Day can become a showcase for live football," he said.

The BBC's director of sport, Richard Sambrook, added: "We believe ours was a very fair and reasonable offer, given that we are spending public money. We have to assume this will be a loss leader for ITV."

Mr Lynam who appeared to have been played as a trump card by ITV said he was "personally thrilled" to be reunited with the Premier League. "I am delighted for my ITV colleagues who have put a vast amount of effort into clinching this contract," he said.

The huge windfall for the game is put into sharp relief when compared to 1986, the last year of the BBC and ITV cartel which paid £6.2m for Premier League coverage over two years.

The retention of the main package of live rights was seen as critical for BSkyB, which has built its business on the back of the Premier League. When the company first made its grab for the rights in 1992, the pay television business was saddled with a £2bn debt and still haemorrhaging cash.

Mr Murdoch described sport as "the battering ram" with which to open new markets.

The inflation surrounding broadcasting rights for the game means the Premier League will receive £548m a year under the new contract compared with £148m a year at present. The last deal, brokered on the eve of Euro '96 saw BSkyB pay £670m over five years and the BBC £73m.

In addition to the flat payment, BSkyB is guaranteeing a minimum of £22.5m for revenues from interactive services such as online merchandising.

The bidding process began in March when Premier League officials sent out 75 tender documents. Shortlists of media candidates who met the quality threshold were drawn for each package and they were asked to submit sealed offers.

Richard Scudamore, chief executive of the Premier League, said: "I offer my congratulations to the winners and commiserations to the losing bidders, particularly the BBC who have been a valuable broadcasting partner since 1992."

Winners need to make a down payment of 7.5% but Mr Scudamore said the division of the money among clubs would be decided at a later date. The Premier League has yet to issue radio rights and rights for new technologies such as the internet and mobile phones.

What's on and what it costs

Live 1: BSkyB (£1.11bn)

Up to 66 Premiership games a season on Sundays and Mondays with "first pick", provided each club is shown three times a season

Live 2: NTL (£328m)

Up to 40 encrypted live matches, shown on a pay-per-view basis on Sundays, with "second pick" of fixtures. No more than eight matches from one particular club each season.

Highlights: ITV (£183m)

Saturday highlights of three Premiership matches to be screened after 7pm, Sunday highlights of two matches after 9pm, plus a Saturday morning preview programme.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: Day six

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: Day six
fields.standfirst: Four men, armed with £50, aim to be the last man standing after 23 days of daily football betting. It's You Bet Your Life, brought to you in association with BlueSq
fields.trailText: Italy's comfortable win against Belgium was good news for all but one of our pundits. The standings now look like this:
fields.body:
Italy's comfortable win against Belgium was good news for all but one of our pundits. The standings now look like this:

Mike Hodgkinson £68.75

Sean Ingle £64.56

Scott Murray £64.17
Paul MacInnes £38

Now for the selections for today's Turkey v Sweden game.

Mike Hodgkinson

Sergen Yalcin first scorer 10-1 (£5)

Turkey have the worst goalkeeper in the competition, by miles, which may make the selection of a Turkish first scorer look a bit thick. On the other hand, Rustu Recber might get dropped - and Sergen Yalcin showed against Italy he's more than willing to have a go from distance. Sweden don't look up to much - Turkey can draw first blood.

Sean Ingle

Turkey to win 15/8 (£10)

How do you assess this one? Both teams are coming off losses, both have obvious defensive flaws and both desperately need a win. If history is any guide, then Turkey hold a slight edge. They've won two games to one in the four meetings between the countries.

However, there are all sorts of imponderables regarding tonight's game: Is Larsson anywhere near fit? Will the intense media pressure overwhelm or inspire the temperamental Turks? And how are Freddie Ljungberg's feet?

But for me the key factor is Sweden's defence. It fell apart against Belgium - and is even more weakened now Roland Nilsson is out with concussion and Patrick Andersson is suspended. It'll be close, but I take Turkey to win.

Scott Murray

Draw 9/4 (£10)

Neither of these teams cut the mustard in their opening match, so odds of just over twos for a stalemate seem worth a punt. Turkey put up a brave but limited display in their first match, while Sweden - the better side on paper - were simply abject. There's enough quality out there - players like Henrik Larsson, Hakan Suker and saucy Freddie Ljungberg could tip the balance either way - but I don't expect to witness the amount of inspired play which is required to ruin my bet.

Paul MacInnes

Sweden and Turkey earning over 40 disciplinary points at 10 points per yellow and 25 per red card 6/4 (£5)

I won a bet. I won a bet. I won a, I won a, I won a £$($*%$"$ bet. That's right, Francesco Totti's strike earned me £8 and my name is now Loki, god of luck and spectacular bet-winning. There is no point in wasting my new-found powers, and so I've gone for the above bet (too complicated to explain again) in the hope that this important match for a pair of evenly-matched sides boils over into bad tackles and even worse diving. One final note, if anybody has a disease that needs curing, I'm available most week nights.

fields.headline: BAE axes 3,800 workers
fields.trailText: Aerospace giant BAE Systems will cut 3,800 white collar and production jobs following its merger with Marconi, it was announced today.
fields.body:
Aerospace giant BAE Systems will cut 3,800 white collar and production jobs following its merger with Marconi, it was announced today.

The company said that a review of its business following the merger had made it clear a number of savings could be made because of duplication and overlapping production capabilities.

The cuts will hit many of BAE's 60 sites. 850 jobs will be lost at Brough, East Yorkshire, While there will be 750 loses at Warton and Samlesbury - two sites near Preston.

BAE's three shipyards at Govan, Glasgow, Barrow, Cumbria, and Scotstoun on the Clyde, will lose 500 jobs between them. Union officials were given details of the cuts at a briefing at the company's head office in Hampshire.

The company's chief executive, John Weston, said savings had been identified throughout BAE's UK operation which would also improve efficiency.

He said: "Decisions that affect jobs and sites are regrettable and are only taken after very careful consideration."

Mr Weston said the company would offer a voluntary redundancy programme, early retirement and reskilling for workers.

BAE sites to close include York, with the loss of 50 jobs, and Ilford in Essex.

The future of a defence factory at Nottingham is under review but the site will lose 250 jobs.

BAE said it would try to restrict overtime and reclaim work from subcontractors where possible to lessen the impact of today's announcement.

The company said there was now a "real requirement" that it remained highly competitive and achieved profitable growth in its business.

Unions expressed "shock" at the scale of the job losses and said they would fight compulsory redundancies. John Wall, national officer of the manufacturing science and finance union said: "We will do everything to lessen the impact of this announcement on our members but we are very shocked, particularly at the size of the cutback at Brough."

Unions were seeking talks with managers at BAE plants across the country to discuss the cutbacks in more detail.

fields.headline: Commonwealth ministers call for democracy
fields.trailText: Commonwealth ministers today called for a restoration of democracy in Fiji shortly after arriving in the south Pacific nation where ultra-nationalists have held 31 hostages for almost a month.
fields.body:
Commonwealth ministers today called for a restoration of democracy in Fiji shortly after arriving in the south Pacific nation where ultra-nationalists have held 31 hostages for almost a month.

The ministers from Australia, New Zealand, Malaysia and Botswana will not hold talks with coup leader George Speight, but plan to meet military, church, tribal and community leaders tomorrow.

"It is our hope that those discussions will contribute to the restoration of constitutional rule and democratic government," the ministers said in a statement on arrival. The Commonwealth has criticised Mr Speight's May 19 takeover and suspended Fiji from its decision-making councils earlier this month. Talks between Fiji's military and Mr Speight to end the hostage deadlock have resumed but neither side appears to willing to budge.

Mr Speight seized the entire government led by Mahendra Chaudhry, Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister, in the name of indigenous Fijians rights. The military has since taken over government, suspended Fiji's multiracial constitution and imposed martial law. Mr Speight has refused to release his hostages, held inside the parliamentary compound in Suva, the capital, until a Fijian-only civilian government is installed that includes him and other coup leaders. He has also called for a racially biased constitution enshrining indigenous political domination of Fiji.

But Fiji's military has said it would rule until an interim civilian government can be installed to prepare for fresh elections in three months. On Thursday, the military reiterated its plan to restore the multiracial constitution.

The UN security council said it was concerned about Fiji's political crisis and instability in the neighbouring Solomon Islands where a separate ethnic dispute has erupted into fighting. Members "expressed their concern about regional instability, given the recent events in Fiji and the Solomon Islands," said security council president Jean-David Levitte. They "reiterated their support for democratic and constitutional processes and the rule of law."

The military warned that the coup was crippling Fiji's economy and would slash revenue by 200 million Fiji dollars. It said it planned to introduce a mini-budget which would cut expenditure by 182 million Fiji dollars.

"We need to do this, firstly, to ensure the effective maintenance of law and order and the safety of all citizens and their properties," said Colonel Filipo Tarakinikini. Fiji's two economic mainstays, tourism and sugar, have been badly hurt by the coup, with resort hotels closing due to falling occupancy and Indian sugar farmers refusing to cut cane.

Col Tarakinikini said the few Indian sugar cane growers willing to return to the fields would be given army protection. Union workers in Australia, Fiji's largest trading partner, are also refusing to handle cargo to or from the country. Fiji's ministry of labour estimated last week that the coup had already cost more than 2,000 jobs in key industries such as tourism and sugar.

Australian trade unions warned they may intensify Fijian trade bans unless Mr Speight released his hostages. Australian council of trade unions leader Sharan Burrow said Australian workers had refused to fully load a fuel tanker bound for Fiji earlier this week and could block further fuel shipments to protest the coup. The Fiji trades union congress, which is seeking a meeting with the Commonwealth delegation, supports international trade bans as a means of restoring democracy.

fields.headline: Theo Angelopoulos:  The Travelling Players
fields.trailText: Even though no one but a Greek can understand all the political, historical and mythic allusions, it is a fascinating progress, enlivened by Yorgos Arvanitis's often luminous photography, Loukianos Kilaidonis's throbbing music, including songs and dances adapted from folk sources, and performances that seem utterly truthful
fields.body:
Of the few great directors who are still with us, Theo Angelopoulos, born in Athens in 1936, is probably the least known. The reasons are obvious. He is a film-maker who refuses compromise. The slow pace and austere style of his work are utterly against current trends, and the content is invariably as formidably intellectual as it is emotional and poetic. He is, to put it bluntly, not everybody's idea of a good night out. At his best, however, he is unquestionably a master. And only the fact that he so obviously knows it renders that fact unsympathetic.

Now finally invested with the Palme d'Or at Cannes - a prize he has coveted for years, even to the extent of making a churlish speech when he was offered the runner's-up award - Angelopoulos seems content to allow history to judge his work. It will certainly judge The Travelling Players (O Thiassos) a classic.

It was filmed in Greece in 1974, at no small risk, under the hard-line rule of the Greek colonels' junta. Why the military police who watched its progress allowed it to be completed is a mystery, since the film clearly examines the turbulent history of its country of origin from a radical Brechtian point of view. Perhaps the colonels' men thought that this story of a troupe of itinerant actors touring Golfo the Shepherdess, a pastoral folk drama set to music and song, was harmless enough. But it wasn't, since the period in which it is set (1939 to 1952) warmed the seeds of their masters' military coup.

Almost four hours long, The Travelling Players has its actors first watch and then get caught up in the political events of the period, so that even the play changes its emphasis. As they progress through the often rainy and wintry provincial Greece in which Angelopoulos usually prefers to shoot, the sequences become longer and longer and the pace seldom changes. The whole film is accomplished in around 80 shots.

But despite that, and even though no one but a Greek can understand all the political, historical and mythic allusions, it is a fascinating progress, enlivened by Yorgos Arvanitis's often luminous photography, Loukianos Kilaidonis's throbbing music, including songs and dances adapted from folk sources, and performances that seem utterly truthful.

How does Angelopoulos achieve this magic? It is partly the utter conviction with which he steers his work towards an inner as well as an outward relevance. But take a look, if you want to see how he manages individual sequences, at the closing passage of this film, when one of the actors is executed for sedition and his fellow performers raise their hands above their heads to applaud his life at the graveside. Nothing could be done more simply - though in most successful simplicity there is a great deal of artfulness. But the sequence, perhaps because of all that has gone before, is far more moving than the myriad funeral scenes in movies manage to be. It has a grace that is almost totally absent from most of today's cinema.

In many ways Angelopoulos has been lucky. As the outstanding Greek director, he has had his every whim granted over the last half of his career by the cultural wing of the country's government. And he is clearly a difficult man to satisfy. But he has forged a unique if often pessimistic style through which to examine as minutely as he can his own country and countrymen. If you were to see all his dozen or so films, you would have not only a much greater appreciation of Greek and Balkan conflicts, but a larger view of the inner turmoil of individuals whose lives have been altered by them.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's transfer talk shrunk to microscopic size and injected into a baboon
fields.trailText: Several newspapers report that David Ginola is to join Aston Villa for £3m. Director of football David Pleat said today: "After some discussion the club have agreed to allow David Ginola to speak to Villa." The Sun suggests that while a deal to take Ginola to the Midlands is far from cut and dried, the fact that George Graham is prepared to sell his star winger means it is unlikely Ginola will play for Spurs again.
fields.body:
Several newspapers report that David Ginola is to join Aston Villa for £3m. Director of football David Pleat said today: "After some discussion the club have agreed to allow David Ginola to speak to Villa." The Sun suggests that while a deal to take Ginola to the Midlands is far from cut and dried, the fact that George Graham is prepared to sell his star winger means it is unlikely Ginola will play for Spurs again.

The Sun believes that Martin O'Neill wants to bring Leeds' Michael Duberry to Celtic, and is prepared to pay £6m for his services. Leeds are willing to trade in on the central defender, only 12 months after buying him, and the 24-year-old could be used as bait to persuade Celtic into selling striker Mark Viduka.

Planet Football meanwhile reports that if Celtic do sell Viduka, they will look to bring in Middlesbrough's Hamilton Ricard as a replacement. The website also suggests that Martin O'Neill will bid for Hibs' highly-rated youngster Kenny Miller.

Everton are after Newcastle's Alessandro Pistone, according to the Daily Mail. The paper believes the two clubs have agreed on a deal for the 24-year-old fullback, with the fee in the region of £3m. Walter Smith is also believed to be looking at Aston Villa's former England winger Steve Stone.

Three English clubs have declared an interest in Portuguese striker Joao Pinto, according to the player himself. "I admire English football and have many friends playing there," he told the Daily Express, "so moving to England is something I would consider." Planet Football believes Chelsea are at the head of the queue.

Arsenal have made a £2m bid for Sweden striker Kennett Andersson. The Daily Star believes Arsene Wenger wants the 32-year-old as a replacement for Davor Suker.

According to reports in Portugal, Lazio have bid £36m for Luis Figo.

Ispwich Town have completed a £1m deal to bring Dutch international Martijn Reuser to the club.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: RIP 1st Line
fields.body:
RIP 1st Line

Just a week after winning third place in Oftel's most complained-about-companies awards, our old friend 1st Line has expired without warning, blaming "changes inthe rapidly developing and increasingly competitive mobile telephone market".

In reality, it seems, one of its principal creditors called time. Consumer readers will notice the void: no more evening salutations from salesmen trained to tether you to the phone until you agree to a two-week trial mobile.

But spare a thought for the 2,000 souls who have gone down unpaid with the vessel. Their sorry tales should explain much to readers who have been on the receiving end of the company's aggressive cold-call techniques.

According to one, who prefers not to be named, many of the floor managers were recently replaced by ex-army recruits who encouraged them to pressurise elderly householders into buying a handset. Staff who did not notch up enough sales were allegedly bullied and humiliated. Last September the staff union, GMB, criticised the company's work practices after complaints from staff about their treatment and it says it was not consulted last week about the job losses.

After Christmas, 1st line, which was the UK's largest direct retailer of post-pay mobiles, almost doubled its staff numbers. However, the number of new customers had begun to plummet recently .

No one from 1st Line is available to answer questions. BT Cellnet, which owns a hefty stake in the company, and Cellular Operations ,1st Line's trading partner, are coy about gory details, but in a statement the latter says it is "aware that 1st Line Mobile Communications has gone into liquidation. We know that they have been experiencing difficulties and had undergone some restructuring in an attempt to deal with the problems."

Consumer was just in time to rescue Fiona Clewes of Whitby whose 1st Line phone didn't work properly because of patchy coverage in her district. She was told she would receive a refund and that no further charges would be made. Instead, she was sent bills and debt collection threats and her line was barred. "There's been a significant degree of misunderstanding," admitted a spokesman. He said that Cellular Operations, 1st Line's network provider, would waive all charges if Clewes returned the phone.

Edna Braithwaite and Averil Freeth have since written to complain that they haven't been able to get through to 1st Line to return trial phones. They fear they will be charged. DW Russell has already been charged £5 a month more than he was promised. Cellular Operations has promised to investigate. Other customers with complaints should ignore the message on the 1st Line number, which insists that all its operators are busy, and call Cellular Operations direct on 0870 243 2300.

Where's the refund?

It's pleasant to suppose that when a bag is snatched and the theft reported to the victim's bank, that is the end of a distressing experience.

Not, alas, when the bank is Barclays. A handbag belonging to A Bishopp was stolen on March 21 - and she duly notified her branch in Epsom. The following week, however, she discovered that she was £1,000 overdrawn after the thieves had helped themselves to £1,300.

She complained to the bank whose response was to send her a reprimand for "mismanaging" her account. Disturbed that her replacement bank cards were issued on the same account number, she decided to close her current account and open a new one at a different branch.

Only later, when she received her quarterly statement, did she realise that her savings account was £900 short, despite Barclays' assurances that it was safe. Next she found that the current account, which she thought she had closed, was still active and that the £1,200 refund paid into it by Barclays had vanished. From the start she had been told that a fraud officer at Epsom was investigating: only now did she learn that he had never been informed.

Bishopp says she has received no apology and no written assurances that her accounts are now safe. Nor has she received a refund of the stolen money.

Barclays says the case was dealt with "according to our procedures". However, the bank concedes that Bishopp was misled and that its departments failed to communicate effectively. It is now refunding the money along with a £100 apology.

Worthless vouchers

Airlines would take an unfriendly view of passengers who turned up a day after their flight, blaming altered work schedules. Yet passengers who painstakingly plan their trips round flight times and turn up on the dot are by no means guaranteed to fly. Airlines reserve the right to change their schedules and cancel flights - or even whole airports - without notice and passengers have no right to complain about it. All was well when E Wilson and her husband checked in at Sheffield for a KLM flight to Washington via Amsterdam, and their return flight 18 days later was confirmed. But when they presented themselves at Washington for the trip home they were told there were difficulties and took off for Amsterdam without any connecting flight in prospect. Eventually they were flown to Leeds/Bradford because, it turned out, KLM had ceased operations at Sheffield the previous day. KLM compensated them with £100 worth of vouchers which the Wilsons claim are useless since it no longer has flights from their local airport. "Does KLM issuing tickets to us not form part of a contract with us?" asks Mrs Wilson.

It does, but does not bind airlines to advertised schedules. KLM says it does reimburse out-of-pocket expenses incurred by passengers, but says disengenuosly: "It is not common practice to offer monetary compensation, but rather vouchers for use for future travel as we see this as an opportunity to regain customer confidence in our service."

Still not up to scratch

A month ago the car rental company, Hire For Lower, won our prize for most prolific newcomer to the column. It achieved a dizzying number of complaints last summer. But since then, we concluded optimistically, it seemed to have cleaned up its act.

Not so, says Peter Sweeney of Guildford, who recently returned from a holiday in Spain. He and his family had arranged to collect their hire car from an office in Seville but arrived to find that it had moved two years previously.

The office number they had been given didn't work and the back-up UK number in case the office was closed was on answer machine. Eventually they discovered the new address a mile away and walked there with their luggage. Sweeney complained but received no response.

Hire for Lower has yet to get back to Consumer but at least Sweeney eventually received a letter from the firm plus a cheque reimbursing him for the phone calls he made.

Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

webTitle: How much can you pay for . . .

fields.headline: How much can you pay for . . .
fields.standfirst:
Cybershopping

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: . . . a shell
fields.body:
. . . a shell

You can save yourself the bother of keeping your eyes peeled as you stroll along the beach by ordering one of Ruzzetti & Gow's cardium shells.

Semi-silvered and approximately 4in wide, this "piece of nature improved", as Ruzzetti & Gow describes it, will set you back $130 (£85). It is guaranteed to give your home that desirable beach-house effect without making it feel too rustic. This is no mere mollusc. It can be used as a paperweight, a soap dish, an ashtray or, indeed, anything else you can think of. And once you have the shell, why not add to the beauty of your mantelpiece with some Ruzzetti & Gow silvered vegetables? A pomegranate is a mere $90 (£40), and spears of asparagus $60 (£40) each. From www.luxuryfinders.com

Father's Day

Father's Day is possibly the most artificial celebration on the calendar, but it's still a good excuse to show the old man that you care.

www.vanpeterson.com is good only if you have serious sucking up to do. The site features jewellery by Eric Van Peterson, whose Walton Street store has welcomed the likes of Cher and Michael Douglas. As tricky as it might be to choose between the oval cufflinks in platinum, (£1,450),and the swivel-back platinum cufflink set with blue sapphires (£1,750), you've only got until the end of the day to place your order, for delivery on Saturday.

Or get pants - always welcome - from www.whyfronts.com . Designer undies include Calvin Klein Shorts Sloggi, Hom and Brass Monkey. Order before 4pm today to ensure Saturday delivery.

If you want to impress dad with your culinary skills but can't be bothered to put in the hard labour, cheat by going

to www.leapingsalmon.com .

There are nine meal "kits" with all the ingredients - washed and chopped - for a gourmet meal for two. Prices range from £14.90 for Thai green curry, to £19.90 for roast duck in port or seared tuna.
