webTitle: Laughing all the way to the bank

fields.headline: Laughing all the way to the bank
fields.standfirst: After the boo.com debacle, e-commerce confidence has taken a knock in Britain. But the head of Amazon.com has plenty to smile about, as Ashley Norris discovers
fields.trailText: After the boo.com debacle, e-commerce confidence has taken a knock in Britain. But the head of Amazon.com has plenty to smile about, as Ashley Norris discovers
fields.body:
The first thing everyone notices about Jeff Bezos is the loud, infectious laugh that punctuates virtually his every sentence. The chief executive officer of Amazon.com, the world's largest e-tailer laughs at my jokes, laughs at his own jokes and even breaks into a hearty guffaw when his coffee turns up.

But he has good reason to have a smile on his face. He might not yet have made any profit - which e-tailer has? - yet his internet business, started with a $300,000 loan from his parents, is now worth over $1bn. He literally is laughing all the way to the bank.

He even manages to find a chuckle when I remind him that Amazon's shares were trading for twice as much at the end of 1999 as they are now.

Bezos is on a short trip to London to speak at the Digital World conference and, in many respects, his visit couldn't have come at a more opportune time.

The unbounded optimism surrounding the e-commerce industry that was so prevalent at the start of the year has now evaporated. And in some quarters Bezos' trip is seen as not just a short stopover for a leading businessman, but the arrival of the US Cavalry.

Although it's clear that he has no truck with any notions of being perceived as the elder spokesperson of the e-commerce industry, he's quite happy to rally the troops. "I am very confident about the future of e-commerce and especially Amazon," he exclaims. "E-commerce is going to be a much bigger deal than people expected, even at the peak of the optimism in 1999."

Quizzed about the current pessimism of the markets, and although he doesn't name names, Bezos has sharp words for some of his rival e-commerce ventures.

"It's clear now that there were certain companies that were over-hyped. They were focusing not on building a great business but on building stock, that never works.

"I think now US investors are more discriminating - they are looking more closely on how a business is likely to develop rather than how its stocks will fare."

I wondered what Bezos thought of the UK's own e-commerce industry and in particular its flagship, Lastminute.com, but he's keeping his opinions to himself. "If you say positive things about other websites they use it against you, while saying nasty things just isn't very nice."

Predictably Bezos moves the conversation back to his own British website Amazon.co.uk. "You know we have the biggest website in the UK don't you! Well do you know who our biggest competitor is?"

Before I have time to answer he's informed me that "Amazon.co.uk's biggest rival is none other than its US parent site Amazon.com" - cue the morning's heartiest chuckle so far.

Bezos has, in the past, been portrayed as a bit of a nerd with a passion for books and sleep. He certainly has a quirky side to his personality. Until the recent birth of his first child he lived in a small two-bedroom apartment in Seattle. He's also notorious in America for being the boss who encourages his employees to make their own desks. And yes he's famous for insisting that he gets eight hours sleep a night.

However, anyone expecting Amazon's CEO to be a hippiesque Ben and Jerry style businessman is way off the mark.

Strip away Bezos' comfortable shoes and casual shirt and you'll uncover a surprisingly old school entrepreneur clearly driven by a desire to make money.

Asked what advice he would give to college graduates keen to start their own e-business, he answers with a statement that seems completely at odds with the get-rich quick schemes that prevail in the UK's own Silicon Alley in Brick Lane, east London.

"I'd say to anyone who wants to run a successful e-commerce company - go out and get an education. Spend 5-10 years in a decent company and learn using someone else's dollars - only then will you be ready to go for it on you own."

And while he admits to being "completely passionate about books", Bezos argues that when setting up Amazon he chose his product category systematically.

"I had a list of around 10 products that I thought Amazon could sell. I chose books as there are so many different types of books available. I thought I would have an advantage over bookshops purely by the range of books I was able to offer. If it made sense to sell kayaks rather than books I would have sold kayaks."

Ironically, kayaks could soon be on the Amazon agenda. Although perceived largely as a book e-tailer in the UK, Amazon.co.uk mirrors its US counterpart in also offering CDs, DVDs and videos.

At the end of last year it added the Z stores to its portfolio offering Britons cheap cut-price deals on electronic hardware, toys and kitchen appliances. Bezos dreams of turning Amazon into the world's largest electronic shopping mall with a massive range of virtual shops selling everything from gadgets to dishwashers. In the US, the Amazon website regularly ships enormous TVs and massive tool kits - and, in spite of my cynicism, Bezos can't see any reason why he can't repeat that formula here.

"When people buy an enormous TV they don't just put it in the car at the shop and drive home, it has to be delivered. So I can't see why Britons won't buy large items from Amazon," he says. Very soon Amazon will move into same-day delivery of books and possibly other items in the UK. It has experiments up and running in London and hopes to expand the service to most major UK conurbations within a year. Bezos is a firm believer in the right of people in central locations to be able to order and receive smaller packages within two hours.

Of course, delivery costs will be a little more than a couple of his beloved Royal Mail stamps (he loves our postal service), but Bezos is confident that whether it be financial analysts requiring books for research, or simply forgetful businessmen ordering a last minute anniversary present for their wives, Britons will pay.

It's ironic that it's his consumers' insatiable demand for instant access to his products that could pose the biggest threat to Bezos's business.

In the future, online delivery of music via MP3 or video via broadband services could seriously eat into Amazon's future profit-margin. Then there's the growth of downloading books into personal organiser devices like the Palm.

Bezos doesn't seem overly concerned. His strategy involves embracing new technology - Amazon is one of the key players in the book download sector - while continuing with core businesses. Or as he puts it: "I'd like to see the day when they can email big power tools!" Another key element of Amazon's UK strategy centres around Wap phones. Bezos is no stranger to Wap phones and, while he fingers my model, admits to being a little jealous of the "fantastic phones you have in the UK which are far superior to the US ones".

Amazon was in on the Wap revolution from day one and is available on most internet phone services. Bezos believes that service will come into its own when phones are delivered with large screens.

He is also excited by the opportunities afforded by interactive TV.

"I see interactive TV as delivering to Amazon to the kind of customers who'd never buy a PC," he explains. "The key, though, is to offer the consumer what they want: full internet access. I have no time for these limited walled garden systems."

With Bezos about to tuck into his breakfast (he goes to work on an egg), I fired the two questions that I'd been itching to ask him from the start of the interview.

If you had to recommend one book to all Amazon's customers, what would it be?

Without hesitation Bezos names Kazuo Ishiguro's Remains Of The Day and seems genuinely disappointed when I reveal I haven't read it but have only seen the film. "Go back home and order a copy," he instructs. "You can get it from Amazon.co.uk!" Once again Bezos explodes into fits of laughter.

Finally I wondered if Bezos has any plans to do something special on the day Amazon finally makes a profit?

For a second the CEO of the world's biggest on-line retailer looks bemused. It's clearly something he's never really thought about, which does worry me slightly.

Just as I'm about to suggest that I think the big day should be celebrated by illuminating Seattle's famous Space Needle building, he gets called away. I'm gutted, because I reckon that line would have kept him chuckling all the way home.

fields.headline: Double Agent
fields.trailText: Eddie Barlow's Headingley hat-trick had an orthodox beginning - Alan Knott and Chris Old bowled - but an unusual end. Don Wilson's bat-pad lobbed straight to silly point, but the fielder there didn't look quite as excited as the others - because he was England's 12th man, Mike Denness.
fields.body:
Eddie Barlow's Headingley hat-trick had an orthodox beginning - Alan Knott and Chris Old bowled - but an unusual end. Don Wilson's bat-pad lobbed straight to silly point, but the fielder there didn't look quite as excited as the others - because he was England's 12th man, Mike Denness.

"They had two injuries - Barry Richards and Rohan Kanhai - and only one substitute, so when the second one happened there wasn't much choice but to send me out," remembers Denness, who had played in the first match of the series but then lost his place.

"Don Wilson got a big nick, and it was so obvious that I don't think I even appealed. The picture just shows me standing there. Don just looked at me and walked straight off. It was a bit embarrassing, and I didn't think I should celebrate too much, but I don't think the England team held it against me!"

Denness, who went on to captain England four years later, found himself in rarefied company during his unscheduled fielding stint. "I was at third slip for a while, alongside Garry Sobers and Eddie Barlow. England were going along nicely at about 200 for 4 - Keith Fletcher and Ray Illingworth had put on a few - and Garry and Eddie were wondering who should bowl with the new ball. Eddie said 'Well, we've got to make something happen - I suppose I'd better come on!' So on he came, and promptly took a hat-trick. England lost six quick wickets, and the Rest of the World ended up winning again."

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: Pressure on Byers to block ITV merger

fields.headline: Pressure on Byers to block ITV merger
fields.standfirst: Carlton-United deal a north-south issue, say MPs
fields.trailText: The industry secretary, Stephen Byers, is coming under severe pressure from northern Labour MPs to block the proposed merger of Carlton and United media groups.
fields.body:
The industry secretary, Stephen Byers, is coming under severe pressure from northern Labour MPs to block the proposed merger of Carlton and United media groups.

The MPs are warning that a southern television giant wil undermine an independent media presence in the north as well as destroying thousands of jobs.

The competition commission is expected to give a conditional go-ahead to the merger when its private report lands on Mr Byers's desk tomorrow.

The £8.3bn deal would create a dominant ITV player stretching across six TV franchises, ranging from Nottingham to Cornwall.

Most ministers and officials accept the need for consolidation in ITV. But the new political pressure suggests Mr Byers now knows that allowing one company to own all the rich southern franchises would prompt a big backbench reaction.

Granada has opposed the merger by mounting a largely tactical counter-bid to buy Carlton.

Three northern Labour MPs have tabled oral questions for Mr Byers to answer in the Commons today, demanding he protect Granada.

One of the MPs, Philip Woolas, for Oldham East and Saddleworth, said: "If the merger goes ahead, the four richest franchises - Central and Carlton, owned by Carlton, and Meridian and Anglia, owned by United - will fall under one company, giving the merged company an effective stranglehold on advertising placement. This is becoming a big north-south issue. It will have a big impact on the production base of Granada, Yorkshire and Tyne Tees."

An independent report prepared by Manchester Business School estimates that the merger could threaten as many as 5,000 jobs in Granada. The company boosts the north-west economy by £188m a year.

Mr Byers, a Tyneside MP, has about six weeks to decide on whether to accept the competition commission report, or to set strict conditions.

Northern MPs do not want the single independent company to go ahead until a new legislative framework is established.

Existing rules restrict any company to 15% of the total TV audience, and restrict the share of all TV advertising by any one owner to 25%. A Carlton-United merger appears certain to break the rules.

This means that the competition commission could recommend lifting the 25% limit to something like 30%.

Alternatively, the commission could recommend limiting the number of wealthy southern licences that any one ITV company is allowed to own.

fields.headline: NHS to use private hospitals
fields.trailText: Private hospitals will treat NHS patients when there is no space available on local wards, health secretary Alan Milburn said today. The NHS will rent operating theatres and beds from private hospitals to ensure waiting lists and times are kept down even during problem periods in winter when demands on the health service rise.
fields.body:
Private hospitals will treat NHS patients when there is no space available on local wards, health secretary Alan Milburn said today. The NHS will rent operating theatres and beds from private hospitals to ensure waiting lists and times are kept down even during problem periods in winter when demands on the health service rise.

A concordat between the health service and the private sector will form a central plank in the government's national plan for the NHS, due to be unveiled in a few weeks. The NHS will provide all the surgeons, nurses and anaesthetists needed for operations and care will still be free for patients at the point of delivery. "This seems to me a sensible thing to do, to allow NHS patients to get the timely care that they need," Mr Milburn said.

Doctors' leaders and the private sector welcomed the announcement, which comes after months of negotiations between department of health officials and the independent healthcare association.

Dr Mac Armstrong, secretary of the British Medical Association said: "We have always called for the health service to use all available facilities."

But the Conservatives accused the government of hypocrisy and claimed public spending on private healthcare had doubled since Labour came to power.

The plan may anger some Labour backbenchers and health professionals who feel the founding principles of the NHS are under threat.

John Austin, a Labour member of the Commons health select committee, said he had grave reservations about the scheme.

When a similar plan to use state money to pay for residential care for the elderly in the private sector was introduced by the previous Conservative government, a host of homes sprang up, offering "inferior" care to residents, he said. "My real fear is that once the state starts waving its cheque-book about, the private sector is there to grab the money It is a fundamental Rubicon that one should be very wary of crossing. It is a question of how you get back."

fields.headline: The passion killer
fields.standfirst:
Jonathan Romney meets Michel Houellebecq, the novelist who has enraged all of France

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: The mark of a true controversialist may be the ability to lean back, fag in mouth, and shrug that there's nothing that controversial about controversy. Novelist and poet Michel Houellebecq has been hailed as France's biggest literary discovery - and source of scandal - since Camus.
fields.body:
The mark of a true controversialist may be the ability to lean back, fag in mouth, and shrug that there's nothing that controversial about controversy. Novelist and poet Michel Houellebecq has been hailed as France's biggest literary discovery - and source of scandal - since Camus. Not only has he sold some 300,000 copies of his second novel, Les Particulaires Elémentaires (now translated as Atomised); he has been attacked for it by both right and left, Catholics and communists, natural enemies and erstwhile allies.

It's no big deal, he says. "Polemical debates happen all the time in France. This was quite a big one, but any attentive reader of the French press gets bored if there isn't one every three months - it's part of the national character. I get bored with it."

It is precisely because of Houellebecq's assault on the national character that his readers hold him in such reverence - or such contempt. Atomised is an ambitious dissection of the modern French social psyche that traces its malaises to the supposed annus mirabilis , 1968. Countless French fictions complain about that year's radical dreams going awry, but Houellebecq goes so far as to identify soixante-huitisme as the beginning of the end for French society.

In Atomised, cherished ideals of left and right alike go to the wall - sexual self-fulfilment, New Age spiritualism, even such unimpeachable liberal concepts as "human dignity" and "progress". Houellebecq's compelling and often vengeful saga of modern France, enacted in the grievously disappointing lives of two half-brothers, is flavoured with a misanthropy not seen in French literature since Céline.

The Flaubertian lucidity of Houellebecq's writing persuades you that he's something more than a venomous wind-up artist, or worse, a sort of literary Bernard Manning. Slight, shabby and 41, he hardly looks a typical French-lit cult hero. The only thing he has in common with Albert Camus is his chain-smoking. He distractedly tweaks his stringy, combed-over hair and ums and ahs barely audibly. Presumably young French readers have tired of flashy nouveaux philosophes in open-neck shirts, and decided to try a diffident poète maudit of the old school.

Quite apart from what Houellebecq's novels say is the way they say it: a strange, fluid blend of thinly disguised autobiography, sweeping sociological tableau and hard scientific treatise. There's nothing new about this approach, he insists. "Balzac never hesitated to launch into his theories halfway through a book. The great advantage of a novel is you can put in whatever comes into your head - it has the same shape as the human brain."

Houellebecq's approach is justified by the fact that he deals not so much with characters as with "symptomatic individuals" who represent their age. If human relations are breaking down, as he suggests in his first novel, Extension du Domaine de la Lutte (translated as Whatever), then the old tales of stormy passion are no longer possible: "We're a long way from Wuthering Heights."

In fact, Houellebecq insists, he's a long way from most novels' concerns. "I describe what happens to normal people - people whom nothing special happens to." His characters either drift robotically through mind-numbing day jobs, obsessively pursue sexual thrills, or live lives of depressive monotony, such as Michel, the scientist in Atomised, who nevertheless makes a discovery that changes the world. "Active people don't change the world profoundly; ideas do," Houellebecq says. "Napoleon is less important in world history than Jean-Jacques Rousseau."

There's a certain bitter facility in Houellebecq's satirising of bureaucracy and New Ageism alike, but where his books really hurt for many French readers is in the way they present sex as a constant source of sorrow, disappointment, even madness. But, he points out, "Not looking for sexual satisfaction doesn't lead to a much better situation, either. People don't like the basic statement that not everyone succeeds in finding sexual satisfaction. It seems a very banal proposition to me, but that's what shocks people - the picture of losers in the sexual competition."

That is not all that shocks, however. The opinions that Houellebecq airs, either through his characters or his narrative voice, often suggest, at the very least, borderline-paranoid right-wing contempt for feminism, sexual freedom and youth culture. One character even tries writing virulent racist literature, although he eventually decides it's just a silly phase he's going through. Houellebecq has been attacked as a reactionary, and Atomised got him thrown off the editorial board of the left-wing revue Perpendiculaires.

He's no reactionary, he insists, although there's a touch of sophistry to his defence. "A reactionary is someone who wants to return to a previous state - that's never a possibility in my books. For me, everything's irreversible in the life of a society, as well as an individual's."

Reputedly a former Marxist, Houellebecq claims he never really was one, and that these days he has no political position at all. "I don't think politics is that important. Belief systems and technological revolutions are important, but I don't think political decisions have the slightest effect on events."

Both on and off the page, Houellebecq likes to offer such dry provocations, as if daring you to guess whether he really has any hard opinions at all. "Any groups with a strong ideology - communists or Catholics - will be split for and against me. That's only normal. You couldn't agree ideologically with the whole of Atomised." So is he just a compulsive position-shifter, out to baffle and antagonise every possible camp? "No, I'd much rather everyone agreed with me. But it's not up to me to make a step towards others - it's up to everyone else to come closer to me."

If Houellebecq is often confused with his characters, it is partly because their biographies overlap. Born on the isle of Réunion, Houellebecq, like the brothers in Atomised, was the son of parents who pursued the hippy dream in the 60s and left him with his grandparents. The prodigal mother in Atomised appears to be based on his own; when I ask if there's an element of revenge in the novel, he mutters a terse "Yes. Definitely". Like the hero of Whatever, he worked in computer admin, and suffered the stultifying effects of French office life. "It's not just deep boredom. Along with the boredom, you're obliged to feign enthusiasm. That's what's really painful."

Like more than one of his characters, he had several depressive spells in mental hospital, although, he claims, "I mainly went to the psychiatrist to get time off work. The problem is, the people in the hospitals are so much more interesting that sometimes you don't want to come out again. Those places suit me rather well - they're not stressful, and you can smoke as much as you like."

Houellebecq's pose of cantankerous intolerance has made him an unlikely pop-culture star. He recently released a CD, Présence Humaine, on which he intones his poems Gainsbourg-style over Lou Reed-esque backing tracks. A film of Extension du Domaine de la Lutte was also released last year. Although it bombed in France (too close to the book, some complained), it is more than respectable, and features the unnerving sight of director Philippe Harel in the lead, doing a spot-on imitation of Houellebecq, nicotine fingers and all.

Houellebecq packed in his computer job two years ago. He now lives in Dublin, and travels to Lanzarote (the setting of his next book) and Thailand (the one after that). He has also remarried, which suggests he is not entirely despondent about the possibility of love. He shrugs. "Given a person's past, it's usually bound to end badly, but sometimes it can go right."

For a seemingly retiring misanthrope, this born-again rock-star ranter seems to have taken to fame with remarkable aplomb. "I don't suffer attacks of excessive modesty," he says. He admits that he has been affected by the stress of his new life. "I'm more impatient. Before, I was calm to the point of apathy." So can his fans be reassured that his outlook hasn't been exactly sweetened by success? "I don't really feel pessimistic," he says. "Just realistic."

Atomised is published by Heinemann, price £12.99. The CD Présence Humaine is on the Tricatel label. The film Whatever is released in the UK on September 1.

fields.standfirst: Our MotD hell; Oliver Bierhoff's rock experience; Vladimir Smicer's secret laboratory, and more
fields.trailText: Our MotD hell; Oliver Bierhoff's rock experience; Vladimir Smicer's secret laboratory, and more
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM OUR SPONSOR

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com. It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"I am disappointed. There are a lot of people in football who are deeply disappointed. I know a lot of chairmen will be sitting at home saying 'what have we done?"' And not rubbing their hands saying: "How much have we made?". BBC Director General Greg Dyke on the loss of Premiership highlight rights to ITV.

THE EURO-TORIAL

When we switched on the telly last night to find Gary Lineker a paler shade of white, we thought he was simply perturbed at the thought of conversing with Johan Cruyff and his unique brand of English. But it wasn't the Dutch legend who shivered Gary to the core, nor the prospect of Barry Davies confusing Francesco Totti with Francesco Toldo again. No, the BBC's anchor was pallid because he'll be out of a job in a year.

The imminent demise of Match of the Day after ITV outbid the BBC for the rights to Premiership highlights by £20m a year is not really related to the progress of Euro 2000. Although it would be fun to see Gary and Alan chain themselves to their moodily-lit desk and sing protest songs throughout the Germany game. But the loss of the BBC's flagship sports programme means the end of an era in football broadcasting and the way the game is covered is likely to change forever.

However much money ITV may throw at pinching presenters from the BBC - Des, Bob Wilson, Terry Venables, Ally McCoist - they are never the same amidst the adverts or the deliberately lightweight approach to coverage ("Just how important is David Beckham to England Ally?"). And, as far as Sky is concerned, it is probably better if we didn't dwell for too long on the in-house promotions scheme that passes for their sports coverage.

The simple fact of the matter is that, even during this current tournament, the BBC is the only place to offer thoughtful football coverage, and still the only station that will admit a game is bad (or, as in the case of the Germany Romania game, positively revel in it). From August 2001 there will be no more of that, and lots more of Gary Newbon. It's a national disaster.

SO, FAREWELL THEN (how the papers view the Beeb's loss)

"A national institution has been lost and everyone is gutted. Everybody was told it was a 99 per cent certainty that we would keep Match of the Day." Alan Hansen in the Daily Express.

"I thought the BBC would think whatever happened in the world, they'd find enough money to keep Match of the Day. Even if they had to abandon a few dramas... no, make that ALL of their dramas.' Des Lynam offers unbiased analysis in the Mirror.

"This is exactly why the BBC's new boss, Greg Dyke deserves praise. He decided not to spend a fortune of YOUR money keeping Match of the Day at the Beeb. He put in a low bid and must have known ITV would top it. This was a brave decision by a good man." The Sun offers distinctly faint praise to the BBC's director general.

"So, farewell Match of the Day. Possibly the six most distressing words I have ever had to write." Brian Viner, the Independent.

"Our Match of the Days are numbered and Saturdays will never be the same again." Paul Kelso, the Guardian.

"It is the sign of a department curling up its toes and preparing to shuffle into oblivion. Here lies BBC Sport.' Martin Samuel in the Daily Express

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM BREATHE.COM

Euro 2000. Big screen sport action. In a pub. With your mates. And £200 behind the bar. perfect. Win a £200 bar tab for Euro 2000 at www.breathe.com

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

Oliver Bierhoff will miss the crucial match between Germany and England on Saturday after sustaining a calf injury in training. "I was standing when I felt a knock on my calf," he said. "It was like I was hit by a stone." The stone immediately distanced himself from the incident. "Hit him? I don't know what he's talking about, I was sitting on the floor" the inanimate object said. "He's a liar that Bierhoff and you can tell anyone I said that."

The FA will call an emergency meeting if England draw Turkey in the quarter-finals of Euro 2000. The English and Turkish footballing authorities have already had preliminary discussions on how to avoid trouble between rival supporters. The most viable plan suggested so far is that neither side qualifies for the quarters and both go home instead.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Heh heh. Mmmm. Hallo my pretty ones, it is I, skinny Vladimir Smicer. I have put Karel Poborsky in a cage. Would you like some bread Karel? Well you can't have any. Not until I have finished my experiments.

Now while I power up my generator I will take the time to tell you today's transfer tales. Heh heh.

HUMMMMMMMMMMM

Liverpool want to bring Dutch wing-back Boudewijn Zenden to Anfield. The Barcelona man could be one of many Dutchmen to leave the club this summer and would cost Gerard Houllier £6m.

Aston Villa are set to sign former French international David Ginola for £3m. According to this morning's papers Villa boss John Gregory has been given permission to talk to the player by Spurs chairman Alan Sugar.

HUMMMMMMMMMMM

That is all. I must go now, as I have work to do. Heh heh.

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

BBC 1: A Question of Sport Special (7pm) 'Special' in the sense that Chris Evans is on it.

ITV: Euro 2000 Live (7.30pm) Sweden v Turkey. Hmmm, tasty.

BBC 1: MoTD@Euro 2000 (12am) But if you miss it there's always the highlights show.

BBC 1: Euro 2000 Replay Sweden v Turkey (12.45) Or the full match, which is on straight after. Do you think the Beeb are trying to show as much football before

ITV: Euro 2000: the Big Match (2.35am) Sideshow Bob takes over. But will he still be up at this ungodly hour? Of course he will - the man's a professional.

Radio 5 Live: Football: (7pm) Better get used to this. Does Alan Hansen do radio?

fields.headline: We won't read your emails
fields.trailText: The regulation of investigatory powers bill continues to be branded as a "massive extension of the state's power to spy on citizens" (Leader, June 12). This bill does not introduce new powers. It does, however, update the law enforcement agencies existing and highly regulated powers to fight organised criminals exploiting developing communications technology. A warrant, signed by the home secretary, will be needed to monitor emails in the same way one is needed now to monitor communications.
fields.body:
The regulation of investigatory powers bill continues to be branded as a "massive extension of the state's power to spy on citizens" (Leader, June 12). This bill does not introduce new powers. It does, however, update the law enforcement agencies existing and highly regulated powers to fight organised criminals exploiting developing communications technology. A warrant, signed by the home secretary, will be needed to monitor emails in the same way one is needed now to monitor communications.

Conspiracy theorists must not be allowed to get away with the ridiculous notion that law enforcement would or even could monitor all emails. The intelligence agencies have neither the inclination nor the resources, nor the legal ability to monitor the massive amounts of electronic communications that flow through the UK every day. It does not happen with letters or telephones and it will not with emails.

The bill will increase accountability in accordance with the European Conven tion of Human Rights and the principles underpinning our own judicial procedures. Organised criminals, not the law enforcement agencies, infringe civil liberties - the civil liberties of victims of crime.

John Abbott

Director general, National Criminal Intelligence Service

Your leader could do far more to drive e-commerce overseas than you allege the regulation of investigatory powers (RIP) bill would. Its conclusions are based on myths pedalled by those who know they are untrue but believe in a world where criminals do not use the internet.

RIP does not usher in an era of unfettered mass surveillance. It ensures that vital law enforcement powers such as interception - which are not new - are more comprehensively regulated than before.

Not all Internet Service Providers (ISPs) in the UK will be asked to provide an intercept capability. This requirement applies to all telephone companies now and only a small number have a standing capability. Similarly, only a small proportion of ISPs may be required to have such a capability in the future. We want a level playing field across the communications industry and we're examining closely the question of costs. Parliament will have a closer look at our detailed intentions in scrutinising the secondary legislation under this bill.

On encryption keys, we expect the disclosure of plain text to be sufficient in most cases. This is especially true of legitimate businesses. But in the event that key confidentiality is breached, an individual may sue, as you would expect. The bill does not threaten e-commerce in the UK - we are ensuring that UK cyberspace provides the best and the safest environment in which to conduct e-commerce.

You call for "citizens' safeguards" to be built into the legislation - they are, and this is what RIP is all about. You ask if we pledge to make the UK the best environment for e-commerce - we have, and this bill will ensure UK cyberspace is also the safest.

Charles Clarke MP

Minister of state, Home Office

You call for "citizens' safeguards" to be built into the legislation - they are, and this is what RIP is all about. You ask if we pledge to make the UK the best environment for e-commerce - we have, and this bill will ensure UK cyberspace is also the safest. Charles Clarke MP Minister of state, Home Office

fields.headline: £120,000 for unfair dismissal
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A deputy headteacher who was unfairly sacked by a local education authority after being falsely accused of trying to trick school governors into giving her a pay rise has been awarded more than £120,000 in an out of court settlement.
fields.body:
A deputy headteacher who was unfairly sacked by a local education authority after being falsely accused of trying to trick school governors into giving her a pay rise has been awarded more than £120,000 in an out of court settlement.

But Cherryll Pepper said that at 53 her career and reputation had been "tainted" by the allegations which meant she would never work again as a head or a deputy.

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers -which supported Mrs Pepper in the action - welcomed the outcome of the "ground-breaking case".

Mrs Pepper accepted the damages from insurers acting for Berkshire county council, after it admitted negligence in allowing her to be sacked.

Mrs Pepper, who started teaching in 1968, was suspended as deputy head of Montem county first school, Slough, in February 1996, after being accused of gross misconduct.

She was alleged to have misled the school's governing body by persuading its finance committee into recommending a pay rise for her. She was sacked in October 1996. She now works as an infant school manager in Southall, Middlesex.

webTitle: How the British lag behind in reading, but lead the world at watching TV

fields.headline: How the British lag behind in reading, but lead the world at watching TV
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Britain has more television addicts than many other countries in the developed world, but is lagging badly behind in advanced literacy - and these two facts are related, according to a new report yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain has more television addicts than many other countries in the developed world, but is lagging badly behind in advanced literacy - and these two facts are related, according to a new report yesterday.

Both trends are disclosed in a study by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, the first to apply common measurements of advanced literacy - defined as ability to cope with written material in the information age - to 20 countries. It found that:

 Britain scores well into the bottom half in the three most crucial yardsticks of literacy. It ranks lower in literacy than England does in football: the England team was 12th in the world before Euro 2000. Britain is behind economic competitors including Germany, the US, Australia, Canada, the main Nordic countries and much of the rest of Europe.

 Britain has the fourth highest level of unemployment among people with the poorest modern literacy skills - those unable to understand dosage instructions on a packet of medicine.

 Britain easily tops the list for citizens who watch TV for more than two hours a day. Six people in 10 do this, 2% more than in the next most telly-addicted country, New Zealand, a third more than in Denmark, Norway and Portugal, and nearly twice as many as in Switzerland.

The link between high TV-watching and low literacy was clear yesterday to Patrick Werquin, the senior OECD official in charge of the report. "Watching a lot of television goes against literacy," he said, "If you are watching TV, you are not reading books.

"I know that you British read a lot of newspapers, which helps to counterbalance it. But if I was Tony Blair, I would say that you have to work at your school system, to make sure people really benefit from it. And I would ask your television people to produce better, more literate TV."

Speaking from OECD headquarters in Paris, Mr Werquin said he thought part of the reason why people in Nordic countries seemed less damaged by their moderately high TV-watching habits was that all their foreign films were sub-titled rather than dubbed.

According to figures, the British are now more avid viewers than Chileans or Slovenians, two of the less developed and least literate countries in the sample.

The report is the climax of the organisation's international adult literacy survey, which began with a smaller sample of countries in the early 1990s. The survey collected standardised data from each country and used the same techniques to measure it, to try to ensure that results were comparable.

Countries in the final survey range from the Czech republic, Ireland and Hungary to Slovenia and Flemish-speaking Belgium. The authors define modern literacy not as ability to read and write but as "whether a person is able to understand and employ printed information in daily life, at home, at work and in the community".

It set five levels of literacy:

1. People with very poor skills.

2. People who can deal only with simple material.

3. Roughly the skill level required for successful secondary school completion and college entry.

4 and 5. People who demonstrate command of "higher-order information-processing skills".

Then it tested three kinds of literacy ability to cope with prose, documents and quantity. Britain's worst showing was in quantitative literacy, coming 16th out of 22 - some countries like Switzerland were split into different language-speaking regions.

Britain did fairly well at the highest level of quantitative literacy but had more citizens than some other countries in the "can only cope with simple material" category.

The only nations which did worse were Hungary, Ireland, Slovenia, Poland, Portugal and Chile. Germany came fifth, behind Sweden, Denmark, Norway and the Czech republic.

Britain's second worst performance was 15th out of 22 at document literacy. Again the three main Nordic countries were top, followed by the Netherlands, Finland, Belgium (Flanders), Germany, the Czech republic, Canada, Australia, Switzerland (French), Switzerland (German), Switzerland (Italian) and the US. Trailing Britain were New Zealand, Ireland, Hungary, Slovenia, Poland, Portugal and Chile.

Britain's highest place, as the country of William Hazlitt and George Orwell, was in prose literacy, where it came 13th, ahead of Ireland, the Czech republic, Switzerland (Italian and German), Hungary, Slovenia, Portugal, Poland and Chile. It was behind, again, the main Nordic countries, the Netherlands, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, the US, Belgium (Flanders), Germany and Switzerland (French).

In all three measures of literacy, Britain did well in the top bands of "higher-order skills" but was betrayed by high numbers among the less skilled.

It was also 13th in the league table of people who say they read a book at least once a month. It scored 60%, compared with 65% in the two leading countries, New Zealand and the Czech republic. Ireland, though low-scoring elsewhere in the survey, was equal third with Germany among book readers.

The nations which read fewer books than the British were the Netherlands. Poland, Slovenia, Norway, Chile, Belgium (Flanders) and Portugal (with about 22%).

Britain's highest place in the 205-page study came in a table of countries with steep unemployment rates among people with very poor literacy skills. It was fourth, beaten in its number of unemployed in this category only by Ireland, Finland and Belgium (Flanders). Countries with lowest proportions of unskilled unemployed were Switzerland, Norway, the US and the Czech republic.

Overall, Britain's performance put it among 14 countries where "at least 15% of adults have literacy skills at only the most rudimentary level - making it difficult for them to cope with the rising skill demands of the information age", the report said.

The minority of six countries with fewer than 15% in this category were Denmark, Finland, Germany, Netherlands, Norway and Sweden. But even in Sweden, the best scorer with only 8%, there was "a severe literacy deficit in everyday life and work".

Literacy in the Age of Information, Final Report, OECD, Paris 2000 ($31). Electronic version available in pdf format.

webTitle: Feature: Foreign artists pierce Britart bubble in 2000 shortlist

fields.headline: Foreign creativity pierces Britart bubble
fields.standfirst: International composition and working background of shortlist suggests fascination with young British artists could have waned
fields.trailText: International composition and working background of shortlist suggests fascination with young British artists could have waned
fields.body:
Rumour got it wrong for the 2000 Turner prize. No Martin Creed (the hottest tip), no return of Mark Wallinger, no bad girl Sarah Lucas.

The shortlist comes as a surprise. Painters Glenn Brown and Michael Raedecker, installation artist Tomoko Takahashi and photographer Wolfgang Tillmans make for the freshest line-up for years.

I like this list, not least because there has been too much focus on the Britishness of the YBA phenomenon, and altogether too much focus on personality in the way in which British art is discussed. Some artists have never fitted the easily packaged phenomenon, and their work does not fit the easy formula.

Britain, and particularly London, has been a great place to make art over the past decade, and the art world has seen waves of incoming artists from abroad, all but eclipsed in the public eye by the media fascination with the YBAs and the spurious promotion of Cool Britannia. It is over.

There are still questions and doubts: has Amsterdam-born Michael Raedecker, who won the first prize in last year's John Moores painting exhibition in Liverpool, really developed enough to be included?

Over and above the novel bits of sewing, the threads and woolly patches which disturb the surfaces of his otherwise somewhat reserved tonal paintings, his work seems to owe too much to Spanish painter, Miquel Barcelo, who also uses as lot of extraneous material along with paint, and to the psychological terrains of Peter Doig, a previous Turner nominee, rather than becoming thoroughly itself. He is bottom of my list.

Image homage

The second painter on the shortlist, Glen Brown, is best known for his flattened versions of the expressionist, painted-from-life figure paintings of Frank Auerbach. While Raedecker strives to attain originality, Brown questions the whole idea.

He has also appropriated images by Rembrandt and Fragonard. Auerbach's work is about a kind of existential, hard-won truth, while Brown's faithful copies render the older artist's thick oil paint as though it were a trompe-l'oeil reproduction.

He has also done the reverse - making sculpted, three dimensional heads based on Auerbach's images, as though made from super-thick oil paint. There is something deathly, oddly glistening, molten and intangible about Brown's paintings, which hover between the real and the reproduction. Auerbach is said to have found it odd that someone should spend so much time and effort duplicating his works.

The Salvador Dali Foundation, on the other hand, threatened to sue the artist when Brown showed a hyper-real version of Dali's painting the Great Masturbator at the Serpentine Gallery in London some years ago. Brown's work is concerned with the differences between the experience of actual art works - with all their physicality and lumps - and their widely disseminated reproductions. Too extreme to be merely academic, Brown's intelligent paintings are a strong second runner in this year's prize.

Chaos theory

Tomoko Takahashi's best known work is the huge, sprawling installation which filled part of the Saatchi Gallery in the New Neurotic Realism show last year. Busted photocopiers, ditched computers, old monitors, miles of electrical wiring, turntables and the detritus of the modern age filled the space. One had a sense of order and system in spite of the chaos.

Was the order to do with the original function of the objects, or was it sculptural? Did the spaghetti and trails of wiring have a purpose, or was it a kind of drawing?

Moving to Britain to escape the conservatism of Japanese society, Takahashi still relates her work to the ritual and order of the tea ceremony, as well as to the rampant consumerism of Japan. Hers is a complex relationship to technology, to consumerism, creativity and waste, which she treats as a kind of modern nature. But lots of artists have travelled this route before. A good third place.

German-born photographer Wolfgang Tillmans has the highest international profile of all the artists here. His images, casually pinned to the wall, range from snapshots of Concorde passing over his house, to large-format portraits sexy images, landscapes and still lives, flowers and pets .

Some images are highly autobiographical and personal, while an entire series, Soldiers (also on show in the British Art Show), is a display of media images of soldiers, represented by the artist as a kind of commentary on our ambivalent relationship to the armed forces.

The way he presents and juxtaposes his work is as important as the images themselves. It took me a long time to get into Tillmans's work - its apparent disregard of what makes a "good photograph". The more I see, the more the narrative unfolds, the more I realise he is dealing with shared experience.

Tillmans, I have little doubt, is the favourite for this year's Turner prize , and my favourite too.

fields.headline: Walsh cuts England  down
fields.standfirst:
The old warhorse sniffed the air at Edgbaston and found it still to his liking. Mike Selvey reports

England 179
West Indies 50 for 2
fields.trailText: After two sessions of torment, England clawed their way back into the first Test after tea yesterday but already it may not be enough to save them.
fields.body:
After two sessions of torment, England clawed their way back into the first Test after tea yesterday but already it may not be enough to save them.

Bowled out for 179 in overcast conditions exploited beautifully by the West Indian bowlers, England needed early wickets in the 19 overs remaining. They managed two, with Chris Gayle, the latest in a long line of openers in recent years, dropped by Andy Flintoff at fourth slip off Andy Caddick but then lbw to Darren Gough without scoring, and Wavell Hinds, suffering perhaps from a surfeit of confidence, striking two outrageous boundaries before driving Caddick head-high to Nasser Hussain at wide mid-off.

Significantly, though, Brian Lara was able to play untroubled through the final dozen overs and England needed his wicket above all. With the weather set fair today, he may make them pay.

For two decades batsmen facing West Indies bowling underwent trial by fire, a withering barrage delivered uncompromisingly at searing pace. But the preferred method of torture now is the death of a thousand cuts. For raw, sometimes wild pace, substitute old-fashioned virtues of relentless length and unwavering line delivered with the patience of a Tibetan monk. West Indies play a waiting game now in these conditions, challenging the opposition not to crack first.

Yesterday belonged to Courtney Walsh, 37 years young, who bowled unchanged through the first two-hour session as if he was taking his morning constitution, making early inroads into the England innings, and by the finish had taken his personal test-match tally to 454 wickets with figures of five for 36. England dietary experts should immediately investigate whatever cocktail of vitamins he must be taking to remain this skittish.

Nor was there any respite at the other end, where Curtly Ambrose dropped his first delivery bang on a length and scarcely deviated from that all day. His single wicket was scant reward for the quality of his performance.

The young pretenders Franklyn Rose and Reon King have learned their craft well from the old masters, losing composure only when the England tail was wagging.

England lost the toss. It can be a difficult decision here, as Hussain said on Wednesday, with early movement offset by uneven bounce later in the match, but any cloud cover was due yesterday with the weekend apparently set for a heatwave: bowling first had to be the option and Jimmy Adams duly took it.

For the best part of an hour, as Walsh trotted off some ring-rust (neither he nor Ambrose had bowled a competitive ball on the tour), Mike Atherton and Mark Ramprakash, declared fit, made slow but largely untroubled progress in hazy sunshine.

Then the cloud rolled in and the game changed. Ramprakash was the first to notice it, for having just hit Walsh sweetly to the long-on boundary he received three deliveries in the same over that cut back alarmingly and bounced over his middle stump.

In Walsh's next over, Ramprakash pushed forward and was caught at short leg and batting was never the same again.

Atherton, stuck on two for three-quarters of an hour as Ambrose pinned him down, gained some respite with the advent of King, hooking him hard, but then received a legcutter from Walsh which he touched to the wicketkeeper. Then, with lunch still half an hour off, Graeme Hick drove stiffly off the back foot and edged hard to third slip, with Sherwin Campbell at second diving to catch the rebound.

As tea approached, the heavy work had been completed, or so West Indies might have thought. Alec Stewart had been tucked up by Ambrose's movement into him and finally edged on to his stumps; Nasser Hussain, who has barely topped 100 runs in first-class cricket this season, received a snorter from Rose which flicked his glove; Nick Knight survived a nervy start to play as comfortably as anyone for his 26, sensibly looking for singles where others had become locked into survival, before hanging his bat tamely outside off stump; and Flintoff, after a couple of beefy blows, did likewise. Thus far in his career he is a big disappointment.

The revival, such as it was, was begun by Robert Croft, whose last test innings in England was his marathon match-saving effort against South Africa at Old Trafford two years ago. Some sensible counterpunching, including a top-notch back-foot cover drive, brought him four boundaries before he became Walsh's fifth victim. No dis grace here: the ball was a fast leg break.

Now came the best stand of the innings, with Andy Caddick digging in and Darren Gough at last displaying the flair that promised so much when he first burst on to the international scene.

Gough hit four boundaries, adding 39 for the ninth wicket before he was run out, by a whisker, as Ridley Jacobs hit the bowler's wicket with a direct throw. Not since he made a half-century against Australia in his seventh test has the Yorkshireman scored more than the 23 he made yesterday.

Caddick, who also hit four boundaries, was left unbeaten on 21 when Ed Giddins top-edged and was caught.

It can be a difficult decision here, as Hussain said on Wednesday, with early movement offset by uneven bounce later in the match, but any cloud cover was due yesterday with the weekend apparently set for a heatwave: bowling first had to be the option and Jimmy Adams duly took it. For the best part of an hour, as Walsh trotted off some ring-rust (neither he nor Ambrose had bowled a competitive ball on the tour), Mike Atherton and Mark Ramprakash, declared fit, made slow but largely untroubled progress in hazy sunshine. Then the cloud rolled in and the game changed. Ramprakash was the first to notice it, for having just hit Walsh sweetly to the long-on boundary he received three deliveries in the same over that cut back alarmingly and bounced over his middle stump. In Walsh's next over, Ramprakash pushed forward and was caught at short leg and batting was never the same again. Atherton, stuck on two for three-quarters of an hour as Ambrose pinned him down, gained some respite with the advent of King, hooking him hard, but then received a legcutter from Walsh which he touched to the wicketkeeper. Then, with lunch still half an hour off, Graeme Hick drove stiffly off the back foot and edged hard to third slip, with Sherwin Campbell at second diving to catch the rebound. As tea approached, the heavy work had been completed, or so West Indies might have thought. Alec Stewart had been tucked up by Ambrose's movement into him and finally edged on to his stumps; Nasser Hussain, who has barely topped 100 runs in first-class cricket this season, received a snorter from Rose which flicked his glove; Nick Knight survived a nervy start to play as comfortably as anyone for his 26, sensibly looking for singles where others had become locked into survival, before hanging his bat tamely outside off stump; and Flintoff, after a couple of beefy blows, did likewise. Thus far in his career he is a big disappointment. The revival, such as it was, was begun by Robert Croft, whose last test innings in England was his marathon match-saving effort against South Africa at Old Trafford two years ago. Some sensible counterpunching, including a top-notch back-foot cover drive, brought him four boundaries before he became Walsh's fifth victim. No dis grace here: the ball was a fast leg break. Now came the best stand of the innings, with Andy Caddick digging in and Darren Gough at last displaying the flair that promised so much when he first burst on to the international scene. Gough hit four boundaries, adding 39 for the ninth wicket before he was run out, by a whisker, as Ridley Jacobs hit the bowler's wicket with a direct throw. Not since he made a half-century against Australia in his seventh test has the Yorkshireman scored more than the 23 he made yesterday. Caddick, who also hit four boundaries, was left unbeaten on 21 when Ed Giddins top-edged and was caught. webTitle: Bye, bye Boo  Asset pick-up by WebTop

fields.headline: Bye, bye Boo  Asset pick-up by WebTop
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Net services company WebTop.com yesterday took possession of failed online clothes retailer, Boo.com's e-commerce technology assets.
fields.body:
Net services company WebTop.com yesterday took possession of failed online clothes retailer, Boo.com's e-commerce technology assets.

WebTop is a division of IT group Bright Stations, formerly Dialog, and is valued at £180m. It paid liquidator KPMG £250,000 for the Boo technology - being carried out by WebTop staff - following Boo's demise in May. It paid a further £1m for Boo's hardware to SunMicrosystems, which inherited the rights after liquidation.

WebTop.com produces a desktop tool which performs searches based on blocks of text rather than the single words offered by other search engines.

WebTop's chief executive, John Snyder, said of the Boo purchase: "Our service will be quicker, and ultimately, it means a faster time to market."

webTitle: Mugabe threat to seize British assets

fields.headline: Mugabe threat to seize British assets
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe yesterday threatened to seize the assets of British and other foreign mining companies in Zimbabwe as soon as he completes the confiscation of hundreds of white-owned farms.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe yesterday threatened to seize the assets of British and other foreign mining companies in Zimbabwe as soon as he completes the confiscation of hundreds of white-owned farms.

"After land, now we must look at the mining sector," he said in an interview 10 days before parliamentary elections.

Complaining that there are "too many Britons" in Zimbabwe, Mr Mugabe said: "There must be Africans in there as owners, not just as workers."

Mr Mugabe's threats to take control of mines and other British-owned companies put him in a league with the former Ugandan leader Idi Amin, who nationalised the assets of his country's Asian population in the 1970s.

Any such steps would increase the already serious breakdown of rule of law in Zimbabwe - and would worsen the country's already severe economic decline.

The property seizures would make Zimbabwe a pariah state, end all international assistance and hasten the country's economic collapse.

Zimbabwe already is suffering what has been dubbed "the world's fastest shrinking economy" with its GDP forecast to decline by 5% to 10% this year. The decline has given rise to widespread opposition, led by the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), to Mr Mugabe's government.

Mr Mugabe also vowed to force the early retirement of the country's white judges and confirmed that the Congolese president, Laurent Kabila, had offered his government the rights to a diamond mine for its involvement in the Congo war.

Mr Mugabe lambasted the British press for claiming that he had a Scottish mansion and was the world's second wealthiest person. Warning that he would not stop with the mines, he told the Independent that he would "Africanise" the rest of Zimbabwe's economy after his government took occupation of the country's mostly white-owned commercial farms, which earn 42% of the country's foreign currency.

"We want the struggle to continue in this socio-economic area, so that you can empower your people economically in the same way as you have empowered them politically," he said. "It requires the political struggle once again to be kindled and the people are better united.

"This is the phase that we're going through. After the coming elections that area will be addressed fully," he said, in a direct threat to the 400 British companies still in the country.

Despite the killings of 28 opposition supporters and the widespread beating, torture and rapes of thousands more by his Zanu-PF party, Mr Mugabe said parliamentary elections, scheduled for June 24-25, would be free and fair.

After Britain and the US voiced concern about voter intimidation, Mr Mugabe said: "I will be ready and willing to accept the outcome, whichever way it goes." But, he added that if the MDC leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, won, "then I will know for sure that we have been visited upon by the devil".

webTitle: Ethical dilemma in a race to map genes

fields.headline: Ethical dilemma in a race to map genes
fields.standfirst: The ethics of genetics: special report
fields.trailText: A wake-up call to the public and politicians was issued yesterday over the dramatic implications of the genetics revolution, as campaigners warned of a new era of inequality, discrimination and corporate control if our new knowledge of how humans work was not used with more care.
fields.body:
A wake-up call to the public and politicians was issued yesterday over the dramatic implications of the genetics revolution, as campaigners warned of a new era of inequality, discrimination and corporate control if our new knowledge of how humans work was not used with more care.

With scientists due to announce in less than a fortnight that they have completed the rough draft of the "book of life", the sequence of genes which builds, maintains and repairs human beings from scratch, there are fears that a rush to exploit the information could provoke the same kind of public backlash that has hit genetically modified foods.

Launching a new watchdog group, the Campaign Against Human Genetic Engineering (CAHGE), the independent geneticist David King said: "There is a widespread concern that genetics is running far ahead of society's ability to cope with these issues."

Dr King said CAHGE was not against genetics research or its possible medical benefits. But he said it was vital to rally public and political opposition to human cloning and human germline engineering (altering humans' inheritable characteristics) before they came within easy reach of science.

Society had to be alert to dangers of employment or financial discrimination against people genetically predisposed to disease, to pressure on women to have abortions with greater antenatal genetic screening, and to genetic explanations for social problems. "There's a large amount of work going on in behavioural genetics and that is beginning to influence mainstream policy formation."

Richard Nicholson, the editor of the Bulletin of Medical Ethics, said: "I regard the mapping of the human genome as an incredible achievement. But much like climbing Mount Everest or getting to the North Pole, it will be something of benefit to a few people and unlikely to benefit the vast majority of mankind.

"Medical research has become a very competitive field, where the priority of many of those involved is no longer to make discoveries for the general good of humanity or even for the sake of knowledge but career advancement and the needs of the shareholders of biotech and pharma companies."

Agnes Fletcher of the Royal Association for Disability and Rehabilitation warned of a subtle revival of eugenics - effectively a selective human breeding programme to weed out "undesirable" traits and promote "desirable" ones - such as that pursued by the Nazis.

"The promise is all about gene therapy and cures for difficult and often painful conditions. In fact, what seems to be is that the money will come from genetic testing and screening out, antenatally, a whole range of genetic characteristics."

webTitle: Martin murder jury may be quizzed on 'intimidation'

fields.headline: Martin murder jury may be quizzed on 'intimidation'
fields.trailText: The jurors who convicted the Norfolk farmer Tony Martin of murdering a teenage burglar could make legal history by being questioned in the court of appeal about allegations that they were intimidated.
fields.body:
The jurors who convicted the Norfolk farmer Tony Martin of murdering a teenage burglar could make legal history by being questioned in the court of appeal about allegations that they were intimidated.

Three judges, headed by Lord Justice Rose, the vice-president of the court's criminal division, are to hold a ground-breaking hearing in London on Monday to decide how far they can look into claims that jurors at the trial last April were menaced by stares from the public gallery.

The judges will decide "whether and in what terms" jurors can be quizzed when the farmer's appeal is heard later this year. Their decision could pave the way for jurors to give evidence for the first time in a criminal appeal.

One of Martin's five grounds of appeal is that a fair trial was not possible because of the "atmosphere of intimidation" faced by the jury and witnesses.

But legal precedents say that the appeal court cannot inquire into deliberations in the jury room. That suggests the jurors could not be questioned directly on whether their feelings influenced their verdicts.

In a 1962 case, the appeal court was told that jurors were poised to deliver a not guilty verdict when the foreman read out a list of the defendant's convictions and they changed their minds. The court refused to hear evidence about the alleged irregularity.

A note on the case in Blackstone's Criminal Practice says: "It may be thought that, if the allegation made by the appellant was true, it was monstrous that his conviction should have been upheld. The case thus demonstrates the absolute nature of the rule that the court of appeal will not, metaphorically speaking, enter the jury room."

In 1995, jurors in a double murder trial who were staying overnight at a hotel tried to contact one of the victims with a ouija board in a drunken experiment to try to find out whether the defendant, Stephen Young, was guilty. The appeal court decided it could look into the incident, since it happened outside the jury room, and quashed the conviction, ordering a retrial.

Those jurors were questioned by the Treasury solicitor with a policeman and gave their evidence in written statements. Martin's solicitor, Nick Makin, said he believed that would be the most likely course of action in Martin's case.

The farmer, 55, was jailed for life in April after jurors convicted him on a majority of 10-2 of murdering Fred Barras, 16, and wounding his accomplice, Brendon Fearon, 30. Martin opened fire on the pair with an unlicensed shotgun last August after disturbing them at his home, Bleak House, in Emneth Hungate, Norfolk.

A spokesman for the lord chancellor's department said: "The judges will consider whether and in what terms jurors can be questioned over the claims of intimidation. It is a very sensitive area.

"The judges will have to decide if the jurors are to be questioned and what form any questioning will take. One of the issues to be decided is whether they should be questioned in open court or if their anonymity should be kept by keeping them behind screens."

webTitle: 120 charged with mafia plot to infiltrate Wall St

fields.headline: 120 charged with mafia plot to infiltrate Wall St
fields.trailText: The American authorities charged 120 people yesterday in connection with what the FBI said was an attempt by the mafia to infiltrate Wall Street, complete with attempts to use hit men to commit murders.
fields.body:
The American authorities charged 120 people yesterday in connection with what the FBI said was an attempt by the mafia to infiltrate Wall Street, complete with attempts to use hit men to commit murders.

Along with suspected gangsters, those charged included brokers, lawyers, and a former policeman. The legal proceedings relate to a multi-million pound stock market fraud said to have been going on for five years.

The charges, resulting from what was described as the largest clampdown on securities fraud in US history, ranged from racketeering to solicitation to commit murder.

Those involved are accused to trying to manipulate 19 stocks and 16 private share placements. In some instances, it is alleged, chat rooms on the internet were used to hype stocks in hi-tech companies. The alleged crimes resulted in $50m (£33m) of losses.

"The greed and reach of this racketeering enterprise knew no bounds," said Mary Jo White, a member of the prosecution team at the US attorney's office in New York's southern district.

She said 98 of those facing charges had been arrested by lunchtime yesterday. Convictions could lead to sentences of between five and 80 years.

At the FBI's New York office, Barry Mawn described the alleged crimes as an attempt by five mafia families to infiltrate Wall Street, tempted by the dramatic rise in stock prices in recent months.

"No matter what market the mob tries to infiltrate, from the fish market to the stock market, the methods it uses are always the same: violence and the threat of violence," Mr Mawn said. Working together, the members of the five families are alleged to have tried to defraud pension funds by hyping stocks and then resorted to threats and intimidation.

Other charges included securities fraud, pension fund fraud, bribery of brokers and union officials, extortion, and money laundering.

"No kind of market professional, or kind of [share] offering or company or types of victims was excluded," said Ms White. The attempts to make money from the stock market knew "no bounds".

Members of all five families were charged, including Frank Persico, allegedly associated with the Colombo crime family and a stockbroker who controlled a number of stock broking firms.

A former New York detective who was involved in looking after a pension fund, investment advisers and lawyers were also charged, along with the head of a fast food chain.

Regulatory bodies on both sides of the Atlantic have been expressing concern about the potential abuse of internet chat rooms. In the present case, websites and emails to investors are said to have been used to to fraudulently hype stocks or to capitalise on the market's interest in the stock of dot.com companies.

"The lesson to be learned [from the current investigation] is that the price of quick and criminally earned profits in the stock market will be arrest and prosecution and jail," Ms White said.

"The message of these cases is that securities fraudsters or would-be securities fraudsters can and should expect law enforcement to be carefully watching, listening and infiltrating and aggressive investigation and prosecution of their crime."

webTitle: Former US colonel on spying charge

fields.headline: Former US colonel on spying charge
fields.trailText: Nearly a decade after the collapse of the Soviet Union, a retired army colonel yesterday became the highest ranking member of the US military to be charged with spying for the former USSR.
fields.body:
Nearly a decade after the collapse of the Soviet Union, a retired army colonel yesterday became the highest ranking member of the US military to be charged with spying for the former USSR.

George Trofimoff, 73, who served as a colonel in the US army reserves, was arrested at a hotel in Tampa, Florida, after meeting an FBI agent posing as a Russian operative delivering a payment.

He was charged with 32 acts of espionage on behalf of the Soviet Union and the Warsaw Pact over a 25-year period in which he had daily access to some of the most sensitive spying secrets of the cold war.

Mr Trofimoff, who was born in Germany to Russian parents and became a naturalised US citizen in 1951, spent 25 years as the US army's top civilian official at the Nuremberg joint interrogation centre in Germany. The post gave him continual access to the interrogation records of Soviet and east European refugees and defectors.

Federal prosecutor Donna Bucella said that Mr Trofimoff had been indicted by a Florida grand jury yesterday and remained in custody. "He is the highest rank United States military officer ever charged with espionage," she confirmed.

Mr Trofimoff was paid by the KGB for providing information to the Soviet Union, Ms Bucella said.

Frank Gallagher, the agent in charge of the FBI's Tampa office, said Mr Trofimoff was paid $250,000 (£160,000) over the course of his spying career.

He also received the Order of the Red Banner, a Soviet award presented for bravery and self-sacrifice in defence of the socialist homeland, prosecutors said.

The information revealed was more than enough to paint a picture of cold war intrigue fully worthy of a John Le Carré novel.

Mr Trofimoff was said to have been recruited to work for the KGB by a senior member of the Russian Orthodox church in the German speaking world.

His recruiter, named as Igor Vladimirovich Susemihl, also the son of Russian emigrants, was a lifetime friend who became an Orthodox priest in Bavaria and Austria.

With his help, Mr Trofimoff was said to have passed details of priceless cold war military and espionage secrets to Moscow.

The authorities allege the conspiracy lasted from 1969, when Mr Trofimoff became chief of the Nuremberg unit, to 1994, just before he retired.

Mr Trofimoff had access to "all classified information" in the unit, including detailed Soviet and Warsaw pact battle plans.

But the crown jewel was that he was able to give the Soviet Union a detailed briefing on the stories and secrets offered to the west by Russian emigres and defectors, in effect giving Moscow a secret window on US defence and counter-intelligence thinking.

Mr Trofimoff had recently worked bagging groceries at a supermarket, a department of justice official said. A hearing was due to take place yesterday.

His recruiter, named as Igor Vladimirovich Susemihl, also the son of Russian emigrants, was a lifetime friend who became an Orthodox priest in Bavaria and Austria. The authorities allege the conspiracy lasted from 1969, when Mr Trofimoff became chief of the Nuremberg unit, to 1994, just before he retired. Mr Trofimoff had access to "all classified information" in the unit, including detailed Soviet and Warsaw pact battle plans. But the crown jewel was that he was able to give the Soviet Union a detailed briefing on the stories and secrets offered to the west by Russian emigres and defectors, in effect giving Moscow a secret window on US defence and counter-intelligence thinking. Mr Trofimoff had recently worked bagging groceries at a supermarket, a department of justice official said. A hearing was due to take place yesterday.

webTitle: Hague bloodied by Tories' Eurosceptic white knight

fields.headline: Hague bloodied by Tories' Eurosceptic white knight
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague suffered an embarrassing blow yesterday when Paul Sykes, the multi-millionaire Eurosceptic who is to bankroll the Conservatives' Keep the Pound campaign, defied party policy to demand a referendum on British withdrawal from the EU.
fields.body:
William Hague suffered an embarrassing blow yesterday when Paul Sykes, the multi-millionaire Eurosceptic who is to bankroll the Conservatives' Keep the Pound campaign, defied party policy to demand a referendum on British withdrawal from the EU.

Within hours of his announcement that he is to rejoin the Tory fold, Mr Sykes placed himself at odds with the party leadership by launching his assault on Britain's EU membership.

Pro-European Tories said Mr Hague would consign the party to years in opposition if he relied on the likes of Mr Sykes.

The row overshadowed an attempt by Mr Hague, in his weekly Commons clash with the prime minister, to highlight government divisions over the single currency. The spotlight was turned once again on the deeper Tory splits over Europe.

Mr Sykes, who dealt a devastating blow to John Major's 1997 general election campaign by funding Eurosceptic Tory MPs, said on Sky News: "I would certainly favour, when the time is right, asking the British people what they think. Have a national referendum on whether our relationship with the EU, the benefits and the deficits, are they good or bad for this nation."

Mindful of the sensitivity of such an intervention, Mr Sykes said he supported Tory policy, which is for Britain to remain a full member of the EU. But he immediately described the EU as intolerable: "The way the EU is going [will] create unemployment. I think the EU, when you balance all the picture up, is something you couldn't possibly tolerate in a free market world."

Pro-Europeans said the leadership was so hostile to Europe that it was inching itself towards a policy of withdrawal.

Ian Taylor, who resigned from the shadow cabinet in protest at Mr Hague's hardline anti-European stance, said he was appalled that the party "can appear attractive to Mr Sykes. We will not return to government until we have a positive attitude to Europe".

Tony Blair said in the Commons that Mr Hague led a party "that has now been bought by someone who wants to take this country to the margins of Europe because he doesn't have the strength to stand up to his Eurosceptics".

He mocked Mr Hague by reading a report of a Labour-organised focus group, in which people dismissed him as a "pathetic drip", a "nonentity" and a "complete waste of time".

Mr Hague said the prime minister was presiding over a cabinet whose members were "fighting like ferrets in a sack" over Europe.
