fields.headline: Tobacco firms face new curbs
fields.standfirst:
Europe and Westminster demand end to misleading descriptions
Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: The tobacco industry came under fire yesterday from Westminster and Strasbourg as members of both parliaments criticised the use of terms such as low tar, light and low nicotine, which give smokers a false sense of security.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire  and Andrew Osborn  in Brussels
fields.body:
The tobacco industry came under fire yesterday from Westminster and Strasbourg as members of both parliaments criticised the use of terms such as low tar, light and low nicotine, which give smokers a false sense of security.

MPs demanded tougher statutory controls over the tobacco industry - including the creation of a Tobacco Regulatory Authority - to police companies and carry out further scientific research.

At the same time, Euro MPs voted to ban manufacturers from using "misleading terms" such as light and mild and demanded that the size of health warnings be increased.

The proposals need the backing of EU health ministers, who are due to consider the anti-smoking measures on June 29 and are likely to face vociferous lobbying from the tobacco industry. But the EU health commissioner, David Byrne, predicted that ministers would endorse the European Parliament's views and said an overall "consensus on the future approach to tobacco products" was close.

In Westminster, a report on the risks of smoking by the Commons health select committee accused firms and their agencies of "conniving" to get round existing restrictions and challenged the government to set higher targets to eradicate the habit.

Ministers were urged to re gard nicotine as comparable to hard drugs, such as heroin and cocaine, when drawing up anti-smoking strategies.

David Hinchliffe, the committee's chairman, said smoking was "a public health scandal of epidemic proportions" that killed 120,000 people a year in Britain. The damage caused by cigarettes had been known since at least the 1950s but tobacco companies denied it and sponsored counter claims.

The Tobacco Regulatory Authority, modelled on the Food Standards Agency, would, he said, be able to take on what is a well-funded and powerful lobby.

Tobacco companies delayed the imposition last year of an advertising ban and the European Court of Justice's advocate-general will today give his opinion.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, is considering a recommendation to order an investigation into allegations that London-based British American Tobacco (BAT), the world's second biggest tobacco company, actively encouraged and profited from international smuggling.

The allegations, made in the Guardian this year, were contested by BAT, which set up an internal investigation as well as hiring lawyers in the UK and US to prepare a defence.

MPs decided the "extremely serious" allegations warranted an independent inquiry by inspectors from the Department of Trade and Industry.

The report said: "If they prove to be substantiated, the case for criminal proceedings against BAT should be considered; if they prove to be false, then those perpetrating them should publicly apologise to BAT for what will have amounted to a malicious slur on the company's name."

Mr Byers is known to be "sympathetic" to an inquiry but BAT is lobbying against it and some senior officials in his department fear it could open a can of worms. The report, agreed unanimously by MPs, called for the appointment of more customs officers to halt the £2.5bn smuggling of ciga rettes into Britain, rejecting company pleas for taxes to be reduced.

"We do not believe it would be appropriate for health policy to be shaped by the activities of criminal gangs," it said.

It also proposed the introduction of plain boxes to undermine marketing, with larger health warnings, lists of additives and anti-smoking telephone hotline numbers printed on the cartons.

A ban on terms such as light, ultra-mild, low tar and low nicotine was also recommended to stop smokers thinking they could light up safely.

Yvette Cooper, minister for public health, said: "I welcome this report. It shows clearly, as we have said, that when it comes to the tobacco industry voluntary agreements just don't work. "That is why we are legislating to ban tobacco advertising and achieve tighter regulation at the European level."

BAT agreed to make the results of its internal investigation into the international smuggling allegations available to the committee.

John Carlisle, of the Tobacco Manufacturers' Association, said the committee was indulging in a "bashing exercise" - "in particular, accusations against us that we're not regulated - we are highly regulated."

fields.headline: Pooh Blair catches a heffalump
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Fans of A.A. Milne - it's a great sadness to me that I never really managed to interest my own children in the Christopher Robin books - will recall that a heffalump trap is a pit that you dig for a heffalump, and then fall in yourself.
fields.body:
Fans of A.A. Milne - it's a great sadness to me that I never really managed to interest my own children in the Christopher Robin books - will recall that a heffalump trap is a pit that you dig for a heffalump, and then fall in yourself.

Yesterday William Hague dug a beautiful heffalump trap, scooped it out, stuck sharpened stakes in the bottom, covered it with branches, leaves and moss, paused to admire his work, then walked slap dab into it.

Ka-poom! The sound of him crashing down reverberated round the Commons for, ooh, minutes if not seconds.

Poor William. He has been doing quite well lately. I've always thought that the boy has an inner calm which has helped him in difficult times, i.e. all of the last three years. With Labour's poll lead down to its lowest since 1992, he might have expected a triumphant prime minister's questions. Instead, he found himself trying to climb out of a heffalump trap.

It all began with some stuff about ministers disagreeing over the euro. "Will the prime minister get a grip on his cabinet, and stop them fighting like ferrets in a sack?" (Fighting ferrets in sacks may be something Mr Hague did to pass the time while nobbut a lad in Rotherham. More fun than memorising parliamentary majorities, which he admits to.) Mr Blair pointed out that the Tories were also divided.

"But our policy on the euro is settled," Mr Hague said, optimistically. "That is because I lead my party, and he now follows his."

This braggadocio was greeted with wild cheering, but mainly from the claque gathered round Mr Hague. On the far back Tory bench I noticed expressions which were rather more thoughtful, perhaps even embarrassed.

"The prime minister wrote an article yesterday, saying the euro had been a success. Well, you can't slow handclap an article!"

And so he went on. It was then that he started to dig the trap. He decided to quote the private memo from Mr Blair's "chief guru", Philip Gould, the one which said that "TB" was lacking in conviction, unable to stick to a position and out of touch.

"Does TB agree with this, or is it just the rest of us?"

"Well," said Mr Blair mildly, "if he's not careful, I'll start reading what the focus groups say about him."

Now this is why Amanda Platell, Mr Hague's own spin doctor, ought to have radio-controlled electrodes sewn into in his Y-fronts. Sitting in the gallery she could press a button, left for "carry on, you're doing fine," right for "shut up, for goodness sake, shuttup, now!" We would know she had hit the button because the opposition leader would start to twitch madly, which we'd all enjoy watching.

Lacking high-tech guidance, Mr Hague blundered on towards his own trap. "We'd be delighted if he'd read what the focus groups said, because then we could have the whole document placed in the Commons library!" he said, going on to add what was meant to be a mighty peroration: "He has run out of steam, run out of time, and if he carries on like this, will be run out of office!"

Mr Blair smiled gently. "He challenged me to read out the focus groups, so I will.

"This is what they say: 'Boring, false, he irritates me greatly, pathetic drip, nonentity, no substance, no personality, complete waste of time, no policies, and a very unimpressive team, particularly William Hague'!"

Labour MPs, who had been fearful a few moments before, erupted in glee. Tories were deeply, deeply glum. Mr Hague began smiling and laughing, in the strained, half-demented way anyone might, but only while sitting at the bottom of a heffalump trap.

webTitle: Nail bomber 'was sent by God to start race wars'

fields.headline: Nail bomber 'was sent by God to start race wars'
fields.trailText: Nail bomber David Copeland is a paranoid schizophrenic who believed that he would be rescued from his trial by God and thought he was being punished like Jesus before his death, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Nail bomber David Copeland is a paranoid schizophrenic who believed that he would be rescued from his trial by God and thought he was being punished like Jesus before his death, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.

Even if this did not happen, he was confident that he would be free within five years when Tony Blair was replaced by an extreme rightwing government whose first act would be to release him from prison, the jury was told.

Opening his defence yesterday, his counsel Michael Wolkind QC said that psychiatrists would give evidence that Copeland was suffering from "religious, grandiose, persecutory delusions" which contributed to the reasons for his behaviour.

"We say he was suffering from diminished responsibility. He was turned into a robot, his illness obsessed him," he told the court.

The witnesses will include the medical director of Broadmoor special hospital in Berkshire, where Copeland is being held.

The 24-year-old engineering assistant from Cove, Hampshire, has pleaded guilty to the manslaughter of Andrea Dykes, John Light and Nik Moore in the Soho pub explosion which was the culmination of his bombing campaign in April last year.

The crown is rejecting these pleas, made on the grounds of diminished responsibility, and is seeking convictions for murder.

Both defence and prosecution psychiatrists consider Copeland unfit to give evidence, the court heard yesterday, as details were given of his state of mind and key episodes from his childhood and adolescence.

First to give evidence was psychiatrist Paul Gilluley, who interviewed Copeland at Belmarsh prison in south-east London and at Broadmoor.

Copeland considered himself a heterosexual, but had in the past wondered whether he was homosexual, the psychiatrist said.

The bomber denied ever having a homosexual physical relationship.

Copeland, whose father Stephen sat listening behind the defence benches yesterday, told the psychiatrist that his parents "turned funny" when he was 13 and had made suggestions that he was homosexual.

Dr Gilluley said: "It was following an incident when he walked into the house and his parents were singing the theme tune to The Flintstones, with emphasis on the words 'have a gay old time'.

"His mother was constantly asking him if 'there's anything you want to tell us' - which he interpreted as suggesting he was homosexual.

"He said he had never confronted these issues with his parents."

Dr Gilluley said that Copeland was suffering from a "delusional belief system with grandiose and messianic elements".

This included the belief that he was a prophet chosen by God for a special mission, which was to be the spark for racial wars in Britain.

Earlier Mr Wolkind urged the jury to set aside the emotions and opinions of "the man in the street and the man in the pub".

He said that rows of victims had sat at the back of the court during Copeland's trial "and not a single one need ever forgive him for what he has done".

He told the jurors: "You must be straining to deliver him justice.

"On the streets, just like the streets of Brixton and Brick Lane and in pubs like Soho ordinary people probably have a good idea of the justice he deserves."

Mr Wolkind referred to Copeland's belief that killers deserved the death penalty, before saying: "But you are no longer ordinary people. You confirmed - each of you - that you were able dispassionately to judge, and reach a verdict on the evidence."

The trial continues.

fields.headline: After Assad
fields.standfirst:
Syria's new boss has no choice but to pursue a peace settlement with Israel. And he must do so quickly
Syrian Ministry of Information
Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel's sigh of relief at the death of Syria's leader Assad was so loud we have virtually been able to hear it from here. Suddenly Israel's most lasting enemy has been plucked off the board of Middle East politics. But Israelis, and their prime minister in particular, should temper their joy. With the old strong-man gone, Syria will find it harder, not easier, to make peace.
fields.body:
Israel's sigh of relief at the death of Syria's leader Assad was so loud we have virtually been able to hear it from here. Suddenly Israel's most lasting enemy has been plucked off the board of Middle East politics. But Israelis, and their prime minister in particular, should temper their joy. With the old strong-man gone, Syria will find it harder, not easier, to make peace.

Israel has painted Assad as the great stumbling block. If it were not for him, we would have had peace years ago, the line runs. The truth is more interesting. The Israelis have knowingly made demands that Assad could not accept. They have continually pressed Syria to do their own dirty work in buttering up the Israeli public. It is as if Gerry Adams asked David Trimble to sell the peace process to Republicans while not promoting it himself. Despite this worrying sign and their flouting of UN resolution 242, the Israelis have imposed tests on Syria's good will. She must give Israel all the fruits of peace - ambassadors, trade - in return for what? Partial troop withdrawals phased over several years?

Furthermore, the kind of peace that the Israelis have thrust at Assad has been too hot to handle. Shimon Peres was a stylish and visionary statesman. But his plans for free-trade zones in the Golan Heights ignored reality. Syria's command economy is flat on its back. A stroll around Damascus will reveal at once the shabbiness and shoddiness of its housing and consumer goods. Israeli competition would gut Syria's industry. The country will need a decade of liberalisation before it can even begin to cope with free trade. Yet the generals and apparatchiks who have milked the system will fight modernisation every inch of the way.

Even without such demands, Bashar al-Assad could be forgiven for hesitating to rush into the arms of Israel. The fate of those who have, is not comforting.

Anwar Sadat, Egypt's charismatic master, who risked far more than any of his Israeli counterparts to make peace, was murdered in 1981 by his own soldiers. And, so many years after Camp David, relations between Egypt and Israel are still cool.

For Yasser Arafat the years since 1993 have brought a series of humiliations and betrayals at the hands of the Israelis. His handshake with Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin has made no difference to the impoverished lives of ordinary Palestinians. The process has been so grim that Arafat has threatened to abandon it and declare Palestinian statehood even without East Jerusalem. Peace with Israel is a bitter pill.

The trouble for Bashar al-Assad is that he has no choice but to swallow. The only question is when. Ehud Barak has sensibly brought home his soldiers from the Lebanese minefield, thus reducing Syria's leverage. And yet his support in Israel's parliament, the Knesset, has crumbled. Peace with Syria is the only prize which can restore his prestige.

As the self-appointed successor to Rabin, Barak has had the courage to admit that, before his death, Rabin guaranteed Assad that Israel would withdraw from the Golan Heights in exchange for Syrian security commitments.

And it is that issue of security which will now be uppermost in Bashar al-Assad's mind. He faces a dilemma. He presides over a security state. There are half a dozen branches of military and civilian intelligence snooping on Syria's citizens. The Syrian army is still large and has 35,000 men in Lebanon as well as forts and listening posts. webTitle: Germans about to hear a mention of the war

fields.headline: Germans about to hear a mention of the war
fields.trailText: A German Basil Fawlty might seem as likely as a pro-German headline on the sports pages of the Sun. But not, it seems, to Germany's top TV channel.
fields.body:
A German Basil Fawlty might seem as likely as a pro-German headline on the sports pages of the Sun. But not, it seems, to Germany's top TV channel.

The commercial RTL network is on the brink of agreeing to buy the right to remake Fawlty Towers in German. Among other things, the deal will allow a German actor to goosestep up and down in front of viewers while doing an imitation of Adolf Hitler.

News that an agreement had been reached emerged when Rupert Gavin, chief executive of BBC Worldwide, the corporation's commercial arm, told an advertising conference in London: "We are making a Hindi version of Yes, Minister in India with an Indian cast and, unbelievably, a German version of Fawlty Towers".

In fact, the new Fawlty Towers will be made by German producers. It will be set in a German seaside resort and German actors will play the roles of Basil Fawlty, his acid-tongued wife, Sybil, and their incongruously sane chambermaid, Polly.

The Guardian revealed last September that talks had begun between BBC Worldwide and RTL. But a deal was said to have been resisted from the creator and star of the 1970s' series, John Cleese.

Fawlty's rudeness, incompetence and intolerance can all no doubt be moved from one cultural context to the other. But with neither party to the deal commenting yesterday, it remains to be seen whether RTL's producers will want to tackle the episode in which German guests turn up at Fawlty Towers, giving rise to exchanges such as:

Basil: "So that's two eggs mayonnaise, a prawn Goebbels, a Hermann Goering and four Colditz salads ... no, wait a moment, I got a bit confused there, sorry ... I got a bit confused because everyone keeps mentioning the war, so could you..."

German: "Will you stop talking about the war!"

Basil: "Me? You started it!"

German: "We did not start it."

Basil: "Yes you did, you invaded Poland..."

The British version of the series has already been shown in Germany, most recently in a dubbed version by Sat-1 in 1997. Viewers gave a good-humoured reaction when the "German guests" episode was first screened by the cable and satellite channel, 3-sat.

According to figures for May, RTL had the largest audience of any German channel, with an average market share of 14.5%.

It currently broadcasts a German adaptation of Top of the Pops and will be showing the drama series Silent Witness in a dubbed version this summer.

webTitle: Fizzy drinks threat to teenage girls

fields.headline: Fizzy drinks threat to teenage girls
fields.trailText: Osteoporosis is starting to become a childhood disease as a result of teenagers consuming large amounts of fizzy drinks while milk has gone out of fashion, according to scientists in the United States.
fields.body:
Osteoporosis is starting to become a childhood disease as a result of teenagers consuming large amounts of fizzy drinks while milk has gone out of fashion, according to scientists in the United States.

A study of 460 teenage girls carried out by a researcher from Harvard Medical School in Boston, Massachusetts, found a significant link between the quantities of cola and other carbonated drinks they consumed and bone fractures, which increased when the girls were very physically active.

Grace Wyshak reports in the medical journal Archives of Paediatrics and Adolescent Medicine that nearly 80% of the girls consumed carbonated drinks. Approximately 20% of them had suffered bone fractures and the fizzy drink lovers were three times more likely to have a fracture than the rest.

Those who reported a high level of physical activity and drank carbonated drinks had nearly five times the risk of fracture.

The study suggests that the changed patterns in drinking and eating of recent decades may be having an effect on the bone structure of young girls which could persist into later life. Milk drinking among young people has plummeted while cola and other drinks have taken off.

Dr Wyshak speculates that the phosphorus contained in carbonated drinks may have a damaging effect on the bone, by altering the phosphorous-calcium ratio.

"Our findings have implications both for the health of teenagers and for the health of women at later ages. In addition to research, health and social policies to promote better behavioural practices, including one's diet, among American women of all ages are needed."

In an editorial in the journal Neville Golden, from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York, says it is important that teenagers approach carbonated drinks with caution because adolescence is a crucial time for bone development.

He says Dr Wyshak's findings are "alarming and warrant further confirmation with well-designed prospective studies" that quantify the amount and type of carbonated drinks consumed, as well as the calcium intake.

"What is clear is that today's teenagers are consuming diets that are high in phosphorus and low in calcium," he said, both of which can hinder the development of peak bone mass. "Osteoporosis should no longer be considered only a geriatric disease but rather a paediatric disease with geriatric consequences."

The National Osteoporosis Society in Britain, said: "Phosphorus is necessary for proper bone formation but is needed in balance with calcium. When blood phosphorus levels exceed calcium levels the body responds by stimulating bone breakdown to release calcium into the blood.

"There is no hard scientific evidence to show a detrimental effect on bone health but we welcome further research."

webTitle: Five killed as air ambulance crashes into the Mersey

fields.headline: Five killed as air ambulance crashes into the Mersey
fields.trailText: Five people died yesterday when an air ambulance clipped the River Mersey, cartwheeled and broke apart less than a minute before it was due to land at Liverpool airport.
fields.body:
Five people died yesterday when an air ambulance clipped the River Mersey, cartwheeled and broke apart less than a minute before it was due to land at Liverpool airport.

The bodies of two nurses were recovered by rescue craft soon after the crash, as helicopters used thermal imagers to check a slick of oil around debris from the plane. Rescuers later found the bodies of the pilot, the middle-aged patient who was being flown from the Isle of Man for neurosurgery in Liverpool and his wife in the wreckage of the Piper Navajo Chieftain.

The pilot, Keith Whyham, 58, was highly experienced. Married with two children, he was a well known figure who co-owned the Blackpool company Air Navigation and Training, which had chartered the twin-engined plane for the ambulance run.

A colleague, flying instructor Jim Duckworth, said: "He has probably well over 30,000 flying hours - extensive in anybody's language. He was much respected and much liked by everyone in the aviation industry. He knew his job inside out."

The possibility that Mr Whyham was taken ill is among theories being examined by crash investigators, who will also check the 21-year-old plane, which had regularly been used for the Manx ambulance service.

The plane was completing its approach to the airport at Speke when it vanished from radar during a rainy squall, according to staff in the control tower at Liverpool.

Rod Hills, managing director of the airport, whose estuary approach has been familiar to pilots since the 1930s, said: "The fact that the plane just went off the radar at such close proximity to the runway suggests a technical problem on board." The airport has ruled out the possibility of the aircraft hitting a runway light gantry or other obstacle on the ground.

The six to eight seater plane was part of a regular service run by Nobles hospital, which does not have specialist facilities for complicated medical cases.

The patient had been booked into the neurological unit at Walton hospital in Liverpool, on a flight sub-chartered to the Manx firm Island Aviation, which usually handles the ambulance runs.

Coastguards from Hoylake, New Brighton and Crosby found the bodies of a 21-year-old student nurse and a staff nurse, who was in her thirties, as cloud and drizzle hung over the site, close to the Mersey's junction with the Manchester Ship Canal at Garston.

The airport was closed to allow rescue helicopters, including a specialist team from RAF Valley on Anglesey, to scour the estuary, and holiday flights were diverted to Leeds-Bradford airport.

Mr Hill said: "The plane was making a visual approach. There was no communication between the pilot and air traffic control, but there might have been a difficulty. There was no problem of visibility - I think it was a bit murky but nothing exceptional."

A helicopter flying instructor, Gary Auld, 28, led the initial search for survivors, after his student pilot spotted debris in the Mersey below them.

He said: "The control tower was trying to call the aircraft. We hovered around looking for survivors and then the police helicopter came with thermal imaging equipment on it and we left."

The Navajo had throttled back to a speed of about 140mph at 500ft on the final stage of its approach to Speke. Superintendent Ted Greenwell, police commander for the Speke area, said: "We would like to hear from anyone who actually saw the plane come down."

Mr Duckworth said the aircraft was made in 1979 and had been owned by the company for a number of years and it had no history of problems. "It has an excellent safety record and the aircraft has been used many times for this type of aeronautical activity."

Yesterday's tragedy is the worst involving a light aircraft since September last year, when eight people were killed and three were injured when a 20-year-old Cessna 404 crashed shortly after leaving Glasgow airport, when one of its twin engines abruptly cut out.

webTitle: BBC Sport gets left on the touchline

fields.headline: BBC Sport gets left on the touchline
fields.standfirst:
As ITV chiefs open the champagne over football deal, Dyke's staff are in a state of shock about the death of Match of the Day
Football Unlimited
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke was so determined that the BBC should retain the rights to show English Premiership football highlights that he sanctioned a bid worth twice as much as its present deal: it was as much as the corporation could afford, he pleaded last night.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke was so determined that the BBC should retain the rights to show English Premiership football highlights that he sanctioned a bid worth twice as much as its present deal: it was as much as the corporation could afford, he pleaded last night.

Over champagne at ITV network headquarters in London, jubilant executives could not contain their delight that his gamble had failed in such a calamitous fashion.

Across town at White City, BBC chiefs were in shock as the enormity of loss began to sink in.

"Match of the Day is the biggest, most successful football programme on television and we are determined to keep in that way," the BBC had said a few hours before the result of the bidding was announced.

Losing such a fixture of the sports schedule is nothing short of disastrous.

When he took up his post earlier this year, Mr Dyke promised to stem the growing tide of BBC Sport losses. His failure to secure Premiership highlights rights is a huge blow to the corporation and its staff, who thought that if anyone could stop the rot, Mr Dyke could.

Morale, already low at BBC Sport, is now in free fall. Summing up the sense of disbelief that such new depths could have been plumbed, BBC commentator Barry Davies said just before going on air at the Euro 2000 championships last night: "It's the end of an era - again."

The decline of BBC Sport began with the loss of formula one to ITV, and continued with the loss of Test cricket to Sky and Channel 4.

One by one, major sporting events slipped out of the corporation's grasp: the FA Cup final, six nations rugby, British Lions tours, Cheltenham Gold Cup racing, and Ryder Cup golf.

On radio, international cricket went to Talksport. Only Radio 5 Live could lay claim to a comprehensive portfolio of sports rights.

"It's a body blow," said Sir Paul Fox, a former BBC managing director. "It is the biggest blow that BBC Sport has suffered. Saturday night's Match of the Day has seemingly gone on forever and I suppose money is a major factor."

There is no doubt that the BBC's bid was an impressive one - £120m over three years. But, quite simply, ITV has bigger pockets, and it dug deep. After years as an also-ran in the sports broadcasting stakes, Britain's most-watched broadcaster is now a significant player.

So viewers of the national game will have to get used to a switch in viewing habits over the next few years.

From the 2001-2 season, ITV will screen a highlights programme on Saturday and Sunday nights. It is expected that the network's star presenter, the former BBC man Des Lynam, will front at least one of the shows.

Sky will continue to screen the main Premiership matches live: a total of 66 live games on Sunday afternoons and Monday evenings will be shown on the satellite network. It will also have the right to broadcast a highlights programme on Sunday mornings.

The deal is a huge relief to Sky: live football is the reason it exists.

In a revolution for British television viewers, the cable operator NTL has won the right to televise 40 Premier League matches live, on a pay per view basis.

NTL said last night that it would show matches on 37 consecutive Sunday afternoons, not conflicting with the live rights package matches. The remaining three matches will be shown on bank holidays or mid-week.

NTL intends to offer its matches to rivals as well as to its own 2m subscribers, so that Sky Digital viewers, for example, could opt to pay for an NTL match.

The NTL deal is also something of a relief to employees at BBC Sport, who will produce the matches for the cable giant.

In addition, Premiership clubs will be able to show their own matches on a delayed basis on their in-house TV channels, such as Manchester United's MUTV, and on their internet sites after midnight on Mondays.

Rights to will also be awarded on an experimental basis for video on demand services and new generation mobile phones, both of which are expected to explode in popularity over the next few years.

In every sense, the 2000 Premier League deal has heralded a brave and somewhat complicated new world for fans of English Premiership football. It is a world, however, which the BBC will only watch from the touchline.

fields.body:
The buff-coloured walls of the 18th-century fortress that is Moscow's notorious Butyrka prison have harboured many a celebrated inmate down the centuries. The rebel poet Vladimir Mayakovsky did time there alongside other old insurrectionary Bolsheviks.

The tsar also incarcerated Lenin's sidekick, Felix Dzerzhinsky, in Butyrka. Dzerzhinsky went on to found what became the KGB, which then put Alexander Solzhenitsyn behind Butyrka's barbed wire and iron bars.

The overcrowding in the prison is such that the inmates take turns to sleep. And yesterday, sharing a cell with a counterfeiter and a suspected embezzler - "decent people", said a justice ministry spokesman - Vladimir Gusinsky became the latest high-profile inmate of Butyrka and, in the words of a Moscow journalist, "the first political prisoner of Putin's Russia".

Wheeling and dealing his way to a colossal fortune during the past decade through the real estate business, banking, and the building of Russia's only independent media empire, Vladimir Gusinsky seems an unlikely candidate for political martyrdom.

Nonetheless, his fate is now intimately bound up with the prospects for media freedom and civil liberties in a Russia which is at a crossroads. Mr Gusinsky's detention is a defining moment for the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, only a month after he was inaugurated in the Kremlin.

"Putin has to decide where Russia belongs. Most Russians believe our natural allies are in the west," Mr Gusinsky told a small group of foreign reporters earlier this month at the lavish headquarters of his Media-Most empire, which had recently been raided by paramilitary "tax police" in black balaclavas.

In the past decade, Mr Gusinsky has been a central player in building the new Russia that has now turned against him. He is an "oligarch", one of the notorious band of fabulously wealthy businessmen who are loathed by ordinary Russians for plundering national assets during the lawless Yeltsin years.

He started small, as a provincial theatre director in the early 80s, then as an illegal commercial taxi driver in Moscow before starting a small metal-working firm. In the early 90s, he moved into banking and property.

He used his fortune to found NTV, Russia's biggest private television channel, and the hard-hitting daily newspaper, Segodnya, in 1993. He also launched a glossy weekly news magazine, Itogi, in partnership with Newsweek.

In contrast to the fortunes of other Russian oligarchs, Mr Gusinsky's is based not on manipulation of Russia's natural resources and heavy industry, but on the forward-looking industries of media, electronics, satellite broadcasting and the internet. He attracts and employs the brightest and the best in Russian journalism.

Deploying his media resources, he helped Boris Yeltsin win a second presidential term - against the odds - in 1996. But the 47-year-old media mogul has been a thorn in the flesh of the ruling clan throughout Mr Putin's meteoric rise to power in the past year. Every Sunday night his NTV channel lampoons Mr Putin, Kremlin bigshots, the entire political class with the silicon puppets and absurd escapades of Kukly - Russia's "Spitting Images". It's popular, it's hilarious and it annoys Mr Putin no end.

The government had been pressing the channel for the past month to remove the Putin puppet from the show.

Every night NTV's news punctures the anodyne claims of Russian triumphs in Chechnya and queries the official version of casualty figures. Every week Mr Gusinsky's Itogi magazine and Segodnya newspaper purvey more revelations of sleaze and corruption among the high and mighty.

When the US President Bill Clinton came to Moscow last week for his first summit with Mr Putin, he made a point of going on Mr Gusinsky's radio station for a phone in. The Kremlin was outraged - but Mr Gusinsky has many friends in the west. He is also an Israeli citizen and a powerful figure in the World Jewish Congress, heading its Russian wing.

Mr Putin yesterday denied there was any "political aspect" to the case, insisting that the law would take its course. If he believes that, he is the only person in Moscow who does.

"Revenge," said ex-president Mikhail Gorbachev. "An attempt to frighten the public and the media." Even Sergei Dorenko, TV star, Putin propagandist and Gusinsky enemy, said the case was "exclusively political".

Mr Gusinsky is the sole oligarch to oppose Mr Putin publicly and consistently. And he is the only one to have ended up in the overcrowded squalor of the jail commissioned by Catherine the Great in 1771.

webTitle: You just know they'll mess with the magic

fields.headline: You just know they'll mess with the magic
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Our Match of the Days are numbered and Saturdays will never be the same again. The worst fears of armchair traditionalists were realised yesterday when the modernising suits of the Premiership consigned MotD to the archives below Broadcasting House.
fields.body:
Our Match of the Days are numbered and Saturdays will never be the same again. The worst fears of armchair traditionalists were realised yesterday when the modernising suits of the Premiership consigned MotD to the archives below Broadcasting House.

In the end 36 years of tradition were worth less than the £21m shortfall between the two bids. But what price history? How much am I bid for the opening bars of the world's greatest theme tune? One is loth to prejudge, but surely nothing ITV can offer, no amount of new camera angles and Gabby Yorath, can compensate for the loss of that theme.

It was the first tune I learnt by heart, and its power is enduring. It signifies the start of an hour of utter contentment, 60 minutes during which the distractions of everyday life can be put aside in favour of truly important events at White Hart Lane.

ITV will argue that little will change. We'll still have our highlights, and not just on Saturdays. But you just know they'll mess with the magic (their football coverage, though improving, consistently lacks the authority of the BBC).

Almost certainly the show will be moved from 10.30pm to an earlier time slot in search of better ratings, robbing us of yet another of life's most delicious dilemmas; do we have one more before closing time, or leave now in time for the football?

ITV will proclaim the return of Des Lynam. On current evidence that's small compensation. His cheeky contributions to ITV's Euro 2000 coverage have led to a backlash. When he was on BBC we called him Sir Des. That title has long since been annulled.

And then there are the voices we shall hear no more come May 2001. Tony Gubba, Ray Stubbs, Gerald Sinstadt, Garry Richardson, Jon Champion. As familiar as Germany winning on penalties, but marginally easier to stomach. Regional TV sports editors should brace themselves for a wave of job applications; the BBC won't have room for them all, especially as this is the end, too, of Football Focus, the 12.20pm preview slot.

One day we might get used to it, but for now the last word goes to Barry Davies, gentleman veteran of a thousand goal-less draws, whose first thoughts on this dark day were for the voice of football, John Motson.

"Motty and I have worked together for a long time on Match of the Day and I know he will be absolutely gutted," he said. He's not the only one, Bazza.

webTitle: Cancer diagnosis errors 'no worse than average'

fields.headline: Cancer diagnosis errors 'no worse than average'
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: James Elwood, the pathologist who faced public disgrace yesterday over his mistakes in cancer diagnosis, had an error rate that was no worse than other doctors in his specialty, said the president of the Royal College of Pathologists yesterday.
fields.body:
James Elwood, the pathologist who faced public disgrace yesterday over his mistakes in cancer diagnosis, had an error rate that was no worse than other doctors in his specialty, said the president of the Royal College of Pathologists yesterday.

"The figures I have seen do not lead me to the inevitable conclusion that he is a bad pathologist," said John Lilleyman.

Mr Elwood, 78, who has opted for voluntary erasure from the medical register in the face of the reviews into his performance at four NHS trusts where he worked as a locum histopathologist, said yesterday that his error rate was no more than 2%, which was average in the UK and better than many doctors abroad.

"Internationally the incorrect diagnosis rate varies from 2% to 7%," he said. "Within my discipline of medicine my level was pretty low and was certainly regarded as so by my colleagues."

Professor Lilleyman said that on the face of it, and without having seen the report of the investigation into Mr Elwood's work, he agreed.

"We will have to wait and see what the full report says, but the sort of error rates that have been published in the few studies there are in this area are in line with the sort of fig ures he is quoting." According to the Department of Health yesterday, the review into Mr Elwood's work at four hospital trusts, in Swindon, Mid Sussex, Surrey and Bath, found seven patients with a wrong diagnosis that had serious consequences and 215 whose histology reports had to be revised. A total of 10,358 cases were examined.

"There were seven which were clinically important. That's less than 1%, which I don't think you will improve on, frankly," said Prof Lilleyman.

He said he and his colleagues had been taken aback by the public release of information from the report.

Gabriel Scully, regional director of public health for the South-west, said he wrote to the college to ask their advice on several matters. He agreed that there was still one case outstanding.

Mr Elwood gave a vigorous defence of himself yesterday. "I think I have been very badly treated by this report. One of the things that concerns me most is that it has been grossly exaggerated.

"Many of the errors in diagnoses or disagreements in diagnoses were not cancerous patients. There were only seven where there was serious consequence from the incorrect diagnosis."

He said he was working as a locum not for the money but because he enjoyed it.

fields.headline: Net record pirates 'will cost billions'
fields.trailText: It poses a greater threat to the likes of Madonna, Britney and Robbie than laryngitis, extreme weight gain or the fickleness of their fans: music piracy on the internet is burgeoning with 25m songs being traded each day, the first figures on the phenomenon yesterday showed.
fields.body:
It poses a greater threat to the likes of Madonna, Britney and Robbie than laryngitis, extreme weight gain or the fickleness of their fans: music piracy on the internet is burgeoning with 25m songs being traded each day, the first figures on the phenomenon yesterday showed.

While record industry executives had predicted internet users would be able to plunder 1m files of music by the end of this year, 25m already exist on known music-sharing sites.

The cost to artists and record companies is as yet unquantifiable, but with an estimated 9bn songs being traded this year, and 1bn downloaded in 1999, it looks set to cost billions of pounds a year, the record industry yesterday warned.

The picture of a world in which web users can avoid paying £13.99 for a CD just by logging on to sites such as the one offering the controversial computer programme Napster was painted at a press conference in London by the body representing the recording industry worldwide, the IFPI.

It called on governments to modernise their laws to crack down on pirates flouting intellectual copyright on the internet.

While the record industry and the rock group Metallica are embroiled in legal battles with Napster, there is no international law prohibiting the copying of music on the net. Individual countries are updating their legislation. America has already done so, and the 15 member states of the EU are expected to adopt a directive later this year.

Jay Samit, senior vice president of EMI, warned: "This all takes time. The internet is borderless but we live in nation states."

He added: "The technology leads the legal systems by 15 years. What we have to do is to make buying music as easy as stealing music and we have to make stealing music a hell of a lot harder."

Internet users can either download MP3 audio files and then repeatedly play it from their computer or "burn" it on to a CD recordable disc.

Jorgen Larsen, chairman of the record company Universal Music Unlimited, said that such a process meant small-time entrepreneurs were flourishing, in addition to the large-scale music pirates who last year cost the industry £2.7bn.

webTitle: Cash will divide top two leagues

fields.headline: Cash will divide top two leagues
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Yesterday's deal will increase dramatically the gap between the haves and the have-nots in the world of football.
fields.body:
Yesterday's deal will increase dramatically the gap between the haves and the have-nots in the world of football.

The current Premier League deal, worth £10m a season for the top -flight clubs, means there is already a gulf between the Premiership and the first division. But the new deal, for £25m a season to each club, will make that gap even wider.

Clubs promoted from the first division have often struggled to keep their place in the top flight, unable to afford the quality of players needed. Now the step up will be harder to maintain while the drop down will be even harder to take. But for clubs who are already in the promised land the news will be manna from heaven.

Many Premiership clubs are running at a loss, spending more money on players' pay and ground redevelopments than is made through ticket sales or television income.

One of the most lucrative parts of the deal is the right to show matches on their own television channels and websites after they have been broadcast live. Big clubs will charge subscriptions and sell advertising when they deliver these matches to a global audience. But for smaller clubs such revenue is likely to be minimal.

But the new deal will not be all good news for Premiership clubs. Players' agents will demand that their stars get a bigger cut and club chairmen can expect a queue of top players outside their office doors.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Drink driver jailed for death
fields.body:
Drink driver jailed for death

A woman drink driver who killed a "highly talented and gifted" schoolboy on a zebra crossing was jailed for 18 months yesterday. Nesbat Khan, 22, who worked for Mercedes Benz and drove a company sports car, was travelling at 60mph when she hit Benjamin Chudleigh, 14. The only child died instantly near his home in south London. Khan was convicted of causing death by dangerous driving.

New Atlantic yachting record

French sailor Francis Joyon set a new record yesterday for the singlehanded transatlantic race, reaching Newport, Rhode Island, nine days, 23 hours 21 minutes after setting off from Plymouth in his 60ft trimaran Eure Et Loire.

He took a full day off the previous record for the Europe 1 singlehanded race. This was the 40th anniversary event - the first was won by Sir Francis Chichester, who took 40 days.

Open wide and say art

A dentist has come up with a way to ease patients' nerves - a maze on the ceiling. It is one of several treats in Christopher Gull's Brighton surgery. He has turned his consulting rooms into an art gallery and the garden into a sculpture park. Surgery spokesman Lydia Salou said: "The artworks help to take people's minds off why they are here."

Street activists target Scotland

Reclaim the Streets campaigners whose May Day protests in London ended in disorder last month, are expected to gather in Edinburgh on Saturday.

fields.headline: Handyman guilty of Laura's murder
fields.standfirst: Killer buried child's body then took mother for a drink at local pub
fields.trailText: The handyman accused of killing nine-year-old Laura Kane was yesterday found guilty of her rape and murder.
fields.body:
The handyman accused of killing nine-year-old Laura Kane was yesterday found guilty of her rape and murder.

There were cheers from the public gallery as the jury returned its verdicts after four hours of deliberation at Newcastle crown court.

Colin Bainbridge, 35, a trusted family friend, was found guilty of raping and murdering Laura at his home in Murton, County Durham, last August, after luring her away from her home. He claimed she had died after an innocent game of Cowboys and Indians had gone tragically wrong.

Bainbridge, had been working at the Kane home in Penshaw, near Sunderland, on the day he abducted her. He took Laura to his house, then raped and murdered her before burying her body under the living room floor and going out for a drink with Laura's mother Carol.

Her body lay undetected for 10 days - and Bainbridge kept in regular touch with Laura's anguished family during the search.

Detective Superintendent Steve Bolam, of Northumbria Police, who led the inquiry, described Bainbridge as a Walter Mitty character who lied to numerous people to gain their friendship.

"I think that he took Laura away with a sexual motive and once that had taken place he killed her to hide his tracks," he said. "He continued life as normal which shows how cold and calculating he was."

Bainbridge sat impassively in the dock as the jury returned its verdicts. Laura's friends and family cheered and wept in the public gallery, also crying for Laura's grandfather who died on Tuesday.

When Laura, who was described by friends as "outgoing and friendly", went missing in August last year, it prompted a huge police operation. During the search Bainbridge was questioned by police several times because he had been plastering an attic room at the Kane home shortly before she disappeared.

He persistently lied to police officers until 10 days after her disappearance he was arrested and Laura's partly decomposed body was found under the floorboards of his living room.

Bainbridge - whose girlfriend of nine years had recently given birth to a son - admitted to police she had died at his home but said that it was an accident. She suffocated while bound and gagged during an innocent game of Cowboys and Indians, he claimed.

On the eighth day of the trial the jury returned a unanimous verdict on a charge of murder and a majority verdict on the charge of rape.

Mr Justice Nelson reserved sentence until Monday after stating the case was one in which he would need to consider imposing a recommendation on how long Bainbridge should serve before being considered for release.

Speaking outside the court Mrs Kane told reporters: "I think that the jury today has come to the right conclusion but I'm a bit sad he hasn't got the sentence.

"I'm sorry that Laura's granddad, who died last night, wasn't here to know this decision. I don't think about Bainbridge at all. My thoughts are with me and my children. I just want to be left alone to grieve for Laura and my father."

Mrs Kane and Bainbridge had been introduced about four years before Laura's death at one of the local pubs where they both played darts.

While carrying out repairs on Mrs Kane's home, he gained her trust and on August 25 last year, took his chance.

He lured the little girl to his own house on the pretext of showing her his baby son. And it was there he carried out his barbaric act.

During the search Bainbridge was questioned by police several times because he had been plastering an attic room at the Kane home shortly before she disappeared. He persistently lied to police officers until 10 days after her disappearance he was arrested and Laura's partly decomposed body was found under the floorboards of his living room. Bainbridge - whose girlfriend of nine years had recently given birth to a son - admitted to police she had died at his home but said that it was an accident. She suffocated while bound and gagged during an innocent game of Cowboys and Indians, he claimed. On the eighth day of the trial the jury returned a unanimous verdict on a charge of murder and a majority verdict on the charge of rape. Mr Justice Nelson reserved sentence until Monday after stating the case was one in which he would need to consider imposing a recommendation on how long Bainbridge should serve before being considered for release. Speaking outside the court Mrs Kane told reporters: "I think that the jury today has come to the right conclusion but I'm a bit sad he hasn't got the sentence. "I'm sorry that Laura's granddad, who died last night, wasn't here to know this decision. I don't think about Bainbridge at all. My thoughts are with me and my children. I just want to be left alone to grieve for Laura and my father." Mrs Kane and Bainbridge had been introduced about four years before Laura's death at one of the local pubs where they both played darts. While carrying out repairs on Mrs Kane's home, he gained her trust and on August 25 last year, took his chance. He lured the little girl to his own house on the pretext of showing her his baby son. And it was there he carried out his barbaric act.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Anger at record SWT profits
fields.body:
Anger at record SWT profits

South West Trains yesterday announced record operating profits of £39m, the highest achieved by any train operator since privatisation four years ago.

The 16% increase from £34.4m last year was criticised by commuter groups, who accused SWT of putting profit before passengers.

Mike Hewitson, secretary of the rail passengers' committee for southern England, said: "We want to see a lot more money put into improving services."

SWT's announcement comes only a week after the shadow strategic rail authority disclosed that the company's performance had deteriorated by 5% in the second half of last year.

The company, which runs trains to the south-west in and out of Waterloo station in London, was fined £4m in penalty charges by the SSRA. These included late services and cancellations.

Later, reacting to passenger anger about the rail company's profits, Brian Cox, SWT's chairman, claimed that it could do nothing to relieve overcrowding without an injection of public funds. He said the entire rail infrastructure needed massive improvements. "The fundamental problem is that we are running every single train and there is no space to run any more," he said.

RJB confirms bid talks

Britain's biggest coal miner, RJB Mining, yesterday said it was in bid talks, but refused to say if it was discussing a management buyout or trade sale.

The troubled company - which is valued at £90m - disclosed the takeover talks at the same time as it announced a deal with cement producer Castle Cements for the supply of 300,000 tonnes of deep-mined coal. Industry sources said RJB could be of interest to a property company, given its extensive land bank of more than 40,000 acres, including existing and reclaimed mines and land affected by potential subsidence.

EC investigates music venture

The European Commission has decided to open a four-month inquiry into the planned music venture between Time Warner and EMI. The commission said the investigation's focus is likely to be on recorded music, music publishing and digital delivery of music via the internet.

Wallis joins Stagecoach

Stagecoach yesterday announced pre-tax profits of £244m, up 11%, and brought on board the former BAA head of finance, Russell Wallis, as a non-executive director to bolster the City's declining confidence in the company. The move was forced on Stagecoach after the worst 12 months in the company's 20-year history.

Keith Cochrane, Stagecoach's chief executive, stressed that its founder and chairman, Brian Souter, had no intention of stepping down from his executive role.

fields.headline: Fend off glamour warns Mendes
fields.trailText: Sam Mendes, the Oscar-winning director who brought the Hollywood actress, Nicole Kidman, to the London stage, last night warned that the theatre was in danger of being "held hostage by the lure of glamour".
fields.body:
Sam Mendes, the Oscar-winning director who brought the Hollywood actress, Nicole Kidman, to the London stage, last night warned that the theatre was in danger of being "held hostage by the lure of glamour".

The plea by the man who claims he unwittingly unleashed a media circus around his production of The Blue Room starring Kidman, comes as the West End is bristling with film stars. With the model Jerry Hall about to take over from Kathleen Turner as Mrs Robinson in The Graduate - a role that requires a much-hyped flash of nudity - and Julia Ormond about to join Ralph Fiennes and Linus Roache on the boards, his comments were construed as an attack on producers blinded by celebrity.

But Mendes, artistic director of the Donmar Warehouse, who won an Oscar for his film debut American Beauty, insisted that for him those great "fleeting moments of grace, emotion, truth and comedy" that only happen live on stage burn their way into the memory far more than anything he had ever seen on a screen.

"Moments that live on in my mental scrapbook are the first time Alan Cummings levelled his mischievous eyes on the audience of Cabaret," he said. "Or when Harold Pinter in The Collection ordered his orange juice as if picking a scab."

He claimed that he was merely trying to show how unique and precious theatre was in "an era of homogenised entertainment", where the same film was showing in every city in the world. He knew nothing of Hall's latest role when he made the remarks, he added.

"My comments were solely about ensuring that the British theatre is not held hostage by the lure of glamour every time it opens its doors."

The Blue Room became the hottest ticket in London and then on Broadway two years ago, largely on rumours of how much of Kidman was visible.

His comments, which were made at a meeting of the Covent Garden community association, amount to a defence of the value of theatre over film, which mirrors his own decision to direct a new play at the Donmar despite the pressure to cash in on his success by taking on another film.

"I'm sure I am not alone in that the majority of evenings spent in the theatre are disappointing. But when it works, it stays with you for a lifetime. All those moments live on in my memory, more vividly even than Charles Foster Kane's giant shadow or Butch and Sundance's final freeze-frame."

fields.headline: Bass falls to Interbrew
fields.trailText: Interbrew, the Belgian producer of Stella Artois, has leapfrogged its rivals to become the biggest brewer in Britain by buying Bass's beer operations for £2.3bn.
fields.body:
Interbrew, the Belgian producer of Stella Artois, has leapfrogged its rivals to become the biggest brewer in Britain by buying Bass's beer operations for £2.3bn.

The deal includes production of brands such as Carling, Tennent's and Caffrey's. It was announced just three weeks after Interbrew snapped up another chunk of Britain's beer heritage, buying Whitbread's brewing arm for £400m.

Once the two acquisitions are complete, Interbrew will control 32% of the country's beer market - putting it just ahead of the current leader, Scottish & Newcastle.

Interbrew's chief executive, Hugo Powell, tried to reduce fears that this could lead to less choice in pubs and off-licences.

Mr Powell said: "To be successful, we must build on local beers, brands and people. We already have 180 beers - we've found ways to make big brands flourish and little brands prosper."

Interbrew's purchase will need to be cleared by competition authorities in London and Brussels. Mr Powell said the company would argue that other brewers had been allowed to build much bigger market shares in other European countries.

"If you look at Europe, there is no other important market where the leading company has as little as 32%," he said.

The deal comprises six British breweries employing 4,100 people including operations in Burton-upon-Trent, Tadcaster, Birmingham and Belfast. Interbrew will also take on Bass's brewing interests in the Czech Republic.

Mr Powell would not make any commitment to keeping all the breweries open, saying Interbrew had only just gained access to detailed information about the business.

The transaction ends a long tradition history of brewing for Bass, which began making beer in Burton in 1777. The group intends to change its name and concentrate on hotels, pubs and restaurants.

Bass's chairman, Sir Ian Prosser, said: "There is a high degree of sadness about this, but our responsibility has to be with shareholders."

The sale price for the breweries was considerably higher than expected, pushing Bass's shares up 23.5p to 726.5p.

Sir Ian said the company's exit from brewing was due to changing drinking habits: "People are still drinking beer, but we've seen soft drinks and wines growing very rapidly recently."

He said the industry was consolidating rapidly and only the very biggest players were likely to remain successful.

The group is likely to spend the proceeds of the sale on another hotel brand - it already owns Inter-Continental, Holiday Inn and Crowne Plaza. Analysts believe that hotels are likely to become the group's core activity, rather than pubs and restaurants.

The Campaign for Real Ale responded cautiously to yesterday's news. A spokesman said: "We wouldn't condemn it out of hand because Interbrew have a good record of keeping different brands and styles of beer alive."

Interbrew has invited representatives from the campaign to meet Mr Powell.

Stuart Neame, chairman of the Independent Family Brewers of Britain, said he thought Interbrew would find it difficult to develop beers for British drinkers.

Analysts said the sale was the right strategic move for Bass. Nigel Parsons of WestLB Panmure said: "They did not have the scale or the brands to compete in the international beer market. They have got a phenomenal price."

webTitle: Poverty row author quits World Bank

fields.headline: Poverty row author quits World Bank
fields.standfirst: US treasury secretary accused of attempt to censor report
fields.trailText: A power struggle at the World Bank burst into the open yesterday after the British author of the global lender's forthcoming report on poverty resigned in protest at attempts by senior members of staff to water down his message.
fields.body:
A power struggle at the World Bank burst into the open yesterday after the British author of the global lender's forthcoming report on poverty resigned in protest at attempts by senior members of staff to water down his message.

In a move which exposes a deep intellectual rift at the heart of the Washington-based institution Ravi Kanbur, a highly respected development economist, quit amid claims that the US treasury secretary Larry Summers is seeking to rewrite this year's world development report to make it less radical.

Professor Kanbur, who was appointed from Cornell University in spring 1998 to act as the leading author of the report, is believed to have wanted to emphasise that economic growth alone will not be enough to reduce poverty and that it will also require equal emphasis on redistributive tax and spending policies.

But Prof Kanbur ran into opposition from the more orthodox economists from the World Bank who believe that growth is paramount.

"He was probably told: 'You are straying too far from the message'," said a former Bank employee who worked closely with Prof Kanbur.

The annual report, one of the cornerstones of global development policy, was being finalised after extensive consultations with governments, non-governmental organisations and researchers all over the world when it ran into opposition from the Bank's powerful research department.

"I suspect that Ravi is very concerned about letting down organisations and groups in volved in the consultation process," said the former bank employee. "He's taken the consultation exercise extremely seriously. If there's pressure on him to weaken his message he would be very unhappy."

Non-governmental organisations lept on Prof Ravi's resignation as evidence of a deeply entrenched free market bias at the Bank.

Alex Wilks, co-ordinator of the Bretton Woods Project, said: "Coming soon after Joe Stiglitz departed as chief economist this is a major blow for an institution trying to position itself as a 'knowledge bank' and a 'listening bank'.

"It raises questions of who really calls the shots and what evidence or opinions about the impacts of globalisation they are trying to suppress."

Kevin Watkins, of Oxfam, said the resignation represented the triumph of "the Neanderthal tendency" at the Bank. "It threatens to take the development debate back about two decades to a time when free market fundamentalism did so much to discredit the World Bank," he said.

Acknowledging the internal row the World Bank's chief spokeswoman, Caroline Anstey, said in a statement that Prof Ravi had repeatedly been given an assurance that the world development report would be objective and analytical but that "he himself felt at odds with some other voices in the Bank over emphasis".

A World Bank official denied that the institution was being leant on by Mr Summers.

"The world development report that is produced will represent the Bank's view, not the US treasury's or anyone else's," the source said.

fields.headline: In Darwin's footsteps
fields.standfirst:
Researchers are poised to announce the decoding of the human genome and hail the greatest scientific breakthrough of our age. But a quiet, insect-loving Oxford academic did much more to reveal how genes shape our life and behaviour. Andrew Brown on William Hamilton, the unsung genius of genetics

The ethics of genetics: special report
fields.trailText: Researchers are poised to announce the decoding of the human genome and hail the greatest scientific breakthrough of our age. But a quiet, insect-loving Oxford academic did much more to reveal how genes shape our life and behaviour. Andrew Brown on William Hamilton, the unsung genius of genetics
fields.body:
Any day now, one of two fiercely competing teams will announce that they have sequenced the human genome, and that this has been the greatest breakthrough in scientific understanding since Darwin; or perhaps even Newton, Copernicus, or the Big Bang. But one man, a scientist whom hardly anyone has heard of, did far more than the whole of the human genome project to discover why genes matter and how they might shape our destiny.

The human genome project is designed to discover the precise composition of tens of thousands of genes. Bill Hamilton, apparently a shy and forgetful Oxford don, was not concerned with what genes are made of, but with what they do, and how their interplay can shape the world. He tried to give biological answers to the large questions, such as, why is there sex? Why do we grow old? And, in the world that made his name, why do animals sacrifice their own interests for the good of others?

Hamilton was born in Cairo in 1936, the son of a civil engineer working in the Middle East, and died in April this year after contracting malaria on a Quixotic mission to collect chimpanzee faeces in the Congolese jungle. It was a characteristically brave and direct attempt to stand up an unpopular theory, in this case that the Aids epidemic was caused by a polio vaccination programme. He never shrank from physical effort or danger. As a teenager he blew the tips off two of his fingers while messing around with explosives (his father was a civil engineer). On a field trip in the Amazon he once jumped off the side of his boat to plug a leak with his finger, explaining afterwards that the ferocity of piranhas was much over-rated. He refused to wear a bicycle helmet even after being pitched through the windscreen of a car as he hurtled round Oxford.

Those are things that made him loved. What will ensure his fame was that in two papers of almost impenetrable mathematics published in 1964, he discovered the selfish gene. In the papers, he expressed mathematically the ways in which self-sacrificing behaviour among individual creatures would spread if it were caused by a gene which was shared by lots of relatives who in their turn benefited from the self-sacrifice.

It is less often noticed that the same theory explains with heartless and unanswerable elegance how selfish or gratuitously cruel impulses may spread and establish themselves if they turn out be more profitable to their bearer's genes than kindness would. Other great biologists, notably JBS Haldane, had seen that something of the sort must be true. Indeed, Haldane had turned a crude version of the idea into a pub joke. When asked, "Should I lay down my life for my brothers?", Haldane replied, "Yes, for three brothers, five uncles or nine first cousins."

But Hamilton gave this vague intuition solid mathematical backing and turned it into something other scientists could use to make predictions about the way any animal or even plant could behave and feel towards members of its own species.

It took some time for the implications of his discovery to sink in. They didn't hit the non-specialist public until the early 70s, when they formed part of the framework of EO Wilson's Sociobiology and Richard Dawkins's The Selfish Gene. Though they are now regarded as perhaps the most important development of evolutionary theory since Darwin, Hamilton's interests were almost incomprehensible to his teachers when he was a postgraduate student at the London School of Economics and University College London.

Years later, Hamilton wrote: "I am afraid I still feel rather resentful about the matter in a general way. I would have hoped that the purpose of Haldane's aphorism was precisely to encourage young men to take up the study of what he considered an important topic. Yet at University College, surrounded presumably by a number of scientists who had been primed in this way, all my own attempts to tell people that a principle of this kind was needed in biology and this was what I was working on were met by the sourest rebuffs - words to the effect that I was wasting my time, there was no such thing as genetic altruism, or, at best, total disinterest.

"I suppose it is understandable that a disciple without a master must expect a hard time and that statements that seem significant or humorous according to the hearer's mood when uttered by a famous scientist seem to be heretical and ridiculous pretension when uttered by a detached graduate student, but I can't help feeling that it is wrong that this should be so in a university. I also have in mind that I was a rather retiring kind of student who preferred to withdraw from people who found me ridiculous rather than argue back."

This came from a letter he wrote to John Maynard Smith, an older and almost equally distinguished biologist who had been one of the earliest champions of his ideas, but from whom he was for some years estranged because he believed that Maynard Smith had granted too much of the credit to Haldane for the ideas that Hamilton later developed. Later, Maynard Smith reproached himself for failing to recognise genius. But it is easy to understand how the student might have been overlooked.

Though he passionately wanted recognition, he did not care at all for cities, and at times appeared to have an overwhelming longing for absence. There is a note of aching nostalgia for the wilderness which breaks again and again through the story of his early struggles. As a poor student he walked everywhere he could: "I wanted to conjure and recreate somehow, below the bricks and mortar around me, the marshy fields that had once been there, the streams dividing them, and the heaths beneath - to seek, in short, the elemental forces underlying the city. Even a lonely child crying on the street did not tug my heart as hard as a bracken fern when I saw it, for example, in the valley of the stream once called the Fleet."

It was not just plants that moved him deeply. A passion for insects ran through his entire life. When he got his first job as a biologist, and moved to a bedsit near Windsor Great Park, it seemed to him a delightful bonus that it was infested with minute bacon beetles: "I should explain that I am generally fond of indoor insects, think of them like pets and generally see an advantage over pets in that they don't need to be fed." In some of his speculations about eugenics, it can seem that he cared as little for humans as he might for insects; but if that's true it should be said that he clearly loved insects. It would be more just to say that he thought nature cared as little for mankind as for insects, as any honest naturalist must do.

Even as a feted professor at Oxford, Hamilton had a quality of absence or self-effacement that was extraordinary. He spoke quietly, almost as if he were hesitant to remind you of something you already knew: my notes from talking to him in his office are almost incoherent, a little from awe, some perhaps from stupidity, but also because he seemed quite as happy to sit in silence as to talk. He was a tall man, extremely handsome, but carried himself like a hunter who would rather observe than be noticed.

Partly as a result of this he was almost unbearably lonely and isolated when he worked on his first papers. "Although supervised at the Galton Laboratory for two years, I never had a desk there - I think virtually no one I passed in the corridors or sat with in the library knew my name or what I was doing - most of the time I was extremely lonely," he wrote, years later, in the introduction to his collected papers. These make one of the most extraordinary books of the century, for they contain not just the science that gave him his place in history, but, in their prefaces, an autobiography in fragments written with an extraordinary clarity, warmth and intimacy.

If you stand in the Sanger Centre outside Cambridge and watch the display over the receptionist's desk, as it flickers a constantly moving line of letters representing the DNA sequence of the human genome as it is decoded, the letters might represent anything. Without huge training it is impossible to grasp their significance or why they excite people. But Hamilton's passions, refracted through his writing, never lacked significance or excitement. In his essays there is no gap between theoretical and emotional significance. He wrote as if the human microcosm and the macrocosm of all biology were transparently linked.

We don't think of scientists as particularly romantic figures, yet Hamilton's autobiographical fragments in Narrow Roads are intensely romantic in their sensibilities, because he sees humanity as essentially tragic and divided against itself. "As I write these words, even so as to be able to write them, I am pretending to a unity that, deep inside myself, I now know does not exist. I am fundamentally mixed, male with female, parent with offspring, warring segments of chromosome that interlocked in strife millions of years before Europe existed or saw any of the human violence that became later, for sure, embedded in my ancestry."

When I discovered his collected papers, I found them enchanting, and wrote a book off the back of the experience. And there is no doubt, from the fervour and warmth of his obituaries, that people who worked with him came to love him as well as to admire him.

The most moving quality in him, I think, was an extraordinary optimism which seemed to contradict everything in his professional life: as a biologist, his efforts were directed at showing that all hope, all passions of any sort, perhaps, were an illusion which go to serve the purposes of the genes. We think we act for our own reasons; but in reality we are merely keeping the score in a millennial battle of chromosomal fragments. This was the message of his science, which has been spread steadily around the world since 1964. Yet he believed in the reality of altruism. Indeed his death was in one sense a testimony to this faith. Perhaps he wrote his own epitaph when writing about his father, an engineer who built a road through Kurdistan which has been almost entirely destroyed in wars since then: "The effort that he made - not in the least made on behalf of kin, or expecting any tangible return - nevertheless made changes. The effect of true altruism like this is never lost completely."

Andrew Brown is the author of The Darwin Wars, published by Simon & Schuster. For futher information visit www.darwinwars.com
