But one man, a scientist whom hardly anyone has heard of, did far more than the whole of the human genome project to discover why genes matter and how they might shape our destiny. The human genome project is designed to discover the precise composition of tens of thousands of genes. Bill Hamilton, apparently a shy and forgetful Oxford don, was not concerned with what genes are made of, but with what they do, and how their interplay can shape the world. He tried to give biological answers to the large questions, such as, why is there sex? Why do we grow old? And, in the world that made his name, why do animals sacrifice their own interests for the good of others? Hamilton was born in Cairo in 1936, the son of a civil engineer working in the Middle East, and died in April this year after contracting malaria on a Quixotic mission to collect chimpanzee faeces in the Congolese jungle. It was a characteristically brave and direct attempt to stand up an unpopular theory, in this case that the Aids epidemic was caused by a polio vaccination programme. He never shrank from physical effort or danger. As a teenager he blew the tips off two of his fingers while messing around with explosives (his father was a civil engineer). On a field trip in the Amazon he once jumped off the side of his boat to plug a leak with his finger, explaining afterwards that the ferocity of piranhas was much over-rated. He refused to wear a bicycle helmet even after being pitched through the windscreen of a car as he hurtled round Oxford. Those are things that made him loved. What will ensure his fame was that in two papers of almost impenetrable mathematics published in 1964, he discovered the selfish gene. In the papers, he expressed mathematically the ways in which self-sacrificing behaviour among individual creatures would spread if it were caused by a gene which was shared by lots of relatives who in their turn benefited from the self-sacrifice. It is less often noticed that the same theory explains with heartless and unanswerable elegance how selfish or gratuitously cruel impulses may spread and establish themselves if they turn out be more profitable to their bearer's genes than kindness would. Other great biologists, notably JBS Haldane, had seen that something of the sort must be true. Indeed, Haldane had turned a crude version of the idea into a pub joke. When asked, "Should I lay down my life for my brothers?", Haldane replied, "Yes, for three brothers, five uncles or nine first cousins." But Hamilton gave this vague intuition solid mathematical backing and turned it into something other scientists could use to make predictions about the way any animal or even plant could behave and feel towards members of its own species. It took some time for the implications of his discovery to sink in. They didn't hit the non-specialist public until the early 70s, when they formed part of the framework of EO Wilson's Sociobiology and Richard Dawkins's The Selfish Gene. Though they are now regarded as perhaps the most important development of evolutionary theory since Darwin, Hamilton's interests were almost incomprehensible to his teachers when he was a postgraduate student at the London School of Economics and University College London. Years later, Hamilton wrote: "I am afraid I still feel rather resentful about the matter in a general way. I would have hoped that the purpose of Haldane's aphorism was precisely to encourage young men to take up the study of what he considered an important topic. Yet at University College, surrounded presumably by a number of scientists who had been primed in this way, all my own attempts to tell people that a principle of this kind was needed in biology and this was what I was working on were met by the sourest rebuffs - words to the effect that I was wasting my time, there was no such thing as genetic altruism, or, at best, total disinterest. "I suppose it is understandable that a disciple without a master must expect a hard time and that statements that seem significant or humorous according to the hearer's mood when uttered by a famous scientist seem to be heretical and ridiculous pretension when uttered by a detached graduate student, but I can't help feeling that it is wrong that this should be so in a university. I also have in mind that I was a rather retiring kind of student who preferred to withdraw from people who found me ridiculous rather than argue back." This came from a letter he wrote to John Maynard Smith, an older and almost equally distinguished biologist who had been one of the earliest champions of his ideas, but from whom he was for some years estranged because he believed that Maynard Smith had granted too much of the credit to Haldane for the ideas that Hamilton later developed. Later, Maynard Smith reproached himself for failing to recognise genius. But it is easy to understand how the student might have been overlooked. Though he passionately wanted recognition, he did not care at all for cities, and at times appeared to have an overwhelming longing for absence. There is a note of aching nostalgia for the wilderness which breaks again and again through the story of his early struggles. As a poor student he walked everywhere he could: "I wanted to conjure and recreate somehow, below the bricks and mortar around me, the marshy fields that had once been there, the streams dividing them, and the heaths beneath - to seek, in short, the elemental forces underlying the city. Even a lonely child crying on the street did not tug my heart as hard as a bracken fern when I saw it, for example, in the valley of the stream once called the Fleet." It was not just plants that moved him deeply. A passion for insects ran through his entire life. When he got his first job as a biologist, and moved to a bedsit near Windsor Great Park, it seemed to him a delightful bonus that it was infested with minute bacon beetles: "I should explain that I am generally fond of indoor insects, think of them like pets and generally see an advantage over pets in that they don't need to be fed." In some of his speculations about eugenics, it can seem that he cared as little for humans as he might for insects; but if that's true it should be said that he clearly loved insects. It would be more just to say that he thought nature cared as little for mankind as for insects, as any honest naturalist must do. Even as a feted professor at Oxford, Hamilton had a quality of absence or self-effacement that was extraordinary. He spoke quietly, almost as if he were hesitant to remind you of something you already knew: my notes from talking to him in his office are almost incoherent, a little from awe, some perhaps from stupidity, but also because he seemed quite as happy to sit in silence as to talk. He was a tall man, extremely handsome, but carried himself like a hunter who would rather observe than be noticed. Partly as a result of this he was almost unbearably lonely and isolated when he worked on his first papers. "Although supervised at the Galton Laboratory for two years, I never had a desk there - I think virtually no one I passed in the corridors or sat with in the library knew my name or what I was doing - most of the time I was extremely lonely," he wrote, years later, in the introduction to his collected papers. These make one of the most extraordinary books of the century, for they contain not just the science that gave him his place in history, but, in their prefaces, an autobiography in fragments written with an extraordinary clarity, warmth and intimacy. If you stand in the Sanger Centre outside Cambridge and watch the display over the receptionist's desk, as it flickers a constantly moving line of letters representing the DNA sequence of the human genome as it is decoded, the letters might represent anything. Without huge training it is impossible to grasp their significance or why they excite people. But Hamilton's passions, refracted through his writing, never lacked significance or excitement. In his essays there is no gap between theoretical and emotional significance. He wrote as if the human microcosm and the macrocosm of all biology were transparently linked. We don't think of scientists as particularly romantic figures, yet Hamilton's autobiographical fragments in Narrow Roads are intensely romantic in their sensibilities, because he sees humanity as essentially tragic and divided against itself. "As I write these words, even so as to be able to write them, I am pretending to a unity that, deep inside myself, I now know does not exist. I am fundamentally mixed, male with female, parent with offspring, warring segments of chromosome that interlocked in strife millions of years before Europe existed or saw any of the human violence that became later, for sure, embedded in my ancestry." When I discovered his collected papers, I found them enchanting, and wrote a book off the back of the experience. And there is no doubt, from the fervour and warmth of his obituaries, that people who worked with him came to love him as well as to admire him. The most moving quality in him, I think, was an extraordinary optimism which seemed to contradict everything in his professional life: as a biologist, his efforts were directed at showing that all hope, all passions of any sort, perhaps, were an illusion which go to serve the purposes of the genes. We think we act for our own reasons; but in reality we are merely keeping the score in a millennial battle of chromosomal fragments. This was the message of his science, which has been spread steadily around the world since 1964. Yet he believed in the reality of altruism. Indeed his death was in one sense a testimony to this faith. Perhaps he wrote his own epitaph when writing about his father, an engineer who built a road through Kurdistan which has been almost entirely destroyed in wars since then: "The effort that he made - not in the least made on behalf of kin, or expecting any tangible return - nevertheless made changes. The effect of true altruism like this is never lost completely." Andrew Brown is the author of The Darwin Wars, published by Simon & Schuster. For futher information visit www.darwinwars.com

webTitle: The local brew - all around the world

fields.headline: The local brew - all around the world
fields.trailText: Belgium's Interbrew describes itself as "the world's local brewer".
fields.body:
Belgium's Interbrew describes itself as "the world's local brewer".

Its acquisition of Bass Brewers, combined with its deal to buy Whitbread's beer business announced last month, will give it a product range from traditional bitters to so-called new world lagers.

Once the Bass and Whitbread deals are complete, Interbrew's brands will include:

Dos Equis

Hoegaarden

Labatt

Oranjeboom

Sol

Stella Artois

Boddingtons

Murphy's

Wadworth 6X

Trophy

Castle Eden

Flowers

Fuggles Imperial

Mackeson Stout

Carling

Tennent's

Worthington

Caffrey's

Grolsch

Bass Ale

... and, just in case that list of beers, ales, stouts and lagers was getting a bit much, the company also makes Hoopers Hooch alcoholic lemonade

webTitle: In the beer world, size matters

fields.headline: In the beer world, size matters
fields.standfirst: World leaders are all overseas
fields.trailText: In little more time than it takes to down a couple of jars of ale, a third of Britain's brewing industry has been sold to an overseas owner. Industry groups were keen to point the finger of blame yesterday and the biggest culprit - without much doubt - is the government.
fields.body:
In little more time than it takes to down a couple of jars of ale, a third of Britain's brewing industry has been sold to an overseas owner. Industry groups were keen to point the finger of blame yesterday and the biggest culprit - without much doubt - is the government.

Just three years ago Bass was keen to expand its brewing interests - so enthusiastic in fact that it agreed a £200m takeover of the Danish group, Carlsberg-Tetley.

That deal was stopped by the then trade secretary, Margaret Beckett, in a decision which helped earn her the nickname "Mrs Blockit". She overruled advice from the monopolies commission that it should be allowed in return for the sale of a few pubs.

That sent a signal to Britain's brewers that they would not be allowed to become world leaders, which was fatal for the future of the domestic industry.

In the beer world, even more than in other modern industries, size is becoming all-important. Overall beer consumption is not growing significantly - because many drinkers are switching to wines, spirits and alcopops. So the only way for companies to grow profits is through vastly expensive brand marketing campaigns to snatch drinkers' loyalty away from their rivals.

There was plenty of sentimental browbeating from drinkers' groups yesterday which bemoaned the fact that brewers are only interested in profits.

However, Britain's beer producers have been swimming against the tide. They have had to contend with the government's inexorable rises in tax - which have encouraged a lively trade in bootlegged beer from mainland Europe. The beer orders limited the number of pubs they could own, then Mrs Beckett forced them to scale down their ambitions to increase volumes.

Scottish & Newcastle is looking a little sad now, having lost its market leadership to Interbrew. Gossip in the industry suggests that it could cast an eye over Guinness - which is not considered central to the ambitions of its owner, Diageo. The government's view of such a move would be a test of its attitude towards the industry.

Synergy français

The rhetorical question was posed in these pages earlier this week as to what synergy the French combine Vivendi saw in its ragbag collection of water, electricity, trains, telecoms, internet and pay-TV businesses, now augmented by a 23% stake in Scoot.com. Yesterday we received an answer: a global media and communications group.

With Vivendi's utilities businesses being spun off - finally cutting ties with the old Générale des Eaux - the putative plan to takeover Seagram, stripping out the drinks concern and then bring in Canal Plus, could create the sort of rounded, forward-looking group that can actually stand alongside groups such as AOL Time Warner.

It promises to leave our homegrown British "media empires" looking like niche businesses scared to swim too far away from the beach.

Utility bathing

Yorkshire Water, for the moment part of Kelda Group, has clearly gone from the ridiculous to the sublime. This is the company where a former boss was caught having a bath at his mum's house over the county border while his own customers were struggling along under a water ban. Now it has popped up with a novel mutualisation plan, shifting its assets into a non-profit making body to be owned by Yorkshire's customers and setting up a new package of debt to finance the business.

The city - in this case Barclays Capital and Merrill Lynch, advising Kelda - may finally have found a way to make the "third way" pay.

The thinking here has been imported from the US, where water company assets owned by local authorities tend to be debt-financed. But for British water companies, the need to find a new approach has been hurried by the fact that firms such as Yorkshire have got themselves into a ridiculous push-pull with their regulator, Ian Byatt - the former constantly trying to extract value from customers and the latter trying to get the best deal for customers.

With the water firms always exaggerating the costs of running their business and Mr Byatt trying to second guess them, the result has been uncertainty among investors. The shares have collapsed and the cost of capital has risen.

Hence this new plan to replace equity completely with a well-structured long term debt package where, once fixed-rate investors have been paid, any further profits should genuinely flow back to Yorkshire's customers.

No doubt Mr Byatt will want to see the construction of a whole range of safeguards here, but in theory there is no reason why this sort of ownership-finance structure should not be applied to any business where there are strong infrastructure assets and a natural monopoly. Perhaps Ken Livingstone should give Kelda a call.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest coal miner, RJB Mining , saw its shares soar yesterday after it confirmed talks that could lead to an offer being made for the company. RJB's stock, which has underperformed the overall market by 95% over the past five years, hit an 11-month high of 62p, a gain of 29% on the day, before falling back to 59.5p.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest coal miner, RJB Mining , saw its shares soar yesterday after it confirmed talks that could lead to an offer being made for the company. RJB's stock, which has underperformed the overall market by 95% over the past five years, hit an 11-month high of 62p, a gain of 29% on the day, before falling back to 59.5p.

Most leading shares closed the session firm but off their day's highs after an early rally on Wall Street - prompted by benign consumer prices data - began to peter out, dealers said.

The FTSE 100 index closed the session 89.2 points higher at 6,536.3 while the Techmark could only manage a 27 point rise at 3,372.94.

Freeserve was the only major casualty after Schroder Salomon Smith Barney chopped its rating to "underperform" from "outperform", and set a down side 12-month price target of 350p. The shares duly fell 31p to 467.5p

Freeserve parent Dixons saw its shares bounce back 10.5p to 310p as Schroder Salomon repeated its "outperform" rating, with a 350p target.

The picture elsewhere among tech stocks and their cousins in media and telecoms was bright. Pearson rose 80p to £20.70, while BSkyB added 81p to £12.25 as investors guessed, rightly, that Rupert Murdoch would yet again control Premier League TV football rights.

WPP Group was up 32p at 907p on plans to invest £16m in five interactive projects. Carlton Communications was 30p higher at 800p.

Invensys added 9.5p to 234.5p, with ARM Holdings up 31p at 706p and FTSE 100 heavyweight Vodafone AirTouch up 9.5p to 327.5p.

Bass hogged the limelight in afternoon trade, up 23.5p at 726.5p, after the long-awaited confirmation of the sale of its brewing operations.

In the banking sector, Standard Chartered saw a return to favour, up 15p at 816p as Lehman Brothers rated the stock "outperform".

National Power , however, was under pressure, down 11.25p at 405p, after Goldman Sachs cut its rating.

Prudential fell back 13p to 952p as the market digested news that the group is planning to seek a listing in New York at the end of the month.

Otherwise, second line technology issues dominated on the leader board in line with Nasdaq's advance in early deals. Vocalis was up 25p at 230p as vague bid talk did the rounds, with some of the more speculative punters suggesting a US predator.

InterX gained 112.5p to £12.75, Fibernet was up 97.5p at £16.97.5, and Easynet rose 42.5p to 842.5p.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: BAE ready to cut jobs
fields.body:
BAE ready to cut jobs

Union leaders are braced for news of 3,500 job cuts among managers and other white collar staff at BAE Systems following its merger with Marconi last year.

The officials have been called to a briefing at BAE's head office in Hampshire today. The job cuts are likely to be across the firm's entire aerospace business.

BAE said it would seek savings of at least £275m when it merged with Marconi last year. The company is expected to seek volunteers for the job cuts and will stress that the recruitment of 2,000 senior engineers every year continues.

John Wall, national officer of the Manufacturing Science and Finance Union, said: "The merger meant that restructuring was going to be inevitable. However, we hope that the level of reduction will not be so great that it will damage the effectiveness of the company and the cooperation of unions."

PA

Railtrack rethink

Railtrack is having second thoughts about its £5.3bn project to develop the west coast main line between London and Glasgow, putting at risk Virgin's plans for 140 mph trains.

An insert in Railtrack's annual report yesterday said the company did not feel the second stage, to be built in 2002-05, "is necessarily the right project for the industry" and other options would be considered. Railtrack said last night the options were track widening and new paths for freight traffic. It said it was still committed to the project but was looking for further government assistance.
Keith Harper

Pru stalks US target

Prudential is joining the race to buy a US fund management group, using a $205m listing of its shares on the New York stock exchange set for later this month.

The insurance company is expected to use its US shares to help it make acquisitions in a hotly contested market, where European rivals such as Aegon and ING are already looking for deals.

Pru's chief executive, Jonathan Bloomer, has said that he would like to sell mu tual funds in the US - the equivalent of unit trusts.

The US share listing is also part of Pru's attempt to broaden its shareholder base. The shares are expected to start trading on June 28 and, while the $205m the Pru will raise through the sale would not fund a big acquisition, it might give the insurer a foothold in the US.

European insurance groups are increasingly anxious to expand in the US market because of the increasing numbers of wealthy Americans looking for ways to save. Raphael Soifer, a financial services consultant at Soifer Consultants, said the scramble among European companies to buy fund management groups was pushing up the price of potential targets.

To Prudential's advantage, however, is that it is more interested in a specialist mutual fund business than the big life firms being sought by European rivals.

Hat-trick for Merrill Lynch

Merrill Lynch was named leading broker for the third consecutive year at the annual Primark Extel analysts awards yesterday. Deutsche Bank took second place, with UBS Warburg third.

The event, at London's Guildhall, did throw up a surprise result in the fund manager category however when Merrill Lynch Investment Managers, formerly Mercury Asset Management, was knocked off top spot into third by America's Capital Group, who jumped from fifth place last year. Fidelity Investments moved up one place to second.

HSBC's engineering specialist, Charles Burrows, took the award for leading pan-European analyst and Hakan Ostling, a paper specialist at Goldman Sachs International, took second.

Charterhouse Securities led the field for rising star brokerages with Credit Lyonnais second and Investec Henderson Crosthwaite third.

Strategist Dhaval Joshi of Société Générale topped the poll in the rising star individual analyst category.

Punch bond raises £1.5bn

Punch Taverns, the privately owned group of 5,000 pubs, has raised nearly £1.5bn through a bond issue in the international debt market.

The refinancing comes a year after the company paid £2.75bn for Allied Domecq's estate of 3,500 outlets, including the Firkin and Scruffy Murphy chains.

Punch said the bond issue was to replace bridging finance put in place at the time of the acquisition. Punch is chaired by the former PizzaExpress executive, Hugh Osmond.
Jill Treanor in New York

fields.headline: Amnesty criticises asylum law
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The government's crackdown on asylum seekers was yesterday criticised by the human rights pressure group Amnesty International.
fields.body:
The government's crackdown on asylum seekers was yesterday criticised by the human rights pressure group Amnesty International.

In its annual report, Amnesty highlighted Labour's passing of the Immigration and Asylum Act last year as an "example of abuse".

Across the globe the Amnesty report said that the number of countries which are torturing people rose by 6% last year.

Amnesty received reports of 132 countries where torture was used on prisoners held by police or security forces, compared with 125 the year before.

It said that throughout Europe, torture and ill-treatment by police was the most widely reported human rights abuse. The report highlighted deaths in police custody in the UK, including that of Roger Sylvester in January, as having "disputed circumstances".

The murder of the lawyer, Rosemary Nelson, in Northern Ireland after death threats from loyalists was one case cited by the report.

Police investigations into the racist murders of Michael Menson and Ricky Reel caused "extreme concern" said Halya Gowan, who compiled the UK section of the report.

According to the survey, the worst torturing states included Saudi Arabia, Brazil and Turkey, and systematic torture in China formed part of the most wide-ranging crackdown on peaceful dissent for a decade.Press Association

fields.headline: Let William be, says Wakeham
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The chairman of the press complaints commission yesterday urged newspapers not to intrude on the privacy of Prince William while he remains at school.
fields.body:
The chairman of the press complaints commission yesterday urged newspapers not to intrude on the privacy of Prince William while he remains at school.

Lord Wakeham said that although the prince turned 18 on June 21 the newspaper industry's voluntary code of practice meant that he should remain "free from unnecessary intrusion" until he finishes at Eton at the end of the month.

His comments follow two rows between the Prince of Wales and the press involving photographs of Prince William. Last Friday, Prince Charles's press secretary, Sandy Henney, resigned after a dispute with the Daily Telegraph over copyright of the official photographs marking William's birthday, while on Monday St James's Palace urged the PCC to act over alleged intrusion into his privacy when the News of the World printed "unseen" photographs of him playing football and polo at Eton.

In yesterday's statement Lord Wakeham said William, who is sitting A-level exams, should not be photographed without the permission of the school authorities.

He said he hoped to set out guiding principles for the press to follow after the prince leaves school. In the past he has called for the code to be extended until William and his brother, Prince Harry, finish their fulltime education around the age of 21.

Lord Wakeham praised the "considerable restraint" shown by most newspapers in not intruding upon William's life at Eton, despite the "difficult circumstances" of recent days.

fields.headline: Transfusion row rocks Jehovah's Witnesses
fields.trailText: Jehovah's Witnesses are braced for a flood of litigation following a vote by church elders in New York which may allow members to accept blood transfusions in critical medical circumstances providing they repent afterwards.
fields.body:
Jehovah's Witnesses are braced for a flood of litigation following a vote by church elders in New York which may allow members to accept blood transfusions in critical medical circumstances providing they repent afterwards.

The revelation that transfusions might now be acceptable, apparently decided by the church's world governing body by a vote of eight to four at a secret meeting last month, caused anguish and astonishment to adherents that one of the central tenets of the faith - and the cause of death for thousands of members over the years - was being abandoned.

The decision means that members who accept transfusions may not be automatically expelled and shunned, so long as they repent and seek spiritual guidance.

The church fears that disaffected members whose relatives have died after refusing blood may now seek damages.

The witnesses' British headquarters at Watch Tower House in north London described the decision, which will be conveyed to members at Kingdom halls across the country by letter as "a minor procedural change".

Geoffrey Unwin, an author and former Jehovah's Witness specialising in writing about cults, who broke the story in Britain, said: "Witnesses are in a state of self denial at the moment. They will be shocked that the elders who are supposed to get their messages direct from God should have voted for a change like this.

"Countless thousands whose relatives have been allowed to die needlessly will be angered that this could now be changed by a bunch of old men hiding in a room in New York after supposedly talking to God. They must be terrified of litigation."

Jehovah's Witnesses believe that as life is a gift from God, blood should not be intermingled, taking their text from Acts chapter 15, verse 20, which instructs the faithful to abstain from things "polluted by contact with idols, from fornication, from anything that has been strangled and from blood."

The religion's 130,000 British adherents - among 6m worldwide - are not supposed to accept blood transfusions even if refusal results in their death.

In January Beverley Matthews, 33, of Stockport, Greater Manchester, died after refusing a blood transfusion and last week a teenager, Brent Bond, of Nottingham, accepted a transfusion only seconds before lapsing into unconsciousness after losing five pints of blood in a machete attack. The church said yesterday that he was not a Jehovah's Witness because he had not been baptised in the faith, although his mother who is a member, tried to prevent the operation.

Jehovah's Witnesses are well known for the strictness of their observance. Members do not give presents at Christmas or birthdays, exchange greetings with non-believers or allow their children to take part in games or plays at school. Even use of the internet is frowned upon.

The church insisted yesterday that the New York decision was clarification of existing rules and a simplification of the process of excommunication, though that came as a surprise to some witnesses.

Paul Gillies, the church's spokesman said: "If someone accepts a transfusion in a moment of weakness and then regrets it afterwards we can offer assistance, just as if they had committed adultery. But if they are no longer living by the rules they have excluded themselves.

"Nowadays the movement towards bloodless health care means we have had members who have had open heart surgery and liver transplants without using blood."

fields.headline: Arrest puts Putin on defensive
fields.standfirst:
International furore over detention of media mogul

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, said last night that he was worried about the summary arrest of one of his most powerful critics, the media mogul Vladimir Gusinsky.
fields.body:
The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, said last night that he was worried about the summary arrest of one of his most powerful critics, the media mogul Vladimir Gusinsky.

And he admitted he was being kept in the dark about the dramatic development in Moscow that yesterday had politicians, analysts, and journalists rehearsing their worst fears about the prospects for civil liberties in Russia.

On a tour taking him to Spain and today to Germany for a summit with Chancellor Gerhard Schröder, Mr Putin found his trip hijacked by the furore over Tuesday's sudden arrest of Mr Gusinsky, the well-connected owner of Russia's only independent media empire and of its biggest private television channel, NTV.

"I am worried," Mr Putin told journalists in Madrid last night after denying all knowledge of the case. A formidable coalition at home and abroad denounced the arrest and demanded an explanation. "I tried to contact the prosecutor general but I didn't succeed," Mr Putin declared lamely.

His remarks marked a change in tack. Earlier in the day, he had implied that Mr Gusinsky was liable for hundreds of millions of dollars of credits being underwritten by the state gas monopoly. On the surface, those comments had nothing to do with the prosecutor's office investigation into alleged embezzlement by Mr Gusinsky of $10m during the 1997 takeover of a St Petersburg television firm.

The fact that Mr Putin was out of the country when the drama erupted fuelled arguments over whether the president was the victim of a backroom plot by shadowy figures determined to call the shots in the young Putin administration, or the tacit accomplice in a manoeuvre to muzzle his critics and restore some of the repressions of the Soviet era.

Moscow was in uproar over the arrest of Mr Gusinsky and his incarceration in the Butyrka prison in the city. Mr Gusinsky's lawyers were allowed to visit him in jail yesterday after saying they were denied access on Tuesday. They announced the initiation of legal proceedings, alleging unlawful detention by the authorities.

The headquarters of Mr Gusinsky's Media-Most holding company were raided a month ago by squads of gun-wielding police in military fatigues and black masks. Mr Gusinsky sued and a Moscow magistrate ruled two weeks ago that the raid was illegal.

The mayor of Moscow, Yuri Luzhkov, said yesterday that with Russia under Mr Putin's rule, Moscow was becoming "a kind of evil empire" and offered to take Mr Gusinsky's place in jail while the authorities pursued their investigation.

A group of 17 leading Russian businessmen issued an open letter to the prosecutor general, demanding Mr Gusin sky's immediate release. "We believed we lived in a democratic country until yesterday," they said. "Today we have serious doubts."

The signatories included Rem Vyakhirev, the head of the gas monopoly Gazprom which Mr Putin suggested Mr Gusinsky was illegally exploiting to avoid repaying loans.

Another signatory was the powerful electricity monopoly chief, Anatoly Chubais, who said that the Gusinsky arrest was a huge political mistake that damaged Russia abroad and frightened hundreds of entrepreneurs across Russia.

Meanwhile, Russia's journalism union issued a statement deploring what it called a threat to press freedom.

The Gusinsky imbroglio resonated internationally, with the White House voicing concern for the freedom of the media in Russia, and Israeli ministers demanding the mag nate's release. Mr Gusinsky has an Israeli passport and business interests in Israel, as well as being a vice-president of the World Jewish Congress and the head of the Russian Jewish Congress.

The signatories to the letter conspicuously did not include Boris Berezovsky, Russia's other main media mogul who controls the country's biggest television channel and who has been locked in a bitter feud with Mr Gusinsky since 1996 when both men combined to use their media to campaign for Boris Yeltsin's re-election as president.

Mr Berezovsky could barely contain his glee at Mr Gusinsky's predicament. While saying that he took a "negative" view of the arrest, Mr Berezovsky added that his peer and rival was a "victim of his own plotting".

The two men are embroiled in various battles, including a dispute over the leadership of Russia's small but influential Jewish community. Mr Berezovsky is backing a grouping of ultra-orthodox Jews who on Tuesday declared their own leader as Russia's chief rabbi, despite the fact that there is already a chief rabbi, who is allied with Mr Gusinsky.

Alexander Voloshin, Mr Putin's chief of staff, is an intimate of Mr Berezovsky and is seen as the éminence grise behind the president's rapid rise to power over the past year. He was also Mr Yeltsin's chief of staff and is a bitter enemy of Mr Gusinsky who deploys his media interests to oppose the Kremlin.

Mr Voloshin was the focus of speculation yesterday that he had planned the "humiliation, intimidation of and revenge" against Mr Gusinsky, as one Russian journalist put it.

Mr Gusinsky alleged recently that Mr Voloshin offered him more than £60m to call off his media attacks on the Kremlin, while other Kremlin insiders have alleged that Mr Berezovsky wanted Mr Gusinsky killed and his media empire broken up.

webTitle: Foreign creativity pierces Brit art bubble

fields.headline: Foreign creativity pierces Brit art bubble
fields.standfirst: International composition and working background of shortlist suggests fascination with young British artists could have waned
fields.trailText: Rumour got it wrong for the 2000 Turner Prize. No Martin Creed (the hottest tip), no return of Mark Wallinger, no bad girl Sarah Lucas.
fields.body:
Rumour got it wrong for the 2000 Turner Prize. No Martin Creed (the hottest tip), no return of Mark Wallinger, no bad girl Sarah Lucas.

The shortlist comes as a surprise. Painters Glenn Brown and Michael Raedecker, installation artist Tomoko Takahashi and photographer Wolfgang Tillmans make for the freshest line-up for years.

I like this list, not least because there has been too much focus on the Britishness of the YBA phenomenon, and altogether too much focus on personality in the way in which British art is discussed. Some artists have never fitted the easily packaged phenomenon, and their work does not fit the easy formula.

Britain, and particularly London, has been a great place to make art over the past decade, and the art world has seen waves of incoming artists from abroad, all but eclipsed in the public eye by the media fascination with the YBAs and the spurious promotion of Cool Britannia. It is over. There are still questions and doubts: has Amsterdam-born Michael Raedecker, who won the first prize in last year's John Moores Painting Exhibition in Liverpool, really developed enough to be included?

Over and above the novel bits of sewing, the threads and woolly patches which disturb the surfaces of his otherwise somewhat reserved tonal paintings, his work seems to owe too much to Spanish painter, Miguel Barcelo, who also uses as lot of extraneous material along with paint, and to the psychological terrains of Peter Doig, a previous Turner nominee, rather than becoming thoroughly itself. He is bottom of my list.

Image homage

The second painter on the shortlist, Glen Brown, is best known for his flattened versions of the expressionist, painted-from-life figure paintings of Frank Auerbach. While Raedecker strives to attain originality, Brown questions the whole idea.

He has also appropriated images by Rembrandt and Fragonard. Auerbach's work is about a kind of existential, hard-won truth, while Brown's faithful copies render the older artist's thick oil paint as though it were a trompe-l'oeil reproduction.

He has also done the reverse - making sculpted, three dimensional heads based on Auerbach's images, as though made from super-thick oil paint. There is something deathly, oddly glistening, molten and intangible about Brown's paintings, which hover between the real and the reproduction. Auerbach is said to have found it odd that someone should spend so much time and effort duplicating his works.

The Salvador Dali Foundation, on the other hand, threatened to sue the artist when Brown showed a hyper-real version of Dali's painting the Great Masturbator at the Serpentine Gallery in London some years ago. Brown's work is concerned with the differences between the experience of actual art works - with all their physicality and lumps - and their widely disseminated reproductions. Too extreme to be merely academic, Brown's intelligent paintings are a strong second runner in this year's prize.

Chaos theory

Tomoko Takahashi's best known work is the huge, sprawling installation which filled part of the Saatchi Gallery in the New Neurotic Realism show last year. Busted photocopiers, ditched computers, old monitors, miles of electrical wiring, turntables and the detritus of the modern age filled the space. One had a sense of order and system in spite of the chaos.

Was the order to do with the original function of the objects, or was it sculptural? Did the spaghetti and trails of wiring have a purpose, or was it a kind of drawing?

Moving to Britain to escape the conservatism of Japanese society, Takahashi still relates her work to the ritual and order of the tea ceremony, as well as to the rampant consumerism of Japan. Hers is a complex relationship to technology, to consumerism, creativity and waste, which she treats as a kind of modern nature. But lots of artists have travelled this route before. A good third place.

German-born photographer Wolfgang Tillmans has the highest international profile of all the artists here. His images, casually pinned to the wall, range from snapshots of Concorde passing over his house, to large-format portraits; sexy images, landscapes and still lives, flowers and pets . It is as if his camera eats everything that comes his way.

Some images are highly autobiographical and personal, while an entire series, Soldiers (also on show in the British Art Show), is a display of media images of soldiers, represented by the artist as a kind of commentary on our ambivalent relationship to the armed forces.

The way he presents and juxtaposes his work is as important as the images themselves. It took me a long time to get into Tillmans's work - its apparent disregard of what makes a "good photograph". The more I see, the more the narrative unfolds, the more I realise he is dealing with shared experience.

Tillmans, I have little doubt, is the favourite for this year's Turner Prize, and my favourite too.

The contenders Fresh line-up

Wolfgang Tillmans (left)

Age 31

Nationality German

Although he popped up first in fashion magazines, Tillmans is no jumped-up snapper. While some of his pictures owe a debt to film-maker Wim Wenders, his portraits and a shot of Concorde passing over his home show all the signs of an original talent at work

Odds 6/4 favourite

Tomoko Takahashi

Age 34

Nationality Japanese

Reclusive, and so publicity-shy she refuses to be photographed, Takahashi is guaranteed to attract the most attention. The fact she uses turnips, cabbages and skip loads of rubbish in her installations will only add to her allure

Odds 9/4

Glenn Brown

Age 34

Nationality British

Made his name with witty, flattened down renditions of masterworks by painters including Dali, Van Gogh and Auerbach "which pose questions about authorship and status in art". Called his take on a Rembrandt portrait, I Lost My Heart to a Starship Trooper

Odds 3/1

Michael Raedecker

Age 37

Nationality Dutch

His trademark disturbing but beautifully made pictures using embroidery hark back to the dream landscapes of the renaissance Dutch landscape artists who painted "idealised views of Italy without ever going there or even seeing a mountain"

Odds 9/4

Betting odds: William Hill

fields.headline: Hare heaven
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Strathnairn
fields.body:
Strathnairn

Just beyond the burn at the bottom of the paddock there is a brown hare feeding, which means I can see it quite clearly from my study window. It normally feeds for a while and then shuffles forward a few inches and starts feeding again and I am able to watch it for short periods every day. Just occasionally it crosses to the side of the burn and trots down the slope only to go out of view into the taller vegetation that includes rushes and beds of yellow flag leaves with buds just forming on their tall stems.

Perhaps the hare is a jill and her leverets are on the side of the burn, although she is not likely to visit them during the day unless they squeal if danger threatens such as the pair of buzzards breeding on a cliff two fields away. Last week I was called out to a walled garden on the edge of the village to identify two mammals that had been found by a pair of dogs, although, fortunately, they had not harmed them. By the time I reached the garden, the two mammals had been put into a shoe box and they were on a shelf in a shed. I had forgotten how attractive young leverets can be, but told the gardener to put them back where they had been found and leave the garden as the jill would come back that evening to feed them and possibly move them on.

As if to indicate that brown hares can have their young at any time of the year, the following day I was driving towards Inverness when suddenly towards me came a three quarter grown hare obviously determined to keep on the road and heading straight for me. I stopped the car and went out and chased it down the road until it left the danger of the tarmac and this was amusing for the people in the village bus as it stopped to look at what I was doing!

One of the other highlights of the week has been the return of the house martins that are at this moment flying, along with sand martins and swallows, round the huge sycamores in the paddock. The trees' yellowish-green, long, hanging clusters of flowers are buzzing with a steady supply of insects. Five house martins nests are being built under the eaves - so far the artificial ones we erected have been ignored.

webTitle: Orthodox leader chastises Athens for identity crisis

fields.headline: Orthodox leader chastises Athens for identity crisis
fields.trailText: It could have been a scene out of a Byzantine play: hundreds of thousands of nuns, priests and ordinary Greeks, some holding icons, others waving flags, enraptured by the rousing words of a black-robed cleric pledging to stand his ground to the end.
fields.body:
It could have been a scene out of a Byzantine play: hundreds of thousands of nuns, priests and ordinary Greeks, some holding icons, others waving flags, enraptured by the rousing words of a black-robed cleric pledging to stand his ground to the end.

Last night, for the first time in the history of the EU's only Orthodox state, close to half a million faithful gathered in Salonika to hear Archbishop Christodoulos, their spiritual leader, denounce the government for pushing the country into an identity crisis.

"First we are Greek Orthodox and then European," said his holiness in language more in keeping with a political speech than that usually used by the church.

The decision by Greece's determinedly modernist prime minister, Costas Simitis, to drop the nation's long-cherished habit of stating religious beliefs on personal identity documents could now cost him dearly. Mr Simitis, a western-trained university professor, announced the reform by saying it was the only way of ensuring the fundamental human rights of all Greeks, not least Catholics, Jews and Muslims.

As thousands of protesters chanted "Greece means Orthodoxy", the archbishop said the decision to drop religious affiliation from identity cards - a reform much-heralded by Brussels - was tantamount to stripping Greeks of the essence of their being.

"I'm not here to turn you into fanatics," he boomed. "I am here to explain that this law is wrong - if the people, millions of people, are against it then it has to be withdrawn."

As the guardian of Hellenism through 400 dark years of Ottoman rule, the Orthodox church was inextricably bound up with the history and traditions of Greece, he said.

"It is part of the identity of this country," the leader thundered as faithful cheered from rooftops and some 80 bishops looked on. "People have said dreadful things about this rally - poison has come out of their mouths, but they must understand that we will not give up."

Human Rights groups have often complained of the discrimination suffered by religious minorities who are noticeably absent from the state and military arena in Greece, in sharp contrast to other EU countries. But the fervour with which the move has been met has surprised politicians.

Above all, clerics fear the identity crisis will be the beginning of a much wider campaign to separate the church, Greece's biggest landowner, from the state, as is the case elsewhere in the 15-nation European bloc.

Across the political spectrum, last night, there was growing concern that the archbishop's fighting spirit could ignite a civil war with hundreds of thousands taking to the streets in Athens.

"I hope tonight's message, this sea of people, will be heard in Athens," the archbishop warned. "We will be doing the same thing in the capital next week - may God be with us all."

fields.headline: Travellers face the palace boot
fields.trailText: They cannot read or write and so did not know where they had ended up, but the caravan loads of travellers who recently invaded a green belonging to the Queen have inadvertently pitched themselves into an eviction struggle with the crown.
fields.body:
They cannot read or write and so did not know where they had ended up, but the caravan loads of travellers who recently invaded a green belonging to the Queen have inadvertently pitched themselves into an eviction struggle with the crown.

Last Thursday, around 10 families were passing Hampton Court Green, in south-west London, when they took advantage of an open gate and moved in. By Monday, almost 60 caravans had moved on to the site, which has no electricity, running water or toilet facilities. Even now that their numbers have dwindled, the huddle of caravans makes a strange site on the green next to the gate of Hampton Court Palace, now in the midst of its annual music festival.

As the soprano strains of Jessye Norman drifted across the night, travelling children mingled the sounds with pop music played on car stereos.

Yesterday, 20 caravans remained as others took to the road again. Even with a greatly reduced number, the travellers are still causing concern to the crown. The Historic Royal Palaces has applied to Chris Smith, culture secretary, for a court order which will effectively evict the travellers from the Queen's property.

A spokesperson for Hampton Court Palace said the crown had applied for a public order notice for the travellers to quit the land and that they would be given reasonable notice to leave.

The green, which faces the palace gates, is usually used for fairs, cricket matches and picnics, and was once home for the workshops of Sir Christopher Wren, who re-modelled the palace interiors.

Its present tenants know that their time there is limited. Yesterday, the women mem bers of the remaining group - the men were "all out on business" - said they were on the green because they had nowhere else to go.

The matriarch of the group, who refused to be named, explained: "We don't know how to read and write and so we don't know how come we ended up here. The gate was open so we just piled in. Other people were passing and saw us and pulled in. We would move if the Queen said so, because she's the head of the country."

One woman explained that a number of the group were pregnant and one had given birth the night before. They did not want to move on because they had found a site with a hospital nearby.

While the older members of the group come from Ireland, most are British. "We were all born here," said one, in an accent that seemed a combination of Irish and minkers, the travellers' dialect.

"We are English citizens because we were born here. And we want somewhere to live here.

"We want to get the children schooling and then they will know the law. We don't know what rights we have to be here but we want to get the chil dren an education so that we will know."

The children were all over the site. A 10-year-old girl said: "I've been to school a few times. I don't know where but it was only for a few days. I want to go to school because it's boring here and I do nothing all day."

Local people want the travellers to move on. One woman working next to the green said she had been spat at by children and "it was quite disgusting".

She added: "They have no facilities and have been using the hedges and trees as toilets. The smell is appalling."

webTitle: MoD faces new demands to recant over Chinook crash

fields.headline: MoD faces new demands to recant over Chinook crash
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence yesterday came under renewed pressure to overturn its finding that pilot error caused the Chinook helicopter crash which killed 25 senior security and intelligence officers after Scotland's senior law officer cast doubt on its findings.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence yesterday came under renewed pressure to overturn its finding that pilot error caused the Chinook helicopter crash which killed 25 senior security and intelligence officers after Scotland's senior law officer cast doubt on its findings.

Colin Boyd QC, the lord advocate, said new information about faults in the helicopter's Fadec software "may be thought to reinforce" the inconclusive findings of a Scottish fatal accident inquiry into the crash on the Mull of Kintyre in June 1994.

That inquiry, and the initial findings of an RAF board of inquiry, concluded that it was impossible to pinpoint blame. However, two air marshals later ruled that the crash was caused by the "gross negli gence" of the two pilots, flight lieutenants Jonathan Tapper and Richard Cook.

Blaming pilots in this way has to pass the test of "no possible doubt whatsoever". But critics of the MoD, who include a growing number of MPs and the former defence secretary, Sir Malcolm Rifkind, say there is mounting evidence that this test has not been met.

Such evidence was not given to the inquiries.

Mr Boydsays that "new information about Fadec invites speculation as to another possible cause for the crash".

Documents obtained by Computer Weekly magazine show that the Fadec system had caused problems in Britain and the US - and that the MoD has given misleading information to the Commons defence committee.

The ministry told MPs that Boeing, makers of the Chinook, did not consider Fadec to be safety critical, but had said the opposite when it sued Textron Lycoming, the systems supplier, after an earlier accident.

The lord advocate's comments are contained in a letter to Kenny MacAskill MSP, who yesterday called for a judicial inquiry into the affair. Sir Malcolm said he hoped Mr Boyd's letter would lead the MoD to overturn its verdict. "I have always taken the view that the Ministry of Defence ought to allow the finding of gross negligence to lapse," he said.

John Spellar, armed forces minister, again insisted the pilots had been responsible, flying too fast and too low in fog in a hilly area.

However, Mike Tapper, father of one of the pilots, said: "The government would rather protect the elite within the MoD than to protect natural justice."

webTitle: Abortion ship angers Malta Abortion protest in Malta

fields.headline: Abortion ship angers Malta Abortion protest in Malta
fields.trailText: The Maltese government and the island's Catholic bishops reacted angrily yesterday to plans by a Dutch doctor to set up an abortion ship in international waters.
fields.body:
The Maltese government and the island's Catholic bishops reacted angrily yesterday to plans by a Dutch doctor to set up an abortion ship in international waters.

Rebecca Gomperts of Amsterdam announced that she planned to offer abortions on a ship moored in international waters close to countries where abortion is illegal, including Malta.

Lawrence Gonzi, the Maltese social policy minister, called the plan "horrendous". He said criminal proceedings would be undertaken against anyone organising or helping to arrange the service.

Malta's bishops issued a statement calling on the government and all those responsible to ensure that no one had anything to do with these "heinous murders".

The Maltese people are said to be strongly against abortion and all the island's political parties oppose it. It is claimed that some Maltese go abroad to have abortions.

webTitle: Rich men who give politicians the needle

fields.headline: Rich men who give politicians the needle
fields.standfirst: Yorkshire millionaire Paul Sykes is heir to a long tradition of wealthy figures who have made a heavy investment in political causes
fields.trailText: Euro-sceptic campaigner Paul Sykes is not the first rich man to dabble in politics. But he is not like most of the multi-millionaires who invest huge sums in politicians, parties or - the other traditional route to influence - the purchase of newspapers.
fields.body:
Euro-sceptic campaigner Paul Sykes is not the first rich man to dabble in politics. But he is not like most of the multi-millionaires who invest huge sums in politicians, parties or - the other traditional route to influence - the purchase of newspapers.

Some do it for political influence, like Lord Beaverbrook, who was simultaneously proprietor of the Daily Express and a member of the war cabinet. Some want to acquire social access or status. Tory treasurer Michael Ashcroft eventually got a peerage.

Others hope for financial benefit from political favours- Rupert Murdoch's usual approach. Many do it for a mixture of motives - or they just buy a football club.

Robert Maxwell tried the lot, including being an MP, and owning Oxford FC and the Daily Mirror. But buying directly into office is rarely an option, at least in Britain. US publisher Malcolm Forbes wasted $60m this year running for the presidency, and Ross Perot's Reform party candidacy cost George Bush enough votes in 1992 to elect Bill Clinton.

Paul Sykes, transparently honest and a touch naive, has no such ambition. A Yorkshire property developer and internet entrepreneur who made £350m, he may be one of a new breed which includes Brian Souter, the Stagecoach boss who financed last month's Scottish poll over repeal of section 28.

Such men are anxious to exploit the populist politics in which mass advertising, mailing shots and the internet - as well as referendums and proportional representation (PR) - give them a chance to influence great issues of the day without getting elected. It is cheaper than owning the Daily Beast and allows them to focus on a single issue. It helps to have money, but it is no guarantee of success.

Most North American states have regular referendums on guns, taxes and smoking, with big money populism busy on both sides. The great issue for the British right remains resistance to Euro-federalism.

But it is not just the right. Lord David Sainsbury's millions have funded moderate think tanks for David Owen and now Tony Blair. New Labour's symbolic campaign to rewrite Clause IV through a party referendum in 1996 could not have been won without private funds. The Brownite Geoffrey Robinson MP's cash still underwrites the New Statesman.

Quick to spot a trend, the late Sir James Goldsmith, a global tycoon, pioneered the latest wave. In the 1975 he helped fund the Yes campaign in the In or Out of Europe referendum.

At the same time he was funding his brother Teddy's pioneering ecology campaigning. He stuck to his Green beliefs, but switched on Europe. The Referendum Party was created to bully both main par ties into committing themselves to holding a referendum on the single currency.

It succeeded in bouncing Tony Blair into his promise. In the 1997 election Goldsmith candidates took 810,000 votes, or 3%, and cost up to 20 Tory MPs their seats.

Boosted by his protectionist book, The Trap, he won election as a French MEP. But he showed no aptitude for politics. When he faded, Paul Sykes took up the Euro-standard, with the Democracy Movement, which now boasts 200,000 members and 170 branches.

Thanks to William Hague's speech in Llandudno last weekend, pledging multiple referendums on Europe, Mr Sykes and his chequebook are now virtually back in the Tory camp, although the wider Democracy Movement has gone its separate way.

There is no telling where it will end. In Italy big business is accustomed to bribing politicians, but media magnate Silvio Berlusconi knew he risked jail if the left won. So he cut out the middleman and got elected prime minister himself.

It didn't work for long, but 10 years on, his Forza Italia has become a proper party and he is poised to regain the premiership.

Who's who

Brian Souter : Ex-bus conductor, owner of a big chunk of Britain's bus fleet. Wooed by Labour as a "Champion of Change" but helps fund the SNP. Favours union rights, but not homosexuality. Funded Scotland's unofficial referendum to prevent repeal of Section 28

Michael Ashcroft : Took his talents to Florida and Belize in the '80s, where his local influence on the banking system won friends and enemies. Took up Tory politics as treasurer and chief donor in the Hague years. In return for assuming UK residence again, finally got his peerage

Sir James Goldsmith : Arrogant Old Etonian drop-out, who ran off with an heiress, made great fortunes, bullied and dazzled the world's politicians. Got his knighthood from Labour, but loved Margaret Thatcher.Dangerous, but now dead.

Greece's former king, Constantine, yesterday took his battle to the European Court of Human Rights to retrieve estates seized in 1994 by the Socialist government.

Supported by his sister, Queen Sophia of Spain, and three of his five children, the exiled former monarch made an impassioned plea at the Strasbourg tribunal to have the property - believed to be worth almost £80m - returned to his family.

"Our claim is for the return of what is rightfully ours: our home, our personal belongings, our property, the ability to pay homage to the graves of our ancestors," said Constantine, 60, who has lived in Hampstead, north London, since being forced out of Greece in 1967. "If the government refuses to return these things to us, our only remedy is fair and just compensations for what the state has wrongfully taken from us."

The 34,000 acres of land include a huge estate outside Athens, and Mon Repos, the exquisite former royal summer palace on Corfu where the Duke of Edinburgh was born.

Constantine, who was stripped of his Greek citizenship, said his case was important to every European citizen. "The injustice we have suffered could be suffered by any victim of the misuse of the powers of the state," he said. Even as an ex-king, he argued, he had the right to ownership as guaranteed by the European convention on human rights.

"We have faith in the European court and hope and believe that justice will at last be done."

Constantine, who was deposed by referendum at the end of seven years of military dictatorship in 1974, filed the claim after Greece's supreme court upheld the constitutionality of the 1994 law under which the property was seized.

The Socialist government, then led by Andreas Papandreou, confiscated the property in fear that it would be used by Constantine to one day re-establish his family in Greece. The Socialists, who are now headed by the reform-minded Costas Simitis, also argued that the former king owed it in lieu of taxes.

Constantine, who was chased out of Greece by gunboats and fighter jets when he visited the country by yacht in 1993, says that unlike most Greeks he always paid his taxes.

webTitle: Tougher law urged on sexist chanting

fields.headline: Tougher law urged on sexist chanting
fields.trailText: Sexist chanting by football fans should be specifically outlawed, ministers were told yesterday after the England midfielder David Beckham endured offensive comments about his wife following a Euro 2000 match.
fields.body:
Sexist chanting by football fans should be specifically outlawed, ministers were told yesterday after the England midfielder David Beckham endured offensive comments about his wife following a Euro 2000 match.

The GMB union urged the creation of a new offence banning sexist abuse in the stands, along the lines of recent legislation strengthening the law against racist chanting.

The Football Association backed calls for a debate on toughening the law against sexist insults, pointing to the growing number of women officials at matches and to the fact that women's football is to turn professional in three years.

The FA and the England coach, Kevin Keegan, came to the defence of Beckham after he made a hand gesture to fans taunting him after his team's defeat by Portugal on Monday night. Reports yesterday said the abuse had included the insult "Your wife's a whore", as well as remarks about his son.

Current legislation bans abuse from the stands at football matches, but - with the exception of racism - the definitions are essentially broad.

The Football (Offences) Act 1991 forbids "chanting of an indecent or racialist nature" at matches, and provides a wide definition of racism. However, amid concern that the law was failing to curb offenders, it was tightened by the 1999 Football (Offences and Disorder) Act to "reflect the seriousness with which this offence [racist abuse] is regarded" and to recommend that "enforcement action" be taken.

The GMB, which sponsors a string of women's soccer teams, argues that sexist abuse should be similarly singled out as unacceptable. Its equal opportunities officer, Karen Constantine, said there was no reason why the law on racist chanting "should not be extended to chanting that is offensive to women...at a time when more and more women are attending football matches and the authorities are trying to promote football as a family sport."

The FA said: "The debate is a valid one, and now is a good time for it".

The number of accredited women officials in the UK stands at around 400, though it remains a handful of the 30,000 total. But their profile is rising, particularly with the selection of Wendy Toms as the only British referee in this year's Olympics.

The Home Office last night said existing legislation already outlawed sexist abuse. A spokeswoman said the reference to "indecent" chanting in the 1991 Act covered sexist remarks, backing up the 1986 Public Order Act, which outlaws "threatening, abusive or insulting behaviour".

webTitle: MP's scream sees off armed burglar

fields.headline: MP's scream sees off armed burglar
fields.trailText: A pregnant Conservative MP described how she faced "a woman's worst nightmare" when she awoke to find a burglar with a knife in her bedroom.
fields.body:
A pregnant Conservative MP described how she faced "a woman's worst nightmare" when she awoke to find a burglar with a knife in her bedroom.

Julie Kirkbride scared off the intruder when she screamed, after he broke into the Westminster home she shares with her husband, the shadow Northern Ireland secretary, Andrew Mackay.

Ms Kirkbride, 40, who is five months pregnant, woke to find the burglar in her bedroom at 5am on Tuesday. Mr Mackay was away campaigning in Scotland.

When she started screaming, the intruder repeatedly shouted at her to "shut up" before fleeing. She said: "Waking up to find a knife carrying intruder in your bedroom is probably a woman's worst nightmare. Mercifully, he ran away at the sound of my blood curdling screams. I feel shocked, but you have to try to put dreadful incidents like this behind you."

Mr Mackay's son, Hamish, 23, rushed out of his bedroom but was too late to catch the burglar. Neighbours also went to the MP's aid.

Police arrived only minutes after the thief got away with a few items of low value.

Mr MacKay said: "Julie was very brave, and I'm just relieved she and Hamish were unhurt...Fortunately, this guy's intent was burglary, but he could have attacked her. I suppose it was a good thing that I wasn't there because I would probably have had a go."

He added: "We hope this dangerous youth is soon caught and put behind bars for a long time, where he can no longer prey on innocent women."

The burglary has raised questions about security at the couple's home, which has since been stepped up. The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, has a 24-hour armed guard at his Notting Hill home, even when he is away.

Ms Kirkbride, MP for Bromsgrove, went to the Commons on Tuesday.

In January, the Liberal Democrat MP Nigel Jones was attacked by a man with a sword in his Cheltenham constituency office. His assistant, councillor Andrew Pennington, died in the attack.

webTitle: Beans back on England team menu

fields.headline: Beans back on England team menu
fields.trailText: They could prove to be the weapon that will help England secure victory against Germany this Saturday and keep the Euro 2000 dream alive.
fields.body:
They could prove to be the weapon that will help England secure victory against Germany this Saturday and keep the Euro 2000 dream alive.

Baked beans are back on the menu for England's footballers after being shown the red card during the World Cup in France in 1998.

England coach Kevin Keegan has decided to select baked beans for the team menu and dozens of tins have been brought out to Belgium following advice from nutritionists that they are healthy and could contribute to the overall fitness of players.

Keegan's predecessor, Glenn Hoddle, banned baked beans during France '98 claiming that they were bad for the health because there was too much sugar in them.

The England team chef, Roger Narbett, revealed however that Keegan has ordered that players cannot eat baked beans on match days for fear that it might effect their performance.

Mr Narbett, who has worked with the England team for 10 years, said: " They [the players] just don't have them on match days. I purchased them and brought them out with me in case you can't get them over here and I have brought vanilla essence for the rice puddings and things like that."

fields.headline: Police gunned down by driver
fields.trailText: Three policemen were killed and another was seriously injured when a driver who was stopped for not wearing a seatbelt opened fire twice from his car yesterday in the western German city of Dortmund, police said.
fields.body:
Three policemen were killed and another was seriously injured when a driver who was stopped for not wearing a seatbelt opened fire twice from his car yesterday in the western German city of Dortmund, police said.

The man was found hours later in a wooded area with a gunshot wound to his head, having apparently tried to commit suicide. He died soon after.

Heiko Artkaemper of the Dortmund prosecutor's office said it appeared the man was afraid that the police would discover that he was driving without a licence.

Police said the man, 31, opened fire without warning after his black BMW was stopped yesterday morning when two patrolmen noticed he was not using his seatbelt. He killed a 36-year-old officer with a shot to the head and seriously wounded his partner.

The man took off, but was stopped about half an hour later about 12 miles away at another police control point. Again he opened fire. Two policemen were hit in the head and died soon after.

While a statewide search was under way for the car, a passer-by noticed it parked in a wooded area and called police, who approached cautiously - not only because of the shootings but also because an urgent search of the man's apartment turned up guns and a hand grenade.

They found him alive, but seriously injured.

Mr Artkaemper said the suspect's driving licence had been revoked in April, but he did not have a police record or a permit to own a gun. He had been identified through his vehicle's licence plate.

The three deaths raise to six the number of policemen killed in the past 12 months while on duty in the state of North Rhine-Westphalia.

fields.headline: Gore eyes death penalty reform
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Al Gore signalled that he was willing to consider a review of how the death penalty is imposed in the US, it was reported yesterday, after a string of reports suggested that errors were common and that innocent people may have been, and may be about to be, executed.
fields.body:
Al Gore signalled that he was willing to consider a review of how the death penalty is imposed in the US, it was reported yesterday, after a string of reports suggested that errors were common and that innocent people may have been, and may be about to be, executed.

Starting a media offensive aimed at setting out his policy initiatives, the vice-president's first substantive remarks on the death penalty in the campaign for the US presidency were made to a group of editors at the New York Times.

His principal emphasis was on the economy, which the Gore camp believes is his strong suit after eight years of continuous economic expansion. Mr Gore promised to pay off the national debt by 2012, while ensuring greater expenditure on education, healthcare and the environment.

His remarks on the death penalty suggested that the sense of unease about miscarriages of justice among lawyers and human rights advocates was beginning to spread to presidential politics. Mr Gore restated his support for the death penalty in principle, but admitted he was concerned about a series of recent events, such as the moratorium on executions in Illinois after 13 death-row inmates were exonerated, and a recent Columbia University study which found that two-thirds of death penalties are overturned because of errors in capital trials.

"If there is a study that shows a large number of mistakes, that has to make you uncomfortable," the vice-president said. "I have assumed up until very recently that the mistakes were rare and unusual."

"If further investigation shows that the Columbia estimates are correct," he said, "then that will have a major impact on the way the country feels about, not necessarily the death penalty itself, but certainly the way in which our judicial system is arriving at these conclusions."

webTitle: DNA may solve French murder epic

fields.headline: DNA may solve French murder epic
fields.trailText: A possible trace of saliva on a stamp sent 16 years ago could solve one of France's most reported murder mysteries - the killing of four-year-old Grégory Villemin, who was bound, blindfolded and thrown into a river in eastern France.
fields.body:
A possible trace of saliva on a stamp sent 16 years ago could solve one of France's most reported murder mysteries - the killing of four-year-old Grégory Villemin, who was bound, blindfolded and thrown into a river in eastern France.

An appeal court in Dijon yesterday ordered the reopening of the case in which his mother, Christine, was originally charged with the murder in October 1984 and not cleared until nine years later.

Her family successfully demanded that DNA tests be carried out on the torn stamp stuck to one of hundreds of threatening letters sent to Christine or her parents in an anonymous mail campaign.

The "corbeau", or crow, terrorised Lépanges on the river Vologne in the Vosges for more than three years with a flood of poison-pen letters and telephone calls, but has never been traced.

At the time, police forced hundreds of men and women to undergo handwriting tests without success and compared their voices with the recorded messages made by a disguised voice. Suspicion has hung over the small village, with its cotton mill and smallholdings, ever since.

Dozens of books, articles and broadcasts failed to break the silence of an introverted, feuding village in which Grégory's grandfather was accused by the letter-writer of being a tyrannical mill foreman. Police believe that a family member also had a grudge against Christine, who was wrongly alleged by the "corbeau" to have drowned the child because he had been conceived during an extra-marital affair.

Although she stuck to emphatic denials until she was cleared by a judge, Christine was also designated as the murderer by the writer Marguerite Duras, who carried out her own investigation into the affair.

The case had many twists including the murder of a cousin, Bernard Laroche, by Christine's husband, Jean-Marie Villemin, the sacking of an examining magistrate for pursuing a murder verdict against Christine on instinct alone, and criticism of the national and international press for encouraging her vilification.

The Dijon appeal court overruled an official decision to close the case in 1993 after being told of recent advances in DNA detection.

The Dijon judges were told that a running feud in the Villemin family had been temporarily suspended so that a joint application could be made for the torn stamp, taken from a letter sent six months before the murder, to be examined by police scientists.

They had been assured that even the tiniest genetic imprint would be enough to point the finger at the true killer, who is still thought to be a member of the family.
