webTitle: Schröder seeks end to nuclear power

fields.headline: Schröder seeks end to nuclear power
fields.standfirst: Radical Greens and German states threaten deal as chancellor begins talks with electricity firms
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gerhard Schröder was last night within sight of an historic deal to shut down Germany's nuclear energy industry - the fourth largest in the world.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gerhard Schröder was last night within sight of an historic deal to shut down Germany's nuclear energy industry - the fourth largest in the world.

The agreement under discussion with electricity bosses would remove more than 6% of global atomic power capacity and, within five years, put an end to the reprocessing of German nuclear fuel.

As Mr Schröder began talks expected to last late into the night, his spokesman said the chancellor was optimistic that the "exceptionally intensive and well-prepared" negotiations would end "positively in the sense of a consensus".

A nuclear shutdown was put on the government's agenda by the Greens when they joined Mr Schröder's Social Democrats in a coalition after the 1998 general election. But the expected deal fell far short of their initial demand for an immediate cessation.

Though the issue of how long to wait was at the nub of the last round of talks, the last switch is not thought likely to be thrown for at least 20 years. However, a Green MP, Reinhard Loske, said last night that Germany could be nuclear-free by 2019. He added that the earliest, oldest reactors to be shut could be off-stream before the next election in 2002.

That presupposes that any deal with the companies will survive. It faces not only resistance from radical Greens, who see it as a shabby compromise, but also the threat of legal challenges from regional governments which have a stake in the atomic energy business. In addition, the conservative opposition has threatened to block any deal in the upper house of parliament. Mr Schröder has said he is confident that a bill could be drawn up which would not need to go to both chambers.

The threat of lawsuits lay behind the government's search for a compromise, launched 18 months ago. The companies had promised to sue for losses if they were forced to close down the reactors before recovering their investment.

Last year, according to figures supplied by the International Atomic Energy Agency, Germany's 19 reactors generated almost a third of the country's electricity. Only the US, France and Japan had a greater nuclear capacity.

Opponents of the shutdown have argued that by scrapping atomic energy Germany could end up burning more fossil fuels, thus endangering the environment in other ways.

A draft agreement between the government and industry, leaked last week, would put the nuclear business into a progressively narrowing tunnel. It would set a fixed amount of power to be produced by each plant from January 1 this year until its decommissioning. The power companies would report the monthly amount of power generated by each plant to Germany's nuclear safety authority, which would then subtract that amount from the total allowed. But generating entitlements could be transferred between reactors, allowing the industry to maximise the output from the newer, more efficient stations and minimise production from the older and less efficient ones.

The draft was reportedly prepared in mid-April but was delayed by disagreements over the fate of the Mülheim-Kärlich plant, which was mothballed in 1988 as an earthquake security measure after just 13 months of service.

Crucially, the document left blank both the date by which the last plant would be shut down and the amount of power each plant was entitled to generate before being shut.

On the question of waste, however, it was plain: the utility companies would be expected within five years to set up temporary storage sites as close as possible to the power plants. The transport of nuclear waste for reprocessing would be allowed until July 1 2005, but the utility companies would be under an obligation to do everything they could to end reprocessing as soon as possible.

This aspect of the deal is crucial for Britain and British Nuclear Fuels Limited. In March, Germany, BNFL's second biggest customer after Japan, suspended indefinitely on safety grounds all contracts to buy reprocessed fuel from the company.

The four major German power companies - RWE, Viag, Veba and Energie Baden-Württemberg - were all represented at last night's session at the chancellery. Among signs pointing to a deal was the calling of a press conference today at which Mr Schröder was due to appear alongside his environment minister, Jürgen Trittin, and the economics minister, Werner Müller.

One of the biggest and earliest challenges to the proposed deal is a Greens' congress in little over a week's time, which could instruct party leaders to reject the compromise. Some Greens have called for a break-up of their party's coalition with the Social Democrats if the exit from nuclear power is not swift enough.

Officials of the regional administration in Bavaria said meanwhile that they were already drawing up an appeal against the deal, which they intended to put before the constitutional court.

It would set a fixed amount of power to be produced by each plant from January 1 this year until its decommissioning. The power companies would report the monthly amount of power generated by each plant to Germany's nuclear safety authority, which would then subtract that amount from the total allowed. But generating entitlements could be transferred between reactors, allowing the industry to maximise the output from the newer, more efficient stations and minimise production from the older and less efficient ones. The draft was reportedly prepared in mid-April but was delayed by disagreements over the fate of the Mülheim-Kärlich plant, which was mothballed in 1988 as an earthquake security measure after just 13 months of service. Crucially, the document left blank both the date by which the last plant would be shut down and the amount of power each plant was entitled to generate before being shut. On the question of waste, however, it was plain: the utility companies would be expected within five years to set up temporary storage sites as close as possible to the power plants. The transport of nuclear waste for reprocessing would be allowed until July 1 2005, but the utility companies would be under an obligation to do everything they could to end reprocessing as soon as possible. This aspect of the deal is crucial for Britain and British Nuclear Fuels Limited. In March, Germany, BNFL's second biggest customer after Japan, suspended indefinitely on safety grounds all contracts to buy reprocessed fuel from the company. The four major German power companies - RWE, Viag, Veba and Energie Baden-Württemberg - were all represented at last night's session at the chancellery. Among signs pointing to a deal was the calling of a press conference today at which Mr Schröder was due to appear alongside his environment minister, Jürgen Trittin, and the economics minister, Werner Müller. One of the biggest and earliest challenges to the proposed deal is a Greens' congress in little over a week's time, which could instruct party leaders to reject the compromise. Some Greens have called for a break-up of their party's coalition with the Social Democrats if the exit from nuclear power is not swift enough. Officials of the regional administration in Bavaria said meanwhile that they were already drawing up an appeal against the deal, which they intended to put before the constitutional court.

fields.headline: Heritage alarm
fields.standfirst: Warning on historic public buildings
fields.trailText: Local authorities were warned yesterday to put their houses in order - as well as their town halls, magistrates' courts, guildhalls and libraries - by the chairman of English Heritage.
fields.body:
Local authorities were warned yesterday to put their houses in order - as well as their town halls, magistrates' courts, guildhalls and libraries - by the chairman of English Heritage.

Sir Neil Cossons said hundreds of historic public buildings were standing empty and semi-derelict, often as a result of local authority reorganisation.

He was speaking at the launch of English Heritage's annual buildings at risk register, which shows that 1,625 buildings listed grade I and grade II* are at risk. The number has slightly increased in the past year: 109 buildings have been removed, but there have been 141 new entries. Of these one in five is regarded as a disaster in the making, an important building in danger of destruction, with no agreement on how to rescue it.

Sir Neil pointed out that redundant civic buildings made up one in six of those on the register.

"We must act to save England's civic and public buildings at risk before it is too late," he said. "This is not a finger pointing exercise: we recognise the real challenge this presents to local authorities and other public owners, particularly in terms of the onus it places on overstretched resources."

English Heritage has allocated listed building repair grants of £6.6m this year.

fields.headline: Pregnancy disorder examined
fields.trailText: British researchers could be on the track of treatment for a disorder that affects one first pregnancy in 10 worldwide. A University of Reading team has identified a protein which could give early warning of pre-eclampsia, they report in Nature today.
fields.body:
British researchers could be on the track of treatment for a disorder that affects one first pregnancy in 10 worldwide. A University of Reading team has identified a protein which could give early warning of pre-eclampsia, they report in Nature today.

Pre-eclampsia causes a mother's blood pressure to rise to dangerous levels. It can lead to eclampsia, associated with convulsions, and thus to the death of mother or foetus, or both. The only treatment is a caesarean birth, but premature babies are at risk.

Philip Lowry and his team report that the protein neurokinin B, secreted by the placenta, increases significantly in mothers when pre-eclampsia develops. High levels can be detected as early as nine weeks, so women could be screened for the condition before symptoms become obvious.

The researchers say a drug already available could be used to block the protein's action, but studies would be needed first to test the drug's potential.

webTitle: Two Koreas toast historic friendship pact

fields.headline: Two Koreas toast historic friendship pact
fields.standfirst:
Summit ends with northern leader agreeing to visit Seoul
Korea: special report
fields.trailText: North and South Korea signed a path-breaking agreement last night after a whirlwind courtship of less than two days. President Kim Dae-jung and the northern leader, Kim Jong-il, raised clasped hands together in a victory sign. Kim Jong-il then led the toast, draining his glass with zest, and his guest followed suit.
fields.body:
North and South Korea signed a path-breaking agreement last night after a whirlwind courtship of less than two days. President Kim Dae-jung and the northern leader, Kim Jong-il, raised clasped hands together in a victory sign. Kim Jong-il then led the toast, draining his glass with zest, and his guest followed suit.

The joint declaration, signed on the second day of the summit, stated that the two sides would "resolve the issues of reunification independently and through the joint efforts of the Korean people". The outside world was shrugged aside in a mood of Korean togetherness.

A second clause tackled the emotive issues of divided families, with an agreement to exchange visits in two months' time. There was also an agreement to tackle the problem of long-term prisoners in South Korea, who include spies and those convicted under anti-communist laws.

A third provision commits both Koreas to full economic cooperation, though without specific details. But a pledge to do so "in a balanced manner" suggest that real linkages will be allowed between the two economies.

Finally and sensationally, Kim Jong-il agreed to pay an exchange visit to Seoul "at an appropriate time". Many observers had doubted that he would ever venture into the media maelstrom of the south.

The agreement followed a second day infused throughout by a warm glow of pan- Korean sentiment. The two leaders met for longer than expected in their first serious talks. If Kim Dae-jung mentioned the concerns of South Korea's allies, particularly about missiles and nuclear development, this was not reflected in public statements.

In a banquet speech after the talks, an elated Kim Dae-jung declared that he and Kim Jong-il had "successfully concluded the summit". A small hitch followed before the two finally signed, at 11.20pm. The precise wording of a formula on interim steps to unification was left undecided.

Some commentators last night asked whether this agreement was more likely to produce results than those of 1972 and 1991, arguing that the wording remained vague. The difference is that both were the result of secret talks which have occurred frequently in the last 30 years. This time there is a commitment in public to achieve results.

"The Korean people are one: we have a common fate," Kim Dae-jung told his audience. "There is nothing we cannot do if we make steady efforts with good faith and patience."

But he stressed the need for "continuing dialogue and exchanges". South Korean officials have insisted that any agreement will require hard work to implement. The Seoul government is expected to reassure the outside world, and Washington above all, that it has not turned its back on multilateral diplomacy.

Kim Dae-jung declared that the two Koreas should "block any recurrence of war, should not harm each other and should expand exchanges and cooperation". In this way, he continued, they would be able to "cleanly eliminate the elements of the cold war from the Korean peninsula". To northern ears, this could sound like a commitment to seek the removal of US troops from the south. Washington may also seek clarification.

For South Korean opinion, the agreement, coming on top of the warm atmosphere of the whole summit, will complete the remarkable transformation of North Korea from public enemy to close family.

"I cried a little bit," said a young Seoul professional. "I felt reborn. We used to believe they were monsters in the north, now we have to realise they are part of us."

Kim Dae-jung can justly claim much of the credit for persisting in his "sunshine policy" after becoming president in 1998, despite initial rebuffs by Pyongyang and scepticism in the south. But Kim Jong-il, though keeping his cards concealed to the end, is believed to have set in motion the north's slow process of opening the door many years ago.

Yesterday the northern leader addressed South Korean concerns by acknowledging that families divided since the Korean war were waiting for "good news".

Later at the banquet, he told Kim Dae-jung that he should "visit Mount Paekdu sometime". This is no casual invitation. The mountain on the northern border with China is sacred to all Koreans as the mythical source of their civilisation.

On the margin of the summit, sports representatives of the two countries discussed the possibility of forming joint football and table tennis teams at the Sydney Olympic games.

fields.headline: Focus  Iceland
fields.trailText: Iceland is trying hard to cast aside its dowdy image and emerge as the most caring, sharing, trendy and progressive of all supermarket chains.
fields.body:
Iceland is trying hard to cast aside its dowdy image and emerge as the most caring, sharing, trendy and progressive of all supermarket chains.

The company was the first big retailer to ban all genetically modified foods, it has been a pioneer of internet shopping and has tried to inject some humour into its brand through a series of offbeat television commercials.

Iceland's reinvention continued yesterday as the company announced it was investing £9m to secure 40% of the world's organic food supply.

The idea is to sell organic products as cheaply as any other food.

This will mean lower margins, but Iceland is confident it can make up the difference by attracting more customers.

Iceland's founder, Malcolm Walker, is keen to shift the chain away from its reliance on frozen foods and attract customers with a bit more money; he remarked last year that middle class customers often wished the chain sold food in brown paper bags because of its downmarket image.

The strategy appears to be working. Iceland has reported faster growth in like-for-like sales than its rivals in the past two years, with a 6% rise in the first five months of this year.

However, the shares have been weak for the past two months, since the company announced it was taking over Booker, the cash and carry group, for £310m.

The price slipped by 1p to 266.5p yesterday, compared to 300p a few months ago.

The Booker deal was intended to create savings of £50m - an aim initially viewed with some scepticism.

There was also concern that Mr Walker is taking a non- executive role, allowing Booker's Stuart Rose to become chief executive. These worries appear to have been overdone - the management team has argued convincingly that these synergies are achievable and Mr Rose is an experienced retailer, having worked at Argos, Burton and Marks & Spencer.

Iceland's renaissance appears likely to continue.

webTitle: Car vision just round the corner

fields.headline: Car vision just round the corner
fields.trailText: A car company is using new technology to give drivers more vision, including a view around blind corners, it was revealed last night.
fields.body:
A car company is using new technology to give drivers more vision, including a view around blind corners, it was revealed last night.

Nissan has developed a vehicle which has two small video cameras mounted on both sides of the front bumper. These send images on to a dashboard monitor, which gives the driver a clear view of right and left before a junction has been reached.

If the camera spots an approaching vehicle on either side of a junction, a red indicator light on the screen advises the driver to take care.

The car will be tested in Japan in October as part of a transport safety initiative. "It will be about three years before we see this kind of technology in place," said a Nissan UK spokesman. "The plan is to have this eventually fitted as standard." Press Association

fields.headline: Invensys faces Baan opposition
fields.trailText: Invensys investors who have seen the share price receive something of a battering since the group announced it was taking over the Dutch business software group Baan received a measure of relief from an unlikely source yesterday.
fields.body:
Invensys investors who have seen the share price receive something of a battering since the group announced it was taking over the Dutch business software group Baan received a measure of relief from an unlikely source yesterday.

The shares rose more than 4% to 234.75p yesterday after news that a group of unnamed Baan shareholders is seeking to table counter proposals which would block the bid.

The man behind the attempt to head off the Invensys offer is Ernst Sonneveldt, who claims to represent the holders of around a fifth of the shares in Baan including, he says, several "several captains of industry". According to reports from Holland Mr Sonneveldt wants to issue 250m new shares in Baan raising some €625m for the group which has been hit by a series of losses and top level departures.

Ahead of the bid from Invensys, Baan had announced that it was reviewing its strategic options and there had been widespread speculation that it would either have to sell off one of its key divisions or accept a takeover deal.

Though Mr Sonneveldt has met Amsterdam stock exchange officials to discuss his plan to issue new shares and claims to represent Dutch, Belgian and US investors, analysts are sceptical about his refusal to release the names of those he says he represents.

Stock exchange officials also made it clear that their meeting with Mr Sonneveldt had only been to explain what would be required for a share issue along the lines of the one he has outlined.

Baan said it had not received any detailed proposals from Mr Sonneveldt.

The Invensys offer of €2.85 a share - valuing the Dutch group at £470m - is conditional on securing the backing of 95% of Baan shares. Invensys already owns more than 15% of the shares and has the support of a number of key shareholders but if Mr Sonneveldt could attract the level of support he is suggesting he can marshal that would be enough to prevent the Invensys offer succeeding.

If the deal does go through it would mark a big step forward for Invensys' ambitions to build up its software-related business.

fields.headline: Hollywood's loudest laughs
fields.standfirst: Men in drag make it big as US film-makers name Some Like It Hot as America's most hilarious movie
fields.trailText: Men in drag make it big as US film-makers name Some Like It Hot as America's most hilarious movie
fields.body:
The enduring appeal of the on-screen cross-dresser was borne out yet again yesterday when the Hollywood film establishment named as its funniest American movie Billy Wilder's 1959 classic Some Like It Hot.

The movie, which in its day won an Oscar only for costume design, starred Jack Lemmon, Tony Curtis and Marilyn Monroe in a story about two struggling musicians who dress up as women and join an all-girl band to escape the Chicago mob after witnessing the St Valentine's Day Massacre.

But the results of the American Film Institute's poll of 1,800 industry insiders to find the funniest of the funny did not leave everyone in the best of humour.

"In large part these lists turn out to be a celebration of ignorance," said the film critic Leonard Maltin. He then took exception to the placing of Peter and Bobby Farrelly's There's Something About Mary - celebrated in large part for a semen joke - above everything by Charlie Chaplin other than The Gold Rush at 25.

"I don't think I'm a voice in the wilderness when I say there's a possibility Charlie Chaplin is a better film-maker than the Farrelly brothers," said Maltin. But he can have had few quibbles with the success of Some Like It Hot, even if Monroe was said to have been so doped-up during filming that she was often not sure what she was doing.

"Sensational from start to finish," Maltin says in his Movie and Video Guide, "with dazzling performances by Lemmon and Curtis and a memorably comic turn by Monroe."

Second in the poll - participants were asked to select from a list of 500 - was Sydney Pollack's Tootsie from 1982, which stars Dustin Hoffman as failed actor who masquerades as a woman to win a part in a sitcom.

Two other cross-dressing tales make the 100 - Mrs Doubtfire at 67 and Victor/Victoria at 76. Woody Allen, whose films rarely do great business at the United States box office, was the director with most movies on the list: Annie Hall, Manhattan, Take the Money and Run, Bananas and Sleeper. Wilder wrote or directed a total of five and Chaplin made it with four.

Mel Brooks appeared three times, with Blazing Saddles, The Producers and Young Frankenstein. Buster Keaton's The General was the highest-ranked from the silent era. The list arrived at by Hollywood's elite differed markedly from that of the consumers, represented by the institute's website poll. The punters' top 10 - headed by Blazing Saddles (sixth on the official tally) - included five films that did not even make the institute's 100 funniest.

The paying customers' affection for films such as Private Parts, Pee-Wee's Big Adventure and Dumb and Dumber might seem to indicate more lowbrow tastes. On the other hand, they make a case for a hipper sensibility by putting Kevin Smith's slacker picture Clerks at number 10 while it is ignored completely by the institute's voters.

The nearest thing to anything alternative high on the official list is Rob Reiner's hard-rock parody This Is Spinal Tap at 29.

Even some of those recognised by the institute were not entirely happy. "It's nice to be nominated but I'm just a little bit leery of lists," said Blake Edwards, director of both Victor/Victoria and A Shot in the Dark, which made 48th place.

"It's the story of my life," says Monroe's character, Sugar Kane, in Some Like It Hot. "I always get the fuzzy end of the lollipop." Not this time.

webTitle: Chile's army vows to come clean on killings

fields.headline: Chile's army vows to come clean on killings
fields.trailText: Chile's military has promised to help determine the fate of more than 1,000 dissidents who disappeared after being arrested during Augusto Pinochet's 17-year dictatorship.
fields.body:
Chile's military has promised to help determine the fate of more than 1,000 dissidents who disappeared after being arrested during Augusto Pinochet's 17-year dictatorship.

President Ricardo Lagos praised the agreement between military officials, the government and human rights activists as another step to national reconciliation.

The defence minister, Mario Fernandez, said the agreement was reached on Tuesday after an 11-hour meeting. The accord includes a guarantee of anonymity for those coming forward with information on the disappeared, the authorities said.

The guarantee had been expected for weeks and drew criticism both from staunch rightwingers who see it as a betrayal of General Pinochet and his regime, and by leftwingers and relatives of the disappeared who see it as protecting human rights violators.

But President Lagos said: "Without a doubt we will make progress in finding the disappeared. This agreement marks a solemn commitment that never again will political opponents be killed or made to disappear, never again will systematic torture be allowed by agents of the state."

The agreement expressed the hope that information on the whereabouts of the missing would be disclosed within six months. Some critics scoffed at such claims. "If the military hasn't done so in 20 years, it won't disclose anything in six months," said Eduardo Contrereas, a lawyer who filed the first of some 112 criminal complaints against Gen Pinochet for human rights abuses.

According to an official report, 3,190 people were killed during the Pinochet regime, and more than 1,000 remain missing. About 200 victims have been accounted for in unmarked graves, but retired officers have said that many victims were thrown from helicopters into the sea.

Gen Juan Carlos Salgado, the army representative in the talks, denied that the accord betrayed Gen Pinochet. "We are aware of the costs and benefits of this," he said without elaborating.

Pamela Pereira, a human rights lawyer whose father is missing, said that the accord did not grant blanket immunity to those responsible for the disappearances. "This is a joint commitment to try to find the missing," she said.

The announcement capped nine months of "dialogue on human rights" sponsored by the government, which involved representatives of all the armed forces, the police, human rights lawyers and activists, academics and the Catholic church.

Claudio Teitelboim, one of the civilians involved in the meetings, said the military was committed to combing its ranks to gather information on the disappeared - how they were killed and, if possible, where they were buried.

Gen Pinochet, 84, remains secluded at his Santiago home awaiting the outcome of his appeal to the supreme court against a lower tribunal's removal of his immunity from prosecution as a life senator.

fields.headline: Classical musicians opt for internet
fields.trailText: American symphony orchestras and musicians' representatives have signed a historic agreement to make the internet their primary distribution medium for live and recorded concert performances of classical music, opera and ballet.
fields.body:
American symphony orchestras and musicians' representatives have signed a historic agreement to make the internet their primary distribution medium for live and recorded concert performances of classical music, opera and ballet.

The agreement, which follows a year of negotiations between more than 70 of America's most famous orchestras and the musicians' union, recognises that the era of commercially recorded discs could be ending. The web is now poised to become the main source for privately purchased orchestral music.

Every famous American orchestra - including the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera - has agreed to the deal, which will eventually govern the way that musicians are paid for web-available performances. More than 5,000 American symphonic musicians have endorsed the agreement.

The orchestras are free to develop their own websites and to decide whether to make their concerts available as live "streaming audio" - which cannot be downloaded by listeners - or as recordings that can be downloaded for a fee, an option which is unlikely to become widespread until high-speed internet access is more commonly available.

There is very little evidence that classical music is in demand on the internet, but the phenomenal success of websites like Napster - which offers free downloads of pop music - has encouraged orchestral managements to create their own demand. Several orchestras, of which the Cleveland Orchestra is the most prominent, have been developing strategies for selling their performances on line.

More importantly, the agreement marks a turning point.

Most recording companies have slashed investment in new recordings and classical music releases, especially when it involves hiring orchestras. In the US, only two orchestras - the New York Philharmonic and the Chicago Symphony - still have recording contracts, though many orchestras continue to make recordings on an ad-hoc basis.

"It's no secret that the volume of classical recording has diminished spectacularly over recent years," said Florence Nelson of the American Federation of Musicians, which negotiated the deal. "This agreement means that the internet [will be] an effective future way of distributing our members' work."

"I see downloading of music on the internet as the next extension of the process that began with 78s. The big difference about the internet is that it streamlines the distribution system and lowers prices," says Joseph Kluger, the president of the Philadelphia Orchestra and the chairman of the management side of the negotiations. "Eventually, it will mean the end of the compact disc industry as we know it, even if not [the end] of the compact disc."

Recording companies have increasingly lost interest in making new recordings of the classical repertoire because sales so rarely rise above a few thousand. Most companies already possess several versions of the standard repertoire, many of them with top performers and in good quality sound from the early 1990s.

Orchestras such as the Cleveland, the Philadelphia, or the Boston Symphony, which were in the forefront of the recording industry for long stretches of the 20th century under celebrated conductors such as Leopold Stokowski, George Szell and Seiji Ozawa, now no longer have recording contracts.

"The recording industry no longer has any significant interest in the creation and effective marketing of new recordings of our orchestras," the two sides said in a joint memorandum explaining the terms of the new deal to their members.

However, neither the orchestras nor the musicians' union appear to be under many illusions that there will be instant financial returns from the new initiative. "My personal belief is that the culture of the internet is based on the premise that the content is free," says Mr Kluger. "I think that, at first, most orchestras will end up offering their music for streaming, free to the consumer."

Ms Nelson agrees: "It's a shared risk. It's going to take some time before we see any returns for musicians, but if there's money to be had, we want to share in the rewards as well as the risks."

fields.headline: Piles of enthusiasm on tap
fields.trailText: Adam Twiss, chief executive of Zeus Technology, believes that a good indication of the health of a company is the number of employees attending its Christmas party.
fields.body:
Adam Twiss, chief executive of Zeus Technology, believes that a good indication of the health of a company is the number of employees attending its Christmas party.

More impressive to others than the 100% attendance at its festive bash, however, was the 75% voluntary turnout at nine o'clock the next morning to help lay a new carpet.

Mr Twiss, 24, founded Zeus with a friend from university, Damien Reeves. The company makes software which helps businesses carry out transactions on the internet: Zeus Technology is considered to be worth well over £100m.

Twiss and Reeves own 34% each - huge wealth on paper. But Mr Twiss brushes aside the valuations, although he is reluctant to offer an alternative opinion.

"I haven't had a holiday for four years," he says.

"I don't think anything I do could be considered indulgent. I have the same car and live in the same place as I always have done."

Mr Twiss is a slight, blond figure with a nervous manner and a habit of gazing into the distance. He says the roots of Zeus go back to his time as an undergraduate at Churchill College, Cambridge, where he met Mr Reeves.

"We had very fast internet connections at college and we did a lot of learning on the net. Being computer science undergraduates, we were playing around with various toys and tools and we began to think we could do a better job."

During his second year, Mr Twiss says, he stopped attending lectures to concentrate on his own projects. A product of a comprehensive school, he was "unchallenged" by the university and despite apparently doing very little work emerged with a first-class degree: "I was disappointed by the whole Cambridge academic system."

One evening, Mr Twiss decided to write his own web surfing program. He bashed it out by 10.55pm - just in time to catch last orders in the college bar.

He posted the program on the net and got feedback from around the world. A friend's father later asked him to help design a website for Levi's jeans and his business career began.

"When I graduated, I didn't want to work for a boring bank in London."

So he went into business with Mr Reeves, using the proceeds from a few website design projects as seed capital.

"Cambridge seemed like an interesting place - I still had student friends and I wanted to get away from nagging parents - so we started doing stuff here."

Zeus recently moved into its own building on the Cambridge Business Park, in the north of the city. It now has 46 staff in four offices around the world.

Mr Twiss's main criticism of Cambridge is the difficulty in obtaining advice - the company looked elsewhere to find lawyers, accountants and public relations consultants with the expertise to deal with an international company.

On Tuesday: Dublin

fields.headline: Rival boasts rich portfolio
fields.trailText: Cambridge University is the biggest single factor in the development of the Silicon Fen phenomenon. However, the institution is falling behind Oxford university in reaping the financial rewards.
fields.body:
Cambridge University is the biggest single factor in the development of the Silicon Fen phenomenon. However, the institution is falling behind Oxford university in reaping the financial rewards.

Earlier this year, Oxford found itself sitting on a portfolio of shares worth more than £50m in five companies which were founded by dons from its research laboratories - including the City high flyers Powderject Pharmaceuticals and Oxford Glycosciences.

Cambridge has yet to chalk up a single such investment -which many believe is a missed opportunity. Powderject's chief executive, Paul Drayson, says: "At Oxford, it's all sorted out exactly who gets what in these spin-outs. Academics are not allowed to commercialise their technology without handing over a stake to the university. At Cambridge, until recently, the rules weren't really written down."

Cambridge has established a holding entity named Cambridge University Technical Services, which holds equity in start-up companies and transfers the profits back to the university.

The first to reach the stockmarket could be Cambridge Display Technology, which makes light emitting devices that could change the way television sets work. The company is valued at over £80m and the university could realise a windfall if it floats.

The lack of any big bonanza so far is a surprise, given Cambridge University's long history of spin-off companies. The first to be established was the Cambridge Scientific Instrument company, founded in 1881 by Horace Darwin, the youngest son of evolutionary theorist Charles Darwin.

However, it has only been since the 1960s that the city has become a genuine centre for profitable industry.

One of the catalysts for change was Harold Wilson 's Labour government - in the early 1960s, Wilson began talking of the Britain to be forged "in the white heat" of the hi-tech revolution. He urged universities to establish links with industry.

According to Trinity College's bursar, Jeremy Fairbrother, this was one of the triggers for a radical change in policy both for Cambridge University and for the City's godfathers.

In 1967, a report by a leading university figure, Sir Neville Mott, recommended the construction of Trinity College's Cambridge Science Park. Hi-tech industries now generate more than £2bn of revenue and Arm Holdings recently became the first Cambridge company to join the FTSE 100.

webTitle: Quiet reclaims the streets of Pyongyang

fields.headline: Quiet reclaims the streets of Pyongyang
fields.standfirst: Korea: special report
fields.trailText: Pyongyang went back to work yesterday while its "Dear Leader", Kim Jong-il, held his triumphant summit with the South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung.
fields.body:
Pyongyang went back to work yesterday while its "Dear Leader", Kim Jong-il, held his triumphant summit with the South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung.

The streets had returned to their usual sparse appearance not long after the joyous, but well disciplined, paper-flower-waving crowd that greeted Kim Dae-jung the day before had dispersed.

Pyongyang's citizens walked briskly on the city's pavements, never crossing the road except at approved points, even when there was no traffic. Outside the shops - which were well-stocked - there were no crowds.

Everyone was clad neatly, the men in white shirts and the women in skirts or traditional dress. Platforms on the Moscow-style underground with its pharaonic pillars and bare walls were also uncrowded. As always, it was a slight mystery where the masses had gone.

The morning newspapers in Pyongyang gave heavy coverage to the visit but focused on the formal side. They said that the summit was one of the most significant events in the two Koreas' 5,000-year history - Koreans north and south claim their civilisation is a thousand years older than China's.

The South Korean president had come to Pyongyang "at his own request", the media stressed, noting that he had "made public a written statement on arrival" - but did not publish it.

The Workers' Daily gave a full account of Kim Dae-jung's banquet speech, in which he thanked North Korea for its hospitality and was deeply moved by "patriotic love".

But ordinary North Koreans heard none of the chit-chat between the two leaders at their first meeting. No one expects them to learn of Kim Jong-il's off-the-cuff remark yesterday that, far from being reclusive, he has taken many secret holidays in China and Indonesia.

All of this has been relayed back to Seoul by a small South Korean press party to more than 1,000 journalists crammed into the Seoul press centre, watching an intermittent live link with Pyongyang.

Some South Korean journalists attempted to leave Pyongyang's Koryo Hotel for an early morning walk, but they were told that "personal contacts with Pyongyang citizens would depart from the spirit of the summit agreement".

The only foreign media represented in Pyongyang were a Chinese and a Russian news agency, and a pro-Pyongyang Japanese newspaper. Even CNN, which had cultivated good links with North Korea, was denied entry for the summit.

Kim Dae-jung and his wife Lee Hee-ho were taken yesterday, like all important visitors for the past decade, to the Mangyongdae Students' and Childrens' Palace. There they saw the usual massed groups of children playing the kayagum - a type of Korean harp - and the accordion; the songs were non-politically patriotic.

Other members of the South Korean delegation visited a computer centre, where they found programs for playing the board game "Go", for North Korean karaoke, for teaching ballet and to introduce famous northern beauty spots.

Some stories in the North Korean press gave a less rosy picture of education in Pyongyang. One report hailed the example of teacher-hero Kim Myong-hun, who invented a portable windmill to generate electricity, it said, because his night school had been hit by "chronic blackouts since 1995" and the students were forced to use candles.

fields.headline: Johnnie Taylor
fields.standfirst: Soul singer with a reputation for consistency - and a string of hit singles and big-selling albums
fields.trailText: Johnnie Taylor, who has died of a heart attack aged 62, was a great soul stylist. Although he rarely wrote his own material and had little instrumental skill, his unique phrasing and sense of vocal rhythm set him apart, even during soul's most commercially vibrant years, from the late 60s to mid-70s.
fields.body:
Johnnie Taylor, who has died of a heart attack aged 62, was a great soul stylist. Although he rarely wrote his own material and had little instrumental skill, his unique phrasing and sense of vocal rhythm set him apart, even during soul's most commercially vibrant years, from the late 60s to mid-70s.

Taylor was born in Craw fordsville, Arkansas, in the middle of blues country, when Howlin' Wolf and Junior Parker were in the neighbourhood and at their peak. But his first loyalty was to the Lord and, like many contemporaries, he was heavily influenced by the vocal style of Sam Cooke, then lead voice in the Soul Stirrers, the hottest act in gospel music. In 1960, Cooke went solo and asked Taylor to replace him as lead tenor; his naturally grittier approach contributed towards Stirrers hits like Stand By Me, Father and The Love Of God.

Later, Taylor joined Cooke in the secular world of rhythm and blues, signing for his SAR Records label and enjoying a couple of minor successes, including Rome Wasn't Built In A Day. But Cooke was shot dead in 1964. Left to decide between Berry Gordy's slick Motown set-up in Detroit or heading south, Taylor flipped a coin and made for Memphis and Stax Records.

For two years, he was portrayed as a blues artist. But in 1968, a pulsating Homer Banks, Al Jackson and Bettye Crutcher composition, Who's Making Love, shot Taylor into the charts - the record made number one in the R&B lists and number five in the pop chart. Initially, he had not liked the song - Detroit producer Don Davis had managed successfully to merge the southern-fried, horn-blasted gutsiness of Stax with the uptown, bass-propelled drive of Motown - but the chart placing soon changed his mind.

For the next seven years, Taylor enjoyed a virtually unbroken run of hit 45s and big-selling albums. Top-10 R&B singles - such as Testify and I Could Never Be President - built his reputation for consistency, while Taylor's musical peaks occurred during the middle 70s. We're Getting Careless With Our Love, a superb Don Davis/ Frank Johnson tune inspired by Billy Paul's Me & Mrs Jones and the number one hit I Believe In You [You Believe In Me], both from the superb Taylored In Silk album, made him a huge box office draw across the States.

When Stax Records succumbed to the weight of its accumulated debts in 1975, Taylor signed for CBS and wisely took his regular producer with him. Their first song for the major, Disco Lady, pulled the neat trick of calling itself a disco record when it was really just a churning, bass-heavy soul tune, and became the biggest selling single in CBS's history. The album it came from, Eargasm, was similarly popular. It was a commercial peak Taylor would never scale again. Ever Ready, in 1978, was the last of his albums CBS released in this country. Although he rarely wrote his own material and had little instrumental skill, his unique phrasing and sense of vocal rhythm set him apart, even during soul's most commercially vibrant years, from the late 60s to mid-70s. Taylor was born in Craw fordsville, Arkansas, in the middle of blues country, when Howlin' Wolf and Junior Parker were in the neighbourhood and at their peak. But his first loyalty was to the Lord and, like many contemporaries, he was heavily influenced by the vocal style of Sam Cooke, then lead voice in the Soul Stirrers, the hottest act in gospel music. webTitle: Damascus bazaar wants peace, reform, and Bashar

fields.headline: Damascus bazaar wants peace, reform, and Bashar
fields.standfirst:
Goodwill based on hope that Assad's son can deliver change

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Traders lining the narrow lanes of the Old City at the heart of Syria's capital were pleased to reopen yesterday after being closed for three days of mourning for the late president, Hafez al-Assad. And they welcomed the prospect of his son, Bashar, becoming president and holding out the chance for a more modern society and peace with Israel.
fields.body:
Traders lining the narrow lanes of the Old City at the heart of Syria's capital were pleased to reopen yesterday after being closed for three days of mourning for the late president, Hafez al-Assad. And they welcomed the prospect of his son, Bashar, becoming president and holding out the chance for a more modern society and peace with Israel.

Salah al-Din, 32, stood cheerfully outside his silver and copper shop looking for trade as his family has done for 500 years. "It will be Bashar, God willing. He will change things. We want a new Syria. The changes might not happen in six months, or a year, but it will come."

This confidence that there will be a peaceful transition was widely shared throughout the souks, where posters of Bashar, some in military uniform, were going up on shop front windows, with his father's portrait relegated inside.

Western diplomats here were far more cautious. One said: "There is no sign of opposition yet - the emphasis is on the 'no sign'." Was some army officer sitting in the barracks plotting a coup? "That is the $64,000 question."

There will be experienced army officers and politicians looking jealously at the handing of power to a 34-year-old eye specialist who until his father's death on Saturday held no government post. Such a dynastic succession would be a first for an Arab republic.

The process of establishing Bashar al-Assad as the successor will accelerate this weekend at the first conference of the Ba'ath party for 15 years. Bashar is the party's presidential "nominee", and at the meeting he will hope to see his supporters gain key posts at the expense of some among the old guard.

The judgment of western diplomats is that the regime has orchestrated the succession very well so far, using state media to build Bashar up and sending groups of supporters on to the streets to mix with mourners and proclaim the young man as the "future of the nation".

For the only other prominent member of the Assad family - Rifaat, 63, the exiled brother of the dead president - there was absolutely no support in the Damascus bazaars yesterday, only derision. "He has been away for 16 years. He is a fool," said one trader.

Even in northern Syria around the port of Latakia - the region of the Assad family and of the Alawites from which they hail, a minority Shia Muslim sect in a country with a large Sunni majority - Arab journalists were finding the same feeling about Rifaat.

"He has no following, no popular base ... Nobody takes him seriously," said Imad Ballan, 42, a Latakia shopowner, echoing the general view.

According to a leading pan-Arab newspaper based in London, al-Hayat, Syria's government has threatened to arrest Rifaat if he flies to Syria from his Spanish home at Marbella.

There was no belief in the souks that Syria was about to descend into turmoil.

Mike, who runs Arwam Oriental goods shop in the Hamidiye souk, was relaxed yesterday as he talked up what good prices he could offer to win sales after being closed for three days.

He had only one complaint: he would be missing the current Euro 2000 football championships because Syrian television was broadcasting recitations from the Koran almost non-stop throughout the 40 days of mourning that began after Hafez Assad's death.

Otherwise, he was content, and optimistic: "We want Bashar. It can only be Bashar. He is a good man, educated, a doctor." He wanted him to be like King Abdullah of Jordan, who is said to be close to Bashar and who has embarked on some reforms since taking over last year.

He thought peace with Israel would come soon, a view endorsed by his fellow trader, Salah al-Din, who scrawled a map on a scrap of paper showing the Golan Heights, lost by Syria in the Arab-Israeli war of 1967. He wanted a return to the previous border, including access to what the Syrians call Lake Tiberias and the Israelis the Sea of Galilee. "We want peace but a Syrian peace, not an Israeli one," he said.

On this, however, western diplomats expect no speedy deal. Given the 40 days of mourning, Bashar cannot take over as president until towards the end of July and by then the US will be concentrating too much on its own elections to oversee a new round of negotiations in the Middle East.

Just off the souk, behind the Umayyad mosque, in the Hubble-Bubble cafe, Toume Kaeet was concerned less about the peace process and more about potential trouble among the array of religions that make up Syria. A Christian, he too wanted Bashar.

As president, Assad from the Alawite minority was relatively tolerant of religions - unless, like the Sunni Muslim Brotherhood, their adherents attempted political opposition.

"Bashar, though a Muslim, likes Christians," Toume Kaeet said, worried at the prospect of Sunnis gaining power and trampling the minorities.

webTitle: Ombudsman condemns out of hours cover for GPs

fields.headline: Ombudsman condemns out of hours cover for GPs
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The health service ombudsman yesterday blew the whistle on the biggest of the private companies providing a deputising service for GPs outside normal working hours.
fields.body:
The health service ombudsman yesterday blew the whistle on the biggest of the private companies providing a deputising service for GPs outside normal working hours.

After investigating the deaths of patients in Gateshead and Manchester, Michael Buckley described the performance of Healthcall as "totally unacceptable".

The company provides 7,500 GPs with out of hours cover. It has about a quarter of the market and provided 1.7m consultations last year.

Defects found by the ombudsman included insufficient training for call handling staff, and inadequate procedures for prioritising calls.

On some occasions there were not enough doctors available to provide cover, which contributed to delays, while procedures for calling in extra doctors were "inadequate or not activated", he said.

Healthcall last night acknowledged that in the cases investigated it "fell short of standards expected by our GP customers and their patients". It had already apologised to the families concerned. Andy Dun, the group medical director, said standards had improved since these cases.

The first case identified in the ombudsman's annual report concerned the death of a Gateshead woman. When her family telephoned Healthcall, there was a "totally unacceptable" delay of nearly three hours before the case was referred to a doctor. When a doctor finally arrived she was unconscious and paramedics were unable to resuscitate her.

The ombudsman found "fundamental problems" in arrangements for sorting and prioritising calls; company's performance was appalling. Staff had been left to make vital decisions without adequate training, advice or guidance.

In a second case in April 1998, a woman died in a Manchester nursing home after staff waited more than three hours for a Healthcall doctor. The ombudsman found the company's operator omitted to record that she was unconscious and the case was wrongly prioritised.

Mr Buckley welcomed assurances from Healthcall that the problems would be addressed. But he was concerned that many GPs did not monitor the quality of their deputising service.

fields.headline: Sir Roualeyn Cumming-Bruce
fields.standfirst: Intuitive and sympathetic judge promoted to the appeal court despite a drink-driving conviction
fields.trailText: Sir Roualeyn Cumming-Bruce, a former Lord Justice of Appeal, who has died aged 88, was a realistic and intuitive judge, renowned for his sympathetic divorce and custody decisions, and vivid turn of phrase.
fields.body:
Sir Roualeyn Cumming-Bruce, a former Lord Justice of Appeal, who has died aged 88, was a realistic and intuitive judge, renowned for his sympathetic divorce and custody decisions, and vivid turn of phrase.

One of his first divorce cases on the bench involved a wife who "put golf before her home duties and any attempt to give any companionship to her husband". Advised by doctors to take up the game following a nervous breakdown, the woman had soon achieved a handicap of 11, but refused to play with her husband; Cumming-Bruce granted him a decree nisi on the ground of desertion.

Cumming-Bruce also granted divorces to the wife of Tony Hancock because of cruelty and adultery; the wife of an architect who hid her engagement ring on his toe to teach her not to lose it; and a retired Royal Naval captain who kept a log of his wife's behaviour and a graph of her gin consumption.

But Cumming-Bruce did not dish out divorces willy-nilly. Among the disappointed petitioners that came before him was a wife whose laughter in the cinema had caused her husband to twist her arm and kick her ankle, and a couple whose marriage he admitted was "as dead as a doornail".

It was a reflection of the high esteem in which Cumming-Bruce was held that he was promoted to the Court of Appeal just 18 months after pleading guilty to drunken driving. "I think I have had an unwise number of gin and tonics," he told the policeman who arrested him in the Mall.

A younger twin (the third son of the Rev Lord Thurlow, 6th Baron), he was educated at Shrewsbury, and at Magdalene College, Cambridge, where he took a first in classics. For a time at Cambridge, he dallied with communism, but during the holidays he put his convictions to one side and enjoyed his hunting.

In 1937 he was called to the Bar by Middle Temple as a Harmsworth scholar, but with the outbreak of war went to serve in the Royal Artillery in North Africa and the Middle East, rising to lieutenant colonel. He was somewhat surprised to be posted to a senior staff job in Cairo - the War Office later admitted they had meant to send his brother, Harry, a regular soldier. In Egypt, he had the job of showing Mme Chiang around Luxor while her husband Chiang Kai-Shek attended the 1943 Cairo conference. To keep her from disrupting the discussions in Cairo, their plane suffered three days of "engine trouble" at Luxor.

Cumming-Bruce did a variety of work in his early years at the Bar, including crime, libel and personal injury, much of it on the Northern Circuit. But it was his accomplished performances for bodies such as the Law Society - prosecuting, among others, people for pretending to be solicitors - and the Registrar of Restrictive Practices that marked him as a potential junior counsel to the Treasury (common law), which he became in 1959.

Senior counsel for the Crown in civil matters are the attorney-general and solicitor-general, but due to their extensive political responsibilities, most of the burden falls on the juniors, who by convention were rewarded with a High Court judgeship after five years without having taken Silk. The positions are thus some of the plum offerings of the profession, and zealously sought-after.

Cumming-Bruce played a prominent part in the contempt proceedings against the silent journalists at the Vassall tribunal - set up to inquire into how John Vassall's spying had led to Russian spy-trawlers turning up at Nato exercises - and in 1964 was duly made a High Court judge, assigned to what was then the Probate, Divorce and Admiralty Division (later the Family Division).

Notwithstanding his earlier Treasury role, Cumming-Bruce became something of a champion of individual rights against those of the executive. In 1967, he strongly criticised the refusal to provide information concerning an injured RAF pilot's promotion prospects (to assess damages). "The minister of defence, I understand," he said, "has as usual insisted that the court shall be denied the opportunity of doing justice with the knowledge of relevant facts." And in 1969, Cumming-Bruce described a House of Lords decision to allow for the production of a policeman's records in an action for malicious prosecution as "a step forward for liberty against the executive".

Following his promotion to the Court of Appeal in 1977, Cumming-Bruce had to make some particularly tough access and custody decisions. In 1983, for example, he ordered a young stepmother to give up the boy she had cherished for eight years, even though, as he admitted: "Her heart is locked round him and to a great degree his heart is locked to hers. She is devoted to the boy and has brought him up quite beautifully." He decided, however, that now she and the boy's father had split up, it was best for the 10-year-old to return to his natural mother, who had remarried.

Cases not involving children no doubt came as light relief, and when sitting with Lord Denning, as he often did, they could also be entertaining. In 1977 he sided with Denning in the 2:1 decision that Lintz cricket club in Durham could carry on playing despite the complaints of a couple who objected to sixes falling on their house just over the boundary fence. And in 1979, he and Denning prevented Auberon Waugh from publishing his proposed "Dog Lovers" general election address for fear of prejudicing Jeremy Thorpe's trial - Cumming-Bruce remarking that it would be "naive" of the court to accept Waugh's offer of an undertaking to limit publication as far as possible to North Devon.

Cumming-Bruce was knighted in 1964 and made a Privy Councillor in 1971. His wife, Lady Sarah Savile, an accomplished pianist, died in 1991. Their two sons and a daughter survive him

fields.headline: Veronica Bamfield
fields.standfirst: Historian of intrepid women who herself loved open-top motoring adventures from Baghdad
fields.trailText: When the British army served the same purpose around the globe as the United Nations does now - being imperially present and occasionally useful - most military wives on station chose to import the social gradations of Sussex to Simla and saw the lands of their exile as plentifully servanted picnic grounds.
fields.body:
When the British army served the same purpose around the globe as the United Nations does now - being imperially present and occasionally useful - most military wives on station chose to import the social gradations of Sussex to Simla and saw the lands of their exile as plentifully servanted picnic grounds.

Not so Veronica Bamfield, who has died aged 91. She wrote of the life of the British army wife from the 17th to the 20th century in On The Strength (1975). It was the life she had been born to: her father was a lieutenant-colonel killed in Palestine in the first world war, her stepfather a general, and in 1930 she married Captain WH "Tich" Bamfield of the Royal Welsh Fusiliers. But she was not a snifter at tiffin on the verandah sort of lady: she identified with women who had shared male hardship, and explored upcountry for themselves.

Bamfield came out as a debutante in the last days of the bright young things, but escaped to study at the Sorbonne before her marriage. Tich was posted to the Assyrian Company of the Iraq Levies in the early 1930s - chaps in an advisory capacity dotted the Middle East because of the British mandate in Palestine and the new petroleum fields. In Baghdad, the Bamfields did not set up housekeeping in a Wimbledon bungaloid manner; they moved into a traditional adobe house by the Diyala river. An 18th-century forebear of Veronica had written of ruined Palmyra, the Assyrian-Greek-Roman city of Queen Zenobia: it was a day-trip away from Baghdad.

The Bamfields drove their open-top Lanchester car over dubious roads east into Persia, north into Kurdistan, west through Syria: their mechanic rode in the back seat both as a human tool kit and a charm against the evil eye. The Iranian Shah had ordered nomads to settle and westernise; radio and Royal Air Force-manned airfields were abridging the distances between the Mediterranean, the Persian Gulf and the Caspian Sea; yet Bronze Age ways of life continued in the hills and the Bamfields pottered off to see them.

In Baghdad, they met Freya Stark (who described Veronica, in Beyond Euphrates, as "a tall and lovely Juno"), a fellow spirit, though rather more expert at operating on muleback. Stark had discovered the privilege of a woman traveller - booted, behatted and disparaging of female silliness, she became an honorary man, welcome to discuss public affairs in the selemlik, the masculine half of the house; while, in a crumpled frock from her saddlebag, she had access to chat about sex in the haremlik, the women's quarters. Bamfield joined Stark on jaunts into this double life, slipping into the all-male zones of mosques, attending weddings and anointing brides with cold cream, washing in beaked ewers of water drawn from heated cauldrons.

The Bamfields were posted to India in 1938, where Veronica stayed on until 1942, although Tich came home at the outbreak of the second world war: long after, she corresponded with Paul Scott, novelist of The Raj Quartet, who recreated his pre-partition India from details checked in fact and tone with those who were actually there - though it is hard to imagine Bamfield, with her inquisitiveness about local life, among his India-despising memsahibs in Pankot.

In 1945, she and Tich rooted themselves in Shrewsbury, Shropshire. She went into radio in the 1950s, broadasting on Woman's Hour, and later interviewed Percy Thrower from the potting shed at Shrewsbury Flower Show. Her interest in the forgotten histories of ordinary people led to her work for the re-publication of Richard Gough's History Of Myddle (an account of a Shropshire parish circa 1700), and to the research for her own second volume, Victory Of The Vanquished (1990), a history of the 1793-96 insurrection in the Vendée region of France against the Parisian revolutionary republican government, a tragedy not much written about, even in France.

She was inspired by the Vendéean heroines, notably the amazon Celeste Bulkeley, who led her crack troops into battle, and survived wounds, defeat, repeated widowhood and a sentence of death by guillotine. Bamfield rented a cottage in the region and supplemented her archive investigations into the period by walking the ground and recording local family memories of the uprising. The book, in translation, provoked scholarly debate in France: Bamfield was delighted by the response.

Her curiosity did not abate with age. She took to the computer at 83, and wrote for both the Shrewsbury Hospice and the Assyrian Journals in her late eighties.

Tich died in 1975; four daughters survive them.

Kevin Brownlow writes: Shortly after the triumphant revival of Abel Gance's film Napoleon at the Empire, Leicester Square, in 1980, I paid a visit to Gance at his home in Paris. He was bedridden, but his neighbour showed me some of the letters he had received as a result of the show. Among those he was most proud of was one headed Homage A Abel Gance, written in impeccable French by Veronica Bamfield.

Veronica, then in her 70s, had contacted me when she heard about my restoration of Napoleon. She explained that she had seen it as a girl while she was at finishing school - "sent by my parents in the hope of transforming a sow's ear into a silk purse" - at the Opera in Paris. "I remember what I can only describe as the magnificent confusion of the whole colossal impact. Nothing I have ever seen, until the reconstruction was shown, ever produced the same complete bouleversement."

When she eventually saw the restoration, with live orchestra, in 1980, it more than fulfilled her expectations. "The tension was incredible and at one moment I felt I was going to scream. There were bursts of spontaneous applause and many more of absorbed silence. We were elated, battered, exhausted. We weren't sitting in a cinema, we were tossing at sea, we were scrambling over the mountains of Corsica. That energy, that dynamism... it poured off the screen."

When I told her I was doing a book, Napoleon - Abel Gance's Classic Film (1983), she offered her help, and proved enormously valuable. I was unable to visit all the locations. Veronica travelled to France and not only checked old newspapers, but tracked down veterans who had played in the picture, recording and translating tapes and providing background from her enormous knowledge of revolutionary history.

Veronica Bamfield was one of those brave, resourceful women one associates with the Victorian era. But it is her enormous charm, her enthusiasm and her self-deprecating humour that I shall miss most.

webTitle: Rooting for the now and Fen

fields.headline: Rooting for the now and Fen
fields.trailText: The villages around Cambridge are popular retreats for university dons, who like to withdraw to a picturesque cottages after slaving away in their ivory towers. This rural idyll has, however, been challenged in recent years by an influx of wealthy young employees of hi-tech businesses who have pushed house prices to stratospheric levels.
fields.body:
The villages around Cambridge are popular retreats for university dons, who like to withdraw to a picturesque cottages after slaving away in their ivory towers. This rural idyll has, however, been challenged in recent years by an influx of wealthy young employees of hi-tech businesses who have pushed house prices to stratospheric levels.

These newcomers, with their designer-casual clothes and elaborate laptop computers, are often blamed for the expansion of villages into surrounding countryside - a trend which upsets long-term residents.

Cambridgeshire is indeed booming; the area known as Silicon Fen is home to one of Britain's biggest clusters of hi-tech companies and there are new arrivals almost weekly. Altogether, about 1,200 hi-tech firms in the region employ around 35,000 people. Among the best known local businesses are the microchip maker Arm Holdings, the internet software company Autonomy and one of Britain's biggest biotechnology firms, Cambridge Antibody Technologies. One of the latest employers to arrive in town is the Malaysian Space Agency, which has set up shop just around the corner from Microsoft.

As David Howarth, the leader of Cambridge city council, says: "Cambridge is no longer a market town with a university. It's a thriving commercial, in one sense industrial, centre."

The centre of Cambridge has changed little through the ages; it has kept its postcard imagery of punts floating on the river Cam, students hurrying around in college scarves and narrow streets separating ancient buildings. Just half an hour's walk towards the outskirts of town, the landscape changes dramatically.

The city is practically encircled by the science parks which nestle just inside the "green belt" that restricts the expansion of the built-up area. Hi-tech companies are based in shiny glass blocks, surrounded by landscaped grassland and busy roads.

The biggest cluster of companies is in the Cambridge Science Park, owned by Trinity college. It is home to 64 businesses, employing more than 4,000 people.

Among them is Cantab Pharmaceuticals, a biotech firm with a stock market value of about £170m. Its research director, Stephen Inglis, says: "Being in Cambridge has been a huge help to us. There's a tremendous science base at the university and there are also other institutions here, like the medical research council."

Like many on the park, however, he complains that the place is slightly soulless: "There's something missing - a spark that's not here."

Despite the idea of creating a community of hi-tech companies, there is little contact between neighbours on the park. Dr Inglis says: "In a way, that has been something of a disappointment. We see people from other companies at the annual fun run here for Children in Need, and it's only then that you get a sense of the number of people around."

Others complain that there has been no "greater plan" for Cambridge. Various developers have established science parks but transport is a huge problem, as is housing.

These issues are partly the result of traditional wrangles between factions with different views of how Cambridge should develop. After the war, local politicians watched with horror as the city's historic rival, Oxford, allowed the development of the huge Cowley car plant - considered a carbuncle on the skyline of dreaming spires.

Beaten by Portsmouth

In the late 1960s, the council caused a furore by refusing to allow IBM to build its European research centre locally. The plant, and the prospect of thousands of jobs, went to Portsmouth instead.

Planners in Cambridge now welcome hi-tech developments, giving them priority over other proposals. However, problems persist - Colin Bastable, marketing director of nCipher, a start-up encryption company, says: "The city's going to have to expand and provide extra accommodation."

nCipher is a typical product of the internet revolution. Founded by brothers, Alex and Nico van Someren, the company makes processors which handle security for online transactions.

The company employs 90 people and has its headquarters in an office block near Cambridge's railway station. Mr Bastable boasts that the firm's customers include eight of the top 10 online stockbrokers, the internet bank Egg and the US defence department.

The Cambridge connection goes back to Nico van Someren's education - he took a PhD at Trinity.

Mr Bastable says: "We're here because we do a lot of work with the university. In terms of employment, the area's got the right skill sets and it offers a decent quality of life."

Adam Twiss, the chief executive of e-commerce software company Zeus Technology, reckons Cambridge compares favourably to America's silicon valley in lifestyle terms. "Silicon valley's a great place to do business but a horrible place to live. I've been to San Jose in silicon valley and it's soulless - there is huge poverty in the area as well as enormous wealth."

Zeus makes software which helps businesses to handle billions of dollars worth of transactions a day. Mr Twiss says that one in 50 of the world's websites uses the company's technology.

The company was established in the St John's Innovation Centre - one of Cambridge's leading incubators of new businesses. The centre is St John's college's contribution to local enterprise. The two colleges, both extremely wealthy, have been significant catalysts in the development of Silicon Fen, with Trinity first off the block in the 1960s. Mr Twiss says: "Trinity realised there was only so much they could spend on port for their high table dinners so they were going to have to find something else to spend their cash on. They decided to try and help local businesses."

Given the historic rivalry between Trinity and St John's - which dates back to an incident in which a cox died in a boat race between the two colleges - it was only a matter of time before St John's plunged into the hi-tech arena as well.

Recent planning guidance has discouraged the construction of any more science parks in south Cambridgeshire but the council reckons there is still space for a few more companies within the city. New entrants had better hurry. House prices are approaching London levels and there is barely any space left on the roads.

webTitle: The price is right: Who will play The Incredible Hulk on the big screen?

fields.headline: The price is right: Who will play The Incredible Hulk on the big screen?
fields.trailText: Arnold Schwarzenegger 10-1
fields.body:
Arnold Schwarzenegger 10-1

Ben Affleck 12-1

Antonio Banderas 16-1

Nicolas Cage 20-1

Keith Chegwin 500-1

Who can possibly follow the footsteps, or indeed fill the ripped clothes of previous Incredible Hulk, Lou Ferrigno? Ed Nicholson, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler, reckons there's a very obvious choice.

"Arnold Schwarzenegger is fit, loved by the public, and used to be a body builder", says Ed. As a cult TV series with a long fan base, the Hulk should be someone who is a little long in the tooth. "I think the part is made for him - it would also appeal to his sense of humour."

But considering that the film version of the Marvel comic strip is to be scripted with both the kitsch and the serious filmgoer in mind, and could well develop into a summer blockbuster, maybe a younger actor would fit the bill.

"Ben Affleck has the handsome chiselled features", observes Ed. He has got a very nice torso, too. "That could work well. He is also someone that the youngsters will want to go and see, and has been involved with action movies. But whether he'd want to rip his expensive clothes up to get the part is a different question altogether."

Ripe for the part is Nicholas Cage, having just had his biggest film opening with Gone In 60 Seconds. He has completed quite a few thinking-man's action flicks and is basically a cheap version of Tom Cruise.

"Or perhaps Antonio Banderas is the man. His body is sure to go down well."

"Finally what about Keith Chegwin? I think I speak for all of us who witnessed his naked torso recently on television (among other smaller parts of the body), when I say we would certainly like to see more colour in those cheeks - but green wouldn't be an appropriate one."

Interview by Jennifer Rodger

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Fabulous Baker Boys
fields.body:
The Fabulous Baker Boys

(Steve Kloves, 1989)

8pm, 1.15am, Sky Cinema

Brothers Jeff and Beau Bridges are Jack and Frank Baker, brothers who once had grand piano ambitions, now playing the Seattle nightclubs. Into their world steps singer Susie Diamond (Michelle Pfeiffer), putting the forte back in Jack's love life. An engaging tale, in which the brothers' embittered relationship is as compelling as the romance.

Get Carter

(Mike Hodges, 1971)

9pm, TCM

Michael Caine gives a 15-minute introduction to this over-influential British thriller, reminiscing on what proved to be one of his definitive screen roles. There's no hint of his loveable Cockney twinkle in this well-'ard thriller; Carter is a very 'eavy London 'ood returning to his native Newcastle to sort out his brother's killers. It's all dour locations, dour faces (Ian Hendry, John Osborne, George Sewell) and violence. Brutally effective and, as Pauline Kael said, soulless.

Take Care of Your Scarf, Tatjana

(Aki Kaurismaki, 1994)

3.15am, FilmFour

Kaurismaki's smashing deadpan comedy is set in rock 'n' rolling 60s Finland, where two chums hit the road in a car equipped with inbuilt coffee machine. They pick up a pair of Estonia-bound Russian women, one the Tatjana of the title, and head off on the most whimsical and touching of trips: at a running time of just 65 minutes, the journey is all too short.

Where The Sidewalk Ends

(Otto Preminger, 1950)

4.20am, FilmFour

We've been here before - Preminger and his stars from Laura, Dana Andrews and Gene Tierney, reunited in another stylish, off-beat noir thriller. Scripted mainly by Ben Hecht, it has Andrews as a violent cop who beats a suspect to death, then concocts increasingly desperate plans to save himself and sweetheart Tierney. Andrews was rarely strung out so far from his dull, deadpan good guys: like a Bad Lieutenant but for a different age.
