fields.headline: Tomorrow's man
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: When Prince William was two years old he had a photo call. A TV cameraman unshouldered his camera like a bazooka and let him look in the eyepiece. Prince Charles said to the child "There are people in there. Trapped." That is a nightmare image. The man felt like a mouse.
fields.body:
When Prince William was two years old he had a photo call. A TV cameraman unshouldered his camera like a bazooka and let him look in the eyepiece. Prince Charles said to the child "There are people in there. Trapped." That is a nightmare image. The man felt like a mouse.

Prince William At 18 (ITV) was a well-thumbed collection of celebrated snaps. There are no unthumbed ones. His schooldays have been off limits. The editor of Tatler had an anecdote about a Eton schoolboy who was asked by his father what William was like. He said "I can't tell you. You're a journalist." One can only hope the sprog got a clip round the ear and a threat to return him to Bash Street Comprehensive in his tails.

We have every right to know what Prince William is like but, in fact, we only know what he looks like. On the evidence of the camera, he is tall, shy, polite, left-handed like George VI, and strikingly like his mother. As your grannie used to say, she'll never be dead while he is alive. "When I look at him it makes me shudder almost, because it's like looking at her. He blushes in exactly the same place on his cheeks. The way he laughs. His eyes. It's uncanny", said Jayne Fincher, who has an eye for such details, being a press photographer and the daughter of a press photographer.

William's sulky sabotage of the cameras - hiding his face, hanging his head - changed overnight when his mother died. He moved among the flood of flowers, shaking hands, saying "Thank you so much" while his softly repeated name "Wi..wi..wi..wi..wi", followed him like a little wind. Not a mouse but a man.

The beautifully filmed Wilderness Men (BBC2) was a refuge from the tramp of the 22 men, as the Harrow school song puts it. It was about Alexander von Humboldt. I thought he was a place. And so he is. A thousand places are named after him. Towns, rivers, mountains, an ocean current, a penguin even. He was a contemporary of Napoleon, but more celebrated and much better looking. Then, almost inexplicably, his fame was erased by Darwin. Who is also a place though not a penguin.

The fox knows many things but the hedgehog knows one big thing. Von Humboldt knew many things. David Attenborough called him the last universal man. He studied every science and believed all life was interrelated. Then Darwin, who admired him to the point of idolatry, formulated his theory of evolution and that was such a very big thing that it blotted out God.

For five years von Humboldt and the French botanist Bonpland explored South America, from the Amazonian rain forest, where man seems irrelevant, to the Andean volcanoes. Strictly speaking he should have died. Bonpland did get typhoid. He wrote like a romantic poet, which is rare in a scientist.

Personally I was gripped by the ghostly guacharo, a large gothic bird which lives in total darkness in an under ground cave and screams like a banshee when it spies strangers. And so would you if your breast were padded with cooking oil. David Attenborough indicated with his usual offhand modesty that he had been there too. "It's creepy. Suddenly you are in pitch darkness and hear this amazing, rattling, castanet-like call." Prince Charles said to the child "There are people in there. Trapped." That is a nightmare image. The man felt like a mouse. Prince William At 18 (ITV) was a well-thumbed collection of celebrated snaps. There are no unthumbed ones. His schooldays have been off limits. The editor of Tatler had an anecdote about a Eton schoolboy who was asked by his father what William was like. He said "I can't tell you. You're a journalist." One can only hope the sprog got a clip round the ear and a threat to return him to Bash Street Comprehensive in his tails. We have every right to know what Prince William is like but, in fact, we only know what he looks like. fields.headline: Enid's big adventure
fields.standfirst: Is it insane, or a stroke of genius? The Famous Five are coming to our screens - but updated for the 21st century. Children's author  Melvin Burgess  explains why Enid Blyton's young heroes continue to mesmerise us all
fields.trailText: Is it insane, or a stroke of genius? The Famous Five are coming to our screens - but updated for the 21st century. Children's author Melvin Burgess explains why Enid Blyton's young heroes continue to mesmerise us all
fields.body:
So the Famous Five are getting updated. Zenith Entertainment, who did a more traditional version of the Blyton classics a few years ago, want to do a contemporary Five for the new millennium. Same characters, but that's about all. New stories, and presumably new haircuts, new shoes and, who knows, new body piercings as well. Alcopops instead of ginger beer? Drug dealers instead of smugglers? Five go Clubbing? Hasn't it already been done by the Comic Strip?

So what for? The usual statement in Blyton's favour is that she gets kids reading and she is, in fact, a reading course all on her own, from Noddy to the Secret Seven. Tens of thousands of us have learned to love reading with her help and still do so today, despite the fact that she is so dated. Countless adults feel gratitude to her for that, and there's no reason to suppose, judging by the shelf space she occupies, that tomorrow's adults will feel any different. You can see why Zenith want to make her young again. How nice if the goose that lays the golden egg could be made to live forever.

It's a favourite game among writers and publishers to ponder what on earth it is that makes Blyton's appeal so strong. It's not easy to understand. The usual Eng. Lit. snobbery actually conceals a real failure of criticism to get to terms with the lasting appeal of this kind of book. The characters are cut outs, the plots predictable. Her prose style is utterly vile - sorry, but it's true. She's not even all that well loved; but she is so well read. We all read her and she's inside us and will stay with us forever, however much we may wish we were filled instead with, say Joyce or the Book of Psalms.

The questions Zenith will be asking themselves are, what stays in, what goes out, what gets added on? How reproducible is it? On this point, things may well look bright for them. Very few people remember any details from Blyton. You never hear conversations of the "Do you remember the bit where...?" kind. You're more likely to remember the cover than any particular plot item. Maybe that's part of the charm.

There are formulaic elements in her work that are translatable. Get rid of the grown ups, line up a group of children of varying gender and ages to provide someone for everyone to relate to. Finally - and this is what makes Blyton the writer she is - every minute has a hook, and every minute has a resolution. Are the Five going to get to go on holiday after all? Whose face was that at the window of the deserted house? Is George going to get better in time for the outing? It might even be as simple as, what's for tea? But there's one hook swallowed and another baited every page. You forget them as soon as you've read them, but they keep the pages turning.

With a clever writer, all this can be done. Plot, place, even style can be changed. But period? There's a vital element that lies right at the heart of her work that no amount of ingenuity will replace: nostalgia.

Nostalgia is an odd word to use in regard to children, but nostalgic they certainly are, and sentimental. If they're not, a page or two of Blyton will teach them how it's done. Books like these were never contemporary. Over fifty years ago, George Orwell pointed out that the world of Jeeves and Wooster hadn't actually existed for almost all of Wodehouse's working life, if ever. The whole point about this type of fiction is that it occurs in the past. The future isn't made of polished steel by accident, it's like that because its scary. It's full of strangers. You die in it. It has horrendous, life-threatening illnesses and accidents, one of which you will not survive. The same is true of the present. Every breath is different, you never know if you're going to finish it. But the past is friendly. You've known it all your life. It's so well upholstered, so comfortable, so easy. Even situations which drive most of us mad, like boarding school and families, look rosy in hindsight.

Ratty and Moley, Jennings and Derbyshire, Winker Watson, and of course Enid Blyton - none of them ever happened now. I suspect that the present will have the same effect on George and Ju and the rest as sunlight does on the vampire - they'll suddenly start ageing, turn to dust and die before our eyes. Zenith could try preserving her a little longer by pickling her not in the present but in the recent past. Nowhere too precise or local - somewhere in north London, perhaps, or the mid-west, if they have an eye on the export market. Personally though, I hope they fail. It's bad enough having the Blessed Enid staring out of yesterday at us from yards and yards of bookshop shelves without having her rise up from the dead to take over the present as well.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Are we reaching the point where a personal satellite will be able to offer us navigational directions or favourite old films?
fields.body:
Are we reaching the point where a personal satellite will be able to offer us navigational directions or favourite old films? Maybe not, but the technology is certainly heading that way. Two scientists working with nano-satellites talk to Quentin Cooper in Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4). They hope the widespread deployment of hundreds of tiny, cheap space vehicles will vastly increase our scientific understanding.

There's a three-hour special on the career of Sir John Gielgud. Michael Billington recalls the actor's many triumphs in chronological order. The first hour of Gielgud Centre Stage (9.0pm, Radio 3) runs from the 20s to the post war decade. The second traces the British theatre's kitchen-sink revolution up to the Swinging Sixties. The final section covers Gielgud's vigorous march through the last three decades of the 20th century. Contributors include David Hare, Richard Eyre, Irene Worth, and Peter Hall.

fields.headline: Notes and queries
fields.standfirst: Why dead birds are rarely seen * Pros and cons of yoghurt drinks * More on wine corks
fields.trailText: Walk anywhere and you see masses of birds, but you rarely see a dead one. Is the food chain incredibly efficiently at having them all gobbled up, or do they all go to a secret place to die?
fields.body:
Walk anywhere and you see masses of birds, but you rarely see a dead one. Is the food chain incredibly efficiently at having them all gobbled up, or do they all go to a secret place to die?

* Live birds attract attention in many ways: singing, flying in the sky, perching in prominent places and hopping around looking for food and twigs. Dead birds aren't as good at all that sort of stuff.

Ian Wallace, London SE16.

* Something like 600m birds from the British breeding population die each year. They die in all sorts of ways and have very different chances of being found.

For instance, a mute swan dying by flying into wires is very likely to cut off the electricity and provides a conspicuous mound of white feathers. Something like 40% of deaths of ringed mute swans get reported. Another bird, dying in the same way, may be so small and so well camouflaged that no one will notice it. The body may be snaffled completely by a scavenger like a fox or a magpie.

Of the deaths each year, about 60m are at the paws of domestic cats. Others occur on roads - and these are the dead birds we see. The bodies are an important reason for the increase in scavengers like foxes, magpies and crows: they provide a good food supply in winter when it used to be scarce. Active predators, like sparrowhawks, also take very large numbers of birds but prefer the easy ones that are a bit under the weather.

Otherwise we are not likely to find the body of a bird that feels unwell and drops dead off its perch in a bush. The smell of decay will attract mammals and insects that consider it lunch. The deaths of ringed small birds are typically reported at a rate of 1% to 2% if they live close to houses - like bluetits and robins - but this is reduced to 0.3% for tiny migrants living in the woods, like willow warblers or tree pipits.

Chris Mead, Thetford, Norfolk.

The electronic door key to my car has a range of about 30ft but this can be increased considerably if I direct it up under my chin and press the open or close button while looking towards the car. Why is this, and is it dangerous?

* Thanks for the tip about this method, by which we now open our electric gate. We are looking forward to expert advice in your column before we do ourselves irreversible brain damage.

My wife has discovered that the range can be increased still further if you also open your mouth wide - the wider the better. My own range-extender is to glare angrily at the receiver.

Brian Turner, St Genis Pouilly, France.

* Without pausing to consider how this theory was developed, the empirical evidence offered seems to indicate that the signal emitted through the bottom of this electronic "key" is much stronger than that projected through its muzzle. Therefore, if used as directed, this device must surely bombard the user's reproductive region with signals much stronger than required to open an automobile door lock. This may result - in the Darwinian sense - in the prevalence of those who persist in using metal keys at close range to get into their cars.

Bruce Levine, Ottawa, Canada.

Recently launched yoghurt drinks claim all sorts of health benefits but they seem very expensive too. The contents list itemises something called lactobacillus casei Shirota . Why is this stuff supposed to be so good for me and why does it cost so much?

* It's a bacterium found in dairy products and environments, as well as the human mouth, the small and large intestines and the vagina.

There is a large body of scientific literature on the subject which suggests, among other things, that oral ingestion of lactobacillus cultures can reduce diarrhoea in children, enhance the growth of the epithelial cells lining the gut and increase the levels of gut microflora in cases of malnutrition.

However, if you are in good health, have a varied diet and have not recently zapped your own gut bacteria with oral antibiotics, it seems unlikely that yoghurt drinks will have any other beneficial effect.

Why do these drinks cost so much? Probably because the manufacturers of these and other "health" products know that the people who buy them work on the (entirely mistaken) assumption that "the more it costs the more good it must be doing me".

Michael Hutton, London SE5.

* Lactobacillus casei Shirota is a lactic acid bacterium first isolated by Dr Minoru Shirota, a microbiologist at Kyoto University, in 1930. Most bacteria in dairy products are killed by stomach acids, but lactobacillus is a unique beneficial strain that can survive the stomach acids and reach the intestines in viable form.

There lactobacillus helps maintain a favourable balance among the billions of different bacteria which make up the intestinal flora. A poor diet, antibiotics, the stresses and strains of everyday life and the ageing process often upset this balance.

Every bottle of Yakult contains 6.5 billion lactobacillus casei Shirota bacteria. A daily bottle will top up the good bacteria in your digestive system. One hundred and ninety billion friendly bacteria per penny seems a bargain. At around 36p a bottle, Yakult costs less than most canned or bottled drinks.

Dr Colette Shortt, chief nutritionist, Yakult UK, London W3.

Agatha Christie's The Sittaford Mystery refers to a game called "Up, Jenkyns". What was this game, and what were the rules?

* My family played the game described by Betty Roycroft (Notes & Queries, May 11) with similar rules. The main difference was that Team B had to identify the location of the coin in the closed fists (not therefore concealed between thumb and forefinger as in her version) of Team A by studying facial expression or the twitching of muscles.

Members of Team B would take turns at trying to locate the coin, and each could have several attempts by tapping the suspect fist and saying: "Tip it." That fist had then to be opened. If it contained the coin, this was surrendered to Team B; if it did not the fist was removed from the table, leaving the rest of Team A unmoved, and Team B then tried again through a different member.

The game was usually played after a family meal, particularly Christmas dinner, when a sixpence from the pudding made an ideal target. An even more hysterical version involved using a ring on a continuous string which went all round the table. Passing the ring secretly among Team A without the jerking of the string revealing its whereabouts to Team B involved skill and daring; on occasions the ring could be lost and even end up on Team B's side.

Family lore has it that the game is so-called bacause it was played by young naval officers round the wardroom table using a small object representing the ear of Captain Robert Jenkins, whose claim that Spaniards cut off his ear in 1731 contributed to public enthusiasm for war with Spain eight years later (the War of Jenkin's Ear). Naval historians might like to comment.

Geoffrey Meredith, Norton St Philip, Somerset.

Why do wine bottles have a large indent in the base?

* Ray Cobbett, who considers wine corks to be a "ridiculous snobbery" (Notes & Queries, May 4), might like to consider that the traditional management of cork oak forest in Portugal, which supplies 80 per cent of the world's wine corks, is vital to both the economy of one of the poorest regions in Europe and the sustainability of one of the world's richest ecosystems. The cork oak forest, habitat of the Iberian lynx, black stork, Bonelli's eagle and Spanish imperial eagle, is under severe threat from the increasing use of plastic "corq" (manufactured by Supremecorq, in which Bill Gates is a major investor). Right-on wine drinkers should express concern to their supermarkets - especially Oddbins, which intends to phase out the use of corks by the end of the year.

Clare Butler, Milton Keynes, Bucks.

Any answers?

I bumped into a friend the other day but had forgotten his name. I know that he had forgotten mine too. How do you get out of such an embarrassing situation?

Jonathan Green, Highbury, London.

What was the purpose of covered bridges in North America?

Stephen Farrugia, Sydney, Australia.

I keep getting e-mails inviting me to obtain an international driver's licence which can never be suspended or revoked. Apparently, this privilege is guaranteed by the United Nations Convention on International Road Traffic (1949), and the World Court decision (The Hague, 1958). Is this true?

Quentin Burrell, Ballabeg, Isle of Man.

If we live in a market economy and pride ourselves on being a trading nation, how can ticket touting at sporting and artistic events be considered wrong or even illegal?

Peter Stokoe, Lambeth, London SE5.

On the death of the Queen , will QCs automatically become KCs?

Brian Robinson, Hutton, Essex.

Post answers to Notes & Queries, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax: 020-7239 9935 email: nq@theguardian.com Please remember to include your address and your phone number

Quentin Burrell, Ballabeg, Isle of Man. webTitle: Work in progress: Dionne Warwick, singer

fields.headline: Work in progress: Dionne Warwick, singer
fields.trailText: I'm touring the US at the moment with Gladys Knight and Randy Crawford. Some people are calling it the three divas show, but I prefer to call it the three friends show. Of course I know them both from way back. I met Gladys at the beginning of my career and we've been girlfriends every since; I've worked with her several times.
fields.body:
I'm touring the US at the moment with Gladys Knight and Randy Crawford. Some people are calling it the three divas show, but I prefer to call it the three friends show. Of course I know them both from way back. I met Gladys at the beginning of my career and we've been girlfriends every since; I've worked with her several times.

I met Randy in Australia 15 years ago and I don't see her as much as Gladys, but she's a lovely lady and I'm really looking forward to working with her for the first time. I think we have three different styles - Randy is more jazzy and blues, Gladys is R'n'B and soul,and I guess the category that I've mostly fitted in to would be pop - and we'll blend together really well.

We're coming over to Britain with the show, and it has been five or six years since I was last there. I'll be singing a mixture of the songs that everyone expects, the classics, as well as songs by people like Burt Bacharach, the Bee Gees, and some Brazilian songs that I've discovered since taking up residence in Brazil. I'm also collecting material together for my new album right now, which I'll be taking into the studio to record in September. Between that and being on the road, I'm just trying to fit in some sleep whenever I can. I'm on the road an awful lot, and even after 38 years of performing I couldn't say there was any magic formula for getting through it - you just do.

The fortunate part for me is I've always been able to reach an audience ranging from six to 60 with everything in between, and my supporters have never expected me to alter or be something I'm not. I think if there has been any change in my voice, it's just that it has matured.

Dionne Warwick performs with Gladys Knight and Randy Crawford, 28 June at Hammersmith Apollo (0870 606 3413), 29 June Birmingham NEC (0121 767 4900), 1 July MEN Arena (0161 930 8000)

fields.headline: Stars in their eyes
fields.standfirst: What happens when leading artists rework the old masters? Adrian Searle finds out at the Encounters, the National Gallery's new show
fields.trailText: What happens when leading artists rework the old masters? Adrian Searle finds out at the Encounters, the National Gallery's new show
fields.body:
Once I saw a man in the National Gallery with a concentrated, almost demented look on his face. He paced about, oblivious to the crowds, madly ploughing vectors and angles into his sketchpad with a felt tip pen that screeched, slid and jabbed across the paper. Visitors and tourists looked on, alarmed. Whatever he was doing - a kind of mad writing - appeared to have little to do with the masterpieces on the walls. Unless I am mistaken, this was Frank Auerbach, responding to an El Greco on loan from New York's Metropolitan Museum.

Auerbach, like many British artists, treats the National Gallery as a resource, returning time and again to study and rework its masterpieces. He is now one of the artists in Encounters: New Art From Old, which opened to the public yesterday. This is the National's ambitious attempt to link current international art with the old masters, with 25 leading names asked to make works inspired by its collection.

Art works are always both homage to and critique of the works that preceded them. There is no art work I can think of that does not bear some relationship to prior art. Manners change, intentions belong to a particular epoch and mentality, techniques and skills are lost and found.

Maybe the past and the present are capable of bearing witness to one another, in some curious unwitting dialogue. Auerbach's 1997-8 painting of Park Village East, close by Regent's Park, and Constable's Hay-Wain, with its carter crossing the Suffolk Stour, share the massing of trees on the left, a similar orientation of perspective, closeness and distance. There is a kind of reciprocation at work - as though one could trace each image in the lineaments of the other, substituting the poles of streetlights for elms, cars for a cart, a No Entry sign for a rotted stump by the river. But I am untouched by Auerbach's oblique transliteration.

In the 18th century, Constable and Turner both took from Claude and made of him very different things. Ian Hamilton Finlay, in Encounters, honours Claude too, in a visual poem and photographs of his Scottish garden at Little Sparta, where Claude's name is carved in stone. Ingres's drawings, meanwhile, inspired David Hockney's portraits of the National Gallery's attendants. Picasso also paid homage to Ingres, often tracing photographs of his subjects, rather than drawing them directly, to imitate the cleanliness and spareness of Ingres's line. I'd rather look at Picasso or Ingres any day. The Hockneys are a pleasant footnote.

Artists are surrounded by their peers and by their forebears. No artist can appreciate another's work with innocence. Jeff Wall takes a pop at George Stubbs, with a stage-managed light-box photograph of a Blackpool donkey in its stable. Champion the donkey carries children across the Blackpool sands on his back, while Stubbs's Whistlejacket, the prime racing stallion, is idealised against a blank background. Both animals have four legs, both give, or gave, pleasure. What more can be said? Wall's Donkey in Blackpool is a comment on class and breeding (the aristocracy of racehorses, the down-market appeal of the beach donkey), making somewhat the same point as Mark Wallinger in his earlier paintings of runners and jumpers.

Some artists in Encounters cannot bear comparison with their models. What can be done with Rembrandt's Hendrickje Stoffels, hoisting up her night-shift as she wades in a stream? Antoni Tapies gives us a woman's back, as though rendered in cement, feet drawn in with an aerosol. Did he need the Rembrandt to make this work? How did it inspire him? What do the two works say to one another? The answers are, respectively: no; it didn't; nothing.

RB Kitaj gets in a lather with Van Gogh, and the kind of people who didn't collect the artist in life, but push up the prices a century or so after his death. Kitaj, who now signs his paintings Ronald, sits a billionaire with a big cigar in Vincent's chair. It is a weak joke, and a weak yet angry painting. Both Stephen Cox and Anthony Caro aim for a kind of portentous architectural abstraction in their respective encounters with Duccio and Piero della Francesca. Cox's somnolent marble room is lucky to inhabit the same space as Louise Bourgeois' Cell XV (For Turner) and Bill Viola's response to Bosch's Christ Mocked (The Crowning of Thorns). Bourgeois' cell, with its mirrors, strange waterfall, lighting effects and shelves of jam-jars, is a peculiar response to the English landscape painter. "Turner was obsessed by nature, and I am obsessed by human nature," she says. Weird light and water connect them.

Bill Viola's slow-motion video, the Quintet of the Astonished, is a beautifully posed, lit and directed work. The five protagonists go through a gamut of expressions, touches and glances, each one a solitary within the group. As with his earlier slow-motion reworking of Pontormo, we are mesmerised by the fluid pacing of gestures and looks. It is wonderful. Where is Christ? The effect is like looking at how a painting unfolds in the mind of the spectator, and how memorable a tiny gesture can be. I suppose the model for this might be Bunuel's frozen moment, in the film Viridiana, when all the tramps at a dinner mimic exactly the composition of Leonardo's fresco of the Last Supper.

Lucian Freud copies Chardin's The Young Schoolmistress unaffectedly, discovering Chardin in himself and himself in Chardin, rendering Chardin's sitters as though they were his own, living models. He attempts a close likeness, but we know this is Freud painting Chardin, discovering in the process that there is no such thing as a straightforward copy, or a true original. Freud comes at the question of originality crab-wise. The connection between Anselm Kiefer and Tintoretto's Origin of the Milky Way is both intellectual and poetic, a commentary that makes one read Tintoretto in the light of the poetry of Paul Celan, via Kiefer. Some might ask how Kiefer aligns Tintoretto with Celan's poetry of the Holocaust.

The artist's business is the invention and reinvention of meaning. Everything and anything can be the artist's material. One of the things this exhibition does is wrest the works in the National Gallery back from the explainers, the interpreters and legitimators of art history, in favour of the creative process. Not that that is much evident in Howard Hodgkin's almost life-size transposition of Seurat's Bathers at Asnières. While much of the show is housed in the temporary exhibition spaces of the Sainsbury Wing, Hodgkin and Seurat hang together in the permanent collection. The Hodgkin is horrible, a monument to folly. His high-key, splotched, blobbed, smeared painting lacks everything Seurat has. Hodgkin cannot compete; Seurat kills him. There is no more to be said.

The status and value of contemporary art worry many people. If we didn't already have an idea what art is, we wouldn't have a clue as to whether the things we look at are art or not. History informs the present, but it is no judge. It wasn't made to judge, even if some works remain unsurpassable. You have to fight them on your own ground, honour them where you can. Encounters is an exhibition of successes and failures, but it is a brave attempt, and should be repeated.

Encounters is at the National Gallery, London WC2 (020-7747 2885), till September 17.

fields.headline: Never mind the dancing
fields.standfirst: The Kirov Ballet has created the most authentically lavish Sleeping Beauty in decades.  Judith Mackrell is enthralled
fields.trailText: The Kirov Ballet has created the most authentically lavish Sleeping Beauty in decades. Judith Mackrell is enthralled
fields.body:
Marius Petipa's Sleeping Beauty is the quintessence of aristocratic poise and purity; out of all the classics, it has most resisted the fantasies and depredations of modern producers. Only the very crass or brilliantly imaginative have dared to muddy its story with Freudian interpretation or political ideology (unlike the wilder, more romantic Swan Lake). So, watching Beauty today, we tend to regard the spectacle on stage as a pretty direct reflection of 19th-century classicism.

The Kirov's enthralling reconstruction of the original 1890 staging shows us how wrong we are. When the curtain opens on the Prologue, with its heavily ornamented set, its milling retinues of fairies and nobles and its blissful riot of costumes, we understand what it is like to time-travel back to the ballet of Petipa's era. This production, at the Royal Opera House, is three times more populated and 100 times more extravagant than modern-day stagings, which by comparison seem like dull parties where only half the guests have shown up.

The Kirov's previous Beauty was much the same, but when the company came to mount a new production, Ballet director Makhar Vaziev was determined to discover some of the work's authentic style. He was directed back to 312 pages of early notation (recorded in St Petersburg but smuggled out of revolutionary Russia and subsequently housed in Harvard) and to extensive photographic records of the original staging. Although companies in the West have based productions on the notation, the choreography, especially the mime, has been edited over the years to suit new dancers and audiences. The original costumes, too, have been streamlined for today's more athletic movers. So this new/old Beauty is as much of a revelation to us as it was to the Russians.

With a cast of 157, it's not only bigger and more lavish but far more leisurely than the work we're used to. Huge crowds of characters - court, peasant and fairy tale - process around the stage, taking all the time they need to show off their costumes and converse in the quaintly-emphatic gestures of 19th century mime. Rather than looking creaky and cumbersome, this pantomimic version makes much better sense of the choreography. We always knew Petipa was a whizz at mobilising his dancers, orchestrating them into dense patterns, then thinning them out to frame brief, dazzling solos. But with all these extra performers the full grandeur of his scheme becomes obvious: the textures of his composition are more intricate, the processionals have a new weight and grandeur, and the solos emerge from the choruses with a more seamless, musical rhythm.

The ballet's story also becomes more poetic and more believable. In our spare modern productions, the action takes place in a depopulated world where the delicate drama looks forced. Here there is life and variety. Aurora's birthday party, for instance, is set in the palace grounds (rather than the formal ballroom we're accustomed to) and the early summer leaves and flowers create a proper pastoral context for the famous Rose Adagio. There are so many guests at this party we're no longer surprised that Aurora can be handed the fateful needle unseen. Usually her parents seem to be ignoring Carabosse's interventions in a bizarre attack of parental myopia. In this production, they're credibly distracted by the huge crowd.

A production that sells itself on authenticity may sound like fun for only a handful of scholars and ballet fanatics, but its four hours pass much more quickly than most of the slicker three hour versions. There is so much to look at, and it changes so rapidly (particularly when driven by the glorious brio of the Mariinsky orchestra), while the costumes alone (500 of them) are worth the trip; even though they have been modified to suit a modern build and technique, they still look like an old photo album come to vivid life. The colours rewrite the rule book and the detailing is sublime. The Lilac Fairy in her floral wreaths and helmet is particularly unmissable - an adorable cross between Britannia and Bo Peep.

The least pleasing element is the dancing, which on Monday was technically adroit but stylistically limited. Diana Vishneva's Aurora moved with a scintillating speed but failed to modulate into tenderness or grandeur. Igor Zelensky as her Prince did his usual star turn with the steps but seemed to have his mind on his next engagement. This, however, is a rare Kirov show where the dancing isn't the central issue. The star is the production itself and, as with all the greatest stars, the world tilts on its axis when you see it.

Sleeping Beauty is in rep at the Royal Opera House, London WC2 (020-7304 4000), till August 10.

fields.headline: Arafat cracks down on broadcasters
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: A day after saluting the coffin of Syria's late dictator, the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, was on his way to Washington yesterday to try to re-energise the plodding Middle East peace talks.
fields.body:
A day after saluting the coffin of Syria's late dictator, the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, was on his way to Washington yesterday to try to re-energise the plodding Middle East peace talks.

He leaves behind a Palestinian public hoping that the salute was protocol, rather than confirmation of their suspicions that his state-in-the-making is going the way of Syria where dissent is stifled.

There is plenty to feed their fears. In the last few weeks, four television and two radio stations have been shut by the Palestinian police under the orders of Mr Arafat. Dozens of people have been arrested.

The crackdown - a sign of Mr Arafat's jitters as he enters the end-game in making peace with Israel - follows rioting in the West Bank and Gaza over the scant gains to come out of the talks. At the same time, he is under pressure from Israel and the US, where he is to meet President Clinton today, for a compromise.

"The Palestinian police are continually violating the press law without any intervention from the ministry of information," said Bassam Eid of the Palestinian Human Rights Monitoring Group.

The crackdown goes beyond the media. Dozens of members of Mr Arafat's Fatah organisation have been jailed recently as well as eight leaders of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. Most were released after a few days.

In the 90s, many Palestinians hoped their home would be an oasis of free speech. But it seems clear now that Mr Arafat will tolerate private stations only if they do not broadcast anything seen as remotely challenging his authority.

The crackdown - a sign of Mr Arafat's jitters as he enters the end-game in making peace with Israel - follows rioting in the West Bank and Gaza over the scant gains to come out of the talks. At the same time, he is under pressure from Israel and the US, where he is to meet President Clinton today, for a compromise. "The Palestinian police are continually violating the press law without any intervention from the ministry of information," said Bassam Eid of the Palestinian Human Rights Monitoring Group. The crackdown goes beyond the media. Dozens of members of Mr Arafat's Fatah organisation have been jailed recently as well as eight leaders of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. Most were released after a few days. In the 90s, many Palestinians hoped their home would be an oasis of free speech. But it seems clear now that Mr Arafat will tolerate private stations only if they do not broadcast anything seen as remotely challenging his authority.

webTitle: The rise and rise of little voice

fields.headline: The rise and rise of little voice
fields.standfirst:
For years, men have written the love songs that women sing. The songs that speak of hurt and longing and missing their man. Now women are calling their own tune. Ruth Padel reports

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: For years, men have written the love songs that women sing. The songs that speak of hurt and longing and missing their man. Now women are calling their own tune.  Ruth Padel reports
fields.body:
The sound men most want to hear, says the Marquis de Sade, is a woman's cry when you're inside her. It tells the world you have this shattering power to make her feel. When Duke Ellington was 12, he and his mates took girls to the reservoir banks, in hearing distance of each other, to see "who did the greater job as a man". The marker was noise. "If the girl's reaction was loud, he was a great fucker because the chick was hollering 'Baby, I'm coming', all that shit." Competition was hot: "Some cats pinched the chicks to make them holler. One slipped his quarters."

For centuries, men have turned that cry into music by writing the love songs that women sing. From "ma man don't love me and he treats me oh so mean" to Mozart's countess in Figaro lamenting her husband's faithlessness, men have written songs that defined the female voice as vulnerable. Hurt by a man. Longing for him. Abandoned. "The problem with operas," Glyndebourne director Graham Vick says, "is they're written by men full of notions that women can't live without them."

I wanted to write a book about what effect this might have on women making music now. Most women, singers or listeners, have in their heads thousands of songs written by men, which seem to express women's feelings. Bessie Smith, Billie Holiday and Edith Piaf did write songs, but until the 70s (give or take trailblazers like Janis Joplin), women mostly sang men's songs and sounded how men wanted them to sound. The difference between women's love songs and men's was that women's were by the people they were about. Carly Simon took off that tradition in You're So Vain (1972). But the trouble with singing "Bet you think this song is about you, don't you?" is ... he's right.

Researching the book, I talked to singers, composers, directors and got the performer's answer - that your job is to feel a song's sentiments until they are your own. "Bessie Smith takes a lyric and makes it like she wrote it," Marianne Faithfull said.

When Josephine Barstow sang Violetta in Verdi's Traviata, was she ware of serving a man's idea of a woman's feelings? "I couldn't look at it that way," she says. "If I think: 'I'm expressing Verdi's desire, not Violetta's', it's not going to work. I have to express Violetta's feeling, try to work out where she's at."

Singers can't afford to distance themselves from the song. "It never bothered me," Faithfull says, "that songs were written from a man's point of view. I don't believe gender's important in a song."

But if women singers and listeners are so used to identifying with men's ideas of how they feel, how can they know how their own feelings sound? Wouldn't their songs follow suit and highlight the vulnerable voice men have given women for centuries?

To an extent, they did. Until the 70s, most women in pop worked, more or less, with man-made ideas of how women sound. What changed everything was punk. Overnight, lyric content was transformed. You got songs about cigarettes, murderers, traffic lights, masturbation. And when punk blew every stereotype to bits, ideas of voice changed, too. "Oh bondage, up yours," screeched Poly Styrene, whose name challenged the artificiality of how women look and sound. "I am a cliché." She and Siouxsie Sioux had a lasting effect. "Siouxsie made me feel things were possible," Shirley Manson of Garbage says.

The punk ethos also brought technical changes. Up to the 80s, most women guitarists used a folk stroke, down-up. Rock style is everything on a down stroke, which makes the music more precise, urgent, aggressive. After punk, women began to switch. Early Elastica played folk-stroke, loose and floppy. When they used a rock right hand, the music sounded different. Sharper edge, sharper beat.

But women were up against something bigger than guitar technique. Above all, there was that rhythm thing. Beat is the heart of rock and roll, and the core of male sexuality. "Male ecstasy in performance starts here," Patti Smith said in 1978, jerking at an imaginary penis. "Building and building till the big spurt at the end."

Rock 'n' roll was first made by men to express, basically, being a man. The Stones took their name from Muddy Waters: "I'm a man, I'm a rolling stone." The astonishing thing about music in the 50s and 60s was the blatant staging of male sexuality. Male self-myths seem to be coded into the chords and style: the dreams of being a hero, violent, omnipotent and dark. The main challenge faced by women in rock is the maleness of their medium.

"There's this huge fuss about women in rock," Manson says, "but I don't feel anything has changed. The whole industry is run by men. How can you change an attitude and an atmosphere? It's nonsense."

Rock's classic sexual politics mean "powerful sexy men and girls on their knees sucking off the stage-hand for a glimpse of God", as a Courtney Love fan put it. There are no male groupies. "I've never been approached and I've never met a female star who has," Chrissie Hynde insists.

This imbalance gives women's work the edge. Rock has always got its energy from challenge. One reason some of the best rock around today is by women is that they make their response to rock maleness their starting point. Women like Kristin Hersh, PJ Harvey and Shirley Manson handle voice or guitar or lyrics differently from pre-punk musicians. Everything is stronger: challenging, not a victim voice. Manson says she likes Hynde's voice because "it's vulnerable and strong".

Perhaps you can best illustrate the problems of women's lyrical relation to male rock tradition by how you hold a guitar. What should women do? You play best higher, but it looks wrong. If you hold it crotch-level, you're imitating men. As for breasts, do you go for one squashed, the other hanging over? Since punk and especially since the early 90s, women have just flung away the worry and got on with it - brilliantly. Voice and stroke, stance and lyrics. Women rockers are a great example of women taking male tradition somewhere new. And maybe it's the first time women are making a sound to express not what men have said they experience but what they really feel.

Ruth Padel's I'm A Man: Sex, Gods and Rock 'n' Roll is published by Faber on July 10 at £12.99.

fields.headline: Uh-oh those summer nights
fields.standfirst: Pity poor Tony Blair: voted the man women would least like to take on holiday. But maybe it's not just him ...  Maggie O'Farrell on bad beach mates
fields.trailText: Pity poor Tony Blair: voted the man women would least like to take on holiday. But maybe it's not just him ...  Maggie O'Farrell on bad beach mates
fields.body:
It's been a bad week for Tony Blair. Fatherhood hasn't done him any favours with the XX chromosome crowd. First catcalls from the formidable doyennes of the WI, now a survey from thomascook.com names him as the man women would least like to take on holiday.

I'm not a huge fan of our prime minister, but I have to say that this seems a little harsh. He'd rub in your sun cream, wouldn't he? He'd pay his way, he wouldn't show off in the pool, he'd never get bladdered on sangria. What this survey does, though, is get you thinking about your lowest companion denominator (was Adolf Hitler included in the options? Bernard Manning?), tapping into the deep fear of the Holiday For Two. Because what from a distance may appear to be a beautiful opportunity for people in a relationship to spend some high-quality relaxation time together is, in reality, a vicious, brutal, make-or-break Darwinian selection ritual.

Your choice of vacation partner is therefore crucial and should be approached with the same caution as buying a property - obtain full surveys and previous owner reports if possible. When I was embarking on a three-month trip around Asia with a boyfriend, a much older and wiser friend said: "That's the equivalent of being married for 10 years." A holiday is a relationship hothouse: whatever is there already will grow, and grow quickly, whether it's nice fruit or horrible choking weeds.

You are about to see your chosen partner as you've never seen them before. You'll be with them every single waking and sleeping moment. You'll get to know every habit, tic, mannerism, weakness. You'll be sharing bed, bathroom, breathing space, balcony, paperback - and possibly a mutual antipathy.

I have a friend who stamped back from a week in the Algarve with an apparently charming chap. "How was it?" I ventured at the sight of her furious and freckled face. "Over," she snarled: every day she'd had to watch him pick his nose and wipe it on the gear stick of the hire car.

I went away once with a man I'd known for several months and discovered that he not only masticated muesli with his mouth open but liked to trim his toenails with his teeth (while watching TV). This wasn't exactly how I'd envisaged the utilisation of his penchant for yoga.

There was a woman who found out her new boyfriend was unable to pass a woman in a bikini without giving her a score. Another who "decided it was a dead loss" when he appeared on the beach in a pair of those tight, bright Speedo penis pouches. Someone else who went away with a man who produced a pocket calculator at every cafe table to divvy up the bill according to who ate what. She finally cracked on day three when he pointed out that she'd eaten more bread than him.

But it's not just that you might stumble on the dark habits of your newly beloved. There are also inherent dangers in holidays for those seemingly solid couples who have been together for years. The microscope intensity of a fortnight alone together can produce cracks and widen those fissures you are usually able to ignore. The usual distractions and dilutions of friends, phones, flats, housework, offices and televisions all fall abruptly silent. Suddenly it's just the two of you, facing each other across a taverna table, wide-eyed with shock.

Holidays are not only rare, but cost hard-earned cash: the pressure to be happy is so overwhelming that you can end up flipping to the other extreme and behaving like a poisonous harpy. And while no one the right side of sanity and reason really expects to stroll hand in hand in the briny surf at twilight every night, if you happen to sense yourselves scoring a few notches below Absolute Romance, you might just find yourself gripped with paranoid doubts. Do you really love him? Does he love you? Do you even like him?

In an Emily Perkins short story, a couple on holiday sit down for dinner, "get a bit drunk and each try to think of something personal to tell the other that they didn't already know". I defy anyone to read this and not wince, recognising themselves and some God-awful holiday they've taken in the past. Tony might not be so bad after all.

fields.headline: Vivendi in Seagram takeover talks
fields.trailText: Vivendi, the French media and telecommunications business that is fast becoming a significant power, yesterday confirmed that negotiations are under way for a $30bn (£22bn) three-way merger with the music, film and drinks company Seagram and the pay-television business, Canal Plus.
fields.body:
Vivendi, the French media and telecommunications business that is fast becoming a significant power, yesterday confirmed that negotiations are under way for a $30bn (£22bn) three-way merger with the music, film and drinks company Seagram and the pay-television business, Canal Plus.

A joint statement said negotiations are under way "to create a three-way strategic business combination", which would effectively be a takeover of the Montreal-based Seagram. The deal is likely to be structured on an all-paper basis and will create a company worth around $100bn.

The merger would combine the content produced by Universal studios' film-making business and the largest music publishing operation in the world, with distribution through the Canal Plus pay TV and mobile telephone networks, including Cegetel in France. Importantly, the advent of third generation mobile telephones which can access high bandwidth services will provide another distribution platform.

The deal would be a step change in chief executive Jean-Marie Messier's reshaping of Vivendi, the former water company Générale des Eaux.

The acquisition would result in the subsequent sale of Seagram's spirits business. Vivendi is already in the process of spinning off its utilities arm, which will leave it a sharply focused media and communications company.

Mr Messier has spread Vivendi's tentacles across Europe and in Britain has a 25% stake in Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB satellite broadcaster as well as a holding in online directory business Scoot.com. It was also among the bidders for mobile telephone network One2One last year.

Vivendi owns a 49% stake in Canal Plus and last year rattled Mr Murdoch by making onerous demands in talks to merge the company with BSkyB which were later abandoned.

Mr Murdoch, however, has developed a grudging respect for Mr Messier and has invited Vivendi to play a role in Platco, the proposed company which will house News Corporation's global satellite interests.

Vivendi is developing an online portal Vizzavi in partnership with Vodafone-AirTouch which will be available through mobiles, PCs and television screens and which would also benefit from the additional content.

The sale would dispel the question mark which has long been hanging over the future of Seagram. The Bronfman family which still controls the company has held talks with a number of potential buyers in recent years. Earlier discussions with Vivendi broke down some months ago.

America Online's merger with Time Warner has set the tone for a new style of media operation combining content with distribution on conventional and new media.

webTitle: Not even the fox can save you now, Tony

fields.headline: Not even the fox can save you now, Tony
fields.standfirst:
Blair the weathercock
Why France is the place for a left-leaning country dweller
fields.trailText:
Blair the weathercock
Why France is the place for a left-leaning country dweller
fields.body:
I've been a Labour voter since I was 21. I've never not voted Labour, even in 1979, when the temptation was so strong - partly because "Farmer" Jim Callaghan left the dead unburied in the streets while he went to Guadeloupe and partly because of the historic thrill of electing a female head of government. I vote Labour because I lean left: there's no choice. Left on abortion (pro), left on capital punishment (anti), left on drugs (legalise everything in the pharmacy except heroin and tiger parts), left on the royal family (cut them down to three palaces, nationalise the Canalettos). I'm way to the left of Jack Straw on "bogus" asylum seekers (I'd far rather live in a country that's besieged by asylum seekers than one from which you'd want to seek asylum). I don't object to higher taxes. I voted for Tony Blair in the full expectation that he would wring my paycheck until it squealed. I barely mutter even now about shovelling 50 quid's worth of petrol into the car while my New York friends pay 99 cents a gallon and my brother in the north gets it off a bloke he knows.

But now I feel pathetically gulled, and cheated, and patronised. And disenfranchised, which is worse. Tony Blair is a weathercock, a trimmer and a poltroon, a faker who can't control his own soppy suburbanite backbenchers, a man without any principle except that of re-election. He's prepared to spend parliamentary time and effort flogging away at an emotional side issue so pathetically unimportant that it makes my teeth grit: whether 50,000 or so "toffs" can tally-ho or not tally-ho among the shire counties.

This is the man who said (last July) "I think it is quite wrong to see fox hunting as the big issue in the countryside. I think people in the countryside are interested in the issues like rural transport, crime, the future of the post offices, jobs in the countryside." Damn right - but by 2003, there'll be no post offices left in the countryside (as well as no jobs, no banks, no transport and no police stations), because Alistair Darling will be paying all state benefits monthly by then (by cheque), into the bank accounts most pensioners don't have. Hopefully, my mother will have popped her clogs by then and I won't need to pay the bank charges.

Labour backbenchers look happier than they've looked since the glorious First of May. I wouldn't mind, but they don't cram the Commons for unglamorous and tedious legislation about disablement benefits or the pensions policy, do they? They'll be baying en masse for the hunting with dogs bill, a "personal issue", an emotional issue, a good old-fashioned anti-toff issue.

Haven't they anything better to do? Like re-tool the pathetic health service? Raise the standards in state schools? "Eradicate child poverty within a generation"? (Last year, it was "eradicate child cruelty within a generation", but that was before the embarrassing league table popped up, showing Cool Britannia ranking 20th out of 23 rich western countries.) Haven't they anything better to ban? Like arms for dictators? There must be fewer arms manufacturers than there are toffs - why don't they go after them like a terrier down a foxhole?

I've lived in the country, on a small potholed road on the Hampshire-Berkshire borders, for more than half my life. I've never hunted, never even sat on a horse, never followed a hunt, never shot anything. My nearest toff is Andrew Lloyd-Webber and I don't think he hunts anything except Pre-Raphaelites at Sotheby's. I've only ever seen half a dozen foxes in my life (and two of those in south London).

I know there are no logical "pro-hunting" arguments: hunting is like smoking - fiercely addictive for the few, fiercely disliked by the many. You wouldn't dare invent it if it wasn't around already. But there are no logical anti-hunting arguments either, certainly not from the baying backbenchers. Lord Burns did his diffident best with "We are satisfied that this experience seriously compromises the welfare of the fox," but can you seriously push through anti-libertarian legislation over that? Fishing compromises the welfare of fish. Handbags compromise the welfare of pigs. Beefburgers compromise the welfare of cows. Are we to ban them all? We're not Jains, for pity's sake.

A Labour MP I heard on The World at One was trying to explain why the proposed anti-hunting bill was suddenly so urgent. It, he said, wasn't about "the difference between townspeople and country people". Not at all. No. It was about "the difference between those who get pleasure from killing animals and those who are repelled by it". I'm personally pretty repelled by having to kill anything bigger than my index finger, but what am I supposed to do with the half-dead fieldmice and starlings the cat drags in? Put them in a shoebox and drive them to the vet? Or knock them on the head with the back of a brush and shove the corpses in the compost-heap?

In a free democracy, you oughtn't to ban minority pleasures because you're repelled by them. I'm repelled by massage parlours, for a start. And Labour MPs scenting blood from old ancestral wars.

Maybe it's time to emigrate

John Prescott is suddenly promising 40,000 houses a year for the next five years throughout the south of England. Another 40,000 ex-townies mashing up the potholes with their four-wheel drives, another 40,000 households to fail to police (except part-time, mornings only, three days a week). Labour really has got it in for the countryside, hasn't it? I'm going to have to move out of here before it turns into a seamless suburb of west London.

France suddenly looks like a robust sort of a place for a left-leaning country-dweller to live. The French have somehow managed to hang on to all the kinds of things I'm nostalgic for: unions calling wildcat strikes on a principle; busy, efficient hospitals curing cancer; state schools effectively teaching both the dim and the clever without being bossed to distraction by HM Inspectorate twice yearly. Minority pleasures that would get you fire-bombed in Britain are still allowed as well: bullfighting in the Roman theatre at Arles, a foie gras farm just down the road from the villa I've got my eye on.

And it's cheap. My son has been living in Paris for the past eight months on the now mandatory "year abroad". His Eurostar fare from Waterloo to Paris was £149 return. Booked from Gare du Nord to Waterloo, the same journey is £49 return, on the day, any train, no restrictions, on production of his international student card.

In September he'll be going back to Manchester for his final year. The return fare from Euston, on a clapped-out Virgin puffer, pre-booked dates only, on selected off-peak trains only, limited accommodation only, will be £45 (more after September 23). Manchester has the biggest student population in Britain, but production of an international student card will get them nowhere.

fields.headline: No: 1656 Ermine Street Guard
fields.trailText: Founded: 1972.
fields.body:
Founded: 1972.

Official description: "A society dedicated to research into the Roman army and the reconstruction of Roman armour and equipment."

Amateur gladiators who spend the weekends prancing around fields with shields, you mean? Enough of your insolence, or you'll feel the sharp end of my onager.

I'm sure I'd be scared if I knew what you were talking about. The onager, as it happens, was a small version of the ballista, a vicious Roman missile launcher that has, erm, catapulted the Gloucester-based Guard into the spotlight this week.

Don't tell me - they've started selling them to corrupt military regimes overseas. Not quite. The pretend centurions have been somewhat over-enthusiastically raising the roof of a Mr Michael Maltin, a former second world war fighter pilot, in the normally peaceful village of Woodchester, near Stroud. Mr Maltin had outfoxed Germany's greatest military strategists, but proved defenceless when one of the 6in diameter wooden missiles fired by the Gloucester gladiators caught the wind and came crashing through the roof of his house.

Resulting, presumably, in bloodshed, carnage and mass death, Roman-style? Nobody was hurt, actually, and Maltin has more prosaic concerns. "This isn't the sort of damage you could easily account for on an insurance claim," he observed, a thought which probably went through the Barbarians' minds on a few occasions.

Presumably the Guard remain defiant. Nope. Chris Haines - the guard's centurion, when he's not being a farmer - mumbled: "We're very sorry for the damage, which we have promised to repair . . . The Romans would have used stone balls but thankfully we use wooden ones the size of a skittle, which is probably just as well."

Most likely to say: "I come not to praise Caesar, but to prang his roof."

Not to be confused with: Hill Street Blues, the Bash Street Kids.

fields.headline: No smoke in their eyes
fields.standfirst:
A telling exposé of the tobacco trade
Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: At last we have a parliamentary report blowing apart a scandal which has lain at the heart of public health policy for nearly half a century. Gone is the equivocation and hesitancy: here is a trenchant and damning document from the Commons select committee on health which exposes the tobacco companies' cynical manipulation of both their customers and the government in the pursuit of profit.
fields.body:
At last we have a parliamentary report blowing apart a scandal which has lain at the heart of public health policy for nearly half a century. Gone is the equivocation and hesitancy: here is a trenchant and damning document from the Commons select committee on health which exposes the tobacco companies' cynical manipulation of both their customers and the government in the pursuit of profit. Showing an independence of spirit rare in the parliamentary Labour party, the committee chairman, David Hinchliffe, subjects the government to scathing criticism ranging from its pusillanimity over tobacco advertising on Formula One through to lack of ambition in its targets to cut down smoking. This report should come to be seen as a turning point, finally coming to grips with an industry which kills 120,000 people a year, and which has succeeded, as Mr Hinchliffe concludes, in "running rings around successive governments. Regulation is still entirely inadequate."

What will delight anti-smoking campaigners is the committee's endorsement of the Royal College of Physicians' conclusion that smokers' addiction to nicotine is comparable to the addiction to heroin or cocaine. The committee re ports shocking material gathered by the US Food and Drugs Administration showing how tobacco companies add chemicals to ease the nicotine absorption and manipulate nicotine levels to addictive levels. The tobacco companies' marketing methods come in for heavy censure for the way they flout voluntary advertising codes and undermine government policy to target children and young people - memorably, Gallaher described their customers as "slobs" as they tried to hook poorly educated young people on the habit which could kill them.

The recommendations are as broad as the diagnosis. For a start, the report wants a halt to tobacco advertising on Formula One as soon as possible. It calls for a powerful, properly funded Tobacco Regulatory Authority to call the industry to order. And for good measure, it lobs a political hot potato into Stephen Byers's lap, demanding that the Department of Trade and Industry should investigate allegations of British American Tobacco's encouragement of international smuggling. Mr Hinchliffe and his colleagues have set a tough benchmark against which to measure the government's much-vaunted claims of a tough stance on tobacco. Congratulations.

webTitle: Haiti poll row fuels international alarm

fields.headline: Haiti poll row fuels international alarm
fields.trailText: Haiti, one of the poorest countries in the world, is being drawn into a destabilising confrontation with the international community about disputed election returns. Opposition parties have denounced the results as fraudulent and are boycotting a second round of senate races.
fields.body:
Haiti, one of the poorest countries in the world, is being drawn into a destabilising confrontation with the international community about disputed election returns. Opposition parties have denounced the results as fraudulent and are boycotting a second round of senate races.

Three weeks after the first round of the long delayed vote to choose a new senate and chamber of deputies, supporters of Jean-Betrand Aristide and his victorious Fanmi Lavalas party are stepping up demands that the Organisation of American States confirm their landslide victory.

Polling stations have been burned down. Graffiti urging the OAS election monitors to go home have been sprayed on buildings across the capital.

Rather than confirming the indebted Caribbean country's final transition from dictatorship to full democracy, the election has cast a shadow on this autumn's presidential contest in which Mr Aristide is expected to return to office.

Haiti has been without a parliament for 18 months. The election on May 21 was remarkably calm after the deaths of 15 people in campaign violence. The turnout was also high: nearly 60%. No one doubts that Fanmi Lavalas won more votes than its rivals and will have command a majority in both houses of the new parliament.

In his air-conditioned villa in Petionville, high above the sprawling, coastal shanty towns, Orlando Marville, the head of the OAS electoral monitoring mission to Haiti, said he was baffled by the furore over his call for a recalculation of the votes.

"I don't understand the problem," said Mr Marville, a former diplomat from Barbados. "We would like to see the votes being recalculated. You would assume that the party that is leading well anyway would not have a great deal of difficulty [with that]."

At issue is whether any opposition senators will be elected at all. The way votes have been calculated by Haiti's provisional electoral council (CEP) has meant that Mr Aristide's party won 16 of the 19 senate seats contested in the first round. Most seats in the chamber of deputies are going to a second round. To win a seat, a candidate had to poll 50% plus one vote. By taking into account only votes for the top four candidates, in most cases, the CEP ensured that Fanmi Lavalas candidates were elected without a run-off. "In a majority of cases the candidates were not elected by the correct calculation," Mr Marville said.

But a Lavalas official, Patrick Norzeus, has warned that "the people will mobilise" if the senate results are revised.

In Creole "Lavalas" means the flash floods which wash down Haiti's mountains, removing the rotting piles of debris accumulating on the streets. The name was chosen by Mr Aristide's political movement to signify a clean break from past decades of corruption and dictatorship under the Duvalier family.

Mr Aristide, a former priest who won the presidential elec tion in 1990 only to be forced into exile for several years by a military coup, has stayed silent. The current president, René Préval, elected after the US military restored civilian rule in 1994, remains close to Lavalas and Mr Aristide and has been more vocal.

Mr Préval dismisses the claims of fraud. "The opposition has members on the electoral council, the opposition is present at all levels of the electoral machinery - so who has made the fraud?" he said.

But Suzy Castor, a defeated senate candidate for the opposition OPL, said: "What we saw on May 21 was a coup to destroy democracy. It's totalitarian power, the same as under the Duvaliers." Her party has pulled out of the election.

The inflamed rhetoric is qualified by foreign observers who caution that the opposition failed to organise sufficiently. "There have been bad losers and bad winners," one observer remarked.

But there have been no arrests for the killings before the vote, fuelling an atmosphere of suspicion. "There's impunity in this country if you have connections with someone in power," Pierre Espérance, director of the Coalition for Haitian Rights said.

The second round of parliamentary elections is due later this month. The OAS has no power to intervene, only to write a final report.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Kosovo ban on Albanian leader
After being told he was unwelcome by UN authorities running Kosovo, the former Albanian president Sali Berisha was forced to cancel a visit yesterday.
fields.body:
Kosovo ban on Albanian leader
After being told he was unwelcome by UN authorities running Kosovo, the former Albanian president Sali Berisha was forced to cancel a visit yesterday.

"Berisha's arrival could make the situation more tense," said a UN spokeswoman in the disaffected Yugoslav province where vengeance killings by the ethnic Albanian majority continue against Serbs.

Border sources said UN troops had been ordered to keep Mr Berisha out.
Reuters, Pristina Victory claim by Ethiopia
Ethiopia said yesterday that its army had retaken a key town in western Eritrea, Tesseney. The Ethiopian foreign minister, Seyoum Mesfin, said he now expected his government to sign a peace deal ending the two-year war.

According to the UN, the last month of fighting has forced up to 750,000 Eritreans from homes and farms.
Reuters, Addis Ababa

Swiss accused of abuses
Amnesty International's annual report yesterday said Swiss police have been maltreating deportees. It said victims had told of their feet being shackled, of being belted into wheelchairs and having tape put on their mouths and heads.

An Arab deportee died at Zurich's Kloten airport last year.
Reuters, Geneva

Suicide blast in Sri Lanka
A suspected Tamil Tiger suicide bomber rammed his bicycle into a bus carrying 25 sick Sri Lankan government troops yesterday, killing himself and two passers-by on the highway from the capital, Colombo, to the international airport, police said.

Officials said the toll would have been worse, but the bus driver became suspicious of the cyclist and swerved.
AP, Colombo

Jakarta leader under suspicion
Indonesian police want to question President Abdurrahman Wahid about a scandal involving the theft of $4.1m (£2.7m) from the state commodities regulator, Bulog, local television reported yesterday.

Mr Wahid has previously said he considered using Bulog funds for projects in the troubled northern Aceh province, but instead used a $2m donation from the sultan of Brunei. A senior presidential adviser has resigned over the Bulog affair.
Reuters, Jakarta

Airlift for Zimbabwe pets
Spurred by TV footage in April showing pets being beaten to death or maimed by groups invading white-owned farms in Zimbabwe, a Johannesburg-based group has started flying out cats and dogs caught in the violence.

British Airways has donated space on three flights from Zimbabwe to South Africa for 10 pets at a time, the Wet Nose Animal Rescue Centre said.

Seven dogs and two cats arrived in South Africa on Tuesday. More are expected soon, as the group says it has a permit to bring out 100 animals initially.
Reuters, Johannesburg

webTitle: Iceland makes big switch to organic veg

fields.headline: Iceland makes big switch to organic veg
fields.trailText: The supermarket chain Iceland yesterday raised the stakes in the store wars by announcing it is to switch its entire own brand frozen vegetable range to organic - at no extra cost to the consumer.
fields.body:
The supermarket chain Iceland yesterday raised the stakes in the store wars by announcing it is to switch its entire own brand frozen vegetable range to organic - at no extra cost to the consumer.

The company claimed to have bought up nearly 40% of the world's organic vegetable supplies to meet the growing demand from customers.

It is paying farmers around the world between 10% and 25% more over three-year contracts, and will cut £8m from its profit margins to avoid charging higher prices.

The aggressive marketing move follows the company's non-GM policy and decision to remove artificial colouring and flavouring from own-brand products.

The policy will mean 2lb bags of frozen vegetables will remain under £1.50, and frozen peas at £1.19.

Supermarket competitors reacted coolly, saying Iceland was a late entrant into the organic stakes, and only accounted for 1% of organic sales.

The company admits that it is starting its all-organic policy in an area where large-scale industrial production can spread the extra costs of going organic.

Frozen vegetables account for between 5% and 10% of Iceland's £1.9bn annual turnover and nearly all of them are own brand. Iceland accounts for 15% of Britain's frozen vegetable sales

The switch on green vegetables, such as broccoli and peas, should take place in October, with potato products such as chips following early next year.

Other products, such as ice-cream, milk, cheese, yoghurt, bread, fresh fruit and vegetables and some meats, are being considered for "organic only" treatment.

Most of the produce will at first come from Europe, the US and central America, and fears were already being expressed last night that the continuing rise in organic sales, though still only a tiny fraction of the £72.5bn annual food bill, was outstripping government funded initiatives to increase organic agriculture at home.

Iceland's chairman and chief executive, Malcolm Walker, said: "Ethically and morally we are happy to be fighting for better food. Commercially it makes sense as well.

"The market is expected to grow at 40% over the next five years. We are giving the customers a choice of buying natural organic food at affordable prices.

"We don't believe the size of your pay packet should dictate the quality of the food you eat. The problem is that the organic market at the moment is still a cottage industry, in terms of supply , and at the retail end it is quite specialist."

Iceland is giving the National Trust £1m to help pay for new green measures on its 700 farms , including converting more to organic status.

The company is among groups lobbying MPs and the government for more support for organic conversion. State aid in England is to rise from £11.5m to £23m a year by 2004, although ministers have hinted the spending review this summer might yield more funds.

A number of backbenchers want to see an organic target of 30% of farmland (10 times the present level), and 20% of organic food consumed in the UK reached by 2010.

Iceland's announcement follows the government's admission that it cannot prevent cross-contamination of conventional or organic crops by genetically modified crops being given trials in Britain.

The move will raise the political heat on ministers who are perceived as favouring the new technology above organic methods.

Sainsbury's, which sells more than £3m worth of organic food a week , said it already sold 650 organic lines, and was working with farmers in Grenada and St Lucia to develop a market for organic exotic fruits.

But the company was sceptical about Iceland's claim that its 35,000 tonnes of orders for fresh vegetables represented 40% of the organic supply worldwide and said it had difficulty in obtaining any international figures for organic production.

Tesco, which believes it will be selling £200m of organic products this year, said: "Iceland is catching up on organics. They are a long way behind."

But Patrick Holden, director of the Soil Association, said: "Iceland has made a bold move to make organic products much more available to thousands of consumers who have not had them before."

Market that shows signs of growth

 Britons ate an estimated£546m worth of organic food last year. This is expected to nearly treble by April 2003.

 About one in three Britons buys some organic food. Germans already eat an estimated £1.5bn of organic food.

 70% of organic food in Britain is sold in supermarkets.

 70% is imported. The figure rises to over 80% for fruit and vegetables, while nearly all eggs and meat are home grown.

 Organic foods can cost up to twice as much as conventionally produced ones, especially meat. But 77% of people would buy organic if it cost the same.

 About 3% of British farmland is in organic production or under conversion.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report headed 'Nuclear weapons secrets vanish from Los Alamos labs', page 18, June 13, we referred to the laboratories at Los Alamos as the site of the first nuclear explosion in 1945. In fact, the first nuclear explosion was at the Trinity test site near Alamagordo, in southern New Mexico, on July 16, 1945.
fields.body:
In a report headed 'Nuclear weapons secrets vanish from Los Alamos labs', page 18, June 13, we referred to the laboratories at Los Alamos as the site of the first nuclear explosion in 1945. In fact, the first nuclear explosion was at the Trinity test site near Alamagordo, in southern New Mexico, on July 16, 1945.

Lord Hoffmann's name was spelt wrongly in a heading to a column on page 5, G2, yesterday. It was spelt correctly throughout the piece itself. Apologies.

Our figures for the number of scientists involved in the splitting up of Dera, the defence evaluation and research agency, page 30, June 13, did not add up. The total number of scientists is 12,000. Therefore the 3,000 scientists to be retained in the public sector represent one quarter of the total, not (as we incorrectly said) one third.

Sclerosis of the liver is a recurring complaint. It cropped up again in a brief item, page 13, June 13. It should be cirrhosis.

The "anti-cancer drug" to which we meant to refer in a report on page 4, yesterday, is Tamoxifen (not Temoxafen).

In a feature headed Internet know-how: email writing style, page 67, Education, yesterday, we said, "Another important rule is to avoid SCREAMING - TYPING EVERYTHING IN CAPS. Using a pair of asterixes is a *much* better way of emphasising a word." Astérix [le Gaulois] is a cartoon character created by René Goscinny and Albert Uderzo. The device referred to is an asterisk (pl asterisks). Read the piece at this web address: www.educationunlimited.co.uk/schools/story/0,5500,331196,00.html
