fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: World's smallest MP3 Player | Listen to my film
fields.body:
The singing matchbox
Forever losing your tiny MP3 player? Well look away now. Hitting the stores this month is the world's smallest MP3 Player (for this week anyway) from German company Vivanco.

The size of matchbox, the Vmax sits quite happily in the palm of your hand and weighs a paltry 30 grams. The £150 player comes with a 32MB-multimedia card and features three music settings. Accessories include a multimedia card reader and software, USB connector and micro headphones.

Vivanco intends to offer a range of optional add-ons to support the player namely, upper arm and belt clips and bags.

Listen to my film
Further evidence that within a couple of years every single electronic device you own will feature an MP3 player has been submitted by Fuji. The company has announced the Japanese release of an MP3-equipped digital camera the FinePix 40i which it hopes to bring to the UK in September.

The £500 camera boasts 4 million pixels and comes with a 8MB SmartMedia card. As this will only give you a couple of minutes of your favourite tunes you can of course, add cards with significantly higher storage capacities.

If you can't wait until autumn, then the company has also unveiled a pair of new budget models.

According to Fuji, the £349 FinePix 1400 Zoom and £249 MX-1200 are feature-rich entry-level cameras which are designed to be simple to use.

Both models feature a SmartMedia card, intelligent signal processors, and a USB cable. They are on sale now.

fields.headline: Systematic
fields.standfirst: Dr Erwin Koenigs is chairman and CEO of the German based Software AG, one of the world's leading providers of systems software
fields.trailText: Dr Erwin Koenigs is chairman and CEO of the German based Software AG, one of the world's leading providers of systems software
fields.body:
Tell us about Software AG. We're a German-based company and are the largest systems software supplier in Europe. We have two core competencies. The first is data management. The second area is what is called application engineering and integration.

We produce mission critical systems software end services for banks, the industrial and automotive areas of business, seaports and rail networks.

We also deal with a great many public sector organisations and administrations from government level right through to Scotland Yard and the CIA.

What are Software AG's main products? The best known is the database called Adabas. We have customers in the banking market who are doing up to 300 million database transactions per day. We also have a product called Natural which is an application development system solely for business applications.

How important is e-commerce to you? In 1997 we had to ask: "Where is the industry going?" We decided that the internet was going to be the business platform for all kinds of transactions and interactions between companies. This might sound a bit obvious now but it wasn't quite so clear back then. Being a German company, and because of the German gene structure, we tend to do things very orderly and pragmatically. We realised that if you accept that the web is going to be the platform for business then you have to migrate the industry towards the web.

The first step to moving on to the web is to make applications talk to each other that were never designed to do so. Therefore we made a middleware product at the end of 97 called Entire X based on a Microsoft standard called DCOM.

We also have a product called Bolero which, put simply, is a tool to help customers write very large, heavy commerrcial transactions applications. We also have Tamino which is the first database written for real genuine web data purposes.

Why do you feel XML is going to be so important? It radically simplifies the distribution, exchange and publishing of digital information. It's also an industry standard because it was invented, and is being managed, by independent industry consortium W3C so they make sure that this is something that no one vendor can tweak or twist to its own advantage.

The beauty of it is that once you have one XML document it is unbelievably simple to exchange it. This way you'll be able to read any kind of document from Unix, Macintosh or mainframe from outer space without employing software to translate it.

It's not going to be the final answer for all disease in the world but it's a major step forward in improving our productivity.

Any favourite places on the web? I think the Sky site here in the UK is very innovative and cutting-edge.

fields.headline: Weblife: pregnancy
fields.standfirst: Emma Gibson  has great expectations - and the net is helping her to fulfil them
fields.trailText: Emma Gibson has great expectations - and the net is helping her to fulfil them
fields.body:
It's not just a baby that changes your life. The long weeks that led up to the birth of my son Oscar on Saturday, changed me more than I would have thought. I became used to my large bump that frequently collided with door handles. I know the location of every public convenience in south-west London and my wardrobe has abandoned style in favour of comfort (the two are in no way entwined).

I also became the ultimate pregnancy bore. No sentence was complete without a reference to pelvic floor exercises or my new Advent breast pump. Time, in more ways than one, to get a life.

I cannot entirely blame Miriam Stoppard and her excellent Pregnancy and Childbirth companion. The bulk of my new found knowledge has come from the world wide web. At my first antenatal appointment, a leaflet for www.babyworld.co.uk nestled among the free nappies and surplus of product information.

In the early stages I went to the pregnancy specific sites www.motherandbaby.co.uk, and www.webbaby.co.uk as well as numerous American affiliates www.pregnancytoday.com and www.babycenter.com who cover pretty much the same ground; medical questions are answered, advice given on conception, birth announce ment e-cards, chat boards, baby galleries and even the occasional birth video.

Designed within a standard format, the sites cover exactly what the manuals and the magazines do, in less detail. There are some nice touches: every week I am emailed a weekly update of both my own and the baby's development (just enter your due date and email address). If, on the other hand, you are searching for some cerebral excitement then these "bump sites" and their bland magazine formula can soon lose their appeal.

You may be able to uncover the mystery that is pregnancy and childbirth and learn your baby wipes from your muslin squares, but the residual pulp does not give birth to much excitement. In my search for stimulation on my favourite topic online, I had to look further afield.

A news site, www.wired.com, was a little more enlightening. Searching on "pregnancy", I found an excellent article about spina bifida babies and the latest radical in-utero surgery that is both saving lives and stirring up great debate in the medical profession.

Is the internet blatantly promoting miracles instead of sound medical and scientific advice? The article also linked to an affected parents web site. Pregnant women are all too aware of the risks of birth defects and I found the latest medical opinions from a reliable source invaluable.

Pregnancy does not just affect women. www.boots.co.uk has an excellent feature on men and pregnancy. The web offers a wealth of sites on conception, contraception and fertility. Try www.fertilitytest.co.uk and www.hfea.gov.uk who provide detailed advice and information to the public. HFEA also have an excellent guide to UK IVF clinics. The British Pregnancy Advisory Service also have a good web site at www.bpas.org.

For me, however, there is no looking back. Time to remember my Girl Guide training and "get prepared". First I went to www.lloydstsb.co.uk for an overdraft and then checked out some of the numerous baby product sites.

Most manufacturers have their own sites and search engines were fairly efficient at finding a required product. www.greenbabyco.com has a good site that lists environmentally friendly products and the most crucial item for any green mama, reusable nappies (8 million disposables are thrown away every day so it is worth considering the alternatives).

Activebirthcentre.com also lists good information about alternative antenatal classes and birthing therapies. You can also try the National Childbirth Trusts web site at www.nct-online.org for slightly more traditional classes, contacts and good information.

Try www.lilliput.com for baby equipment and furniture. Mothercare.co.uk also provide online catalogues for all your essential needs and offer a far more informed service on line than you get in the stores.

Again, the more specific information you have beforehand, the most successful your search.

Try keying in your pushchair manufacturer (www.mamasandpapas.co.uk for example) to get photographs and prices direct from the horse's mouth. It can save time and money.

Not only information can help your rapidly expanding girth and overdraft. Maternity clothing manufacturers advertise online, and shopping from home undoubtedly saves aching ankles and unwitting jabs to the belly by Saturday shoppers.

Recommended sites include www.bloomingmarvellous.co.uk and www.jojomamanbebe.co.uk. Handbag.com offered some constructive advice about how to stay fashionable while pregnant (do a Patsy or Meg and refuse to cover the bump). For sheer cost-effectiveness and comfort I would recommend big knickers and staying at home.

I was trying to surf up to the last minute, even with my bump spilling over the keyboard. Despite this discomfort there was one one web site that got a daily visit - www.womens-health.co.uk/pain.htm.

A riveting and truly interesting read.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
It's a rare thing that the Diary receives press statements from the Royal Ulster Constabulary, let alone reprints one. But here, in an historic first, is the full text: "Following inaccurate media coverage of an incident in which an RUC drugs dog is alleged to have snapped at the Secretary of State [Peter Mandelson], the dog's handler wishes to make it absolutely clear that the encounter between the secretary of state and Sky, the labrador, was completely friendly." Absolutely. Readers may recall that the Diary yesterday quoted RUC Inspector Tom Crawford, an eyewitness to the incident when O'Mandy tried to stroke the black labrador bitch: "She can be a wee bit cross if you get too close, and I think the secretary of state found that out when she bared her teeth at him." But no - according to the RUC: "The meeting between the secretary of state and Sky was amicable and the dog handler and the secretary of state had an enjoyable conversation about their mutual interest in labrador dogs." Anxious to maintain his dog-friendly image as proud owner of Bobby, the lovable golden retriever, O'Mandy also issued his own rebuttal (although he seems confused about Sky's sex). "At no point did he snarl, growl or bare his teeth," O'Mandy said. "I and his handler then had a perfectly amicable conversation." There are some things you couldn't make up, even if your brain was erased with mind rubbers.

Our plans to rescue the England football team (by getting has-been Alan Shearer interred in a donkey sanctuary) having fallen down, we turn to the Diary Vicar, the Rev Steve Chalke. My colleague Esther Galan asks Steve if he can suggest suitable prayers, and he turns to the Old Testament (Isaiah, 35: 3,4). "Strengthen the feeble hands. Steady the knees that give way." Amen. And with Shearer's injuries in mind, Steve suggests appealing to St Roch, the patron saint of knee problems. But since St Roch was French, English prayers are better directed to St Giles, patron saint of cripples.

Mystery surrounds poor Sarah Macaulay, "companion" of Gordon Brown. Sarah appeared quite unhappy at Nick Brown's 50th birthday party at the Marquis of Granby pub on Monday night, and Gordon was most ungallant - reminding some of those present of the words of one of the chancellor's old flames, Princess Margarita of Romania: "I never stopped loving him, but one day it didn't seem right any more. It was politics, politics, politics, and I needed nurturing."

And now we unveil a new Diary service: "The Young Meteors: Labour's Leaders of Tomorrow", where we highlight the candidates lobbying to get safe seats at the next election. Today's Young Meteor is Jon Cruddas, on the short list for Dagenham. As an employee of the No 10 policy unit, Jon's attraction is his unrestrained loyalty to Mr Tony (which, after all, is what the party so desperately needs). Jon is also not afraid of getting into a fight: party workers fondly recall the fight he got into with the revolving door of a Brighton hotel at the Labour conference in 1989 - and the door lost!

Anyone free in Leatherhead on July 2 might like to hear a speaker at the Pioneer People evangelical church: "Jonathan Aitken's career crashed amidst headlines. Has he really turned to Christ?" Hmmm. We'd all like to know.

Alastair Campbell's decision to keep a lower profile is a great disappointment to all his fans, who are counting the days until he starts his new job as editor of the Mirror after the election. But what of his deputy, now thrust into the limelight, Godric Smith? Anyone with any background on Godric should get in touch. All we know so far is that he's currently 23rd in the lobby's Euro 2000 football pool, just above Fatty Riddell of the Times. The Guardian Diary is in second place. Ha!

Readers may recall that the Diary yesterday quoted RUC Inspector Tom Crawford, an eyewitness to the incident when O'Mandy tried to stroke the black labrador bitch: "She can be a wee bit cross if you get too close, and I think the secretary of state found that out when she bared her teeth at him." But no - according to the RUC: "The meeting between the secretary of state and Sky was amicable and the dog handler and the secretary of state had an enjoyable conversation about their mutual interest in labrador dogs." Anxious to maintain his dog-friendly image as proud owner of Bobby, the lovable golden retriever, O'Mandy also issued his own rebuttal (although he seems confused about Sky's sex). "At no point did he snarl, growl or bare his teeth," O'Mandy said. "I and his handler then had a perfectly amicable conversation." There are some things you couldn't make up, even if your brain was erased with mind rubbers. Our plans to rescue the England football team (by getting has-been Alan Shearer interred in a donkey sanctuary) having fallen down, we turn to the Diary Vicar, the Rev Steve Chalke. My colleague Esther Galan asks Steve if he can suggest suitable prayers, and he turns to the Old Testament (Isaiah, 35: 3,4). "Strengthen the feeble hands. Steady the knees that give way." Amen. And with Shearer's injuries in mind, Steve suggests appealing to St Roch, the patron saint of knee problems. But since St Roch was French, English prayers are better directed to St Giles, patron saint of cripples. Mystery surrounds poor Sarah Macaulay, "companion" of Gordon Brown. Sarah appeared quite unhappy at Nick Brown's 50th birthday party at the Marquis of Granby pub on Monday night, and Gordon was most ungallant - reminding some of those present of the words of one of the chancellor's old flames, Princess Margarita of Romania: "I never stopped loving him, but one day it didn't seem right any more. It was politics, politics, politics, and I needed nurturing." And now we unveil a new Diary service: "The Young Meteors: Labour's Leaders of Tomorrow", where we highlight the candidates lobbying to get safe seats at the next election. Today's Young Meteor is Jon Cruddas, on the short list for Dagenham. As an employee of the No 10 policy unit, Jon's attraction is his unrestrained loyalty to Mr Tony (which, after all, is what the party so desperately needs). Jon is also not afraid of getting into a fight: party workers fondly recall the fight he got into with the revolving door of a Brighton hotel at the Labour conference in 1989 - and the door lost! Anyone free in Leatherhead on July 2 might like to hear a speaker at the Pioneer People evangelical church: "Jonathan Aitken's career crashed amidst headlines. Has he really turned to Christ?" Hmmm. We'd all like to know. Alastair Campbell's decision to keep a lower profile is a great disappointment to all his fans, who are counting the days until he starts his new job as editor of the Mirror after the election. But what of his deputy, now thrust into the limelight, Godric Smith? Anyone with any background on Godric should get in touch. All we know so far is that he's currently 23rd in the lobby's Euro 2000 football pool, just above Fatty Riddell of the Times. The Guardian Diary is in second place. Ha!

fields.headline: Review
fields.trailText: Olympus C-3030 Zoom
fields.body:
Picture this
Olympus C-3030 Zoom £799.99
Olympus Optical's new C-3030 Zoom is one of the first affordable cameras to take pictures at 3.1 megapixels, which gives a maximum on-screen resolution of 2048 x 1536 dots. It's small but can deliver very high quality images (uncompressed files weigh in at 16 megabytes each).

The 3030Z does let you choose between shutter- and aperture-priority exposure or manual operation, three "film speeds" (100, 200, and 400 ISO) with exposure bracketing, and multiple flash modes. You can set slow shutter speeds (up 16 seconds on manual), and operate the shutter using a wireless remote control. You can focus the lens manually, using a readout on the LCD screen on the back of the camera, or take a three-minute QuickTime digital movie with sound.

There are 15 picture formats and a 16 megabyte SmartMedia storage card can hold up to 165 images in VGA quality (640 by 480 pixels) mode.

I tended to use the HQ (high quality) mode which takes 20 pictures in 700K .jpg format. The 3030Z comes with serial and USB cables for transferring pictures to a PC or Mac when the storage card is full. A PC Card and floppy disk adapter is available for easier file transfers.

The 3030Z has a 3x aspheric glass f/2.8 zoom lens but you have to wait for this to extend itself from the body when the camera is turned on.

While the 3030Z works well in snapshot mode, using the advanced functions can be tedious, because most settings are on submenus on the LCD screen. For example, the exposure mode change is the last option on a long menu.

At first I found it tedious scrolling all the way down to it - then I realised it took only one keypress to scroll up to it.

I also grew to love the Quickview mode: after you've taken a picture, this is flashed up on the LCD so you can have a quick look without turning the screen on and off.

As for the apparently pointless remote control, you can also use it to give slide shows with the camera plugged in to a TV set using the cable supplied, and the built-in microphone means you can add four second soundbites to your "slides".

webTitle: Japanese craze that could wipe out Wap

fields.headline: Japanese craze that could wipe out Wap
fields.standfirst: While the west is taking its first tentative steps towards web-enabled mobile phones, i-mode is walking tall in the east, writes  Jonathan Watts
fields.trailText: While the west is taking its first tentative steps towards web-enabled mobile phones, i-mode is walking tall in the east, writes Jonathan Watts
fields.body:
There is a new walk on the streets of Tokyo these days. It is too slow to be a stroll and too purposeful to be a wander. In crowds, it often results in the odd stumble, bump and mumbled apology. But it is no drunken stagger either. The legs know where they have to go, but the eyes are too preoccupied to chart a clear course.

Suddenly it is cool not to look where you are going in Japan. Why? Because you are engrossed in the latest way to surf the "wireless web" - a mobile phone and internet service called i-mode.

I-mode (the "i" is for information) is the first system to put cyberspace in subscribers' pockets 24 hours a day with cheap and continuous access to a range of information services. Technically sophisticated, but simple to use, it is tipped as the next big thing to come out of the land of the Walkman, the Game Boy and the PlayStation.

What's the big deal? Britons can already use their cell phones to get online and exchange email messages using the wireless application protocol (Wap) system. Like i-mode, Wap phones do not access the internet as we know it - rather a cut down version designed to work on small screens.

But, while Wap and i-mode are rivals, their contest is in danger of turning into a mismatch between a weedy infant and a bodybuilding giant. In terms of cost, popularity, ease of use and commercial success, Wap is being whipped. It may have been adopted last summer as the European standard, but it has been slow to take off, whereas i-mode is here, now and changing millions of lives

Since its launch in February 1999, the system has transformed Japan from an online laggard into one of the fastest growing online markets in the world. With 7 million subscribers, i-mode is the country's most popular online portal. At current rates of growth it will make Japan the first country in the world where mobiles are more popular than PCs as a way of getting into cyberspace, and 600,000 new customers signing up every month have put i-mode on course to overtake America Online (AOL) as the planet's leading online portal by the middle of 2002. The service is so popular that its operator, NTT DoCoMo, had to halt sales and advertising temporarily last month because demand kept crashing the system.

Meanwhile investors have made DoCoMo the hottest company in Japan. Last year, it overtook the motor manufacturer Toyota to become the country's most valuable corporation.

In Tokyo's trendy Shibuya district, the system is changing the way people look, sound and spend their time.

For Yoko Uenishi, a 17-year-old high school girl, a stylish i-mode phone completes a look that includes bleached grey hair, white eyeshadow and precariously high-platformed sandals.

"I bought it because it looked cool and all my friends had one," she says. "But now I use it all the time, especially when I want to kill time on the train."

Her phone - a tiny, ultra-light, metallic pink device that flips open like a Star Trek communicator - is decorated with a designer strap and stickers of cartoon characters. To personalise it even further, she has downloaded a Hello Kitty animation for the 3cm by 5cm screen inside and a pop song melody that plays when she has a call or a new email. Each day, she picks a new image and tune, for which 100 yen (60p) is added to her monthly phone bill.

Like most teens, Yoko mainly uses i-mode for email. She reckons she sends and receives about 15 messages a day - which means clicking away at tiny phone pad buttons until her fingers ache. But she also checks her horoscope each morning, books concert tickets and follows the latest chart news - which, naturally, includes a new top 10 of downloaded melodies.

But i-mode is not just child's play. Through more than 13,000 sites, subscribers can book airline tickets, trade stocks or find a lover. Date clubs are said to be particularly popular among would-be adulterers because i-mode offers more anonymity than a phone and a less risk of being discovered than a PC. One site provides information about the nearest available love hotel.

Keiji Matsuo, a broker at one of Japan's biggest securities houses, is a recent convert, but finds that the service already fills up a large part of his day. Each morning, he gets a wake-up call from i-mode, then uses it to check what happened on the New York stock market while he was asleep. The latest analysts' reports are emailed to him when he is out of the office and he clicks onto the net to show clients the latest share prices. Last thing at night, he checks the London markets before he goes to bed.

"It's fun, it's useful, it's lighter than a laptop and quieter than a mobile phone," he enthuses. "Best of all it is cheap so my wife doesn't get angry." He spends less than £5 a month on i-mode, including the basic £2 fee.

It may not sound much, but analysts say i-mode is creating a revolutionary new pattern of consumption. The buzz word is micro-niches - tiny purchases that can be made while walking along the street or waiting for a train. Until now, these have been impossible because of the costs of distribution and billing, but with i-mode the marketplace is in your pocket and the cash register is your monthly phone bill.

Because i-mode offers continuous access to the internet, there is no need to dial up and wait for a response and most sites can also be accessed with just a few button clicks rather than typing out web addresses.

Yet the service is far cheaper than using a personal computer and landline because charges are based not on time, but on the volume of data downloaded. Receiving five short emails costs about 10 yen (6p), while the charge for checking a train timetable or the weather is unlikely to be more than 10p. You do not need a credit card - these transactions are automatically put on your phone bill.

This allows almost unconscious consumption. It is as though DoCoMo and partners have found a way to package plankton and sell it to whales.

The toy maker Bandai, for example, earns about £600,000 a month from a website that simply provides a different picture each day for i-mode users to download onto their screens. More than a million people pay 60p a month for this service.

DoCoMo president, Keiji Tochikawa, says simplicity is the key: "We hope customers will use our next generation of mobile phones to exchange information as naturally as they breathe air."

These microniches are already generating huge revenue. According to the Nomura Research Institute, i-mode's 7 million subscribers spend an average of 1,600 yen (£10.60) per month on content. This means big bucks for DoCoMo, which gets 9% of the fee for every cartoon character, melody or news service that is downloaded.

On top of this, DoCoMo rakes in monthly subscription fees of 300 yen per person and 0.3 yen (a fifth of a penny) for each 128-bit package of data received or transmitted.

For the first full year that i-mode was in operation, DoCoMo racked up record profits of 252.1bn yen (£1.6bn), a jump of 23% from the previous 12 months. Much more is to come, according to fore casts that the wireless market will grow fivefold by 2003.

"This is just the beginning," said Kaji Nishigaki, president of NEC, which makes handsets. "Within three years everyone will be on i-mode."

Currently the system is a prototype available only in Japan, but DoCoMo has plans to make it smoother, faster and more widely accepted.

From next spring, it will the first company in the world to introduce a third generation mobile communication system that it says will allow data transmission at 15 times the existing speed of 9.6 kilobits per second. By 2003, the company hopes to raise the pace further to a blistering two megabits per second, swift enough for webcasts, interactive games and video conferencing.

This is frightening news for European telecommunication companies, which are at least a year behind.

Until recently, it was widely believed that i-mode would be difficult to export because of technical standards, security concerns and cultural differences.

However DoCoMo has begun to move aggressively into overseas markets. Last year, it formed partnerships with global giants Microsoft and Sun Microsystems. Last month it bought a bridgehead in Europe with a € 5bn stake in KPN, a Dutch mobile phone company. It has also paid $5bn for 20% of Voice System, the US cellphone firm.

Further takeovers and tie-ups are expected as DoCoMo becomes evangelical about its system. It will be hard to resist. As the world's most valuable telecommunications company, DoCoMo has an almost bottomless war chest as well as the backing of its politically powerful former parent company, NTT.

Unless Wap gets moving, European consumers could be the next ones doing the i-mode walk.

In Japan, there has been no contest between i-mode and Wap. The EZ system (based on Wap) is faster and technically superior, but i-mode is cheaper and has greater marketing clout. Who says the best man wins? Remember VHS vs Betamax.

Speed: 9.6 kbps
Subscribers: About 7 million
Standard: cHTML
Sites: 13,000
Outline: The cheapest and most popular way onto the wireless web. Uses packet switching system to offer continuous connection. Able to tap into 30 million mobile phone customer base of DoCoMo.

EZaccess and EZ web
Companies: IDO and Tu-Ka
Speed: Up to 64 kbps
Combined subscribers: Less than 2 million
Standard: HDML (handheld device markup language)
Site numbers: Less than 500
Outline: Second most popular system, but far less content because the relative difficulty of HDML has deterred many site designers.

J-Skyweb
Company : J-Phone
Estimated subscribers: Less than 2 million
Code: MML (mobile markup language). Very similar to cHTML
Speed: 9.6 kbps
Site numbers: Less than 500.
Outline: Clearest colour images. In third place at present, however it is seen as the main rival for i-mode because its programming code is so similar and because it also offers continuous access.

webTitle: UN firefighter at the heart of chaos

fields.headline: UN firefighter at the heart of chaos
fields.standfirst: Deliver Us From Evil by William Shawcross
fields.trailText: United Nations troops taken hostage, a weak government under threat from warlords, a Western power dispatching its forces with an opaque mandate and total obscurity about its intentions - the current drama in Sierra Leone is only the latest example of the recurring world crises that William Shawcross has been watching at close range for 10 years.
fields.body:
United Nations troops taken hostage, a weak government under threat from warlords, a Western power dispatching its forces with an opaque mandate and total obscurity about its intentions - the current drama in Sierra Leone is only the latest example of the recurring world crises that William Shawcross has been watching at close range for 10 years.

A fly on the wall at UN headquarters in New York for some of that time, Shawcross was given unprecedented access by Kofi Annan, first when he headed the peacekeeping department, and later as secretary-general. He accompanied the soft-spoken Ghanaian on numerous trips. The result is a profile both of Annan and the organisation that he heads. Inevitably, and this is no criticism of Shawcross, both come out well. Annan is a good man heading a good organisation, which is flawed more by the environment in which it works than by its own faults.

The point is made throughout the book that the UN is the sum of its constituent governments' parts. They usually fail to provide the troops or money they promise, and then blame the UN when things go wrong. On the rare occasions when things things go right, they take the credit for themselves.

There is also a sad inability in governments to learn lessons. Annan's observations in his private report on Nato's air strikes against the Bosnian Serbs in the aftermath of Srebrenica in 1995 bear an uncanny resemblance to Nato's mistakes four years later in Kosovo. He criticised Nato because it had no plans except for more air strikes and failed to provide accurate information on the damage they had inflicted.

Shawcross describes his book as "fragments of the last decade" and an account of "some of the problems encountered by interventions". He is low-key, cautious and reasonable, and his approach is unmistakably British, with its understated but manifest resentment of American high-handedness, and constant sneers at the French. But there are few recommendations. One obvious conclusion to be drawn from recent failures is that the UN needs to move towards having a standing army of national contingents, jointly trained and ready for prompt use in emergencies under UN command. Surprisingly Shawcross does not deal with this, and in a recent Guardian article on Sierra Leone he bizarrely preferred the use of mercenaries.

Shawcross also elides the serious grounds for criticism of UN operations in action. The UN is an easy butt for attack from its ill-wishers, just as the "faceless Brussels bureaucrats" are for Eurosceptics. But there are genuine problems in the field when the peacekeeping machine - with its inflated salaries, excessive security, untransparent operating style and exaggerated mistrust of the locals - is elevated too high above the war-shattered and poverty-stricken populations it is meant to serve.

As the UN increasingly moves into delivering "good governance" and trying to reconstruct civil society and failed states in new "protectorates" such as Bosnia, Cambodia and Kosovo, overlap and lack of co-ordination with other agencies are becoming important issues. On his travels Shawcross must have seen this, and it is not a fault of the member governments alone. There is a "UN culture" that needs to be changed.

But these are warts on an otherwise pleasant UN face. Shawcross is right to accentuate the positive, and to point out that Annan has done more than any of his predecessors to open up the UN and reform some of its practices. Narrow-minded governments are the bigger problem.

Surprisingly Shawcross does not deal with this, and in a recent Guardian article on Sierra Leone he bizarrely preferred the use of mercenaries. Shawcross also elides the serious grounds for criticism of UN operations in action. The UN is an easy butt for attack from its ill-wishers, just as the "faceless Brussels bureaucrats" are for Eurosceptics. But there are genuine problems in the field when the peacekeeping machine - with its inflated salaries, excessive security, untransparent operating style and exaggerated mistrust of the locals - is elevated too high above the war-shattered and poverty-stricken populations it is meant to serve. As the UN increasingly moves into delivering "good governance" and trying to reconstruct civil society and failed states in new "protectorates" such as Bosnia, Cambodia and Kosovo, overlap and lack of co-ordination with other agencies are becoming important issues. On his travels Shawcross must have seen this, and it is not a fault of the member governments alone. There is a "UN culture" that needs to be changed. But these are warts on an otherwise pleasant UN face. Shawcross is right to accentuate the positive, and to point out that Annan has done more than any of his predecessors to open up the UN and reform some of its practices. Narrow-minded governments are the bigger problem.

fields.headline: Hafez al-Assad
fields.standfirst: Obituary
fields.trailText: President Hafez al-Assad, master of Syria since 1979, was a towering figure of Arab politics, respected and feared in his own country and throughout the Middle East. His death, at 69, marks the end of an era.
fields.body:
President Hafez al-Assad, master of Syria since 1979, was a towering figure of Arab politics, respected and feared in his own country and throughout the Middle East. His death, at 69, marks the end of an era.

His achievements were threefold: he gave Syria years of much-needed stability; he turned his relatively small country into a major regional player whose views could not be ignored; and, with patient consistency, he fought to prevent Israel from imposing its will on the Arab world.

In the end he came to terms with the fact of Israel's existence, and was persuaded to open negotiations for a permanent peace settlement. But his dream of containing the Jewish state within its pre-1967 borders, and of checking the spread of its regional influence by an Arab-Israeli balance of power, was not realised.

Assad's long rule was all the more remarkable in that he was not born a Sunni Muslim, the orthodox mainstream of Islam in Syria. His family were Alawites, a small, heterodox community. Politics was his life-long interest. As a schoolboy, he joined the pan-Arab socialist Baath party, and rose to be a student leader. He joined the air force and became a conspirator, plotting with a small group of officers to overthrow the government, a task accomplished in 1963.

In the next seven years, Assad clawed his way up the ladder until he emerged as sole leader in 1970. His revolution turned Syria's social and political structures upside down. The Alawites, although no more than 12% of the population, came to occupy plum positions in every sector of life.

Externally, the main landmarks of Assad's life had to do with the struggle against Israel. As a young and inexperienced defence minister in the 1967 war, he presided over the loss of the Golan Heights. In 1970 he sent tanks into Jordan to help the Palestinians against King Hussein, but had to beat a humiliating retreat when Israel threatened to intervene. In 1973 he secretly planned the October war with Egypt's Anwar al-Sadat, but Israel turned the tables on them both, and by defeating Egypt took it out of the Arab military equation.

When the hardline Menachem Begin came to power in Israel in 1977, Assad faced a militant Likud determined to create a "greater Israel". In 1982 Israel invaded Lebanon. Rallying his allies, Assad fought back. Israel's adventure turned into a debacle. From Syria's point of view, it was Assad's finest hour.

Assad had an ally of sorts in the Soviet Union. But the Soviets were reluctant to give their Arab allies the means to recover their lost territories by force, still less to defeat Israel in all-out war. So Assad never entered fully into the Soviet orbit. Once the Soviet empire faltered, he was quick to grasp that a major prop of his world was gone. By 1987 he was busy making overtures to Washington.

The destruction of Iraq in the Gulf war further weakened Syria's strategic position. Assad recognised that Iraq's aggression was a serious threat to Syria's interests. So Assad joined the American-led coalition and sent troops to help defend Saudi Arabia. But he did not welcome the war. As an Arab patriot, he deplored the destruction of Iraq, the depletion of Arab financial assets, the ever-greater influence of the United States, and the loss of Arab independence. Israel's position became unassailable.

Such was the impetus for the new phase of Middle East peace-making launched in October 1991. Assad had long argued that peace with Israel was not worth having unless it was comprehensive, involving an Israeli retreat on all fronts. He opposed separate deals, which he felt divided the Arab camp. It was with great hesitation that he fell in with the formula of separate tracks, which was to Israel's advantage. The September 1993 Israeli accord with Yasser Arafat's PLO, which put an end to the intifada in the occupied territories without giving the Palestinians any substantial gains, was another setback. A year later, to Assad's dismay, Jordan concluded a peace treaty with Israel.

These agreements brought the Palestinians and Jordan into Israel's sphere of influence - a development Assad had struggled for years to prevent. But Assad was anxious to keep open his lines to Washington. To his great disappointment, the Clinton administration was to prove one of the most pro-Israeli in US history. As a result, Syria's peace negotiations with Israel made slow progress. He offered Israel "full peace for full withdrawal", making clear that a normalisation of relations could take place only once Israel had committed itself to a full withdrawal from the Golan and southern Lebanon.

Assad displayed two principal traits. The first was an exceptional degree of political foresight; the second was a foxy fighting instinct when driven to the wall, as he was by the Muslim Brothers at Hama in 1982 or by the Israelis in Lebanon a year later. On both occasions, he proved he could fight as dirty as anyone.

Patrick Seale

fields.headline: Cronje ready to reveal all
fields.standfirst: The former captain is to take the stand today
fields.trailText: The former South Africa captain is to take the stand today
fields.body:
Hansie Cronje is expected to reveal today that he received thousands of rand and a leather jacket to ensure a positive result in the Centurion Park Test match against England last year.

After weeks of allegation and innuendo, Cronje will finally take the stand at the King inquiry where he will explain the extent of the extraordinary double life he has led since 1995. It is understood he will admit taking his first payment from a bookmaker that year to provide information.

But interest will be focused more around the Centurion Test that is a central element of the commission's inquiry.

It is believed Cronje will admit that he was paid for "making a game" of the match, which England won by two wickets after the South Africa captain's surprise last-day declaration, to save bookmakers a fortune after huge bets on a draw following three days of rain.

Cronje is also expected to say that his first involvement with bookmakers came soon after he became his country's captain six years ago. He will draw a parallel with Shane Warne and Mark Waugh, who received payments of $5,000 (£3,150) and $8,000 for providing information to a bookmaker in 1994.

He will detail that, as the demands of the bookmakers increased, and when certain match forecasts he had made did not come true, the bookmakers were forced to try to chase their losses with a couple of "certainties". When they did not produce results he and his wife Bertha received death threats on South Africa's recent tour to India and Sharjah.

That was when he started making genuine approaches to team-mates, always wrapped in the disguise of his obtuse sense of humour.

Cronje will testify that he believed the tour to India would be his last. He hoped that he might be able to retire from international cricket and put an end to the double life he had been leading.

Today's proceedings will be preceded by a local television station's petition to Judge Edwin King to be allowed to televise proceedings live; it is likely to be granted. Cronje, apparently, is so far lost in the depths of despair and sorrow he would not notice if there were television cameras or not. According to one member of his legal team he has not eaten for days and is in poor health.

Defence is not really a viable option for Cronje and his legal team but there are mitigating factors of such emotional force that South Africans are likely to transfer their bitterness from their former favourite son to the men who trapped him and led him astray. And that is all Cronje now wants, having accepted, according to his legal advisers, that "his playing days are over".

Ali Bacher, the head of the United Cricket Board of South Africa, denied allegations yesterday that he fixed a match during a rebel tour by a West Indies side in 1983.

In a statement submitted to the match-fixing inquiry, the Johannesburg lawyer Peter Soller accused Bacher of offering to pay West Indies extra if they "agreed to blow the match".

Soller and Bacher had been asked to help resolve a dispute when the rebel side refused to go back on to the playing field after lunch because they were not paid enough.

"This statement is false and defamatory and I regard it as the gravest possible imputation against my character," Bacher said. "There is absolutely no substance in this allegation whatsoever.

"At one point the West Indies XI threatened that they would not play a particular match should they not receive the promised bonus. It was in this context alone that the dispute arose and it had nothing to do with payment to influence the outcome of any match. The dispute was amicably resolved."

Bacher was instrumental in establishing the commission of inquiry and testified before it on Monday, alleging that corruption was widespread in international cricket. He implicated several top players and an umpire.

fields.headline: Now the summer gets serious
fields.standfirst: England and West Indies join battle.  Mike Selvey  savours the prospect
fields.trailText: As England and West Indies join battle, Mike Selvey savours the prospect.
fields.body:
No disrespect to Zimbabwe, and thanks for the wake-up call at Trent Bridge, but the main event begins in Birmingham today. England versus West Indies, with the weekend weather set to scorch and the cricket to match: summer has arrived at last.

For England it did so in typical fashion yesterday with the season's first emergency call-up. The victim was Mark Ramprakash who awoke with a cricked neck, the result it seems of tweaked fibres near his shoulder blades.

The prognosis suggests he is significantly more likely to play than not and will get every opportunity, right up to just before the toss, to prove his fitness. Michael Vaughan has been summoned from Headingley, where he is playing for Yorkshire against Kent, just in case.

Vaughan is a centrally contracted player who established himself in the England team last winter and scored 94 for Yorkshire last week in his only match since fracturing a knuckle on his left hand at the start of the season.

He seems the obvious replacement and rather than Nick Knight, who has opened in all but six of his 24 Test innings, would accompany Mike Atherton. That he was not deemed sufficiently match-fit in the first place for this test, however, begs the question as to what has changed in the past few days.

The answer would seem to be a misplaced loyalty to Vaughan's original replacement Knight, whose attitude is exemplary but whose technique is less so. Should Ramprakash be fit, Vaughan will rejoin the county match. This series promises to be one of the best seen here for years. Both sides have touched desperation in recent times; both are now showing pleasant signs of resurgence.

If England's began with the appointments of Nasser Hussain as captain and Duncan Fletcher as coach, then that of West Indies can be traced to March 20 this year when, after a humiliating winter in New Zealand, they were on the brink of losing in Port of Spain to Zimbabwe, who required 99 in their second innings for victory. They made 63 as Franklyn Rose, Curtly Ambrose, Courtney Walsh and Reon King applied a tourniquet.

"It was a very important win," said the impressively dignified captain Jimmy Adams yesterday. "We can only speculate what might have happened if we had lost. Personally I think cricket would have gone on. In New Zealand, for example, it was terrible but I don't believe it dampened any interest in cricket in the Caribbean."

Had that game been lost however, it is unlikely West Indies would have gone on to win not just that series but the following one against Pakistan as well.

Under Adams the team has grown visibly in spirit and stature, with young bowlers such as King, Rose and Nixon McLean maturing under the tutelage of Walsh and Ambrose (73 years and 847 wickets between them) and at last worthy batsmen in the form of Wavell Hinds - whose ankle injury should not keep him from playing - and the teenaged Ramnaresh Sarwan, who will be kept out of this match only by the presence of one Brian Lara.

The return of this prodigal after his three-month sabbatical has been greeted warmly within the side and can only add massive power. A year ago, lest it be forgotten, Lara single-handedly won two tests against Australia with some of the greatest batting ever seen. "I rather hope that we have yet to see the best of Brian," said Adams wistfully.

Lara is relaxed now and has a point to prove, not least to the people of the Caribbean. England could pay heavily this summer. The key to the series in general and this match in particular will be how the England top six (and to a lesser extent the tail) cope with the controlled, disciplined and relentless fast bowling that will come at them from Ambrose, Walsh, King and Rose and what questions the England pace bowlers - on a pitch that will offer early help to the seamers but whose cracks will widen as the sun beats down - can pose to a batting order containing six left-handers in the first seven.

No bowler at this level ought to be inept against left-handers and those, like Ed Giddins and Darren Gough, who can pitch the ball up and swing it into the pads as well as fire it across, will relish the chance to bowl at them.

The fact that there is only only one right-hander up the order, Sherwin Campbell, to rotate the strike and disrupt the bowlers' line should help. Their recent away form suggests this could be the golden chance to beat West Indies in a series for the first time since 1969.

The opposition arrive having lost 10 matches in a row abroad since beating Australia inside three days in Perth 3 years ago. They are sustained, though, by the subsequent home series against Zimbabwe and Pakistan, while their last two in England were drawn. The past may be of no consequence to Hussain or Adams but it is a pointer. Lara's form could decide it but this will be close.

 The West Indies players have been offered a cash incentive of $250,000 [£166,000] by their team sponsors Sandals Resorts to win the five-Test series against England and a bonus of $50,000 if they win the triangular one-day series, which also features Zimbabwe. "Regardless of the cash incentives, these guys genuinely want to do well," said the team manager Ricky Skerritt.

West Indies: Adams (capt), Campbell, Gayle, Hinds, Lara, Chanderpaul, Jacobs, Rose, Ambrose, Walsh, King.

webTitle: Lord's bends the rules over Vaughan's England call-up

fields.headline: Lord's bends the rules over Vaughan's England call-up
fields.standfirst: Kent 127-7 v Yorkshire
fields.trailText: Kent 127-7 v Yorkshire
fields.body:
Ryan Sidebottom, the Yorkshire left-armer who took four wickets for two runs in 11 deliveries to leave Kent in a position of some subsidence at 26 for five, walked from the field at the close with the diffident half-smile of a man who knew he had siezed the day.

In this he was grievously disappointed. The man who really dominated proceedings yesterday, though he did not score a run or take a wicket, and shuffled from the ground at tea in the vague direction of the M1, was Michael Vaughan.

The batsman was called to Edgbaston as cover for England's injured opener Mark Ramprakash and could make his home test debut today.

Vaughan was replaced in the field by the 12th man Paul Hutchison and, if needed by England today, his place will be taken by Anthony McGrath or Vic Craven.

The fact that Yorkshire were allowed to name two replace ments, or could bring in another seamer for that matter, is an argument in itself but is not the point at issue here.

What is at issue here is the fact that the Yorkshire coach Martyn Moxon has permission from Lord's to reinstate Vaughan in this match should the player not be required by England.

This clearly contravenes Law 2.1 of the current playing conditions which says: "The cricketer who is substituted shall take no further part in the match even though he may not be required to play for England."

Alan Fordham, the ECB's Cricket Operations Manager (First Class), told me yesterday: "We feel we've made a common sense decision. If Michael is not required by England it is better that he is playing than sitting around for two or three days."

The pragmatic Fordham does make sense. But what if Kent, who are struggling this season, lodge an objection? Last night they were seeking clarification. The men at Lord's have ridiculed their own rules.

And what happens if it rains over the next two or three days, both in Birmingham and Leeds? Yorkshire supporters could go through this entire match without knowing whether Vaughan is playing in it or not. At the moment Vaughan inhabits some strange nether world.

Vaughan, told of his call-up at the tea interval, hurried off to Edgbaston. He said: "I had an idea as I walked off the pitch because I knew that Ramps was injured and I could see the TV cameras were gathered.

"Being called up because of injury is not ideal but whether the phone calls come on Sunday or Wednesday, it's still a great honour. Because of my broken hand I've had only one week of cricket since the winter but I've had a lot of nets in my head."

In the 71 overs possible yesterday, Kent scored 127 for seven. Only Rahul Dravid, with an unbeaten 45, mastered the juicy pitch.

"Being called up because of injury is not ideal but whether the phone calls come on Sunday or Wednesday, it's still a great honour. Because of my broken hand I've had only one week of cricket since the winter but I've had a lot of nets in my head." In the 71 overs possible yesterday, Kent scored 127 for seven. Only Rahul Dravid, with an unbeaten 45, mastered the juicy pitch.

fields.headline: Powell plods to his century
fields.standfirst: Warwickshire 289-1 v Northamptonshire
fields.trailText: Warwickshire 289-1 v Northamptonshire
fields.body:
A couple of church spires are visible from the pavilion at the County Ground here and yesterday they looked on cricket which had the air of a good and worthy, but not particularly inspiring, church service.

Warwickshire won the toss and, in the absence of Ed Giddins and Allan Donald, and with Dougie Brown carrying a slight shoulder niggle, chose to bat under skies of mottled grey.

Excitement beckoned when the third ball of the day, from Devon Malcolm, bounced and shot over David Ripley's outstretched hand for four byes.

However, the pitch turned out to be rather a pudding; the bowlers conceded 18 wides and at least half a dozen edges fell short of the field.

Graeme Welch and Michael Powell, who both got ducks against Nottinghamshire in the last championship match, and then had to sit and twiddle their thumbs while Darren Bicknell and Guy Welton rewrote the record book for their opponents, were determined not to fail again.

Welch chugged to his eighth championship fifty, off only 59 balls, which was full of cheeky pulls forward of square. He lost his off-stump after a break for rain but that was Northamptonshire's only success.

Powell anchored the innings and plodded remorselessly to a century. His best shots were the straight drive that took him to 50 and the skimming on-drive with which he reached three figures in the penultimate over of the day. His partner in an unbeaten second-wicket stand of 202 was the more powerful Dominic Ostler, who made the most of anything loose and smacked 15 fours in his 93.

Darren Cousins, winner of the bowler of the month award, was the most consistent of the Northants seamers. Although his back is held together with screws and bits of metal plate after three major operations, he ran in with great gusto.

Michael Davies, who recovered well from a horrible first four overs, and Graeme Swann found some turn in the pitch at the end of the day but that will not make Northants feel much better because Warwickshire have two spinners of their own.

On a chilly day, the ice cream man sold 50 cornets at lunchtime but if the crowd thought they were going to sit and eat them in the sun and watch Northants prosper in this Second Division match they were to be disappointed.

fields.headline: Sexton rings a brighter bell
fields.standfirst:
Hampshire prosper at last on a ground they are set to abandon
Hampshire 255-4 v Durham
fields.trailText: Hampshire 255-4 v Durham
fields.body:
During the winter Hampshire's committee ruled that this would be Basingstoke's last championship match. The decision is still being resisted by angry locals and, judging by events at May's Bounty yesterday, they are right to do so.

When bad light ended play at 5.30, Hampshire's struggling batting line-up was approaching its highest score of the season with significant power to add. The county should play here more not less.

Those opposed to the decision to abandon Basingstoke claim they first heard the news on television. A petition followed. Then came a protest meeting. Hampshire's chairman Brian Ford and the club's chief executive Tony Baker heard their arguments but the decision to pull the plug on the ground that first staged a championship match in 1906, and which gave the young John Arlott his first view of cricket, was not reversed.

Now a campaign has started to persuade the club they are making a mistake. "We are fairly upset about it but we are doing all we can to get it back," said Tony Gibson, vice-chairman of the Basingstoke & North Hampshire Cricket Club, whose ground it is.

The strategy involves raising funds from the local council and local businesses and guaranteeing Hampshire a fee to play here. Sussex's match at Horsham this season came about through a similar arrangement. A figure in the region of £12,000 has been mooted.

"Our grounds are part of the fabric of county cricket. They make it unique," said Richard Whitehead, spokesman for the campaign. "But we are not trying to preserve a white elephant. Hampshire are turning their back on their biggest attendance of the season."

Hampshire, though, will not be swayed. Around £10m has been raised to move the county's headquarters from Northlands Road to the Rose Bowl in the east of Southampton at the end of the season. That is taking precedence.

"We've made a decision," said Baker. "We're committed to play at the Rose Bowl to justify our investment. We need to concentrate all our efforts on one ground."

If it is to be Basingstoke's last game, then at least there was something decent to watch. Giles White hit three fours in the first over of the morning, bowled by Simon Brown, and put on 50 for the first wicket inside 10 overs with the 20-year-old debutant Andrew Sexton.

Steve Harmison ended the stand at 62, having White smartly taken at second slip by Paul Collingwood. Harmison, released from his duties with England, was Durham's biggest threat. Given a pitch with pace and bounce he could be a real handful.

Sexton, a left-hander who played some neat shots on the leg side, nearly made it through the morning session. But, when he pushed forward to Melvyn Betts, the umpire Tony Clarkson had his finger up for lbw almost before the bowler had cleared his throat.

The captain Robin Smith gave Will Kendall a 19-over start but had passed his score within a further nine. The occasional false stroke from Smith was punctuated by powerful thumps through the offside. He did not look like a man who is averaging only 17 this season.

The biggest surprise came when Collingwood, Durham's fifth seamer, dismissed both in quick succession after a partnership of 67. Kendall was caught at backward point from a delivery that bounced alarmingly; Smith was strangled down the leg side.

Derek Kenway and Adrian Aymes ensured against a characteristic Hampshire collapse after tea. Their stand is already worth 79.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Granted, his return to the saddle has been more Vivienne Westwood than Clint Eastwood, but the England selectors could have been forgiven a discreet "Yesss!" at yesterday's bulletin from Surrey: Graham Thorpe has made his first century of the season.
fields.body:
Granted, his return to the saddle has been more Vivienne Westwood than Clint Eastwood, but the England selectors could have been forgiven a discreet "Yesss!" at yesterday's bulletin from Surrey: Graham Thorpe has made his first century of the season.

When his exclusion from the brave new world of central contracts was announced, Thorpe, the batsman most likely to succeed at tackling Curtly and Courtney with sabre rather than shield, had cause to feel miffed.

Typically he took it on the chin and kept quiet. He reasoned that he needed the challenge; 10 years of non-stop coffin-packing had taken their toll. Perhaps the selectors were justified in asking him to prove he still had the drive.

All the same, the notion of Thorpe and Mark Butcher keeping the Oval flock waiting until mid-June before reaching 100 and 50 respectively strained credulity as much as a declaration of undying devotion from Henry VIII. Until yesterday's visit by Somerset the pair boasted a combined return of 294 runs in 19 four-day knocks, Thorpe averaging 12.44. But an alliance of 190 hinted at renewal.

Weather and pitches inevitably score high on the Surrey coach Keith Medlycott's alibi-ometer. "That six-month break has been a problem for Thorpey, and the circumstances have aggravated it. But he looked good against Hampshire, won a National League game against Derby on Sunday and capitalised brilliantly today in seaming conditions.

"It's a question of being strong, of having great self-belief, which he has. He hasn't seemed worried at all. He's worked bloody hard, mind. He's still one of the best, if not the best, batsman in the country."

Butcher is another, more vexing case. He returned from South Africa without a half-century in five Tests, Michael Vaughan sniffing his opening berth, career in reverse. His Brisbane century the previous winter - only the fourth for the Poms at the Gabba - had bracketed him with Botham, Greig and Leyland. The pole is rarely so greasy.

Judgment and execution, according to Medlycott, remain problematic. "He's been looking in good nick but getting out in the thirties too often, once or twice through poor execution. He's lining the ball up well, leaving it well. He just needs to convert. Until he nicked a short wide one he played exceptionally well."

Which is more than could be said of Leicestershire or Derbyshire, for the predictable reason that proceedings at Grace Road were washed out, taking the number of hours lost there this season to 781. Anil Kumble must wish he'd stayed in sunny Dhaka.

To the dismay, no doubt, of Alec Stewart and Shane Warne, not to mention Australian umpires of an officious bent, Arjuna Rana- tunga refuses to hang up either paunch or attitude. In Colombo yesterday the chap who led Sri Lanka to the World Cup set a milestone for longevity by becoming the first person to play in his country's first and 100th tests. Waqar Younis claimed his 298th and 299th wickets for Pakistan as the hosts limped to 115 for three before the opening day of the series was rained off.

fields.headline: LVMH to launch luxury portal
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: LVMH will reveal details of the first roll-out of E-luxury.com portal next week. Group chief executive Myron Ullman said that the US launch of E-luxury, which will carry LVMH's own top brands such as Louis Vuitton, Givenchy and Tag Heuer, is imminent.
fields.body:
LVMH will reveal details of the first roll-out of E-luxury.com portal next week. Group chief executive Myron Ullman said that the US launch of E-luxury, which will carry LVMH's own top brands such as Louis Vuitton, Givenchy and Tag Heuer, is imminent.

Though the portal will carry most of the group's top brands, it will not offer, at least initially, LVMH's wines and spirits products which range from Moët & Chandon champagne and Chteau d'Yquem, one of the world's most expensive wines, through to Hennessy cognac, because of the complex licensing laws in the US.

LVMH is planning to bring E-luxury.com to Europe "subsequent to the US being successful," said Mr Ullman.

Investment in E-luxury.com and the beauty products internet operation Sephora.com is expected to total around €100m this year. The group is also continuing to expand its 300-strong chain of Sephora stores, particularly in the UK.

British expansion will bring Sephora into competition with established departments stores and with Boots - a confrontation not lacking in irony as Sephora used to be the Boots brand name in France.

Mr Ullman remains upbeat about LVMH's prospects for online retailing and shrugs off the fate of Boo.com, in which LVMH chairman Bernard Arnault held an 8% stake through his family holding company Group Arnault.

"It was not a failure because of the internet," said Mr Ullman. "Boo.com tried to do too much and there were too many investors so that when things started to go wrong, there was no one really to step in."

Mr Ullman confirmed that LVMH, which is building up its watches and jewellery division, would be interested in the watch brands which Vodafone acquired when it bought the German group Mannesmann and which are now up for sale.
